notes: Took place one year after President Roosevelt died in office, and was largely seen as a referendum on the unpopular President Truman, who had a rating of 32%.

Truman's second midterm elections; with the Korean War, his popularity was once again down and his party (Democrats) lost seats in both chambers.
Concurrent with the presidential election of Dwight Eisenhower; Republicans gained control of Congress, due to unhappiness over the Korean War and Truman's low popularity.

Eisenhower's first midterm election; the Democrats regained control of Congress, partially due to the Army- McCarthy hearings.
Concurrent with presidential race in which Eisenhower won as an incumbent; Senate gains cancelled each other while two Republican House seats went to the Democrats.

Eisenhower's second midterm elections; Republicans lost huge numbers, partly due to the Recession of 1958 (unemployment was high)

Legislative elections were held in the US on November 4, 2008. All of the seats in the House of Representatives were up for election, as well as 33 seats in the Senate (plus special Senate elections in Mississippi and Wyoming). The Democrats gained 8 seats in the Senate, while the Republicans didn't gain a single seat. Of the 435 House seats, Democrats gained 21 seats, increasing their majority from 54.3% to 59.1%. Overall, the results of the legislative election were a victory for the Democratic Party, who increased their majorities in both houses of Congress. A presidential election was held, simultaneously, and resulted in the election of Democrat Barack Obama as president of the US.

nelda21notes: The incumbent, George W. Bush, had reached his term limit, but the incumbent party (Republican) did have a candidate in the election.
nelda56notes: The election of President Obama was received very warmly by the rest of the world. The incumbent, Bush, had grown quite unpopular for his foreign policy, particularly in the Middle East. The election of Obama was viewed widely as a fore-coming positive change in US foreign policy.

nelda16notes: There are obvious media biases among hardline- Democratic and hardline-Republican news outlets. Nevertheless, there is no outright overall bias toward the Democratic incumbent party. And there is no evidence that the government initiated this bias.

nelda18notes: The country was still struggling to avoid another recession, similar to the one that occurred in 2008 after the housing bubble burst.
nelda24notes: The Republican Party gained 63 seats in the U.S. House of Representatives, recapturing the majority, and making it the largest seat change since�1948�and the largest for any midterm election since the�1938 midterm elections. The Republicans gained six seats in the U.S. Senate, expanding its minority.
nelda26notes: Most polls indicated falling support for the Democratic party. Sweeping gains were predicted for the Republican party.

notes: Legislative elections were held in the US on November 6, 2012 simultaneously with presidential elections. nelda24notes: Incumbent president Obama's Democratic party retained it's majority in the Senate, and the opposition Republican party retained its majority in the House of Representatives.
nelda27notes: Despite the fact that the Republican party retained its majority in the House of Representatives, it actually decreased the number of seats they controlled; thus the vote count was not actually a gain for the opposition.

notes: The US presidential election held on November 6, 2012 resulted in the reelection of Democratic candidate Barack Obama. The Republican candidate was Mitt Romney. Legislative elections were held simultaneously with the presidential elections.

notes: First direct, secret-ballot elections since 1959, but there was no opposition allowed and candidates were vetted by Communist-affiliated organizations.

nelda3notes: Officially all candidates were selected by grassroots Committees of the Revolution (labor and social groups associated with the Communist Party) and were not obliged to be PCC members. However, in practice none was an opponent of one-party rule
nelda4notes: The Cuban Communist Party is the only legal party in Cuba.
nelda5notes: Voters were given the option of voting yes or not at all to candidates from a list of 589 candidates for the 589-person Assembly. Eligible voters can mark a box at the top of their ballots approving all the candidates in their districts.

notes: Contrary to popular belief, Cuba regularly held elections (albeit single-party in nature) throughout the reign of the two Castro regimes. They feature only one party, and serve a limited legitimising function. Some interesting features include debates about gender equality in Cuba (a large percentage of the new Parliament are women), disputes over media control, and the arguments over the provision of economic services.

nelda1notes: Gen. Prosper Avril, who had seized power in a military coup in September 1988, resigned as President of Haiti on March 10, 1990 after a period of prolonged and intensifying popular opposition to his government.
nelda6notes: Elections, originally scheduled for Nov. 4, were put off until Dec. 16 by the Electoral Council.
nelda11notes: Prior to the election there were fears that voters could be easily manipulated or intimidated by the army or the remnants of the Duvalier militia, the Ton-tons Macoutes, and other Duvalierist forces.
nelda33notes: In one incident, Tonton Macoutes were blamed for a grenade attack after Aristide left a rural campaign stop. Seven people died and 53 were wounded.
nelda46notes: Both the U.N. and the OAS sent observers.

notes: The first of a two-round election. A rerun of 16 seats occurred on August 13 for consticuencies where, because of technical difficulties, there was no declared winner the first round. The second round occurred on Sept 17 in areas where no candidate had won a majority of the vote.
nelda6notes: The L1 election was pushed back from June 4 to June 25 and the L2 round was pushed from July 16 to August 13.
nelda11notes: In the run-up to the election, there were growing fears of insecurity and violence. There were also fears of manipulating of elections.
nelda14notes: Most opposition parties boycotted the makeup elections in August and September (L2 and L3), saying the results were being manipulated to favor President Aristide's supporters.
nelda27notes: The ruling Lavalas party took majorities in both the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate.
nelda50notes: A U.S. military intervention in September 1994 restored Aristide to power.
nelda57notes: A US foreign aid bill passed by the House of Representatives on July 11, 1995, included the stipulation that Haiti would only receive aid if its electoral process met certain standards.�

notes: These elections were marked by the hurricane that swept the country shortly before. The incumbent People's National Party (PNP) of Prime Minister Simpson-Miller was challenged by the opposition Jamaica Labour Party (JLP) led by Mr. Bruce Golding. Crime, poverty and high unemployment were the main issues in the campaign. In these elections, the opposition JLP increased their seats to 33 seats, hence preventing the PNP from securing a fifth term in office. The PNP took the remaining 27 seats, and accused the JLP of vote buying. Protests erupted from both sides, but eventually Golding was sworn in.
nelda6notes: Following premature dissolution, and then due to the postponement caused by a hurricane that hit the country in mid-August 2007, these parliamentary elections which had been originally scheduled for 27 August were postponed to 3 September.
nelda11notes: Though there was much worry of political violence spilling over, of which Jamaica has a long history.
nelda15notes: In fact, it seemed that the opposition JLP were harrassing government supporters to some extent. In the lead up to the elections, 7 people were unned down - all PNP supporters and one a PNP party member. In a different attack, two homemade bombs were hurled at a police station in an often violent northern area of Kingston.
nelda18notes: In the aftermath of the devastating hurricane, Prime Minister Simpson-Miller came under severe criticism for her inefficient response, and the country was still in disaster-mode.

In these elections, the opposition JLP increased their seats to 33 seats, hence preventing the PNP from securing a fifth term in office. The PNP took the remaining 27 seats, and accused the JLP of vote buying.
nelda30notes: The incumbent PNP, which lost these elections, at first refused to concede defeat and accused the JLP of vote-buying. Following the elections, street protests involving supporters of both sides ensued. Some violent incidents were reported.

nelda17notes: (1995 CIA Factbook) Trinidad and Tobago has earned a reputation as an excellent investment site for international businesses. Successful economic reforms were implemented in 1995, and foreign investment and trade were flourishing.

nelda27notes: The opposition gained two seats from the last election and the political deadlock of a tie in the House of Representatives was resolved when President Robinson chose opposition PNM leader Manning to be the next Prime Minister.

notes: Trinidad and Tobago, now a relatively stable democracy, held elections which saw the removal of the incumbent, and in fact relatively successful government. Major issues included the depletion of natural resources and the looking threat of economic calamity, which either side would have had to contend with. Despite being ahead in polls and public opinion, albeit narrowly, the incumbent ultimately lost on election day. No major controversies.

notes: First election since independence was established on November 30, 1966. The domestic political process had been established, however, since legislative elections began in the decade prior. Governor General Sir Winton Scot led the country at this time, and announced elections in 1971. This election saw the Democratic Labour Party achieve a majority in the House of Assembly, with a 3-seat increase from the previous, pre-independence election.

notes: Barbados Labour Party (BLP) wins 17/24 seats in the House of Assembly, with the rival Democratic Labour Party (DLP) winning 7. Between 1971 and the present election, the Barbadian economy suffered as a result of oil price increases and the international energy crisis. Unemployment, inflation, and government waste became campaign topics.
nelda56notes: The election of Adams began an era of improved relations with the United States, in part because of his government's willingness to work with the US on American-sponsored military operations and defense initiatives.

notes: BLP attains a majority in the House of Assembly, with 17 seats, while the DLP wins 10 seats.  For the present election, 3 seats were added to the House of Assembly. The BLP was credited during its previous term with cutting unemployment, increasing per capita income, and expanding tourism.

notes: The 1981-6 BLP term was marked by economic problems, including unemployment, inflation and slowed growth. Barbadian acceptance of US intervention in Grenada damaged relations with regional states, while participation in the US-funded Regional Security System was said to damage relations with the UK.
nelda16notes: The BLP dealt with accusations of bias and political favor of whites. A libel case was filed and led to the closing of a newspaper favoring the incumbent party, as well as to the imposition of a fine against the editor.
nelda43notes: PM in power following the previous election, John Adams, died of a heart attack on March 11, 1985. Bernard St. John was sworn in and led the BLP into the present election.
nelda54notes: Relations with the UK were said to have suffered over the previous five years.

notes: The previous government was marked by fiscal deficit and large public expenditures. One campaign was reduction of the Barbados Defense Force, but the country took place in military maneuvers with the US and Britain. Previous PM Errol Barrow died in mid-1987, and Erskine Sandilford was sworn in.
This election ended 8 years of DLP (Democratic Labour Party) rule.

notes: Controversial election in Saint Vincent. It is deemed free and fair by observers, but the reality on the ground looks far different. Due to the nature of the outcome (Gonsalves� party wins the elections 8 seats to 7, and wins one of its 8 seats by 6 votes total) and the fine margins involved, there is vociferous debate over the legitimacy of the outcome. The defeated party refuses to concede, and protests break out across the island, with allegations of irregularity and illegal voting. Other dominant issues in the build-up to the election include youth unemployment and environmental concerns.

notes: These elections were for the 500-member Chamber of Deputies, the lower chamber of the Mexican Parliament (these occur every three yearrs, while Presidential and Senate elections occur every six). Major issues were the recent outbreak of H1NI in Mexico which had affected thousands; President Calderon�s war on drugs which had seen the country rocked by between 6000 and 10,000 deaths since he took power in 2006; and the economic crisis. In the previous elections held in July 2006, President Calderon�s National Action Party (PAN) won 206 seats in the Chamber of Deputies. The Democratic Revolutionary Party (PRD) won 126 seats, and the now-opposition Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI), which had ruled the country from 1929 � 2000, took 104 seats. In these elections, the opposition PRI won a decisive victory securing 237 seats, a large increase from 104. The incumbent PAN of President Calderon came in second with 143 seats, losing 63. The opposition PRD took 71 seats, losing 55. Thus these Chamber of Deputy elections marked a large swing from a PAN-controlled parliament, to a lower house controlled by the PRI.
nelda12notes: Pre-election polls predicted an opposition PRI win.
nelda18notes: The global economic crisis had severely affected the Mexican economy - being so closely tied to the US - and thus the economy was predicted to shrink by 5.5 per cent in 2009. The government warned also that the recent Swine flu outbreak may cost the economy more than $2bn.
nelda24notes: President Calderon's National Action Party (PAN) lost 63 seats down to 143, and the opposition PRI increased its seats from 104 to 237. This election in some ways was considered a referendum on Calderon's war-on-drugs, which despite his crack-down had claimed over 10,000 lives since he had been elected.
nelda26notes: Polling company Demotecnia gave the opposition PRI 36 per cent of the vote based on pre-election surveys, while President Calderon's National Action Party (PAN) polled only 31% and the leftist opposition Democratic Revolution Party polled 16%.
nelda27notes: In the previous elections held in July 2006, the National Action Party (PAN) won 206 seats in the Chamber of Deputies. The Democratic Revolutionary Party (PRD) won 126 seats, and the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) took 104 seats.  In these elections, the opposition party PRI won a decisive victory securing 237 seats, a massive increase from 104. The incumbent PAN of President Calderon came in second with 143 seats, losing 63 seats and its control of parliament. The opposition PRD took 71 seats, losing 55. Thus these Chamber of Deputy elections marked a large swing from a PAN-controlled parliament, to a lower house controlled by the PRI.
nelda33notes: In the state of Guerrero eleven people, including an opposition PRD town councillor and his family, were killed.
nelda54: EU, UN, ILO, WTO, OECD, WHO

notes: Legislative elections were held in Mexico on July 1, 2012 for the upper chamber of the National Congress (128 contested seats) and the lower chamber, the Chamber of Deputies (500 contested seats). In the National Congress, the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) won 52 seats (19 more than in 2006), the National Action Party (PAN) won 38 seats (14 less than in 2006), and the Party of the Democratic Revolution (PRD) won 22 seats (7 less than 2006). In the Chamber of Deputies, the PRI won 207 seats (30 seats less than in 2009), the PAN won 114 seats (28 seats less than in 2009), and the PRD won 100 seats (29 seats more than in 2009). The main opposition party, PRI, regained the legislature, thereby replacing PAN as the ruling party.
nelda7notes: Incumbent president, Felipe Calderon, was constitutionally barred from seeking another term.
nelda27notes: The ruling National Action Party won considerably less seats in both houses of the legislature; whereas, the main opposition party increased its seat count in both chambers, thereby replacing PAN as the ruling party in Mexico.

notes: Unspectacular parliamentary election in Mexico which sees the ruling PRI extend the rule of their coalition with a collection of other parties, including Greens. Reports on the election understandably focus on the twin issues of crime and corruption, which had reached an unprecedented peak around 2014. While there were no official boycotts, several unions protested the election, and there were some, infrequent outbreaks of violence before the poll.

Standard election which saw the opposition reclaim power despite solid economic growth and sturdy international integration. notes: A peaceful election which saw the re-election of Barrow. Economic performance, while somewhat poor, is not really a topic for discussion in the election. OAS observers give the process a clean bill of health.

Snap election in Belize which sees the re-election of incumbent Dean Barrow with an increased majority. While Western reports - i.e. OAS - tend to cast the election as free and fair, highlighting the role of women and minorities in the parliament and the electoral process, local sources display more concern about intimidation and harassment, in particular in the closing phases of the campaign. This disparity is interesting and, unfortunately, rather common in smaller states.

notes: A distasteful election in the midst of a political crisis. The incumbent's party hijacked the previous election after a successful coup. This election was propped up as a deciding factor for the direction of the county. After both candidates mistakenly assumed victory, the incumbents party along with his successor finished on top.

A distasteful election in the midst of a political crisis. The incumbent's party hijacked the previous election after a successful coup. This election was propped up as a deciding factor for the direction of the county. After both candidates mistakenly assumed victory, the incumbents party along with his sucessor finished on top.
The incumbent was the second provisional leader in place after a long time dictator was ousted the year before.

notes: This elected Constitutional Assembly was to maintain the presidential system with a one-chamber congress. These were held in conjunction with Presidential elections.These elections were somewhat free - they followed a military coup that had deposed Castaneda Castro in 1948. Fifty-two members of the Constitutional Congress were at stake in this election. The Revolutionary government Council which had taken the role of provisional government following the 1948 coup was represented in this election by the Democratic Revolutionary Union (PRUD) party. The main opposition was the Reform Action Party (PAR). Secret ballot and women's right to vote were introduced in these elections. PAR won 14 of the 52 contested seats, the incumbent PRUD won the rest.
nelda1notes: Under the Castaneda regime, elections had not been held regularly.
nelda6notes: No established procedure - these were the first elections following the 1948 coup.

However, it was remarked in the international press that the military provisional government was conducting the elections in a democratic manner.

notes: After two years of puppet rule, Somoza and the Conservative leader, Chamorro, reached an agreement to hold these general elections. The Conservative (opposition) party was guaranteed 1/3 of the parliamentary seats through that agreement.

nelda6notes: There was no established procedure; it was an ad hoc election. There was talk of elections for 1951 or 1952, but 1950 was chosen instead.
nelda13notes: Only the two major parties were eligible.
nelda14notes: The Independent Liberal faction boycotted the elections and did not support the conservatives. In previous elections, they had supported the conservatives.
nelda16notes: Somoza  allowed the press wide berth.
nelda27notes: The opposition was guaranteed by law (negotiated between Somoza and the leaders of the conservative party) 1/3 of the seats in parliament.
nelda29notes: An El Salvadorian newspaper reported a revolt in Managua on May 13 (before the election), but Nicaraguan newspapers denied it and other evidence which could corroborate the account was not forthcoming.

notes: The preceding year, Nicaragua's president/dictator had been assassinated and his son took his place. In the investigation, many opposition leaders were arrested. These were the first elections after the assassination, regularly held.
nelda3notes: The party that opposed the incumbent in these elections was a puppet party, which the incumbent had organized to take the place of the real opposition parties that boycotted the election .
nelda4notes: The two real opposition parties boycotted these elections.
nelda6notes: These elections were originally going to be held in November 1956.
nelda13notes: The Communist party was banned, but they were weak to nonexistent. Other parties were not banned.
nelda15notes: However, after the assassination of the president the previous year, around 200 opposition leaders were jailed and questioned.
nelda16notes: Freedom of the press was curtailed by law.

nelda45notes: During the electoral campaign, which began Dec. 4 and ended on Feb. 21, approximately 2,500 international observers including representatives of the United Nations (led by former President Jimmy Carter) and the Organization of American States arrived in Nicaragua to monitor these elections.

nelda50notes: In 1985, Nicaragua logged a damage suit against the United States in the International Court of Justice, relations had been rocky since then, in particular given the American reputation in the aftermath of its support for the Panamian contras during the Reagan administration.
nelda52notes: US President George Bush said on Feb. 25 that relations could improve if the elections were judged to have been free and fair and explicitly endorsed UNO candidate Chamorro; the Bush administration organised in Washington a photo opportunity to this end.
nelda53notes: Beyond the U.S., other powers such as the Organization of American States and the UN were involved politically, sending observers and otherwise placing pressure in support of free and fair elections.

nelda58notes: US President George Bush said on Feb. 25 that relations could improve if the elections were judged to have been free and fair; in 1990, following the election, $300 million aid promised (designated primarily for debt repayment and petroleum imports) was sent.

notes: In this Nicaraguan Presidential election, the support of the USA for opposition candidate Chamorro produced an unexpected electoral outcome. Despite pre-election confidence, incumbent Ortega lost the election to Chamorro. The election was widely considered free and fair by international observers.
nelda2notes: According to the Guardian (London), on November 1, 1984, a freely run election- in the opinion of international observers- gave the Sandinistas just under 70 per cent of the popular vote. The U.S. did not recognize that vote, however.
nelda3notes: In addition to the government-sponsored Sandinista Party, numerous opposition parties were allowed including the National Opposition Union (the primary opposition party/party of Chamorro) and the Nicaraguan Social Christian Party (PSCN).
nelda8notes: The Constitution adopted in 1995 allows presidential candidates only a single term; it is unclear what the 1987 constitution prescribed.
nelda12notes: Despite several polls (conducted by actors as far-reaching as the Washington Post-ABC) suggesting that Ortega possessed a comfortable lead, the government's actions leading up to the election made their victory less certain.
nelda15notes: Not significantly; one Chamorro (opposition) supporter was murdered at a rally, but overall the election was considered clean.
nelda16notes: Media bias was endemic - but equally expressed support for Chamorro as well as for Ortega.
nelda17notes: Since the flight of Somoza in 1979, with the intermittent years full of war and the effects of a US trade embargo, the Nicaraguan economy had been imploding. Working class living standards had fallen by 90 percent and inflation was running high.
nelda18notes: Since the flight of Somoza in 1979, with the intermittent years full of war and the effects of a US trade embargo, the Nicaraguan economy had been imploding. Working class living standards had fallen by 90 percent and inflation was running high.
nelda25notes: A Washington Post-ABC poll conducted a few days prior to the elections suggested that Ortega was leading with 48% support to Chamorro's 32%. Similarly, the last of 29 pre-election surveys conducted since April by research organizations from at least five countries showed Ortega leading.
nelda28notes: By and at large the government's handling of the election was viewed favorably as free and fair.

notes: Ortega controversially ran for an illegal third term claiming the Supreme Court had given him legal permission. According to the constitution of Nicaragua, however, that is a power reserved only for the Congress. Ortega illegally won the election and his third term. His party, the FSLN, likewise won 60.85% of the vote.

notes: Various opposition parties banded together to support Otillo Ulate for president, while the government party and the communists backed Calderon, who had been president 1940-1944 and had rigged the 1944 elections.
nelda15notes: There was significant violence and several deaths in the campaign, caused by fighter on both sides.

notes: Various opposition parties banded together to support Otillo Ulate for president, while the government party and the communists backed Calderon, who had been president 1940-1944 and had rigged the 1944 elections.

nelda39notes: It was only after two months of civil war between the government and rebels that a peace agreement was drawn up. A temporary junta would lead the country, hold elections for a constituent assembly, and install Ulate (the 1948 winner) into office.
nelda41notes: He was replaced due to a civil war.

notes: After a bloody civil war, the military junta that lead the country held these elections in order to write a new constitution.
nelda1notes: The military junta ruled by decree until democratic elections could be held.
nelda6notes: These were outside of normal procedure.
nelda13notes: Out of all the parties, the communist party was barred from running; however, it backed the constitutional party in these elections.
nelda33notes: There was an incursion by Nicaraguan forces and deposed Costa Ricans that began to attack the northern parts of the country, but this was not so much a response to the elections.

notes: These were the first parliamentary elections after the civil war and the new constitution of 1949; also, this was the first time Costa Rica women could vote.
nelda1notes: There had been a constituent assembly election the previous year, but these were the first under the new conditions.
nelda12notes: There was no incumbent party.
nelda13notes: Only the Communist affiliated party was banned.
nelda24notes: The incumbent (Figueres) disbanded his own party before the elections.
nelda27notes: The proportion of the vote the opposition received was roughly the same as that which they got in the previous year's constituent assembly elections.

notes: These were the first executive elections since the civil war and constituent assembly of 1948, and since it was already decided that Otilio Ulate (who won 1948's presidential election) would be the president, Costa Rica voted on two vice presidential candidates.
nelda1notes: There had been a constituent assembly election the previous year, but these were the first under the new conditions.
nelda12notes: There was no incumbent party; Figueres, the incumbent leader, had formed a party, but he disbanded it before the elections.
nelda13notes: Only the Communist affiliated party was banned.
nelda24notes: The incumbent (Figueres) disbanded his own party before the elections.
nelda27notes: The proportion of the vote the opposition received was roughly the same as that which they got in the previous year's constituent assembly elections.
nelda34notes: The party of the newly inaugurated president, Ulate, won soundly; the junta had backed his democratically elected presidency.

notes: This, and the accompanying presidential election, were the second set of elections held under the Constitution written after the 1948 civil war. It was also the first election in which women were allowed to vote.

nelda13notes: Only the Communist party was banned.
nelda24notes: The two parties that competed in the 1953 elections were different than the parties that were represented in the congressional and presidential races before that point.
nelda27notes: It was minor, however; just a couple percentage points of the vote and a few more seat than they previously had.
nelda52notes: Figueres ran on a very openly pro-US and anti-Communist platform.

notes: The government-supported presidential candidate and member of the Democratic Revolutionary Party (PRD) was Balbina Herrera. The Liberal Party and the People's Party were in alliance with the PRD, in support of Herrera. Ricardo Martinelli was the candidate of the opposition party Democratic Change, also supported by the Patriotic Union Party, the Panamenista Party, and the Nationalist Republican Liberal Movement. Martinelli won the presidential election. The incumbent president Torrijos was barred from running for another term by the Constitution. The election of Martinelli defied a trend of left-wing political victories in Latin America. Contrastingly, Martinelli is a pro-business conservative with extensive business experience (he's a multimillionaire supermarket chain owner).

notes: The ruling People's Progressive Party/Civic (PPP/C) was returned to power as a result of the elections held on November 28th for Guyana's unicameral legislature, the National Assembly. Despite retaining it's power, the PPP/C lost its majority, securing only 32 (of 65) seats, as opposed to the 36 seats it previously held. This was the first time in almost two decades that a ruling party did not secure a majority in the National Assembly in Guyana. The opposition coalition, A Partnership for National Unity (APNU), won 26 seats, and the Alliance for Change (AFC) won seven seats. Because the PPP/C won a plurality, their nominated presidential candidate, Donald Ramotar, is set to become Guyana's new president.
nelda7notes: Incumbent President Bharrat Jagdeo was barred by the constitution from seeking a third consecutive term in office.
nelda19notes: Guyana relies heavily on international development aid.
nelda20notes: Despite the fact that the president is the de facto leader of Guyana, his election is indirectly determined similar to the role of a prime minster in a parliamentary system. Thus, these parliamentary elections indirectly determined which party's candidate (in this case, the ruling PPP/C party candidate) would become the next president of Guyana.
nelda27notes: The ruling PPP/C party retained power in the elections, but they lost their majority; thus, the election results were actually a gain for the opposition.
nelda29notes: Opposition supporters protested the results of the election.
nelda30notes: Protesters demanded for a recount of the vote, which they viewed went wrongly in favor of the ruling PPP/C Party.
nelda31notes: The police used tear gas and fired rubber pellets at protesters. The opposition coalition APNU publicly condemned the actions of the police in the wake of protests, and members of the government, notably the Home Affairs minister Clement, denied giving any orders to members of the security forces to fire on opposition demonstrators. The incident was deemed a bad judgement call by junior-level police officers by government officials.

notes: The opposition Mega Combinatie (MC) coalition led by the National Democratic Party (NDP), which is led by  Desi Bouterse, won more seats than any other party to the 51-seat National Assembly, but they failed to secure a two-thirds legislative majority. Bouterse was convicted of drug trafficking in absentia in 1999 in the Netherlands, and faced trial in Surinam on charges linked to the death of his political opponents in 1982. The MC won 23 seats. The ruling New Front for Democracy (NF) coalition, led by incumbent president Ronald Venetiaan, secured 14 seats. Jennifer Geerlings-Simons of NDP was elected as leader of the National Assembly. And the National Assembly chose Bouterse as the new president, causing the Netherlands to promptly cut all aid to Surinam in response.

notes: Although Arosema is widely regarded as having ascended to the presidency as a result of this election, NELDA codes this election differently--following its rules. The members of the Constituent Assembly were elected directly by popular vote, and the election is coded as such. Arosema, however, was elected by members of the constituent assembly and not by popular vote. As such, this is not a presidential election, and the incumbent does not change as a result of this election. This election was a move away from junta dictatorship and bolstered Western confidence in ecuador's government and economy. The Conservative Party won over 34% of the vote, with the Radical Liberal Party winning 20% of the vote.

First election in over a decade in which left wing party APRA was allowed to participate; APRA won a plurality in the Congress.

Left wing Bustamente won in a 2-to-1 victory over the right wing Ureta. Came during a time when Peru was becoming increasingly democratic, and was regarded as a successful election. It was the first election for over a decade in with APRA, a left wing party, was allowed participate.

Following a 1950 coup by the armed forces overthrowing left wing Bustamante, Manuel Odria (the leader of the coup), was elected in the 1950 presidential election (his chief opponent was not on the ballot) and his PR party was the only one on the ballot.

notes: At stake in these elections were all 513 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and 54 of the 81 seats in the Senate. These parliamentary elections were held in conjunction with the presidential elections. Final results showed that the ruling left-wing parties, including President Lula's Workers' Party (PT) and the Brazilian Socialist Party PSB, gained 310 of the 513 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and 50 of the 81 seats in the Senate. The main opposition parties, including the Brazilian Social Democratic Party PSDB and the Democrats DEM, took 138 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and 24 seats in the Senate. These legislative elections were not paid much attention by the media, due to the Presidential elections occurring in parallel.
nelda13notes: law preventing candidates without a clean record from running, the names of candidates barred from running for elections under the law appeared on the ballot but the High Electoral Tribunal considered the votes cast for those candidates invalid. However in March 2011, the Supreme Court ruled that the clean record law should not be applied to the 2010 elections.
nelda17notes: Brazil at this point had the world's 8th largest economy, which had grown 7 percent a year on the strength of a commodities boom and market-friendly policies.

nelda27notes: In the previous 2006 elections, the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party (PMDB) took 89 of the 513 seats, followed by President Lula da Silva's Workers' Party (PT) with 83 seats. The main opposition Brazilian Social Democratic Party (PSDB) and its electoral ally, the Liberal Front Party (PFL, in 2007 renamed DEM), took 66 and 65 seats respectively, while the opposition Popular Socialist Party (PPS) and the Brazilian Labour Party (PTB) took 22 seats each. In these 2010 elections these opposition parties together amassed only 138 seats in the Chamber of deputies and 24 in the senate, a drop from their 2006 numbers.
nelda39notes: Notably the incumbent was soon replaced after these elections, but only because the Presidential elections were held concurrently.

notes: This Presidential election was the first since 1985 that President Lula (who at this point had an impressive 80% approval rating) had not run in - his hand-picked successor was Ms.  Dilma Rousseff. These elections were generally considered a referendum on Lula. Lula's Workers' Party (PT) was challenged by the Brazilian Social Democrat Party PSDB, which endorsed a former mayor of Sao Paulo, Mr. Jose Serra, as its presidential candidate. In this first round, no candidate secured the required 50 per cent of the votes to be elected without a second round. Rousseff led the race with 46.9 percent of the vote, according to the Superior Electoral Court. She therefore faced Jose Serra, one of the county's most experienced politicians, who had 32.61 percent of the vote. The elections were considered quite well conducted and clean.
nelda8notes: These were the first presidential elections since the end of military rule in 1985 that Lula had not run in - he was constitutionally barred from seeking a third consecutive term.

notes: This codes the second round of the Presidential Election run-off. This Presidential election was the first since 1985 that President Lula (who at this point had an impressive 80% approval rating) had not run in - his hand-picked successor was Ms. Dilma Rousseff. These elections were hence generally considered a referendum on Lula. Lula's Workers Party (PT) was challenged by the Brazilian Social Democrat Party PSDB, which endorsed a former mayor of Sao Paulo, Mr. Jose Serra, as its presidential candidate. Rousseff ultimately won with 56% of the vote, compared to Serra's 44%. She had campaigned on a platform of poverty eradication and inequality targetting, and her success was largely attributed to Lula's support.

General Higinio Morinigo decided to step down; Natalicio Gonzalaz was the only candidate and people could either vote for him or cast a blank ballot. notes: , pledged to tackle corruption and poverty. These elections were a decisive defeat of the ANR's longtime dominance. Though the ANR remained the largest party in both chambers, its margin was significantly reduced. It took 30 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and 15 seats in the Senate. The parties in the APC won a total of 31 and 17 seats respectively. The UNACE, the second opposition coalition headed by Presidential candidate (and exiled former army chief) Lino Cesar Oviedo took 15 and 9 seats respectively.
nelda12notes: Fernando Lugo was backed by a nine-party coalition, in opposition to the ANR. Furthermore, in the 2003 elections the ANR had obtained its worst results since the country returned to democracy in 1989.
nelda17notes: Relatively strong revenue growth enabled the Paraguayan central government to post a fiscal surplus of 1% GDP in 2007, a trend of currency appreciation and rapid accumulation of international reserves continued into 2008, and overall the Central Bank estimated that Paraguay�s GDP grew by a robust and historically high 6.4% in 2007. The gloabl financial crisis had yet to hit.
nelda19notes: Paraguay receives some aid from the US to help combat drug trafficking, money laundering and the infringement of intellectual property rights, to protect its rainforests, and to bolster its democratic institutions from USAID. This is not a very significant amount, however. Paraguay had not received money from the IMF since 1984.
nelda24notes: Though the incumbent's party lost the Presidential elections and took the biggest hit in their history in the legislative elections, they still remained the largest party in both the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate. However, though the ANR remained the largest party in both chambers, its margin was significantly reduced. It took 30 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and 15 seats in the Senate. The parties in the APC (Lugo's opposition coalition) won a total of 31 and 17 seats respectively. The UNACE took 15 and nine seats respectively. Thus, key positions did not go to the ANR (the largest party): the Chamber of Deputies elected Mr. Enrique Buzarquis C�ceres (Lugo's PLRA) as its new Speaker, while the Senate chose Mr. Enrique Gonz�lez Quintana (UNACE, the party of the other Presidential Candidate Lino Cesar Oviedo) as its new President.
nelda26notes: A variety of polls gave many different readings (mostly as to the Presidential elections, though this involved support for particular parties). Opposition Lugo was either winning, or the candidates were in dead heat. For example,one poll showed that 31.9% of respondents would vote for Lugo's Alliance for Change (APC) ticket, while the ruling National Republican Association - Colorado Party (ANR) were second with 27.5%, followed by retired Army general Lino Oviedo and his National Union of Ethical Citizens (UNACE) with 24.9%. But one poll released by the polling group I.C.A. showed a virtual dead heat, with Mrs. Ovelar (incumbent party's candidate) ahead, 36 percent to 33.5 percent for Mr. Lugo.
nelda27notes: In this election for the Chamber of Deputies, the ANR won 30 seats, as compared to 37 in the last election (2003). The ANR failed to win a majority in either chamber, and lost the Presidency. They were still the largest party in both chambers, however.

notes: this was the election that began the end of the Pinochet rule in Chile.  As per the 1980 constitution, the military junta had a referendum, as scheduled, in 1988 to decide whether to return Pinochet for another 8 years in power.

notes: Parties allied with the president's PJ party lost seats and the opposition made significant gains in these midterm elections.

The partial legislative elections held on October 23, 2011 in Argentina were held simultaneously with presidential elections that culminated in the reelection of incumbent president Kirchner. 130 of the 257 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and 24 of the 72 seats in the Senate were contested. The FV party (incumbent Kirchner's party) and its allies won 85 seats in the Chamber of Deputies, and the UCR and FAP won 15 and 14 seats, respectively. The FV and its allies regained control of both chambers of the legislature (they'd lost the majority in 2009, despite Kirchner's presidential win).
nelda17notes: The economy had experienced a crash in 2001, and had subsequently been further weakened during the worldwide 2008-2009 crisis; however, in the past couple of years the Argentinian economy had been experiencing relatively high growth rates. And despite the fact that international organizations such as the IMF warned Argentinian policy makers of high inflation and likely economic downturns, the perception was that Argentina was actually doing relatively well to other countries in the region.

notes: Incumbent president, Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner, secured a landslide reelection with 53.96% of the vote  in the October 23rd presidential elections that were held in Argentina. Kirchner was the candidate for the Front for Victory (FV) party, a faction of the ruling (Peronist) Justicialist Party (PJ). Her closest opponent in the election, Hermes Binner, the candidate of the Broad Progressive Front (PS) won 16.87% of the vote.

nelda17notes: In 2003, Uruguay went through the steepest economic and financial crisis in recent history, which developed mostly from external factors. Devaluation in Brazil in 1999 made Uruguayan goods less competitive.

notes: This coding is for the Senate and House of Representatives, which were held in conjunction with the elections for the Presidency. In the previous elections held in 2004, the Broad Front (FA) coalition took 53 seats in the House of Representatives and 17 in the Senate. The FA's victory ended 170 years of political dominance by the National Party (PN) (who took 34 seats in the House of Representatives and 10 in the Senate) and the Colorado Party (PC), who 10 and 3 seats respectively. In these 2009 elections, the incumbent FA retained the majority in both chambers, taking 50 seats in the House of Representatives and 16 in the Senate. The opposition PN took 30 and 9 seats, and the PC took 17 and 5.
nelda8notes: In the concurrent Presidential elections, FA President Vazquez had reached the end of the single five-year term required by Uruguay's constitution, though many complained that this term wasn't enough to consolidate the successes of Vazquez, who had enjoyed 71% approval ratings in a poll before these elections.
nelda17notes: Though the government had managed to retain positive growth in the economy despite the global financial crisis, growth had nevertheless decelerated to 2.9% in 2009. Competitiveness had shrunk and unemployment was rising.
nelda18notes: Despite the global economic crisis, the country's economy remained admirably stable. GDP was expected to rise by 1.2 per cent in 2009.
nelda20notes: Presidential elections were held concurrently.
nelda24notes: In these 2009 elections, the incumbent FA retained the majority in both chambers.
nelda26notes: FA Presidential Candidate Mujica's charismatic, blunt, grandfatherly personality was thought to have given the FA the lead in opinion polls.
nelda27notes: The FA lost 3 seats, down to 50, in the House of Representatives as compared to the 2004 elections, and lost one seat, down to 16, in the Senate.
nelda45notes: Observers from international NGOs were present, such as from the Instituto interamericano de derechos humanos (InterAmerican Institute for Human Rights).
nelda46notes: About 20 election judges from Chile, Colombia, El Salvador, Mexico, Panama, Paraguay and the Dominican Republic attended, but none from Western countries.
nelda47notes: The elections were reported as occurring in a calm and orderly environment: international observers praised the organizations of the polls and democratic spirit of voters that queued naturally at the booths for their turn.

notes: This coding is for the Presidential elections, which were held in conjunction with the elections for the bicameral legislature. In the previous, 2004 elections, the Broad Front (FA) candidate, Tabar� V�zquez, won the run-off presidential elections. Because of the constitutional limit of one term for President, in the 2009 elections the incumbent FA party of President Vazquez endorsed Senator Jos� Mujica as its presidential candidate, to replace Vazquez. A former member of the rebel Tupamaros National Liberation Movement (MLN) who was jailed and tortured for years during Uruguay�s military rule, Mujica was extremely charismatic and campaigned as a blunt but grandfatherly figure. He was challenged by former president Luis Lacalle of the opposition National Party (PN) and Mr. Pedro Bordaberry of the Colorado Party (PC).  No candidate won the required majority in the presidential elections to be elected in this first round � Mujica won just over 48% and Lacalle 29%.
nelda8notes: The FA party's President Vazquez had reached the end of the single five-year term required by Uruguay's constitution, though many complained that this term wasn't enough to consolidate the successes of Vazquez, who had enjoyed 71% approval ratings in a poll before these elections.
nelda17notes: Though the government had managed to retain positive growth in the economy despite the global financial crisis, growth had nevertheless decelerated to 2.9% in 2009. Reports of shrinking competitiveness were emerging.
nelda18notes: Despite the global economic crisis, the country's economy remained admirably stable. GDP was expected to rise by 1.2 per cent in 2009.
nelda22notes: President Vazquez's party, the FA, had nominated Mujica as their Presidential candidate.
nelda23notes: Note that this is only because this was the first round of the election - in the second round, Mujica would indeed take power.
nelda24notes: Vazquez fell just short of the 50% needed to avoid a run off. His closest competitor, Lacalle, won only 29%.
nelda26notes: FA Presidential Candidate Mujica's charismatic, blunt, grandfatherly personality was thought to have given the FA the lead in opinion polls.
nelda27notes: In the previous Presidential elections of 2004, the FA candidate had won 52%, thereby avoiding a run off. In these elections, a run-off was not avoided.
nelda39notes: Because the required 50% of votes to avoid a run-off was not achieved. Vazquez would be replaced in the next round.

nelda46notes: About 20 election judges Chile, Colombia, El Salvador, Mexico, Panama, Paraguay and the Dominican Republic attended, but none from Western countries.

notes: This coding is for the second round of the Presidential elections. In the previous round, no candidate won the required majority 50% to be elected in the first round � Mujica of the incumbent Broud Front coalition (FA) won just over 48%, and his main opposition, former president Luis Lacalle of the opposition National Party (PN), won 29%. A former member of the rebel Tupamaros National Liberation Movement (MLN) who was jailed and tortured for years during Uruguay�s military rule, Mujica was extremely charismatic and campaigned as a blunt but grandfatherly figure. In these run-off presidential elections between Mujica (of the FA, who had won in the recent legislative elections held in conjunction with the first round of the Presidential elections) and Lacalle (of the PN, with Colorado Party endorsement), Mujica retained the Presidency for the FA, elected with over 52 per cent of votes.
nelda8notes: The FA party's President Vazquez had reached the end of the single five-year term required by Uruguay's constitution, though many complained that this term wasn't enough to consolidate the successes of Vazquez, who had enjoyed 71% approval ratings in a poll before these elections.
nelda17notes: Though the government had managed to retain positive growth in the economy despite the global financial crisis, growth had nevertheless decelerated to 2.9% in 2009.
nelda18notes: Despite the global economic crisis, the country's economy remained admirably stable. GDP was expected to rise by 1.2 per cent in 2009.
nelda22notes: President Vazquez's party, the FA, had nominated Mujica as their Presidential candidate.
nelda24notes: Mujica retained the Presidency for outgoing President Vazquez's FA coalition, elected with over 52 per cent of votes.
nelda26notes: FA Presidential Candidate Mujica's charismatic, blunt, grandfatherly personality was thought to have given the FA the lead in opinion polls.
nelda40notes: Note that Vazquez had reached his term limit, and this is why he did not run again. Mujica was his chosen successor from the FA coalition.
nelda46notes: Observers from international NGOs were present, such as from the Instituto interamericano de derechos humanos (InterAmerican Institute for Human Rights), but the observers hailed from Latin American rather than Western countries.

Though the Conservative Party received the largest vote share, gaining the post of PM, the election resulted in just the second hung parliament since WWII. Resulted in a coalition government between the CP and the Liberal Democrats, ending 13 years of Labour rule.

notes: This was Ireland's first contested presidential election. The ruling party, Fianna Fail, nominated Sean O'Kelly, who won, but in a tight race that went to a second count, showing that the country was shifting away from the party.

notes: O'Kelly reached his term limit. De Valera, previously the Prime Minister, under pressure from his party (FF), ran for and won the presidency. Lemass took over for de Valera as the PM after de Valera won the election.
