notes: The issues of the election centered around Irish troops in the Congo, joining the European common market, and the Irish language.  The main parties involved were the incumbent Fianna Fail, Fine Gael, and the Irish labour Party. The elections resulted in the victory of Fianna Fail but the loss of its overall majority (from 78 to 70 seats), small gains by both Fine Gael (40 to 47 seats) and Labour (12 to 16 seats), and the loss of all its former seats by Sinn Fein. Fianna Fail lost its majority but was still able to form the new government without a coalition.
nelda6notes: There is a five-year term, but elections are generally called within four years of the last election, in order to avoid postponing the dissolution of Parliament until the last possible moment, when an election would have to take place irrespective of the circumstances prevailing at the time. Mr. Lemass noted that it was desirable that a general election should take place when all the prevailing circumstances�international as well as national�minimized the risk of serious national disadvantage caused by a dissolution.
nelda7notes: The Taoiseach (Irish PM) is determined by the party with the majority in the Irish Parliament (Dail), hence there is no term limit as such.
nelda12notes: Fianna Fail made unofficial predictions estimating the margin that they would win by.
nelda17notes: Over the last two years, the Irish economy was considered to have shown promising growth. Both agricultural and industrial output were up, and an overall growth of 7% was expected. Ireland was preparing itself for EEC membership.
nelda25notes: Opinion polls were not widespread through Ireland with regard to the election process.
nelda27notes: The elections resulted in the victory of Fianna Fail but the loss of its overall majority (from 78 to 70 seats), small gains by both Fine Gael (40 to 47 seats) and Labour (12 to 16 seats), and the loss of all its former seats by Sinn Fein.
nelda54notes: Ireland was heavily embroiled in the UN peacekeeping mission in the Congo, was closely economically tied to Britiain, and had applied for full membership to the EEC.

notes: This election was fought between incumbent Fianna Fail led by Taoisheach LeMass, against the two main opposition parties Fine Gael and Labour. The main issue was whether or not a coalition government would be the best for the country (incumbent Fianna Fail was opposed to this), and what a social improvement programme would look like (the opposition wanted an overhauling of the tax system). In short, the election was to decide to what extent Ireland could afford to be a welfare state, and who was best equipped to lead this transition. This election was marked with comments on how sophisticated and detailed the political debate was, and how dedicated to understanding party manifestos the electorate was. The Fianna Fail Government of Mr. Lemass slightly improved its position as a result of this general election, gaining exactly half of the Dail (parliament) seats (from 70 in 1961 to 72 in 1965), and suceeding in forming a Cabinet without a coalition.
nelda6notes: There is a five-year term, but elections are generally called within four years of the last election, in order to avoid postponing the dissolution of Parliament until the last possible moment, when an election would have to take place irrespective of the circumstances prevailing at the time.
nelda7notes: The Taoiseach (Irish PM) is determined by the party with the majority in the Irish Parliament (Dail), hence there is no term limit as such.
nelda12notes: LeMass had announced that he was confident that Fianna Fail would win 72 seats in the Dail, which is exactly half. This, however, would not be an absolute majority and therefore they needed more in order to have a stable government: he urged his party members on in their campaigns.
nelda20notes: The Irish Taoisheach is determined by the party who wins a majority in the Dail.
nelda25notes: Opinion Polls were not widely used in Ireland, and national newspapers commented on how this led to considerable speculation about results.
nelda27notes: Fianna Fail gained two seats, from 70 to 72, giving them a majority with the support of some independents.
nelda33notes: There wasn't significant violence involving civilian deaths; however, fire bombs were hurled at the Fianna Fail headquarters in Dublin at election day. No one was injured, and this was the only blip in an otherwise very calm and civilized campaign.

notes: Mr. Eamon de Valera (Fianna Fail) was re-elected President for a further seven-year term, with a narrow majority of 10,717 votes over Mr. O�Higgins, his Fine Gael opponent. Of the total valid poll of 1,107,005 votes (about 65 per cent of the electorate), President de Valera obtained 50.8 per cent and Mr. O�Higgins 49.2 per cent. The Irish Times said that it was felt that a major factor contributing to the drastic fall in the President's vote compared with 1959 was �the economic situation as reflected in the rash of strikes which have given Ireland the unenviable reputation of having the greatest strike rate in Western Europe ever the past 12 months.� Note that the incumbent leader of Ireland is not the President, but in fact the Prime Minister (Taoiseach). Both de Valera and incumbent PM LeMass were of the Fianna Fail party.
nelda6notes: Elections occur every seven years, and the last was in 1959, hence these were on schedule.
nelda8notes: Presidents are allowed two seven-year terms, and this would be de Valera's second. However, President is not incumbent leader.
nelda20notes: The incumbent leader of Ireland is the Taoiseach - determined by Parliamentary (Dail) elections.
nelda24notes: De Valera was incumbent Fianna Fail's candidate, and he won these elections.
nelda27notes: The Irish Times said that it was felt that a major factor contributing to the drastic fall in the President's vote compared with 1959 was �the economic situation as reflected in the rash of strikes which have given Ireland the unenviable reputation of having the greatest strike rate in Western Europe ever the past 12 months.� Other contributory causes adduced included the President's age, and statements by Ministers that �a vote for his opponent was anti-national.�
nelda39notes: Election did not involve incumbent leader's position.
nelda54notes: Ireland was heavily embroiled in the UN, was closely economically tied to Britiain, and had applied for full membership to the EEC.

notes: This election was held between Jack Lynch's Fianna Fail government, and the opposition Fine Gael and Labour parties. The election resulted in a decisive strengthening of the Government's position in that Fianna Fail, for the first time since 1957-61, gained an absolute majority over all other parties, increasing its seats from 72 to 75. Fine Gael also made gains; both Fianna Fail and Fine Gael's successes were achieved at the expense of the Labour Party and Independents. The major issues during the election were who could guide the country's economic and social development, and best manage Ireland's accession to the EEC. Fianna Fail campaigned on the strength of its previous terms in government.
nelda6notes: There is a five-year term, but elections are generally called within four years of the last election, in order to avoid postponing the dissolution of Parliament until the last possible moment, when an election would have to take place irrespective of the circumstances prevailing at the time.
nelda7notes: The Taoiseach (Irish PM) is determined by the party with the majority in the Irish Parliament (Dail), hence there is no term limit as such.
nelda12notes: Lynch spoke at Fianna Fail rallies of how neither Fine Gael nor Labour had any chance of running the government.
nelda17notes: There were accusations by the opposition that the Fianna Fail government had released the recent optimistic Budget in order to rose-tint the economic situation. In general, the economy had been growing, though national debt was beginning to increase considerably.
nelda21notes: Jack Lynch had replaced Sean LeMass as Taoisheach of Ireland and Fianna Fail leader a couple of years after the 1965 elections.
nelda25notes: Opinion polls were not used regularly in conjunction with Irish elections.
nelda27notes: Fianna Fail gained an absolute majority for the first time in its previous three terms, winning 75 (up from 72) seats. Fine Gael also increased its seats by 3, but Labour and the independents lost seats.
nelda51notes: Relations did not change, as the government stayed the same.

notes: This election between Jack Lynch's incumbent  Fianna Fail part saw Fianna Fail, which had held power uninterruptedly in the Irish Republic since 1957,  narrowly defeated by a National Coalition of the two main opposition parties, the Fine Gael and Labour parties. Party strengths at the dissolution on Feb. 5 were: Fianna Fail 69, Fine Gael 50, Labour 17. In these elections Fianna Fail retained their 69 delegates, but Fine Gael increased to 54, and Labour to 19, meaning that they had an absolute majority of two over Fianna Fail. Lynch has based his campaign on a call for a vote of confidence in his handling of Ulster situation; Opposition, led by Prime Min L Cosgrave, did not choose to confront Lynch on question of North and instead launched a strong campaign for tax relief, increased housing and social benefits and the fight against inflation.
nelda6notes: There is a five-year term, but elections are generally called within four years of the last election, in order to avoid postponing the dissolution of Parliament until the last possible moment, when an election would have to take place irrespective of the circumstances prevailing at the time.
nelda7notes: The Taoiseach (Irish PM) is determined by the party with the majority in the Irish Parliament (Dail), hence there is no term limit as such.
nelda17notes: The economy was lagging, unemployment high, and inflation approaching 9%.
nelda18notes: This year Ireland joined the EEC.
nelda24notes: Fianna Fail actually retained their position as the largest party, with a majority of 69; however the two main opposition parties had an absolute majority when combined, hence they were able to form a government without Fianna Fail.
nelda25notes: were used instead of polls.
nelda27notes: In these elections Fianna Fail retained their 69, but Fine Gael increased to 54, and Labour to 19, meaning that they had an absolute majority of two over Fianna Fail.
nelda51notes: Relations did not change, as both the outgoing and incoming governments were friendly with the US.
nelda54notes: Note that though Ireland was close to the UK economically, the political situation was very cold and fraught with antagonism.
nelda56notes: Like Lynch's outgoing government, the National Coalition Government pledged itself to maximizing Ireland's influence within the European Community. Fine Gael was however known to be less militant and aggressive in their stance on a united Ireland (Northern Ireland joining the Republic) than the outgoing Fianna Fail government.

notes: As de Valera had reached his two-term maximum as President, the new Fianna Fail candidate was Erskine Hamilton Childers. He had served in different cabinet posts until defeating T.F. O'Higgins of Fine Gael in these elections. The incumbent in government at the moment was Liam Cosgrave, a Fine Gael Prime Minister leading a Fine Gael cabinet. Hence, the incumbent government's candidate was actually defeated (Childers of Fianna Fail defeated Higgins of Fine Gael).
nelda6notes: They occur every seven years, and the last was in 1966, hence these were on schedule.
nelda8notes: Presidents are allowed two seven-year terms, and de Valera had reached this maximum. However,  the President is not incumbent leader; the Prime Minister is.
nelda12notes: Taking Fine Gael as the ruling party (according to the Archigos dataset, Cosgrave of Fine Gael is incumbent), they were not confident of victory in these Presidential elections. Indeed, their candidate lost.
nelda20notes: The incumbent leader of Ireland is the Taoiseach - determined by Parliamentary (Dail) elections.
nelda24notes: The incumbent in power is Fine Gael (Cosgrave is PM and this is considered incumbent leader in Ireland), and their candidate for President lost.
nelda32notes: Results did not favor the incumbent Cosgrave, because his Fine Gael Presidential candidate lost.
nelda39notes: The election did not involve incumbent leader's position.
nelda54notes: Ireland was heavily embroiled in the UN, was closely economically tied to Britiain, and had applied for full membership to the EEC.

notes: In these elections for the Dail, the National Coalition Government of Fine Gael and the Labour Party was decisively defeated by the opposition Fianna Fail, led by former Taoiseach Jack Lynch. The results of the three main parties were Fianna Fail 84 seats (as compared to 69 in the 1973 elections), Fine Gael 43 (compared to 54), and Labour 17 seats (compared to 19. Observers saw this upset victory as repudiation of the government's economic policies - the last government term had seen Ireland experience the worst recession since the 1930s, due to the international oil crisis of 1972 onwards.
nelda6notes: There is a five-year term, but elections are generally called within four years of the last election, in order to avoid postponing the dissolution of Parliament until the last possible moment, when an election would have to take place irrespective of the circumstances prevailing at the time.
nelda7notes: The Taoiseach (Irish PM) is determined by the party with the majority in the Irish Parliament (Dail), hence there is no term limit as such.
nelda17notes: Ireland had by 1977 successfully weathered the worst effects of the recession of 1974-5 (the worst since the 1930s). In 1976 production in manufacturing and mining had risen by 11 per cent, one of the largest increases ever, and the Republic was now one of the few countries where production was above its pre-crisis peak. Inflation was decreasing, and employment levels decreasing.
nelda18notes: The economic crisis of 1973 onwards had come to an end.
nelda25notes: This as the first time opinion polls had been introduced to Irish elections.
nelda27notes: There was a swing to opposition Fianna Fail of over five per cent - The results of the three main parties were Fianna Fail 84 seats (as compared to 69 in the 1973 elections), Fine Gael 43 (compared to 54), and Labour 17 seats (compared to 19.
nelda51notes: Relations did not change, as both the outgoing and incoming governments were friendly with the US.
nelda54notes: Note that though Ireland was economically tightly bound to the UK, politically speaking the situation was fraught with antagonism.
nelda56notes: Both the outgoing and incoming governments were very pro-EU, and enthusiastic about Ireland's commitment to the UN and other facets of the international Community. Traditionally, Fianna Fail and Jack Lynch had been very vocally and agressively for the unification of Ireland (Northern Ireland with the Republic). Lynch was noticeably more quiet about the situation during these elections, choosing to focus on the state of the economy. This perhaps reflected the increasingly intractible nature of the problem.

notes: These elections saw the Fianna Fail incumbent government of Taoiseach Charles Haughey lose a substantial number of seats. Mr Haughey had went to the polls with the comment that the Government needed a clear mandate to pursue its efforts to achieve a political solution to the problem of Northern Ireland - the situation had become particularly grave in the weeks before the elections, due to the death (which occurred on May 5) of Mr Bobby Sands during the Provisional Irish Republican Army (IRA) hunger striker in the H-Block of the infamous Maze prison. The results for the three main parties were  that Fianna Fail won 78 seats as compared to 84 in the 1977 elections, Fine Gael won 65 as compared to 43, and Labour won 15 as compared to 17. No individual party or potential coalition of parties secured an overall majority in the Dail (Lower House of Parliament) without the support of a number of independent members. Eventually, on June 30, Dr Garret Fitzgerald, leader since 1977 of the main opposition party Fine Gael was elected Taoiseach and formed a coalition Fine Gael- Labour Party Government. Hence though Fianna Fail were still the largest party in the Dail, they were not part of the government that resulted from these elections. Note that two IRA hunger-strikers currently imprisoned in Belfast's H-Block won seats in the Dail during these elections, and their deaths after these elections would soon help to destabilize this already fragile government. Their election victory were seen to reflect the Irish public's support for their cause, and the new government was thought to be under pressure to take a more aggressive line against Thatcher, and agitate more for Irish reunification.
nelda6notes: There is a five-year term, but elections are generally called within four years of the last election, in order to avoid postponing the dissolution of Parliament until the last possible moment, when an election would have to take place irrespective of the circumstances prevailing at the time.
nelda7notes: The Taoiseach (Irish PM) is determined by the party with the majority in the Irish Parliament (Dail), hence there is no term limit as such.
nelda8notes: There is no term limit for Taoiseach.
nelda17notes: Economists and bankers  warned that, in addition to pressing problems of high inflation and unemployment, Ireland has plunged dangerously deep into debt by borrowing from foreign bankers to cover huge budget deficits.
nelda26notes: Final public opinion polls predicted a tight finish between Haughey and Fitzgerald.
nelda27notes: Incumbent Fianna Fail won 78 seats as compared to 84 in the 1977 elections, Fine Gael won 65 as compared to 43, and Labour won 15 as compared to 17.
nelda29notes: There weren't riots and protests after the election, but there were demonstrations and rioting in the heart of Dublin before the elections, following the deaths of the four hunger strikers. Youths battled police, smashed store windows and set cars on fire in Dublin, and a half dozen British-owned homes were burned in the countryside. Businesses were pressured to close during the hunger strikers' funerals. Heckling demonstrators who carried black flags  harassed Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey during the campaign because he refused to support the hunger strikers' demands that Irish nationalist terrorists be treated as prisoners of war rather than criminal convicts in British prisons in Northern Ireland.
nelda33notes: These elections occurred in the middle of the hunger-striking protests of IRA volunteers who were protesting their treatment as 'civilians' instead of as political prisoners in Northern Ireland's H-block. Undoubtedly, voter sympathies were affected by the Maze Prison hunger strike. Four inmates died the month before the election, and each was succeeded by another volunteer. To intensify the pressure, the I.R.A. began putting another inmate on fast each week. As a result, four IRA prisoners (one a hunger striker) who were at the time imprisoned in the H-block ran in these elections, and two were elected to the Dail (as Sinn Fein members). Note that these men were considered citizens because Ireland at this point claimed sovereignty over the whole Ireland.
nelda40notes: Though admittedly Haughey's Fianna Fail Party still had the highest vote count, there had been a significant swing to the opposition, and Fianna Fail could no longer form an absolute majority against an opposition coalition.
nelda51notes: Relations did not change, as both the outgoing and incoming governments were friendly with the US.
nelda54notes: Note that though Ireland was economically close to the UK, politically the situation was very dire and aggressive.
nelda55notes: Both the outgoing and incoming governments were very pro-EU, and enthusiastic about Ireland's commitment to  other facets of the international community. However, the election of IRA members to the Irish Dail did cause a souring of Irish-British relations even further than they were deteriorating. Notably though, Mr. FitzGerald seemed certain to continue the political dialogue that Prime Minister Haughey initiated with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain during the last year. With the election in border constituencies of the two IRA prisoners, the new government was   under pressure to take a more aggressive approach to relations with Britain and the problem of Northern Ireland. These elections were said to have been the most affected by Northern Ireland in the nation's history. However, Taoiseach Fitzgerald, in the ensuing talks with Margaret Thatcher, was cautious and diplomatic.

notes: though in reality the focus of these elections was very much Ireland's fiscal crisis and the impending budget, rather than the struggles in the North.
nelda6notes: Following the defeat, by a single vote, of the fragile minority Fine Gael-Labour Party coalition Government's budget in the Dail (Lower House of Parliament), Taoiseach FitzGerald gave his Government's resignation to the Irish President. A general election was accordingly held on Feb. 18 (only 30 weeks after the previous poll in June 1981). The usual term is 4 -5 years.
nelda7notes: The Fine Gael-Labour coalition seriously considered giving government another try, when the results of these elections proved inconclusive.
nelda16notes: The Government did banned the state-run radio and television networks from giving air time in this election to Sinn Fein, the legal political front of the illegal IRA. Taoiseach FitzGerald issued a statement saying the Government had decided it was ''inappropriate to allow Provisional Sinn Fein to promulgate their views in view of their commitment to violence.'' The decision brought protests from both Sinn Fein and the local branch of the National Union of Journalists.
nelda17notes: Economists and bankers  warned that, in addition to pressing problems of high inflation and unemployment, Ireland has plunged dangerously deep into debt by borrowing from foreign bankers to cover huge budget deficits.
nelda18notes: FitzGerald's government fell because of its attempt to deal with the crisis - independents had refused to support the extremely severe budget he proposed to deal with Ireland's fiscal crisis. To combat 23 percent inflation and 12 percent unemployment, the Prime Minister proposed major tax increases and a debt-reduction program.
nelda26notes: Conflicting last-minute opinion polls Thursday afternoon forecast victory for both Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald's coalition government of Fine Gael and Labor Parties and for Charles Haughey's Fianna Fail Party. The Irish Times poll gave Fianna Fail a five-point lead over the center-left coalition of Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald, although it indicated his popularity was still high.
nelda27notes: Though marginal, Fianna Fail gained three seats, and eventually (after much negotiation) ended up forming a government.
nelda51notes: Relations did not change, as both the outgoing and incoming governments were friendly with the US.
nelda54notes: Note that though Ireland was economically close to the UK, politically the situation was very dire and aggressive.
nelda55notes: Haughey was infamous for his thorny relationship with Margaret Thatcher. Though it should be noted that despite incoming Taoiseach Haughey's supposedly very aggressively pro Irish re-unification, in reality he followed much the same policy towards Thatcher's UK as his predecessor Fitzgerald had done. In any case, the focus at the moment was very much the economy rather than Britain, and both Haughey and Fitzgerald were enthusiastic about Ireland's opportunities in the EEC.

notes: With its economy crashing and tensions in the North rising, this was one of the most turbulent times in the Irish republic's history. Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey's minority Fianna Fail government fell by two votes after eight months in office, forcing the third parlimentary election in 18 months. Mr. Haughey was defeated 82 to 80 in a vote of no-confidence in the Dail (lower house of Parliament). In these resultant elections Fianna Fail lost a total of five seats in the Dail, while Fine Gael gained six seats and the Labour Party gained two. As in the two previous elections, held in June 1981 and February 1982, no individual party secured an overall majority. After much deliberation, and despite the fact that Fianna Fail remained the single largest party in Parliment, a Fine Gael/Labour coalition Government was formed on Dec. 14 under the leadership of Dr Garret FitzGerald.
nelda6notes: Though usual terms of government last between 4 - 5 years, this was a time on intense political instability for Ireland. Prime Minister Charles Haughey's minority Fianna Fail government fell by two votes after eight months in office, forcing the third parlimentary election in 18 months. Mr. Haughey was defeated 82 to 80 in a vote of no-confidence in the Dail (lower house of Parliament).
nelda8notes: The incumbent in Ireland is the Taoiseach (PM), who does not have a term limit as such, as they are typically the head of the largest party in Parliament.
nelda18notes: Haughey's government had collapsed as it struggled to revive an ailing economy afflicted by chronic foreign debt, 17 percent inflation, and 13 percent unemployment.
nelda24notes: Though Fianna Fail were still the largest party in Parliament, they lost these elections as Labour refused to enter coalition with them (Haughey's premiership was quite controversial). A Fine Gael coalition with Labour resulted.
nelda26notes: The last public opinion poll indicated neither party would win an overall majority and the most likely prospect was for a coalition between Fine Gael and the small Labor Party.
nelda27notes: Incumbent Fianna Fail lost a total of five seats in the Dail, while opposition Fine Gael gained six seats and the Labour Party gained two.
nelda51notes: Relations did not change, as both the outgoing and incoming governments were friendly with the US.
nelda54notes: Note that though Ireland was economically close to the UK, politically the situation was very dire and aggressive.
nelda55notes: The focus at the moment was the economy rather than Britain, and both Haughey and Fitzgerald were enthusiastic about Ireland's opportunities in the EEC.

notes: The incumbent Fine-Gael/Labour coalition collapsed over the proposed government, and PM (Taoiseach) Fitzgerald was faced with criticism of his party's handling of Ireland's economic woes over the past 4 years. These elections hence focused on Ireland's current economic problems, and how each party would tackle the problems. In the background to the elections was the 1985 Anglo-Irish Agreement on Northern Ireland, which Fine Gael viewed as a triumph of their term, and which Fianna Fail opposed (they saw it as making too many concessions to the British). Fianna Fail increased to 81 from 70 seats, Fine Gael went from 68 to 51, and the new party - the Progressive Democrats - overtook Labour to be the third largest party, with 14 seats. A Fianna Fail minority government ensued.
nelda6notes: The Fine Gael- Labour Party government collapsed in January 1987 when the four Labour ministers resigned from the Cabinet in protest against proposed public expenditure cuts under the 1987 budget. The Fine Gael Prime Minister (Taoiseach) Dr FitzGerald immediately requested President Patrick Hillery to dissolve the D�il. New elections were set for Feb. 17, nearly 10 months before the expiry of the current five-year parliamentary term.
nelda8notes: The incumbent in Ireland is the Taoiseach (PM), who does not have a term limit as such, as they are typically the head of the largest party in Parliament.
nelda16notes: The existing legislative ban on Sinn Fein broadcasts or interviews on Irish radio and television  remained in force, with the support of the parties of the outgoing coalition, whereas Fianna F�il came out in favour of relaxing the broadcasting ban in the case of Sinn Fein candidates and elected representatives.
nelda17notes: The official forecast for 1987 was a mere 1.5 per cent growth overall.
nelda18notes: By the beginning of 1987 the state debt had exceeded 23,000 million Irish pounds. The austerity measures that the FitzGerald government was employing affected the Irish working people badly. There were 250,000 unemployed in the country -  that is one out of every five able-bodied persons. The growth of taxation and the population's impoverishment have led to the situation when over one-third of the families live in the conditions of poverty, as charity organisations estimate.
nelda26notes: Opinion polls predicted a loss for Fitzgerald.
nelda27notes: Opposition Fianna Fail increased to 81 from 70 seats, incumbent Fine Gael went from 68 to 51, and the new party - the Progressive Democrats - overtook Labour to be the third largest party.
nelda51notes: Relations did not change, as both the outgoing and incoming governments were friendly with the US.
nelda54notes: Note that though Ireland was economically close to the UK, politically the situation was very dire and aggressive.
nelda55notes: The recent Anglo-Irish agreement of 1985 on Northern Ireland which had been achieved by Fitzgerald's Fine Gael party had been opposed by the incoming Fianna Fail. Hence though the Anglo-Irish Agreement was not a major election issue, incoming Taoiseach Mr Haughey asserted  that a Fianna F�il government would seek to renegotiate the agreement, that it had brought no real benefits to the Catholic community in the North, and that it enshrined a permanent �Unionist veto� on eventual Irish unification.

notes: Taoiseach Charles Haughey had on May 25 asked the President to dissolve the D�il and announced a premature general election, as his Fianna Fail minority government had been defeated six times in the D�il since March 1987, and he sought a majority in order to wield more control. Opposition politicians maintained that the election was unnecessary - the minority government had not created political instability over the past two years, it was pointed out, with both Fine Gael and the Progressive Democrats supporting Haughey's economic austerity measures. The economy was slowly improving from the crisis of the early 80s.  In these elections Haughey�s incumbent Fianna Fail failed to win an overall majority � they performed less well than in the 1987 elections, while gains were made by Fine Gael, by the Labour Party and by The Workers� Party. Unable to form a government, Haughey was forced to resign on June 29, but he was later to agree to a Fianna Fail coalition with the Progressive Democrats.
nelda6notes: Charles Haughey had on May 25 asked the President to dissolve the D�il and announced a premature general election, as his Fianna Fail minority government had been defeated six times in the D�il since March 1987, and he sought a majority in order to wield more control.
nelda8notes: The incumbent in Ireland is the Taoiseach (PM), who does not have a term limit as such, as they are typically the head of the largest party in Parliament.
nelda12notes: Haughey had called these elections because he thought he could win a majority.
nelda17notes: Since coming to power in 1987 Haughey's government had succeeded in reducing the budget deficit from 13 per cent of gross national product to around 6 per cent and achieving an annual growth rate of 4 per cent. However, unemployment remained high at 17 per cent, emigrations had increased in 1988 to 40,000, and traditional working class support for Fianna F�il was affected also by cost-cutting policies such as reductions in funding for the health service.
nelda26notes: The final opinion poll before the election reinforced expectations that Haughey's Fianna Fail would not achieve his elusive majority government, though Fianna Fail would remain the largest party in Parliament - the Irish Times poll indicated that Mr Haughey's Fianna Fail party would win 44 per cent of votes  (a repeat of its performance in the last election, in 1987).
nelda27notes: Out of a total of 166 seats, Fianna Fail won 77 seats and Fine Gael won 55 seats, a gain of five. Fianna Fail performed less well than in the 1987 elections, while gains were made by Fine Gael, by the Labour Party and by The Workers� Party.
nelda54notes: Note that though Ireland was economically close to the UK, politically the situation was very dire and aggressive.

notes: consists of redistributing second preference votes to the top two candidates of the first preference vote. In these elections Mary Robinson, the candidate supported by the Labour Party and the Workers� Party, became the first woman to be elected President, with 51.9 per cent support (after the redistribution of second preference votes). The candidate of the ruling Fianna F�il party, Brian Lenihan, who had been the clear favourite until the controversy which led to his dismissal as Deputy Prime Minister in late October (Lenihan stumbled into a scandal over whether he had lied about placing a phone call to incumbent president Patrick Hillery eight years earlier), finished with 46.4 per cent of the vote. Robinson's defeat of the candidate of Prime Minister Charles Haughey's entrenched political machine marked one of the biggest political upsets in Irish history. Robinson, 46, a lawyer associated with human rights and civil liberties work, had resigned from the Labour Party in 1985 in protest at the Anglo-Irish agreement. After the results had been confirmed she attributed her victory to votes from the women of Ireland, who �instead of rocking the cradle rocked the system�.  Note that the incumbent party was Fianna Fail at this time, and Mary Robinson, as an independent, was therefore technically oppositon.
nelda6notes: Elections occur every seven years, hence these were on schedule as the last one occurred in 1983. Notably in 1983 people never actually went to the polls, as President Hillery was the only nominated candidate.
nelda8notes: Presidents are allowed two seven-year terms, and Hillery had reached this maximum. However, the President is not incumbent leader.
nelda12notes: The Fianna Fail candidate had recently weathered a political scandal, so he was no longer the favorite.
nelda20notes: The incumbent leader of Ireland is the Taoiseach - determined by Parliamentary (Dail) elections.
nelda26notes: Opinion polls had mostly showed Lenihan leading, though recently they had showed Robinson and him neck-and-neck. The polls gave Mr Lenihan and Mrs Robinson 43 per cent of the vote each.
nelda27notes: Robinson won.
nelda39notes: The election did not involve incumbent leader's position.
nelda55notes: Actually, Mary Robinson did tend to irritate the British government, for example when she travelled to Belfast and shook the hand of Gerry Adams (chief of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the IRA). However, because President is largely a ceremonial post, this didn't actaully alter relations between the governments of both countries.

notes: Earlier this year, Prime Minister Albert Reynolds took over from Charles Haughey as head of the Fianna Fail/Progressive Democrat coalition government. These elections were called early when he lost a vote of confidence. The distribution of seats among the major parties in the D�il after the elections was incumbent Fianna Fail 67 (previously 77), Fine Gael 45 (55), Labour Party 33 (15), Progressive Democrats 10, Democratic Left 5. In the general election the Labour Party made sweeping gains, more than doubling its share of the seats in the D�il at the expense of Fianna F�il, which won its lowest number of votes since the 1920s, and Fine Gael, which suffered its worst result since 1948. These elections coincided with national referendums on the subject of Ireland's strict policies on abortion, which was the main focus. Seven weeks after the general election, the  Fianna F�il and the Labour Party formed a coalition: it was headed by the outgoing Prime Minister, Albert Reynolds, with Labour leader Dick Spring as Deputy Prime Minister. The coalition, the first involving the two parties, enjoyed an overall majority of 36 seats, the largest in Irish history.
nelda6notes: Elections were held early. The coalition that has governed Ireland since 1989 collapsed  after  Prime Minister Albert Reynolds lost a vote of confidence in Parliament. Reynolds then had the Presidential Commission dissolve the 166-member Parliament and set elections for Nov. 25.

nelda55notes: Negotiations over the North were a major talking point in these elections, with Bruton insisting that talking to Sinn Fein was akin to voting against peace, while Ahern and the Progressive Democrats asserting the opposite - that electoral support for Sinn Fein was a vote for peace. Both sides wanted to move towards peace in Ulster (especially with the new Labour government in Britain), but they had different opinions as to whether Sinn Fein and the IRA should play a part in this peace.
nelda56notes: There is a positive change after these elections, also because the British government changed to Tony Blair's Labour party, alongside the Irish government change. Three weeks after winning the Irish general election in June of that year, Mr Ahern joined with Mr Blair to give the IRA a five-week deadline in which to call an unequivocal ceasefire before any talks could begin. The landmark Good Friday Agreement in 1998 was regarded as Mr Ahern's finest hour, and the result of his personal dedication and political style.

notes: consists of redistributing second preference votes to the top two candidates of the first preference vote. In these elections Mary McAleese, the incumbent Fianna Fail�s candidate, was elected President on Oct. 30, replacing Mary Robinson who had stepped down in September in order to serve as UN High Commissioner of Human Rights. First preference votes indicated a clear victory for McAleese, and she won close to 59 percent of the total vote after the second count. Her closest challenger was Mary Banotti of the opposition Fine Gael party, a member of the European parliament.  McAleese had been nominated by the ruling Fianna F�il and right-of-centre Progressive Democrats. McAleese's campaign was dogged by allegations that she was sympathetic to the republican Sinn F�in, but she denied the allegations insisting that �all my life, I have been anti-violence, strongly anti-IRA�. She was the first person from British-ruled Northern Ireland to fill the mostly ceremonial position. Her Irish passport made her an eligible candidate. However, she could not vote in the election because she lived in Northern Ireland.

notes: during the war). Premier Van Acker was incumbent, from the Socialist party, before these elections. The Christian Socialists won a sweeping victory, winning 92 seats in the Chamber of Deputies (an increase of 19). However, the Socialists (69) and Communists (23 - considerable gain), in coalition, had a majority of one over the Christian Socialists. The Liberals won only 17 seats (losing 16). The major issue was the return of King Leopold the Third, which the Christian Socialists supported but the other three main parties did not support. Thus, these three parties refused to enter a coalition with the Christian Socialists, who as a result were unable to form a cabinet. Mr. Spaak of the Socialist party was then invited by the Prince Regent to form a cabinet, and Spaak was thus incumbent for 18 days. After 18 days, his exclusively Socialist (and non-party independents) government broke down, and van Acker (also Socialist) once again formed a Socialist-liberal-Communist coalition, like the one that had been in power before the election.

notes: These elections were for the Belgian Lower House, the Chamber of Deputies, which determined the incumbent. Elections for the Senate were held at the same time. The government in power before this was a grand coalition of Christian Socialists and Socialists, the two biggest parties in Belgium. The Prime Minister incumbent was Spaak, a Socialist. The Parliament had been dissolved on May 19th due to a disagreement between the Christian Socilaists and the Socialists about how to fund an increase in unemployment benefits and tax industry, though the principal point at issue; however, remained the Royal question, the Socialists demanding King Leopold's abdication and the Christian Socials refusing any other solution but his return.The Christian Socialists made gains in these elections, but not as significant as they expected - they gained 13. The Socialists remained much the same (losing 3), while the opposition Liberals gained 12, and the Communists lost 11. These results meant that despite the Christian Socialist gains, a coaliton of Socialists, Liberals and Communists would have a majority of two over the Christian Socialists. The Christian Socialists had a majority in the Senate, hence had to be part of the government, but needed another party to enter a colaition with as they did not have a majority in the Lower House. Failure of van Zeeland to form a government resulted in Prince-Regent asking M. Eyskens, the Christian Social Finance Minister in M. Spaak's Government, to form a Cabinet. Eyskens formed a bipartisan government with the Liberals. Notably, these were the first Belgian elections in which women could vote, as of a law passed the year previous.

notes: but the Royal return prompted massive strikes in the streets around the country. After further internal splits in the Cabinet, the Liberals left and the Christian Socialist Cabinet resigned. The result was a scramble by new Prime Minister Deveze, and then Van Zeeland, to piece together a Cabinet, but both attempts failed and elections were held. These elections, then, pivoted on the Royal Question, and proved a success for the Christian Socialists, which were able to exclusively form a one-party government (they won a majority both in the Chamber of Deputies elections, and in the Senate elections held at the same time). The membership of the new Cabinet, which was drawn entirely from the Christian Social Party, comprised the first one-party Government in Belgium since the war. The Parliament voted, and the King returned on the 22nd of July.

notes: These elections were for the Chamber of Deputies, which determines the Prime Minister. Since the last elections in 1950, the Christian Socialists held an absolute majority in the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies, hence were able to form a one-party government. Van Houtte was the Christian Socialist Prime Minister. These elections were brought about by the dissolution of Parliament: The completion of Parliamentary action on the bill for ratifying the European Defense Community treaty was followed by the dissolution of the Belgian Parliament on March 12, because the adoption of the E.D.C. Bill involved amendments to the Belgian Constitution which, under the Constitution itself, could not be legally carried out except by a Parliament specifically elected for that purpose. In the elections to the Chamber of Deputies, the Christian Social Party lost 13 seats and thereby lost their small overall majority (they also lost their majority in the Senate elections held simultaneously), the Socialists gained nine seats, the Liberals gained five seats, and the Communists lost three seats. The Socialists and Liberals were thus able to form a government without the Christian Socialists, despite the fact that the Christian Socialists were the largest party in Parliament. Van Acker (Socialist) was made Prime Minister.

notes: These elections were for the Chamber of Deputies, which determines the Prime Minister.This election campaign revolved chiefly around the question of education - the Socialists and Liberals advocated priority for the official �free� schools accessible to pupils of any denomination, whereas the Christian Socials demanded increased subsidies for the Roman Catholic schools to ensure equal treatment of both categories. The elections gave the (opposition) Christian Socials a majority in the Senate, though they narrowly failed to obtain an overall majority in the Chamber. However, their gains meant that a Socialist-Liberal government could not be formed without them. Both the Socialists and the Liberals lost seats. M. Van Acker, head of the Socialist-Liberal coalition government which had been in office since 1954, resigned in view of the electoral victory of the Christian Social Party. King Baudouin asked M. Eyskens (the leader of the Christian Social Party) to form a new Government. M. Eyskens' attempts to obtain the support of the Socialists or the Liberals failed; however, and on June 25 he announced the formation of a Government drawn solely from the Christian Social Party.

notes: The three main contenders were the center-right candidate of the UMP Nicholas Sarkozy, the socialist PS candidate Segolene Royal, and to a lesser extent Francois Bayrou (of the center-right UDF). The first round of elections eliminated all the candidates but Sarkozy and Royal. Sarkozy received 31% of the vote in the first round, providing him with a strong core of support with which to enter into the second round of elections. Royal had 25.8% of the vote in the first round.

notes: The first round of a two round election to the French National Assembly. Sarkozy's (who was elected president in May 2007) UMP party was expected to win a majority of the 577 seats in Parliament, as was customary for newly elected presidents. The first round of elections resulted in 98 seats for UMP, and 1 seat for the Socialist Party (PS): the main opposition.

The second round of elections to the French National Assembly. The UMP party of newly elected President Sarkozy received an overall majority (313/577 seats). The UMP received slightly fewer seats than it did in 2002 (355). This is because the PS (Socialist Party) did considerably better at the polls in the second round than had been expected. The PS received a total of 186 seats, compared to the 140 seats it had received in 2002. The second round swing to the PS is attributed in part to the government's confirmation on June 12th that value added tax was increased to finance cuts in pay roll taxes. There was also a lower turnout of UMP voters in the legislative elections than in the presidential elections held in May when Sarkozy beat the PS candidate Royal.
nelda12notes: The UMP party had already received enough votes in the first round of legislative elections to secure a majority.
nelda27notes: The PS party had received 140 votes in the last legislative elections that were held in 2002. This time around it received 186 seats.

his coding is with reference to the lower house, the Nationalrat. A second round was required for the upper house elections, and this second round was held from November 11th - 25th in different Swiss cantons. In these elections, the four-party coalition government was returned to office. The coalition consisted of the senior ruling far-right nationalist Swiss People's Party (which increased its share of the vote from 55 to 62, which was the highest number won by a single party in Switzerland since 1919), the centre-left Social Democratic Party (lost 9 seats), the conservative Radical Democratic Party, and the fourth-placed Christian Democratic People's Party. The opposition as a whole increased their seats from 29 to 33 - in particular, the Green Party increased its seats from 13 to 20.  These elections were dominated by the issue of immigration, and were unusually violent for Swiss elections. Much press attention was given to the leading Swiss People's Party's controversial poster showing three white sheep kicking a black sheep out of Switzerland, which brought sharp criticism from the UN's special rapporteur on racism. This polarizing campaign provoked accusations of racism against the Swiss People's Party and rioting in the capital Bern.
nelda12notes: Competitive elections were predicted, and the uproar against the incumbent far-right Swiss People's Party over their racist posters and harsh anti-immigration campaign tactics had been heated.
nelda17notes: In 2007 GDP Growth was 3.6%, which was considered healthy. Unemployment was low.
nelda24notes: President Calmy-Rey is a member of the Social Democratic Party. Although this party actually lost nine seats in these elections, it was nevertheless the second biggest party and party of the four-party ruling coalition that remained in power after these elections.
nelda26notes: The right-wing incumbent Swiss People's Party dominated opinion polls, in which they were projected at least 27% of the vote.
nelda27notes: for the opposition: the largest party in the incumbent four-party coalition (the Swiss People's Party) increased its share of the vote by 9 seats, winning them largely from its other coalition member parties.
nelda29notes: In an outburst that was very rare for Switzerland, and made international headlines - riots shook the capital of Berne two weeks prior to the elections. Left-wing protestors hurled petrol bombs and set fire to cars in a protest against a Swiss People's Party (incumbent, far right-wing party) election rally. The police had to use tear gas, water cannon, and rubber bullets to disperse the protesters. This outburst was thought to be the bubbling over of frustration at the tense campaign, in which anti-immigrant posters of the Swiss People's Party, depicting a white sheep kicking a black sheep out of Switzerland, had been condemned as racist by the UN.
nelda31notes: In the riots prior to these elections, police used tear gas and rubber bullets against the protesters.
nelda34notes: Results were favorable to the incumbent because her party remained in the ruling coalition. In fact however, her party lost votes.
nelda43notes: Note that the Swiss President is not in fact the Head of State of the country: the Swiss Federal Constitution knows neither a Head of State nor a Head of Government. Both of these functions are administered by the Federal Council collectively, and President of this Council is elected for a one year term, rotating between Council members.

nelda18notes: Not necessariy, but the economy is not as good as it was prior to 2008. The sovereign debt crises currently unfolding in neighboring euro-zone countries pose a significant risk to Switzerland's financial stability and are driving up demand for the Swiss franc by investors seeking a safehaven currency. The independent SNB has upheld its zero-interest rate policy and conducted major market interventions to prevent further appreciation of the Swiss franc, but parliamentarians have urged it to do more to weaken the currency. The franc's strength has made Swiss exports less competitive and weakened the country's growth outlook; GDP growth fell to 2.1% in 2011.

nelda1notes: Before the elections, Spain was ruled by the dictator Franco. After he died in 1975, King Juan Carlos appointed Adolfo Suarez Premier.
nelda2notes: First freely contested election since 1936.
nelda3notes: Political parties were allowed after the passage of the Political Reform Act of 1976.  Electoral law, however, favored the ruling Conservatives and Moderates by favoring rural areas.
nelda4notes: 156 political groups in ten national coalitions and 12 regional alliances contested the elections. There were 6,000 candidates.
nelda7notes: The incumbent ran with the newly formed Center-Right UDC party.  Suarez created an electoral law that favored the center-right.
nelda8notes: There were no limits on Suarez's tenure.
nelda10notes: Suarez was the chief executive appointed by the King of Spain.  He did oversee new elections, but he was not tasked with holding them.
nelda11notes: Commentators called it a fair electoral campaign.
nelda12notes: Suarez believed he would win a majority of seats in the houses of Cortes.
nelda15notes: The opposition was allowed to criticize the government and campaign vigorously.
nelda16notes: TV time was allotted equally to all parties.
nelda17notes: Spain was experiencing poor economic growth.
nelda18notes: The 1973 oil crisis created an industrial crisis in Spain that lasted until 1985.
nelda24notes: The UDC only won a plurality, not a broad majority as expected. Many more people voted for the Leftists than had been expected.
nelda27notes: Opposition was seated for the first time.
nelda56notes: Democratization was encouraged by the EC, and it helped further Spain's accession to the EC.
nelda58notes: It was understood that democratization was necessary to gain admission to the EC, which was essential for getting Spain out of the economic crisis.

nelda1notes: First free, regular, and multiparty elections were held in 1977.
nelda3notes: Some 9,000 candidates sought seats.
nelda4notes: There were four major political parties: UCD, the Socialists, the Communist Party, and the Democratic Coalition
nelda5notes: There were 9,000 candidates.
nelda6notes: It was expected that elections would be held after a new constitution was written.
nelda7notes: Suarez ran as head of the UCD, again.
nelda12notes: The election was more heated than in 1977, with economic concerns being more of an issue than before.
nelda17notes: Economic issues were important in this election, with political parties accusing each other of mismanaging the economy.
nelda18notes: The 1973 oil crisis created an industrial crisis in Spain that lasted until 1985.
nelda27notes: The UCD increased its lead by 3, but fell 8 short of a majority. There was little shift in balance of power in the Houses of Cortes.
nelda54notes: While many thought it was important for Spain to join the EC, others were more ambivalent. It took until the mid-1980s for Spain to gain accession to the EC.

nelda4notes: Over 20 political groupings, including 17 coalitions, contested the elections.
nelda5notes: 8,200 candidates competed for 350 seats in the Congress and 208 seats in the Senate.
nelda6notes: Elections did not need to be held until March 1983; however, because the UCD had lost deputies in defections in 1982 and 1981 and had done poorly in regional elections, Suarez caled for early elections.
nelda7notes: Suarez stood as head of his new party, CDS.  The new Prime Minister, Calvo Sotelo, was the new head of the incumbent UCD.
nelda17notes: Economics formed a major issue in the campaign, this time resulting in an opposition win.
nelda18notes: Spain had been in an economic crisis since the oil shock of 1973.  The situation had not improved substantively.
nelda21notes: The head of the UCD, Aldolfo Suarez, left the UCD before the election to form a new political party, the Social and Democratic Centre (CDS). The new Prime Minister (and thus, incumbent) was Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo.
nelda24notes: Both Suarez's party, CDS, and his old party, the ruling UCD, lost the election to the Socialists (PSOE). The ruling UCD came in third place.
nelda26notes: It was widely believed that the ruling UCD was going to do poorly in the elections.
nelda27notes: The Socialist Workers Party (PSOE) won an outright majority (202 of 350 seats) in the lower House and won 134 of 208 seats in the Senate.
nelda33notes: There was significant violence in the Basque region.  Security became an issue in the election campaign.
nelda42notes: There were multiple military coup attempts against the democratic government months before the elections.  This was seen as another failure of the UCD.
nelda52notes: A major issue facing the political parties was the status of US military bases in Spain. There was no indication whether the results of this election and the stance of PSOE affected Spain's relationship with the US.
nelda54notes: Spain became a member of NATO in May 1982.
nelda56notes: Many in Spain readily agreed that accession to the EC was desirable. However, the process was slow.

nelda6notes: The elections were early by four months.  The elections were held early so that the PSOE could capitalize on its big national referendum win on membershp in NATO earlier that year.

nelda12notes: PSOE was expected to win.
nelda17notes: The economic situation of the country was improving.
nelda18notes: Spain was no longer considered to be in an economic crisis.
nelda19notes: Spain benefited from European Community regional aid programs. Spain joined the EC in January 1986.
nelda24notes: PSOE won a reduced but still absolute majority of the Cortes--184 of 350 seats in the lower house and 124 of 208 seats in the upper house.
nelda26notes: PSOE was widely considered to be the front-runner.
nelda27notes: PSOE's lead was reduced somewhat. The opposition remained a minority in parliament.

nelda4notes: 11 parties were seated after the election.
nelda6notes: The election campaign ended early because of the Madrid Train Bombings and Aznar's call for a three-day mourning period.
nelda24notes: Aznar stepped down after two terms as Prime Minister. His successor, Mariano Rajoy, lost the elections bringing an end to eight years of conservative rule. The bombings were a decisive factor in the election.
nelda26notes: Most polls going into the election predicted a PP win. However, the Madrid Bombings changed the political dynamics.
nelda27notes: PSOE won 164 to the incumbent PP's 148 seats in the 350 seats lower house. Larger than expected numbers of voters came out on election day to protest against a percieved PP manipulation of information regarding the Madrid Bombings.
nelda33notes: Four days before the election, Al Qaeda terrorists bombed communter trains and train stations, killing 200 people.  This violence and the PP's blaming ETA (when many didn't believe PP claims) shifted the momentum to PSOE.
nelda51notes: PSOE planned to take Spanish troops out of Iraq.
nelda56notes: PSOE and Zapatero ran on a platform of increased cooperation and ties with the EU.

notes: These elections were for the Congress of Deputies and the Senate. These elections were fought between incumbent Prime Minister Zapatero� of the PSOE and the opposition People�s Party (PP). The elections were complex, with religion, the economy, Zapatero�s terrorist policies with regard to the Basque region, and immigration all at issue. One of the topics of discussion was the liberal nature of the reforms Zapatero had introduced, including the legalization of gay marriage, fast-track divorces, amnesty for illegal immigrants, and a gender equality law. Many of these had met fierce opposition from conservative and religious opinion in Spanish society. Another big issue was the stagnating economy: the bursting of the Spanish housing bubble, the rising unemployment rate and a 12-year peak in the inflation rate had given the PP ample fodder for criticism of Zapatero. The results of the elections showed both the PSOE and the main opposition PP increased their percentage of the vote and their number of seats compared with the 2004 election, at the expense of small leftist and regional parties. Though the PSOE increased their overall share of the vote compared to 2004, they still fell 7 seats short of an overall majority in the lower house. Zapatero formed a minority government.

nelda17notes: One of the main issues of these elections was the sudden slow-down and stagnation of the Spanish economy, the bursting of the Spanish housing bubble, the 12-year high inflation rate, and the rising unemployment rate. This was relative however, as the government predicted 3.1% growth for 2008.

nelda27notes: In the previous (2004) elections, current Prime Minister Zapatero's Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE) became the largest party in the Congress of Deputies, winning 168 seats to the 152 of the then-incumbent People�s Party (PP). The PP, however, remained the largest party in the Senate, with 126 seats to the PSOE�s 96. In these 2008 elections, the incumbent PSOE of Prime Minister Zapatero remained the largest party in the Congress of Deputies, with 169 seats. The main opposition PP won 153. As in 2004, the PP took more seats than the PSOE in the Senate though their lead diminished: the PP�s seats fell from 126 to 101, while the PSOE�s fell from 96 to 89. Thus overall, the election for the PSOE was a gain of one seat in the Congress of Deputies, and a gain on the PP in the Senate.

During the dictatorial Estado Novo regime; opposition candidate Delgado ran (without an official party) against party-backed Tomas, winning 25 % of the vote despite significant fraud; these results caused Salazar to change the electoral process so that the legislature would chooose the president.
Portugal legislative election 11/12/1961, round 1 of 1.
nelda1notes: There were 130 seats in this election, 10 more than in the previous election, added in order to represent overseas territories.

nelda4notes: Though oppostion candidates were allowed to run after being approved by the governmnent, the government's National Union party was the only legal political party.
nelda5notes: After the 53 opposition candidates decided to boycott the election to protest the regime, the unfairness of the election, and the decision to change the presidential elections from direct to indirect, there were only 130 candidates left.
nelda16notes: There were accusations of reporters being harassed or arrested for supporting the opposition.

nelda2notes: However, they were the first since 1928.
nelda4notes: 12 parties fielded candidates.

nelda16notes: There was leftist control of the press.
nelda27notes: Though the military required all parties pledge their support for a military-controlled constitution, moderates and socialists won most of the votes, disappointing the communist MFA movement.
nelda29notes: Anywhere from 40-50,000 socialists marched to support their leader, Soares, who alleged that despite being the largest group in the legislature, the Socialists had no real power.
nelda32notes: Though the socialists won more seats than expected, they had no real power, and so the election was favorable to the incumbent MFA group.
nelda50notes: There was widespread fear that Portugal was going to become a Communist state, and Portugal's threat that the US could no longer use the Azores as a military base for Middle East operations heightened that fear.
nelda52notes: The election of moderates and socialists relieved the US.
nelda54notes: Portugal was a founding member of NATO, though not much of a participant, but NATO at this point feared that Portugal's possible move to communism might lead to Soviet bases in Portugal and its overseas territories.
nelda56notes: The election of moderates and socialists relieved NATO countries.

notes: Portugal presidential elections, 1/22.2006, round 1 of 1.
nelda17notes: Portugal's economy had stagnated.
nelda32notes: Cavaco Silva, a former Prime Minister and member of the Social Democratic Party (PSD), who had previously run for and lost the election for president, became president in this election, beating out the Socialist candidate and former president.

notes: The incumbent Prime Minister Jose Socrates and his party, the centre-left Socialist Party (PS) won the parliamentary elections with a plurality. However, the new government will be considerably more constrained going forward than the outgoing one, as the PS lost its absolute majority. This meant that they would be obliged to govern in a more fragmented and polarized parliament. The main opposition party in parliament and also the incumbent president Anibal Silva's party, the Social Democratic Party (PSD) also suffered a heavy defeat. Thus, overall, the two main centrist parties which had always led the government since the country's democratization in 1974, saw a marked decrease in their share of seats in parliament. Small-party successes both to the right and to the left meant that there was mounting instability within the political sphere. Upon the time of this coding, either a coalition or minority government led by the PS is likely.
nelda16notes: It should be noted that there was a controversy related to the cancelation of a tv program. The  tv program was critical of the PS, and there was a perception that PM Socrates of the PS was influential in the cancelation of the program, even though there wasn't any evidence of this.
nelda20notes: The incumbent here is coded as the president, not the prime minister.
nelda24notes: The incumbent president's PSD party (they are the opposition party in parliament) suffered a defeat, and preformed significantly more weakly than it did in the previous election. They also weren't a member of the government because the PSD decided to rule as a minority government since no other party wanted to join with it in coalition.
nelda26notes: The election was too close to call, but this was favorable to the incumbent because they were in the opposition in parliament, and the opposition party was portrayed favorably.
nelda27notes: It was a vote gain of only 3 votes. The perception of the election was that it was an extremely poor showing, one of the worst, for the PSD.
nelda46notes: Monitors from the OSCE were present.

notes: The presidential election that was held in Portugal on January 23, 2011 resulted in the landslide re-election of incumbent President Anibal Cavaco Silva to a second five-year term. Silva, backed by the main opposition party, the center-right Social Democratic Party (PSD), ran against five other candidates and received 52.95% of the vote, sufficient to avoid a run-off round. The nearest rival to Silva was Manuel Alegre, who was backed by the ruling center-left Socialist Party (PS) and who received 19.76% of the vote. Turn out was exceptionally low in this election (less than 46%), and analysts said this was a reflection of voter disenfranchisement with political leaders. The re-election of Conservative President Silva was seen as a blow to the minority center-left government, led by Prime Minister Jose Socrates of the PS.

Snap elections were held in Portugal on June 5, 2011 when early elections were called in March 2011. Prime Minister Jose Socrates of the ruling center-left Socialist Party (PS) resigned in March because his party failed to secure parliamentary backing for new austerity measures aimed at fending off an international bailout. As a result, a snap election was scheduled for June, and Socrates served as a caretaker Prime Minister in the interim. The main opposition party (and the party of President Silva), the center-right Social Democratic Party (PSD), won the election with 38.66% of the vote and 108 seats. However, the PSD fell short of an absolute majority in the 230-seat legislature. The PS received 28.04% of the vote and 74 seats (23 less seats than it received in the 2009 election). The opposition conservative People's Party (PP) came in third with 11.71% of the vote and 24 seats. The incoming Prime Minister of the PSD is Pedro Passos Coelho, a business man with no prior political experience.
nelda6notes: The elections were held early because the ruling PS failed to secure backing for austerity measures and Prime Minister Socrates resigned in March 2011.
nelda10notes: The country was ruled by caretaker Prime Minister Socrates (who'd previously been Prime Minister), but officially became the caretaker Prime Minister after his resignation in March 2011.
nelda18notes: The economic crisis in Portugal is believed to have manifested itself in this election. The failure of the center-left PS to handle the economic crisis has resulted in a victorious showing for  the more conservative PSD. Conservative parties across Europe have had sweeping victories in the wake of the EU debt crisis.
nelda24notes: The incumbent is President Silva of the PSD. In these early parliamentary elections, the PS was ousted after the resignation of Prime Minister Socrates of the PS, and the elections resulted in a victory (a plurality) for the PSD.
nelda26notes: The polling was favorable toward the incumbent President Silva of the PSD; however, they were unfavorable toward the ruling party in parliament (PS).

notes: This election was characterized by the econmic state of Portugal. Many of the issues that the people were worried about were Portugal's finances. Furthermore, there was a low turnout rate for voting.

The Christian Democrats gained a larger majority over the Social Democrats, but the two stayed in a coalition government (holding about 2/3 of the seats); the success of this coalition was seen as the Germans embracing democracy and Adenauer's policies of reconciliation with the West.
Continued Adenauer's coalition government of the Christian Democrats and Social Democrats.
Adenauer remained chancellor with a coalition of the CDU/CSU-FDP parties; the CDU had the plurality but lost seats to FDP and second largest SDP.
CDU/CSU/FDP coalition kept power after the government.  Though the  CDU and CSU gained seats, the large losses of the FDP made the coalition lose ground. The FDP would leave the coalition in 1966.
SPD won a plurality and left the coalition with the CDU/CSU to form a coalition with FDP. Brandt first SPD chancellor post-WWII.
''SPD lost majority due to defection of members to CDU/CSU. However, early election resulted in increase in votes to ruling coalition.
SDP and FDP kept power of the government, but they lost ground to the CDU/CSU.
SDP and FDP kept power of the government and gained seats.
In 1982 the government coalition changed, with a CDU/CSU/FDP coalition taking power. This coalition remained in power after this early election.
CDU/CSU and the FDP kept control of the government although the coalition lost seats.
First election after the unification of Germany. Ruling CDU/CSU-FDP coalition gained seats, boosted by national euphoria after reunification.
CDU/CSU-FDP coalition kept power but with a reduced majority.
SPD-Green coalition won surprisingly large majority and took power.
Ruling SPD-Green coalition returned though with a decreased number of seats.
CDU/CSU and SPD formed coalition government after gaining in the election.

notes: The first national election since the end of WWII and since the creation of the GDR the previous year; took place under the power of the USSR; the election was denounced universally as a sham for running a single list of candidates and not allowing secret ballots.
nelda51notes: The US openly denounced the elections as undemocratic.

notes: Under Soviet control, the people were only allowed to vote for or against a 'unity list' of the National Front; the vote was not secret and people were marched en masse to the polls, and told they were enemies to the state if they voted against the coalition.

notes: Like the previous elections, the people were only allowed to vote for or against a 'unity list' of the National Front; the vote was not secret and people were marched en masse to the polls, and told they were enemies to the state if they voted against the coalition.

notes: First elections after the end of the World War. Though the US and Britain tried to push for free and fair elections, elections were widely thought to be rigged in Soviet favor.
nelda7notes: Position of incumbent not contested.
nelda10notes: While Poland was supposedly ruled by a Provisional Government, there was no sign that the government - and especially Communist elements - were willing to step down.
nelda11notes: There is evidence that members of the Polish Peasants Party were arrested throughout electoral process; Britain and the US both sent notes accusing Poland of not holding fair elections.
nelda12notes: Elections seemed heavily rigged by the Communists, so it was unlikely that anyone but the Communist-led Democratic bloc win.
nelda15notes: Government arrested members of the Polish Peasants Party and used legal means to eliminate other opposition candidates.
nelda16notes: Communist and Stalinist forces controlled the Polish media for decades.
nelda17notes: This was a period of nationalization, agricultural reform, and central economic planning, but the Polish saw little stimulation of the economy due to this at the time.
nelda19notes: Soviets begain a period of economic reform, but Polish economic recovery was slowed because it did not receive German reparations as promised and was not part of the Marshall Plan.
nelda25notes: No evidence of polls.
nelda27notes: The opposition gained some seats in Parliament, although due to vote fraud, they did not take as many seats as they should have.
nelda28notes: Critical reports from the US and Britain, as well as the Peasants Party leadership, existed but may not have reached the domestic population.
nelda33notes: There were allegations that the Polish Secret Police murdered memebers of the Polish Peasants Party. Murders of several members of the Electoral Commission also occurred.
nelda51notes: The US warned Poland against vote fraud, citing the Potsdam Agreement, so relations further deteriorated after the election, and Poland became a de-facto Soviet satellite.
nelda58notes: Soviets had a large stake in the election.

notes: Implicit threats (i.e. from the USSR) loom ominously but there is a dearth of sources concretely confirming their existence. notes: This one (and the second round) are a bit tricky to code. To my knowledge, Jaruzelski was the �incumbent� as Chairman of the party, a role he held until the Round Table Agreements of early 1989, after which he promised to cede power and hold somewhat democratic elections, meaning that a newly established PM position would be the leader thereafter. So the incumbent�s position was not contested, and he was not �replaced� by the election, strictly speaking. I hope that helps clear up some of the coding.

nelda20notes: Jaruzelski�s position of Chairman of the Council of State - making him the de facto leader - was not contested, while the position of the Prime Minister for instance was.
nelda24notes: The Communist Party, which Jaruzelski did belong to, lost significantly in these elections. While it retained a plurality, it de facto lost control of the government.
nelda39notes: As Prime Minister, yes. Though the post of President was explicitly reserved from the incumbent and the Communist party, meaning that he retained a leadership role.
nelda40notes: In a sense, yes.

nelda58notes: There is the promise of economic aid from the West which is conditional on political reforms and freer elections. Perhaps this influenced the outcome - it probably did - but this link is not made explicitly clear in any sources. It is also questionable whether or not the public knew about the promised aid.

nelda2notes: These were the first free democratic presidential elections in Poland since World War II.
nelda6notes: Direct elections for the president had been added to the system, and these were the first presidential elections, but Parliamentary elections had not been suspended.
nelda7notes: President Wojciech Jaruzelski on Sept. 19 yielded to the demand from the vast majority of Poland's political forces that as an anachronism from the former communist regime he should resign.
nelda18notes: Under a new set of international conditions, the long history of riots and strikes by workers and students, criticism by the intellectual classes, and general lack of cooperation by society with the economic programs of successive communist governments, the economy was in crisis.
nelda19notes: Following Solidarity leader Lech Walesa's visit to the United States in November 1989, the Congress passed the Support for East European Democracy (SEED) Act, which authorized a $928 million assistance program for Poland and Hungary.
nelda26notes: In pre-election polls, Mazowiecki trailed Solidarity chairman Lech Walesa in popularity polls. In the 2nd round elections, Walesa opened up a 3-to-1 margin on Tyminsky, the other runoff candidate.
nelda27notes: Solidarity candidate Walesa led after the 1st round of elections, with 39.96% of the vote and went on to win the runoff round with 74.6% of the vote.
nelda50notes: Official relations between Washington and Warsaw began to improve after the Jaruzelski government's 1986 general amnesty released all political prisoners. By early 1987, the administration of Ronald W. Reagan lifted all economic sanctions.
nelda52notes: After the Round Table Agreement of mid-1989, the United States moved quickly to encourage democratic processes and assist economic reform in Poland. Toward this goal, President Bush initially promised some US$100 million in economic assistance.

nelda1notes: Premature dissolution.

nelda18notes: Inflation was running at an annual rate of more than 70 percent and unemployment was above 10 percent.

nelda24notes: Solidarity emerged with only 11 seats in the Senate and 27 seats in the National Assembly while the communisty party's successor party, the Democratic Left Alliance, took 60 seats in the National Assembly to the Democratic Union's 62.
nelda26notes: In pre-election polls, the greatest support was for the Democratic Union party, Solidarity came second, followed by former communists in the Democratic Left Alliance.
nelda27notes: In the Senate, the Democratic Union took 21 of the 100 seats (the most of any party) and won 62 seats in the National Assembly (also the most of any party). The communisty party successor, the Democratic Left Alliance, took 60 seats in the National  Assembly.
nelda46notes: A 10-member team from the Council of Europe observed the elections.
nelda47notes: The Council of Europe's Parliamentary Assembly delegation announced that the polling had taken place in an entirely fair environment.
nelda56notes: Following the Oct. 1991 elections, Poland was admitted into the Council of Europe in November of 1991.

nelda17notes: Unemployment and inflation remained high, although the economy was not in a crisis state.

nelda26notes: Pre-election polls showed the Alliance of the Democratic Left (SLD) and the Polish Peasants' Party (PSL) clearly ahead of Prime Minister Hanna Suchocka's Democratic Union.
nelda27notes: The Democratic Left Alliance (SLD) and the Polish Peasant Party (PSL), both with roots in the party structure of the former communist regime, emerged as the principal victors, winning respectively 20.4 per cent and 15.4 per cent of the vote.

nelda12notes: The election was forecast as a neck-and-neck race between incumbent Walesa and the reformed communist Kwasniewski.
nelda26notes: Election opinion polls showed Kwasniewski, a former Communist Party minister for youth and sport, leading with some 23 per cent, compared with 14 per cent for incumbent President Lech Walesa and 12 per cent for Hanna Gronkiewicz-Waltz.
nelda27notes: The leader of the ruling Democratic Left Alliance (SLD), Aleksander Kwasniewski, a former communist who had held ministerial office in 1985-89, defeated the incumbent, Lech Walesa, in the second round of the presidential election on Nov. 19.

nelda17notes: Poland's economy was referred to by one commentator as Eastern Europe's most dynamic economy. At the time, Poland's economy was growing 6 per cent a year, the fastest in Europe. Privatization of formerly state industries was forging ahead.
