nelda27notes: The Solidarity Electoral Action party emerged with 33.8% of the vote, giving it 51 seats in the 100-seat Senate and 201 seats in the 460-seat National Assembly.

nelda12notes: Kwasniewski, the incumbent, was favored to win in pre-election polling.
nelda24notes: Incumbent President Aleksandr Kwasniewski was easily re-elected on Oct. 8.��He gained the support of 53.92 per cent of the electorate, compared with 17.3 per cent for his closest challenger.

nelda12notes: Polls predicted a landslide victory for the opposition Democratic Left Alliance.

notes: The parliamentary elections that were held in Poland on October 9, 2011 resulted in Prime Minister Donald Tusk's ruling Citizens' Platform (PO) party returning to power with 39.18% of the vote and two less seats. The main opposition conservative Law and Justice Party (PiS) came in second with 29.89% of the vote and nine less seats. And the junior coalition Polish Peasants' Party (PSL) came in fourth with 8.36%. Thus, the ruling coalition retained its majority with 235 out of 460 seats in the Sejm. The Palikot Movement (Ruch Palikota-RP) came in third in the elections with 10.02% of the vote. This was a new liberal center-left party that was started by former PO legislator, and it made inroads, particularly among younger voters, for its willingness to support same-sex marriage, legalization of abortion, and the legalization of marijuana.
nelda46notes: The OSCE deployed an Election Assessment Mission (EAM) to Poland to observe the October 9th election.

notes: The Direction-Social Democracy (Smer)  party of the incumbent Prime Minister Robert Fico won a plurality. The new government consisted of a coalition led by the Slovak Democratic and Christian Union- Democratic Party's Iveta Radicova (the new Prime Minister) and included KDH, SaS and Most-Hid. Smer increased its seat share by 12, for a total of 62, but the incumbent Prime Minister's coalition partners in the People's Party-Movement for a Democratic Slovakia lost all 15 of their seats and the Slovak National Party barely passed the 5% vote threshold required for parliamentary representation, while losing 11 of their 20 seats.
nelda12notes: Polls prior to the election indicated support for the incumbent party, but falling support for its coalition partners. Polls also foresaw that the incumbent would have a hard time forming a coalition if he received a plurality.
nelda18notes: The country itself is not said to be in crisis, although there are emerging signs that countries such as Greece could be going into recession at this point, thus impacting Slovakia because it also uses the Euro as its currency. Nevertheless, there is no perception of crisis in Slovakia, at least not relative to recent years.
nelda19notes: Slovakia receives EU aid.
nelda24notes: Even though the incumbent party won a plurality (its coalition members faced devastating defeats), the opposition coalition has more seats in parliament. The perception was that the incumbent party lost, especially because newly elected members did not want to form a government with incumbent Prime Minister Fico.
nelda27notes: Despite the fact that the incumbent party received the largest number of votes, it only had a plurality. An opposition coalition of four parties had more votes (79) overall than the single incumbent party (who's coalition partners suffered major defeats). Therefore, the newly formed opposition coalition made up the new government and position of Prime Minister.
nelda40notes: The newly formed coalition made up of opposition parties meant that the new Prime Minister was a member of the coalition party; thereby ousting the incumbent Prime Minister, despite the fact that his party received a plurality.

notes: Early elections were held in Slovakia on March 10, 2012 because of a vote of no confidence in Prime Minister Radovica. The center-right coalition government fractured in October 2011 over legislation to expand a stability fund meant to contain the European debt crisis. Former Prime Minister Robert Fico of the Smer-Social Democracy Party (Smer-SD) agreed to supply the votes needed to pass the legislation if early elections were to be held. These elections saw the return of Smer-SD with a win of 83 out of 150 seats in parliament, and the return of Fico as Prime Miinster. Incumbent Prime Minister Radovica's Slovak Democratic and Christian Union-Democratic Party (SDKU-DS) won 11 seats total, with a loss of 17 seats total in parliament. The Christian Democratic Movement (KDH) and Ordinary People and Independent Personalities parties won 16 seats each in parliament. The Smer-SD pledged to maintain a welfare state, increase the corporate tax, and raise income taxes for the highest earners. The Smer-SD became the first party to govern on its own since the country split from Czechoslovakia in 1993.
nelda6notes: These elections were held early because of a vote of no confidence in parliament for Prime Minister Iveta Radicova of the Slovak Democratic and Christian Union-Democratic Party (SDKU-DS).
nelda7notes: Early elections were held after the coalition of the center-right government of Prime Minister Radicova broke up in October 2011 over legislation to expand a stability fund meant to contain the European debt crisis, eventually culminating in a vote of no confidence for Prime Minister Radicova.
nelda10notes: A caretaker government has been led by Prime Minister Iveta Radicova of the SDKU-DS since a vote of confidence took place against her, following the fracturing of the ruling coalition in October 2011.
nelda12notes: The elections were held almost two years early after the ruling center-right coalition fractured.
nelda18notes: Slovakia has been weathering the EU debt crisis relatively well, largely because of high export rates.
nelda27notes: The main opposition party (Smer-SD) overwhelmingly won the parliamentary elections, becoming the first party to rule without a coalition since Slovakia split from Czechoslovakia in 1993.
nelda45notes: The OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights sent a Needs Assessment Mission (NAM) to Slovakia in January 2012, and determined that it was not necessary to send observers for election-related activity for the early 2012 parliamentary elections.

notes: These general elections for a new Chamber of Deputies were held in conjunction with elections for a new Senate � this coding refers to the Chamber of Deputies. The incumbent coalition was Prime Minister Fanfani�s Christian Democrats, the Socialists, the Social Democrats, and the Republicans. These elections saw the Christian Democrats lose votes, and the Leftist opposition Liberals and Communists gain substantially. After a five-week political crisis Signor Giovanni Leone, the president of the Chamber of Deputies, succeeded on June 21 in forming a minority Cabinet drawn solely from the Christian Democratic Party. The principal electoral issue was the continuance in office or otherwise of the Centre-Left coalition.
nelda12notes: In that Fanfani was not sure that his Centre-left coalition would survive. The Christian Democrats as a whole were quite confident, however.
nelda17notes: The 1950s and 1960s had seen Italy maintain a healthy and robust economy, which President Kennedy had even praised.
nelda24notes: Though the Christian Democrats lost seats, they ultimately retained their hold on power - moving from coalition to minority government.
nelda27notes: The Christian Democrats, while remaining the largest party in the new Chamber of Deputies, lost 13 seats; their overall position was less favourable than in any of the three previous general elections since the establishment of the Italian Republic. Of their allies in the Centre-Left coalition, the Social Democratic Party gained 11 seats, while the small Republican Party remained static. The position of the Socialist Party remained virtually unchanged, with a gain of three seats. Of the parties not represented in the Centre-Left coalition, the biggest gains were made by the Communists and the Liberals: the Communist Party, with a gain of 26 seats in the Chamber, polled more than one-quarter of the total votes.The Liberals more than doubled their representation by gaining 22 seats.
nelda32notes: Results did not favour Prime Minister Fanfani as he ultimately stepped down, though his party remained in power, hence here we are coding as if results did not favor the incumbent.
nelda40notes: Fanfani's centre-left coalition had lost, so even though his party maintained the prime ministership, his government had been censured by the vote.

notes: These general elections for a new Chamber of Deputies were held in conjunction with elections for a new Senate � this coding refers to the Chamber of Deputies. The results of these elections were much like the results of the last elections. Before these elections, the incumbent government was led by Christian Democrat Prime Minister Moro. The incumbent Centre-Left coalition in power before these elections was comprised of the Christian Democrats (DC), Republicans (PRI), and the United Socialist Party (PSU). An economic crisis of 1964 had been tamed by extensive structural reforms.  The main issue in this calm election was whether the centre-left coalition would continue. The results of the election were mixed � the opposition Rightist parties were weakened, but the opposition Leftist parties (the Communists and the PSIUP) gained substantial number of seats. As a result of this surge in popularity of the Leftist opposition parties, the United Socialists who were part of the incumbent centre-left coalition decided that their voters thought that they had made too many concessions in the coalition, and so decided to leave the ruling coalition (despite the fact that it could have stayed in power with them). As a result, Senator Leone of the Christian Democrats formed a minority Christian Democratic government.
nelda6notes: They occurred at the end of the 5 year mandate since the previous elections.

nelda27notes: The opposition rightists actually lost seats, but the opposition leftists gained seats, and this was why the ruling coalition crumbled, as the United Socialists lost confidence for their involvement with the coalition.
nelda32notes: Results favored the incumbent's party, but not the coalitoin that he was personally in charge of, thus PM changed.
nelda40notes: The gain in votes for Socialist Parties meant that Moro's Centre-Left coalition lost its incumbent position, and Leone (a Christian Democrat like Moro) took over the new Christian Democrat minority government.

notes: These general elections for a new Chamber of Deputies were held in conjunction with elections for a new Senate � this coding refers to the Chamber of Deputies. These elections were 16 months early, precipitated by the dissolution of the incumbent centre-left coalition, which had broken down partially over differing views on divorce legislation. The four parties of the outgoing centre-left coalition � Christian Democrats, Social Democrats, Socialists, and Republicans � no longer presented joint lists or a common programme, but ran separately. The results for these elections showed only very little change � the Christian Democrats retained their 38% of the votes, and the main opposition Communist Party retained the same 27%. The other radical Left parties lost votes, while the extreme right doubled their representation to the 8.7%. The outcome was a more centrist coalition government than the previous one (the Socialists were replaced by the Liberals), though Prime Minister Christian Democrat Giulio Andreotti retained the premiership.
nelda6notes: These elections were 16 months early, precipitated by the dissolution of the incumbent centre-left coalition, which had broken down partially over differing views on divorce legislation.
nelda17notes: The OECD had noted that Italy, like Britain, was lagging behind the growth of other Western European nations, and in 1972 had yet to recover from the global economic strife of the early 1970s.
nelda20notes: Prime Minister is determined by the leading party in the two houses of Parliament, as per these elections.
nelda27notes: Leftist opposition lost votes, Rightist opposition gained voted. The election results were generally thought to show the stability of the status quo.
nelda39notes: Note that the incumbent coalition changed, but Andreotti retained his leadership of the Christian Democrats.

notes: in the Chamber of Deputies. Christian Democrat Giulio Andreotti was designated as Prime Minister (replacing Moro, a fellow Christian Democrat), and the Christian Democrats were left running a minority government.
nelda6notes: These early elections were precipitated by a political crisis in which the minority Christian Democratic Government of PM Moro resigned, after the Socialist group in parliament refused to support them. Mounting inflation and unemployment together with social problems intensified the crisis.
nelda12notes: For the first time in 30 years, it was thought that the Christian Democrats might lose their ownership of the Prime Minister's seat.
nelda18notes: It had precipitated these elections. Unemployment refused to come down, and the Lira had just undergone a massive devaluation. Since January 1976 the Lira has fallen in value by 33 per cent (the same as the � over the past five years); food prices rocketed by 7 percent in March and April and unemployment had reached 1,300,000.
nelda27notes: The Communist vote ballooned, but notably, not by enough to overtake the Christian Democrats as the biggest party in Parliament.
nelda34notes: Note that results were favorable because the Christian Democrats managed to remain the biggest party in Parliament, though they allowed the Communists to rule the Chamber of Deputies.
nelda40notes: The Christian Democrats retained their voting strength as the largest party in parliament and also retained the premiership. But the surge in Communist votes meantthat they had to compromise by promising they would abstain from voting in the Chamber of Deputies, so that the Communists ruled the lower body of parliament while the Christian Democrats ruled the Senate and led a minority government. Hence Moro handed over the PM position to Andreotti, and went on that year to become President of the Christian Democrats and highly influential in Italian politics.
nelda58notes: Though the EEC and NATO looked at these elections with interest - if the Communists had won, Italy's alignment may have shifted.

notes: These general elections for a new Chamber of Deputies were held in conjunction with elections for a new Senate � this coding refers to the Chamber of Deputies. These early elections (two years ahead of schedule) were precipitated by the withdrawal of the Communist Party (PCI) support for the minority Christian Democratic Government of Prime Minister Andreotti, which resigned as a result. A new coalition comprising the Christian Democrats, Social Democrats and Republicans, fell after losing a vote of confidence in the Senate. The electoral campaign revolved around domestic issues ranging from the economy to communist Red Brigade terrorism � the Red Brigade had shocked the country by kidnapping and murdering Christian Democrat President and ex-Prime Minister Moro the year previous to these elections. As a result of the terrorism they were loosely associated with, the Communist Party lost votes for the first time since World War II. The Christian Democrats remained stable in their position as largest party, and the main gainers were small centre groups and the civil-rights conscious Radical Party. The Socialist Party, the country's third largest, improved its share of the votes. The resultant coalition was the Christian Democrats, some Social Democrats and the Liberals, and was led by Prime Minister Francesco Cossiga (Christian Democrat).
nelda6notes: The Communists withdrew support from the Christian Democrat minority government, causing a parliamentary crisis in which no party was strong enough to rule, hence these elections were called.
nelda12notes: For the first time in 30 years, it was thought that the Christian Democrats might lose their ownership of the Prime Minister's seat.
nelda21notes: Due to criticism over the way he had handled negotiations with the terrorists during ex-Prime Minister Moro's kidnapping (he refused to compromise and Moro was killed) and the way he had lost trust from the Communists supporting his government, Andreotti did not hold political office for years after this.
nelda22notes: Another Christian Democrat leader was to take over the lead of the party in government.
nelda27notes: The Communists, the main opposition, lost more substantially than they had since WW2.
nelda33notes: organizations. Also, the terrorist activities of the red Brigade the year before were thought to explain the weak voting strength of the Communists this year. PM Andreotti announced during the election lead-up that the Army would provide added protection against terrorism during the electoral campaign, but this prompted a Red Brigades attack on the Rome headquarters of the DC party on May 3  - one among many. Other terrorist attacks include the shooting of a professor in front of his students, the bombing of the entrance to Rome's Regina Coeli prison, a series of bombings in Perugia against a police station and DC premises.

notes: These elections occurred a year before the constitutional expiry of the five-year parliamentary term, and are for the Chamber of Deputies (Senate elections are held concurrently and reflect the same trends). These early elections were called when the Socialist Party withdrew from the incumbent four-party coalition led by Prime Minister Fanfani (Christian Democratic). Campaign debate focused on the outgoing Government's austerity measures to combat economic problems such as inflation and unemployment, as well as on the personalities of the various party leaders. The results of the elections rocked Italy � the Christian Democrats lost nearly 6% of the vote it had obtained in 1979, and for the first time in decades did not hold the Prime Minister�s position in the incoming government. Corruption charges and and ailing economy were cited as explanatory reasons. Unusually, the main opposition party (the Communists) also lost its seats in parliament decrease slightly. The gains were made by smaller rightist and centrist groups, and by the Socialist Party. Following several weeks of negotiations, Socialist leader Bettino Craxi was made Prime Minister as head of a five-party centre-left coalition (Christian Democrats, Socialists, Republicans, Liberals and Social Democrats). This was the first time a Socialist would be Italian Prime Minister.
nelda6notes: They were early - these elections occurred a year before the constitutional expiry of the five-year parliamentary term. The elections were called after the withdrawal of the Socialists from the four-party coalition, comprising Christian Democrats, Social Democrats, Liberals and the Socialists.
nelda11notes: From the government coalition, several Christian Democrats, several Social Democrats and one Socialist were reportedly among nearly 900 people in the Naples area sought by police in a round-up of the Camorra (the local Mafia). Criminal association and Mafia links, bribery, and corruption charges were hurled against the government in these elections.
nelda12notes: Though note that the Christian Democrats are confident of being in a governing coalition - it is their ownership of the PM position that was up for grabs.
nelda14notes: The Radicals, who said initially that they would not take part in the elections, later announced that they were campaigning in favour of blank or invalid ballots.
nelda17notes: The deficit was 15% of GDP at this point.
nelda24notes: Though they were still the largest party in Parliament, the loss of a considerable number of seats meant that the Christian Democrats lost the Prime Minister's position.
nelda26notes: The contrary results shocked Italy.
nelda27notes: The Christian Democrats suffered a serious setback, experiencing a drop of over five percentage points in its share of the vote and remaining only three percentage points ahead of its closest rival, the Communists, who also received fewer votes than in the last elections. The Socialists, the Republicans and the neo-facist Italian Social Movement all increased their vote in comparison with 1979. Because the Socialists had withdrawn from incumbent government before these elections, and they made significant gains, this is considered as a gain for the opposition.
nelda33notes: There was considerable scandal surrounding these electons though. Seven Socialists were arrested in mid-June on various charges, including criminal association, bribery and corruption. Additionally, several Christian Democrats, several Social Democrats and one Socialist were reportedly among nearly 900 people in the Naples area sought by police in a round-up of the Camorra (the local Mafia).
nelda40notes: Note that the Socialists didn't beat the Christian Democrats - incumbent was replaced due to relative gains/losses.
nelda50notes: Though the US had long found a reliable friend in the outgoing Christian Democrats, Craxi (a socialist) did not worry them at all - Crax was a firm supporter of the North Atlantic alliance's position that the United States should install medium-range missiles in Western Europe unless the Soviet Union dismantles its missiles already targeted on that area.
nelda54notes: Upon election, Craxi pledged Italy's determination to proceed with the installation of cruise missiles at Comiso (Sicily), in accordance with the 1979 �two-track� decision of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

notes: These elections are for the Chamber of Deputies, note that the Senate elections are held concurrently. After Christian Democrat and Prime Minister Fanfani�s attempted government lost a vote of confidence, early elections were called. The election campaign did not revolve around any particular issues, but more so around the personalities of Socialist Craxi and Christian Democrat Ciriaco De Mita. Craxi defended his record in office (especially in the economic sector) while DC emphasized its ties to the Roman Catholic Church and support for traditional family values. Results produced gains for the incumbent Christian Democrats AND the opposition Socialists, but loses for the opposition Communists. A new centre-right coalition (including the Christian Democrats, the Socialist Party (PSI), the Social Democrat Party (PSDI), the Liberal Party (PLI) and the Republican Party (PRI)) was formed, headed by Prime Minister Giovanni Goria.
nelda17notes: Craxi's government (before Fanfani's short-lived coalition) had reduced inflation and made Italy a leading industrial country. An OECD report commended Italy's overall economic performance, noting that it had the highest annual growth rate of all the OECD countries (2.7 per cent), that inflation had been reduced to 4.2 per cent in 1986 (from 14 per cent in 1984), and that the current account showed a surplus of US$4,600 million in 1986.
nelda22notes: Goria was the Christian Democrat designee for PM rather than Fanfani.
nelda26notes: Not Fanfani personally, but the Christian Democrats generally.
nelda27notes: The Christian Democrats gained in these elections.

notes: The four-party (Christian Democrat, Socialist Unity Party, Social Democrat Party and Liberal Party) incumbent coalition was primarily challenged by the Democratic Party of the Left (PDS - the former Communist Party and the newly founded Communist Refoundation Party. Following an unusually calm and lackluster campaign, polling results were very shocking. The DC-PSU-PSDI-PLI alliance secured less than 50% of the total vote for the Chamber and narrowly retained its majority in the Senate. The centrist Christian Democrats managed to remain the largest single party but its share of the vote fell to an all-time low. On the contrary, the regionally-based Northern League was the biggest gainer. This generally inconclusive result produced the same four-party coalition as before, headed by Prime Minister Giuliano Amato (of the Socialist Unity Party). Hence though the outgoing and incoming coalition stayed the same, the incumbent Prime Minister actually changed.
nelda6notes: Admittedly, these elections were approximately two months earlier than constitutionally due, though this was not particularly significant - the last government had had the longest uninterrupted parliamentary term in years, which observers credited to a large extent to the political skills of Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti.

notes: These elections are for the Chamber of Deputies, note that the Senate elections are held concurrently. Following an early dissolution of parliament and new electoral laws which essentially neccesitated the formation of coalitions in the election campaign, three main opposing alliances contested these elections: the right-wing Freedom Alliance (consisting chiefly of Berlusconi's Forza Italia, the Northern League (LN) and the National Alliance), the centrist Pact for Italy, and the left-wing Progressive Alliance. One of the main issues in these elections was the plague of political corruption scandals that had emerged recently, and the campaigns were marred by allegations of Mafia-ties and bribery. The results of these elections were a big change for Italy: the centrist parties that had dominated Italian government since World War II lost out to Berlusconi's Freedom Alliance. Berlusconi secured an absolute majority in the Chamber of Deputies, and was made Prime Minister. Note that the incumbent government under Prime Minister Ciampi was a technical government, so essentially all parties were in opposition.

notes: These elections are for the Chamber of Deputies, note that the Senate elections are held concurrently. This was only the fifth government since World War II to complete its full five-year mandate. Outgoing Prime Minister Amato of the Olive Brance coalition did not stand for re-election, though did run for a Senate position. Berlusconi, the leader of the right-wing coalition the House of Freedoms, caused controversy over the undue political advantage his dominant position in Italy's communications industry gave him. Studies before the election revealed that his networks gave him considerably more attention than they did to Olive Tree leader Francesco Rutelli. There was criticism in Europe, during the electoral campaign, over the media magnate's vast business interests and the numerous criminal charges brought against him, including tax fraud, bribery and illegal party funding, which he denied. Notably, there were many technical difficulties on the day involving polling stations. Authorities blamed complex ballots and a reduction in the number of polling places in an effort to save money. Berlusconi�s House of Freedoms coalition won 366 seats in the House of Representatives compared to the outgoing Olive Tree coalition�s 242.

There was criticism in Europe, during the electoral campaign, over the media magnate's vast business interests and the numerous criminal charges brought against him, including tax fraud, bribery and illegal party funding, which he denied.

Authorities blamed complex ballots and a reduction in the number of polling places in an effort to save money. Voting was officially prolonged for an hour on the polling day by order of the outgoing Interior Minister, but even this measure was not enough to enable everyone who turned up at polling stations to cast a valid ballot.

notes: These elections are for the Chamber of Deputies, note that the Senate elections are held concurrently. The political environment in the run-up to elections was sharply divided between a center-right coalition �The House of Freedoms�, and a center-left coalition �The Union�, and between their leaders, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi and former Prime Minister Romano Prodi. The two blocs - left vs right - were highly polarized. The economy and the presence of Italian troops in Iraq were the main issues on the agenda during the election campaign. Prime Minister Berlusconi had pledged a stronger economy under his leadership. However, the GDP growth rate stagnated at 0.8 per cent per year and youth unemployment remained high. During the election campaign, he promised to abolish property tax, while his rival Mr. Prodi promised to boost the economy by reducing labour costs and the country's deficit. Both leaders pledged to withdraw Italy's troops from Iraq by the end of 2006. Allegations of corruption and bribery relating to the Prime Minister's private business interests formed a backdrop to the campaign. After a very heated election period, Prodi was declared winner by the tiny 0.1%. Berlusconi refused to acknowledge his defeat, but the Olive Tree coalition replaced the House of Freedoms as incumbent coalition.
nelda11notes: Berlusconi's media hegemony, shady history of fraud and corruption, and hooliganism had many of the opposition concerned about the legitimacy of the elections.
nelda16notes: The broad-cast media was thought to be under the influence of Berlusconi (he was the richest man in italy due to his ownership of various private national media stations), and the opposition was very vocal about the need to scrutinize the lead-up to the elections. Hence the OSCE election monitors. The media environment in Italy was largely characterized by the fact that the Prime Minister had a controlling interest in three major nationwide commercial television networks and had a degree of control over the public television outlets by virtue of his office.
nelda17notes: Italy was the only European country in which there was an almost-zero rate of growth in economy, andit had one of the highest debts in the whole EU. Much criticism was launched at Berlusconi's economic policies.
nelda26notes: All opinion polls predicted a strong win for Prodi - apart from the papers owned by Berlusconi.
nelda28notes: Dark rumours surfaced on the left about the unexpectedly strong performance of Silvio Berlusconi's coalition, which confounded all the polls except those commissioned by Berlusconi himself. While the Left pointed out that the traditional three million spoilt or blank ballot papers fell by some two million in 2006 and the only beneficiary of this increase in votes had been Forza Italia, Berlusconi's party, Berlusconi refused to acknowledge that Prodi had defeated him when the votes had finally been counted, claiming fraud.
nelda30notes: There were allegations of vote fraud, but they didn't precipitate riots.
nelda40notes: Note that Berlusconi never actually publically admitted that he had lost to Prodi!
nelda51notes: Prodi, unlike Berlusconi, was against the war in Iraq, and withdrew Italian troops from Bush's campaign.
nelda56notes: Prodi was considerably more welcome in the EU than Berlusconi, who had caused various issues over his highly publicized and often controversial antics. As Italy's prime minister, Prodi conducted a eurocentric foreign policy, and supported efforts to revive the EU constitution which foundered after referendum defeats in France and The Netherlands. European leaders including E.C. President Jose Manuel Barroso welcomed Prodi even before his formal confirmation as Italy's next prime minister.

notes: The first post-independence Maltese elections are held in relative stability and produce two significant events, the first being that PM Borg Olivier is re-elected and continues in power. notes: An election which marked a peculiar occurrence: the NP won the most first-place votes, but nonetheless received a minority of seats. Mintoff continued as PM, yet had to deal with political strife, protests and resignations in Parliament, and numerous riots.

These elections were to the unicameral National Assembly of Serbia, and were the first elections since Montenegro seceded. These elections were called when the liberal G17+ party withdrew from the ruling coalition, a move prompted when the government failed to arrest Ratko Mladic, the fugitive Bosnian Serb army commander charged with genocide. The main issues under scrutiny in these elections were the economy, the fight against corruption, accession to the EU and the future status of Kosovo. In these elections, the extreme nationalist SRS emerged as the largest party, with 81 seats.  The DS of President Tadic won 64 seats, the Democratic Party of Serbia and New Serbia DSS-NS coalition won 47 seats, the G17+ won 19 seats, and the Socialist Party won 16. Following lengthy negotiations, the DS and the DSS reached a new coalition deal, and with the NS and the G17+ formed the new coalition government. Together this pro-European coalition held 130 seats, an increase from the 2003 votes. In the run-up to these elections, EU officials had openly come out in support of the pro-European parties allied to President Tadic (of the DP), calling upon voters to reject the nationalist SRS. EU Enlargement Commissioner Olli Rehn had offered Serbia accelerated progress to EU membership if voters �leave their nationalist past behind� in these elections. Negotiations on Serbia�s accession to the EU had been suspended in May 2006 when the government failed to arrest Mladic, who had been indicted for war crimes by the ICTY.
nelda4notes: 20 parties contested these elections.
nelda6notes: A new Serbian constitution had been approved in October 2006 following the referendum signaling the seccession of Montenegro, and President Boris Tadic had called early elections shortly after. In particular, these elections were called when the liberal G17+ party withdrew from the ruling coalition, a move prompted when the government failed to arrest Gen. Ratko Mladic, the fugitive Bosnian Serb army commander charged with genocide.
nelda19notes: The US had recently cut off aid to Serbia, and the EU had paused talks on accession, as the government had failed to arrest war criminal Mladic.
nelda24notes: The incumbent's party - the Democrat Party, DS - had won 37 seats in the 2003 elections and was not included in the ruling coaltion. In these elections; however, Tadic's DS Party won 64 seats, and formed the ruling coalition with other pro-European parties.
nelda27notes: In these elections, the SRS again emerged as the largest party, with 81 seats. As in 2003, no party secured an absolute majority. The DS of President Tadic won 64 seats, the DSS-NS coalition won 47 seats, G17+ won 19 seats, and the Socialist Party won 16. Following lengthy negotiations, the DS and the DSS reached a new coalition deal, and with the NS and the G17+ formed the new coalition government. Together this pro-European coalition held 130 seats, an increase from the 2003 votes, though an increase more modest than they had hoped for.
nelda46notes: Some 500 international observers monitored the polls, including monitors from the OSCE.
nelda47notes: and were in line with OSCE commitments and Council of Europe standards.
nelda50notes: Though relations with the US were complicated particularly over the issue of Kosovo, at this point the diplomatic overtures and pro-European, liberal outlook of President Tadic had been adversely affected over the government's failure to arrest war criminal Mladic. Six months previous to these elections, the US had cancelled a $7 million aid package to the Serbian government.

In January, EU Enlargement Commissioner Olli Rehn offered Serbia accelerated progress to EU membership if voters �leave their nationalist past behind� in these elections. Negotiations on Serbia�s accession to the EU had been suspended in May 2006 when the government failed to arrest Mladic, who had been indicted for war crimes by the ICTY.

notes: This election was the first round of the Serbian Presidential elections, which were fought mainly by hard-line nationalist opposition Tomislav Nikolic (SRS) and incumbent, more pro-EU President Tadic (DS). Seven other candidates also contested this election. In this first round, opposition Nikolic won 39.6%, while incumbent Tadic won 35.5%. As neither won the requisite 50%, the election went to a second round. The poll is seen as a key for Serbia's future, with tensions high over Kosovo, the stalling economy, and the road to EU membership. Kosovo was expected to unilaterally declare independence very soon, and so the President�s control of the armed forces was potentially relevant. Main opposition candidate Nikolic had been a supporter of Milosevic, and was currently standing in for the Radical Party's official leader, Vojislav Seselj, who was on trial at the UN war crimes tribunal in The Hague. Though, broadly speaking, both candidates favored membership to the EU and argued that Kosovo should remain in Serbia, Nikolic emphasized friendship with Russia as more important than the EU, while Tadic urged a more speedy accession to the EU and Western market reforms.
nelda17notes: GDP growth was dipping, from 5.4% in 2007 to 3.8% in 2008. The global financial crisis was beginning to take its toll.
nelda20notes: Please note that this coding considers President Tadic (not the Prime Minister), as incumbent - though the Prime Minister is the head of government, the President's symbolic influence and control of the armed forces makes his position the most prominent in media reports and political discussions of Serbia, since the Presidency of Milosevic (whose authoritarian reign strengthened the political position of the President).
nelda24notes: Nikolic won this first round.
nelda26notes: Opinion polls prior to the first round of the presidential elections consistently put Nikolic in front of Tadic.
nelda27notes: In the previous Presidential elections 0f 2004, Tadic and Nikolic also went head to head. In those elections, Nikolic had also won the first round but lost in the second round � though then, he had won the first round by just over 30%, whereas in this first round he won by almost 40% (39.6%).
nelda39notes: As no candidate obtained more than 50% of the vote, a second round was held.
nelda44notes: Note that incumbent did not change because the election went to a second round.
nelda46notes: Observers from the OSCE's ODIHR and from the Council of Europe's Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe (PACE) were present, and declared the elections to have been in line with their standards.
nelda48notes: Serbia's electoral commission barred US and British poll monitors from this election over their support for Kosovo's independence.
nelda50notes: Relations had undergone a sudden freeze over Washington's support for Kosovo's impending independence. Hence no US observers were allowed attend this election.
nelda58notes: The EU and Washington supported Kosovo's impending independence and promised to compensate Serbia for its loss by accelerating the country's path toward EU membership, a proposition shunned by both Presidential candidates, who considered Kosovo integral to Serbia. Nevertheless this offer was looked upon more diplomatically by Tadic, who took EU accession more seriously than Nikolic. Many European politicans came out in support of Tadic's pro-European vision.

notes: This election was the second round of the Serbian Presidential elections, which were fought by hard-line nationalist opposition Tomislav Nikolic (SRS) and incumbent, more pro-EU President Tadic (DS). In this first round, opposition Nikolic had beaten Tadic, but in this second round Tadic won 51% against Nikolic's 47%. The poll was seen as a key for Serbia's future, with tensions high over Kosovo, the stalling economy, and the road to EU membership. Kosovo was expected to unilaterally declare independence very soon, and so the President�s control of the armed forces was potentially relevant. Main opposition candidate Nikolic had been a supporter of Milosevic, and was currently standing in for the Radical Party's official leader, Vojislav Seselj, who was on trial at the UN war crimes tribunal in The Hague. Though, broadly speaking, both candidates favored membership to the EU and argued that Kosovo should remain in Serbia, Nikolic emphasized friendship with Russia as more important than the EU, while Tadic urged a more speedy accession to the EU and Western market reforms. In response to Tadic�s victory, the EU promised to speed up the process of Serbia�s EU integration.
nelda17notes: GDP growth was dipping, from 5.4% in 2007 to 3.8% in 2008. The globaly financial crisis was beginning to take its toll.

nelda24notes: Incumbent Tadic won this second round with 51% of the vote to Nikolic's 47%. Opposition Nikolic had won the first round.

notes: These presidential elections were the first presidential elections (there had been parliamentary elections in 2006) since independence. Incumbent President Vujanovic was a close ally of PM and leader of the ruling Democratic Party of Socialists leader Milo Djukanovic. There were three opposition candidates, Srdjan Milic of the Socialist People�s Party, Andrija Mandic of the Serb List and Nebojsa Medojevic of the Movement for Changes. All candidates campaigned on the basis that membership of the European Union was their main goal.  The opposition candidates attacked Vujanovic and his party for tolerating corruption and organised crime, making it the main topic of discussion of the campaign. Incumbent Vujanovic nevertheless won over fifty percent of the votes in the first round, so a second round was not necessary. The OSCE reported that the elections had been conducted well.

notes: These were Montenegro's second parliamentary elections since independence in 2006. These elections determined incumbent leader, the Prime Minister. In the previous elections of September 2006, the pro-EU-and-NATO Coalition for a European Montenegro (DPS-SDP) led by Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic won 41 seats in the 81-member Parliament. This coalition applied for membership of the European Union in December 2008, and had enjoyed considerable economic growth largely attributed to the tourism industry. However, an economic downturn was expected due to the global recession, a reality which the opposition parties cited as the reason for these snap elections. The opposition was comprised of pro-Serbian parties, the largest of which was the Socialist People's Party (SNP). In these elections, Prime Minister Djukanovic again led the Coalition for a European Montenegro, of which President Filip Vujanovic was also a member. They won, increasing their seats from 41 to 48, and this was seen as public approval of EU membership.
nelda2notes: These were the second parliamentary elections since Montenegro's independence from Serbia in 2006.
nelda4notes: Six coalitions and eight parties contested these elections.
nelda6notes: The approaching economic downturn was potentially another contributing factor to these snap elections, and this is why opposition parties complained of these early elections.
nelda8notes: The position of Prime Minister does not have a term limit.
nelda11notes: Though the local media commented on considerable voter apathy, perhaps denoting a lack of confidence in the political candidates.
nelda17notes: The incumbent coalition was campaigning on Montenegro's admirable recent growth: the country's economy, especially the tourism sector, has grown robustly since 2006 when Montenegro ended its union with Serbia. Montenegro saw an increase in GDP of 10.7% in 2007 and 8% in 2008. However, opposition parties warned that the full effects of the global recession would become more evident later in the year, and the IMF had predicted a drop in growth down to 2%.
nelda20notes: Prime Minister is incumbent - a directly elected President exists, but is secondary to Prime Minister.
nelda24notes: The incumbent Coalition for a European Montenegro won an absolute majority 48 of the 81 seats available, and thus Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic secured a sixth term as the Prime Minister.
nelda26notes: Opinion polls previous to the election indicated that the ruling DPS-SDP would secure a majority of the votes.
nelda27notes: In the previous elections the incumbent coaltion of PM Djukanovic had won 41 seats - in these elections, it won 48. The opposition was notably fragmented.
nelda33notes: It was noted that these elections were more peaceful than the previous elections.
nelda46notes: Over 200 international observers monitored the polls. The OSCE led the international election observation mission.
nelda54notes: Montenegro had recently applied for membership to the EU and NATO. This was the central issue in these elections.

notes: Nikola Gruevski, the prime minister of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, and his VMRO party won early parliamentary elections.
nelda6notes: The SDSM walked out of Parliament in January, protesting a 2010 raid on the offices of a private TV company. The powerful media group led by Velij Aramkovski was targeted officially for tax evasion, but unofficially for being critical of the government given that tax fraud is commonplace in Macedonia. Gruevski dissolved Parliament for early elections in a bid to catch the SDSM by surprise.
nelda18notes: The elections took place in the context of a political crisis but also 30% unemployment and low GDP growth of about 1.8%.
nelda27notes: The VMRO-led coalition won 39.3 percent of the votes, giving it 55 seats in the 123-seat assembly, less than the 63 seats it controlled after the 2008 regular general elections, DPA said.�The opposition Social Democratic Union, known as SDSM, won 33 percent and will have 43 lawmakers in parliament, an increase from 27 seats the party controlled after the 2008 elections.

notes: Fairly straightforward election in which the main issues were economic underperformance and the migrant crisis. Two years prior, Croatia had acceded to the EU, meaning that this took a prominent place in political discourse as well. The process of forming a government following the election proved difficult, as well, as neither victorious candidate was ultimately chosen as PM - rather, an outside businessman formed a coalition government.
nelda18notes: Intertwined with the Euro and migrant crises.

notes: This was the first election after Tito's coalition government was formed.
nelda4notes: Opposition parties, even those ones not under the People's Front, like the Democratic Party, were not banned until after the election.
nelda5notes: Voters were only permitted to vote for or against the single-list of candidates from the Popular Front. The way to vote against the government was through the option of the box without a list.
nelda11notes: Opposition parties ended up resigning in view of the expected unfairness in the elections.
nelda19notes: Yugoslavia was receiving assistance from the UN (mostly material), but not significant amounts of economic aid.
nelda20notes: The legislative elections can lead to a change in Prime Minister, at this point, Tito, who was the incumbent at that time.

notes: This was the first election after the Yugoslav-Soviet split and after the 1946 Constitution.
nelda3notes: Under the electoral reform of January 21, 1950, candidates not approved by the People's Front may stand in any constituency on the condition they obtain 100 voters' signatures.
nelda5notes: Voters were only permitted to vote for or against the single-list of candidates from the Popular Front. The way to vote against the government was through the option of the box without a list.
nelda7notes: Tito's position was only contested as a representative to the People's Assembly.
nelda19notes: Welcoming the Yugoslav-Soviet Drift, the West commenced a flow of economic aid in 1949, which saved the country from hunger in 1950. The first loan from the World Bank of $3 million was given in 1949.
nelda20notes: Tito was Prime Minister at the time, and legislative elections could lead to a change in prime minister, who is considered the incumbent.
nelda21notes: Tito was running as a representative of the People's Assembly.
nelda54notes: The Soviet-Yugoslav split initiated a period of US support for Tito's government.

notes: For the first time in post-war Yugoslavia, there were a number of individual contests. This was the first election with Tito as president of Yugoslavia. This was also the first time a secret vote was conducted in Yugoslavia.
nelda3notes: Voters could choose between balloting for the candidates presented by the Socialistic Alliance of the Working People of Yugoslavia,  or voting against the government, but no opposition political party existed to contest the election.
nelda5notes: There were 299 candidates for 282 seats in the Assembly. The odd 17 candidates were not backed by the Socialist Alliance but were not specifically opposed to it.
nelda6notes: Elections were supposed to be held in March,  but they were delayed until November.
nelda19notes: Yugoslavia received more than $250,000,000 in aid from the US, Britain and France from 1951 to 1954.  It also received a World Bank loan of 30 million dollars.
nelda20notes: Tito was not Prime Minister any more, but president. Nevertheless, the result of this election still affected his position of president, as the Parliament is the body that would later re-elect him as president.
nelda21notes: Even though Tito was already President by then, he ran for representative of the Federal Parliament.
nelda54notes: The World Bank announced in February 1953 that it was making a loan equal to 30 million dollars to Yugoslavia.

notes: The 1953 election was conducted mainly by secret-vote. But in this election, voters marked their ballots in full view of election officials.
nelda3notes: The only party that was legal was the Socialist Alliance of Working People, formerly the People's Front.
nelda5notes: There were 306 candidates for a federal Parliament of 301 deputies. In 5 of the 301 districts, and the voters had a choice between two candidates.
nelda17notes: Yugoslavia had the world's second highest economic growth rate between 1957 and 1960.
nelda20notes: Although his position as president was not directly contested, parliament would later elect him as president, therefore the outcome of this election would have an effect on his office.
nelda21notes: Tito was the unopposed candidate in the Cukarica-Rakovica election district, on the edge of Belgrade.
nelda54notes: The only significant aid being received from the West is an annual wheat loan from the US to make up a local grain deficit.

nelda1notes: A new constitution had been adopted by the federal legislature of Yugoslavia that substantially rearranged the electoral system of the country.

notes: In the first round of election for the Serbian presidency, no candidate achieved an overall majority.
The incumbent won the third round, but the results were cancelled because the voter turn out was below the 50% necessary threshold.
This election was a rerun, but despite having resulted in a victory for the incumbent, the results were cancelled (again) due to poor voter turnout.
Serbian Radical Party candidate Tomislav Nikolic came in first with about 46% of the vote. However, the results were cancelled due to voter apathy; 50% of the voting population threshold was not met.
Defections from the ruling Democratic Opposition of Serbia resulted in the ultra-nationalistic Serbian Radical Party forming a majority.
Nikolic and Tadic advanced into the second round of the presidential election.
Tadic of the Democratic Party won the second round of the election against the ruling Radical Party.

notes: The Tri-Presidential system and legislative system makes the determination of incumbent and opposition extremely complicated. The 2010 elections were held in accordance with the Dayton Agreement of 1995, whereby elections for the House of Representatives are conducted with ethnicity and residence-based limitations to suffrage. Hence this national election was in effect the composite of three federal elections for Bosniaks, Croats and Serbs: the 42 seats are ethnically segmented into three. Citizens who do not identify themselves as Bosniak, Croat or Serb are barred from running for any elections. Generally speaking, parties representing Serbs called for a split of the Republika Srpska from the rest of the country, those representing Croats called for the further division of the country along ethnic lines, while Bosniak parties insisted on greater centralization of the country. These contrasting visions remained the main issues in the 2010 elections. The tripartite presidential incumbents were, Mr. Radmanovic (Serb nationalist and separatist, SNSD) and Mr. Komsic (moderate Croat, SDP), Mr. Silajdzic (Bosniak, SBiH, vehemently against dialogue with the separatist Reublika Srpska). While Mr. Radmanovic�s and Mr. Komsic�s party gained seats, Mr. Silajdzic�s lost seats (from 8 in 2005 to 2 in 2010). These elections were held in conjunction with the tripartite Presidential elections, the incumbents listed above refer to the Presidents pre-election results. At the time of this coding (13 Nov 2011), the government had still not been formed due to political deadlock..
nelda12notes: This is rendered extremely complicated by the fact that there are essentially three mini-legislative elections occurring for Croats, Bosniaks, and Serbs which together comprise this single House of Representatives; voting is ethnically segmented. As a result, there are essentially three sets of incumbent parties, and three sets of opposition parties. Thus while the Bosniak and Croat parties anticipated competitive elections, the Serb incumbent party was quite confident of victory.
nelda17notes: GDP had shrunk by 3.4 per cent in 2009 and the unemployment rate soared to 42 per cent in 2010.
nelda24notes: The tripartite presidential incumbents were, Mr. Radmanovic (Serb nationalist and separatist, SNSD) and Mr. Komsic (moderate Croat, SDP), Mr. Silajdzic (Bosniak, SBiH, vehemently against dialogue with the separatist Reublika Srpska). While Mr. Radmanovic�s and Mr. Komsic�s party gained seats, Mr. Silajdzic�s lost seats (from 8 in 2005 to 2 in 2010).
nelda27notes: There are three sets of incumbents in the three ethnic segments. Though the moderate SDP gained seats from 5 to 8, the nationalist separatist Serbian SNSD and SDS also increased their seats to 8 and 4 respectively. It is difficult to tell whether these elections were a triumph for ethnic nationalists, or moderates. The ethnic breakdown is as follows. Bosniak: In the previous elections held in October 2006, the then Prime Minister Adnan's Terzic Party of Democratic Action (SDA) won nine seats, followed by the Party for Bosnia-Herzegovina (SBiH) with eight.  In 2010, the SDA took 7 seats while SBiH took 2.  Serb: In 2006 the Party of Independent Social Democrats (SNSD) in Serbia took seven seats while the Serb Democratic Party (SDS) took three seats. The SNSD� election campaign demanded for a split of the Republika Srpska from Bosnia Herzegovina. In 2010 SNSD took 8 seats, the SDS took 4. This indicated an increase in nationalist, separatist sentiment in Serbia.  Croat: In 2006 the Croatian Democratic Union-Croatian National Union (HDZ-HNZ) took three seats. The Croatians Together (HDZ 1990), comprising dissidents of the HDZ, took two seats. In the 2010 campaign, the HDZ called for an autonomous region for Croats and was in a partnership with the Serbian SNSD to support each other's calls for greater independence. The 2010 results gave HDZ 3 seats, and HDZ 1990 2 seats (no change from 2006).  Moderate: The Social Democratic Party of Bosnia and Herzegovina (SDP), is the only major party that draws support from all three ethnicities: moderate Bosniaks, Serbs and Croats. The SDP took 5 seats in 2006, and 8 seats in 2010. This potentially implied an advance for moderate parties, but was countered by the gains of Serbian nationalists.

nelda51notes: It is unclear whether nationalist parties advocating for the abandonment of Dayton gained in these elections, however mere days after the elections US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton visited Bosnia Herzegovina, urging for unity and criticizing Serbian separatist parties. She was seen to be pushing for unity in order to accelerate accession to the EU and NATO: She called for reforms to be pursued so that a democratic multi-ethnic state could eventually join the EU and NATO.
nelda58notes: The EU and NATO demand greater national unity and the dissolving of such salient ethnic divisions, if Bosnia Herzegovina is to gain membership. As a result, moderate parties such as the SDP were praised, while as the nationalist SNSD were criticized. Hillary Clinton's post-election visit and the speeches she gave were an example of this.

notes: The Tri-Presidential system makes the determination of incumbent and opposition extremely complicated. The 2010 elections were held in accordance with the Dayton Agreement of 1995, whereby the Presidency rotates between a council of three elected Presidents: a Bosniak, a Serb, and a Croat. There are corresponding ethnicity and residence-based limitations to suffrage. Hence this national election was in effect the composite of three federal elections for Bosniaks, Croats and Serbs. The tripartite presidential incumbents were, Mr. Radmanovic (Serb nationalist and separatist, SNSD) and Mr. Komsic (moderate Croat, SDP), Mr. Silajdzic (Bosniak, SBiH, vehemently against dialogue with the separatist Reublika Srpska). These elections resulted in the defeat of incumbent Bosniak member Haris Silajdzic of the Party for Bosnia-Herzegovina (SBiH) and the election of Bakir Izetbegovic of the Party of Democratic Action (SDA). Izetbegovic was presented as more open to dialogue with the Serb radical nationalists. The other two incumbents, Nebojsa Radmanovic (Serb) of the Alliance of Independent Social Democrats (SNSD) and Zeljko Komsic (Croat) of the Social Democratic Party (SDP), were re-elected. Overall, the results were seen as indicating that established nationalist parties remained dominant. Legislative elections were held concurrently, and seemed to reveal more hope for multi-ethnic parties.
nelda12notes: This is rendered extremely complicated by the fact that there are essentially three mini-presidential elections occurring for Croats, Bosniaks, and Serbs. As a result, there are essentially three incumbents. Thus while the Bosniak incumbent anticipated competitive elections, the Serb and Croat incumbents were quite confident of victory, as they had been leading in opinion polls.

notes: This was a snap election that was held after a vote of no-confidence in the government that brought forward the election.  The PDK party won a plurality with 34.3% of the vote, the LDK won 22.6% of the the vote. The election led to a coalition between LDK and PDK and to the nomination of Hashim Thaci as Prime Minister of Kosovo. Under pressure from Belgrade, some Kosovo Serbs boycotted the vote.  Reports of drugs, weapons, and human organ trafficking linked to Thaci led to a formal re-opening of an investigation by the EULEX mission. Despite these post-election allegations in regards to Prime Minister Thaci, international observers deemed the overall voting process and vote count as free and fair.
nelda1notes: These was the first election since Kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence and the ICJ's advisory opinion on the legality of the declaration.

The northern part of Kosovo where the man was shot was in a Serb-dominated town called Leposavic. Serbs in northern Kosovo reject independence and Belgrade had advised them to not take part in the vote.
