nelda17notes: Despite the economic slowdown in Europe in 2001-03, Slovenia maintained 3% growth. Structural reforms to improve the business environment allow for greater foreign participation in Slovenia's economy and help to lower unemployment. (Theodora)
nelda19notes: In March 2004, Slovenia became the first transition country to graduate from borrower status to donor partner at the World Bank. (CIA Factbook).
nelda26notes: The polls indicated that the election would be a very close call between the LDS (incumbents) and the SDS (opposition).
nelda27notes: �The elections resulted in a defeat for the centre-left Liberal Democracy of Slovenia (LDS), which had ruled as part of a series of coalitions since the first post-independence elections held in December 1992 [see pp. 39240-41; for 1996 electio
nelda54notes: Slovenia on April 3, 2004 became a NATO member, and on 1st May, 2004 became a EU member.

notes: A 7-way first round election for president (PM is head of state) that was won, by a smaller margin than expected, by frontrunner Lojze Peterle, supported by the ruling conservative government. He and Danilo Turk (who would win the second round) advanced.
nelda17notes: It had just joined the eurozone in early 2007
nelda24notes: Peterle was a member of the ruling center-right coalition
nelda27notes: It was expected that Peterle would win the round with a larger percentage.

notes: Turk (an independent supported by left-wing parties) won the second round over Peterle, a member of the ruling government coalition, with about 68% of the vote.
nelda17notes: It had just joined the eurozone in early 2007
nelda26notes: Polls had Turk winning by about 2-to-1 over Peterle

notes: The ruling rightist Slovenian Democratic Party narrowly lost to the leftist Social Democrats, who formed a coalition government with three other leftist groups.
nelda26notes: Polls had the opposition SD ahead
nelda27notes: While the ruling SDS party only lost 1 seat, the Social Democrats increased their seat share from 10 to 29

notes: This was the first early election in Slovenia's history. Zoran Jankovic's new center-left party surprisingly won the election, but 5 right-leaning parties united under ex-PM Jansa of the SDP party and formed a government without Jankovic's party.
nelda6notes: The first early elections in Slovenia's history, it followed a vote of no confidence in Pahor's SD-led government.
nelda12notes: The latest of EU members to hold early elections in the midst of the debt crisis, the ruling party expected to lose the election.
nelda17notes: Slovenia was a victim of the economic crash and debt crisis in the Eurozone.
nelda44notes: Although Jankovic's party narrowly won the election in an unexpected upset, he could not successfully create a majority coalition. Jansa was able to create one with 5 right-leaning parties and became PM, although his party only received the 2nd greatest number of votes.

notes: The first round of the election saw a surprise upset of the independent incumbent, Turk, by Social Democrat Pahor, both of whom moved on to the second round (where Pahor would win). The election took place during a period of economic austerity in which Slovenia worked to avoid needing international assistance.
nelda7notes: The President is largely ceremonial and not the head of state in Slovenia.
nelda26notes: The polls indicated that Turk would win the first round.

notes: The second round of the election the independent incumbent, Turk, lose to Social Democrat Pahor. Pahor won decisively with nearly two-thirds of the vote. The election took place during a period of economic austerity in which Slovenia worked to avoid needing international assistance.
nelda7notes: The President is largely ceremonial and not the head of state in Slovenia.

notes: An odd snap poll in which the incumbent PM calls early elections only for her party to collapse and win only 4 seats. Overall, the election is said to be free and fair, for example by OSCE observers who attend. However, there are reports of vote-tampering and harassment which tend to dominate local media. Other primary issues included management of the economy and relations with the European Union.
nelda6notes: Early

notes: First elections since dictator John Metaxas seized power in 1936.
nelda6notes: First elections after WWII and since 1936.
nelda14notes: All left wing parties, including the E.A.M, decided not to run in the elections claiming that the elections would not be free.
nelda19notes: By the end of 1946, Greece had received around $45 million from the US in financial aid.
nelda20notes: Sophoulis was the prime minister and his office was therefore contested in the parliamentary election.
nelda33notes: Clashes between communists and government forces left 20 people dead on March 31.
nelda39notes: Panayotis Poulitsas became prime minister after the election, heading a coalition cabinet of populist and national bloc leaders. He only served for two weeks, until April 17th, when the Populist Party elected a leader, Constantin Tsaldaris, to take his place as head of the government.
nelda46notes: British, French and American observers were present.
nelda47notes: The Allied Mission reported the election to be �free and fair� and that it represented a �true and valid verdict� of the Greek people.
nelda49notes: Russia declined an invitation to send observers and charged that conditions for free elections did not exist in Greece.
nelda54notes: Greece was living under the protection of Britain. The presence of British troops is said to have given the Right a decisive advantage in the elections.
nelda58notes: Russia wanted the elections to be postponed two months, when conditions would be more favorable for the left; and Britain wanted election to proceed as scheduled' but neither of them made threats in regards to this. It was up to Greece to ultimately decide.

notes: Second elections after WWII, first elections after civil war, caretaker government ruling.
nelda1notes: It was the second post-WWII general election.
nelda2notes: Previous one had been in 1946.
nelda3notes: Communist party illegal.
nelda4notes: The Communist party was illegal because of its rebellious attitude, but the rest were legal.
nelda5notes: 2869 candidates of 44 parties contested 250 seats.
nelda6notes: Elections were initially scheduled for April, then for February and finally for March.
nelda7notes: Theotokis announced on March 3rd his intention, and that of the caretaker government he headed, to resign as soon as soon as the results of the elections were published.
nelda13notes: Communist party was illegal at the time, and communist leaders were prevented from running.
nelda17notes: Greece economy was starting to show signs of recovery, but economic growth was not yet good.
nelda18notes: The economy was expanding, improving and quite rehabilitated; Marshall Plan would end in 1952.
nelda19notes: Greece was still receiving Marshall Plan Aid.
nelda20notes: These parliamentary elections lead to the election of a new prime minister, who is considered the incumbent.
nelda21notes: Theotokis announced on March 3rd his intention, and that of the caretaker government he headed, to resign as soon as soon as the results of the elections were published.
nelda22notes: Theotokis had left the Populist Party in November, and, as head of the caretaker government, he was not associated with any party.
nelda24notes: At the time, Theotokis was no longer associated with the Populist or any other party.
nelda26notes: The incumbent did not run, and he was not associated with any party.
nelda27notes: Moderate left party headed by Plastiras held to a slim lead but fell far short of a majority.
nelda40notes: The vote count gave way to the formation of a coalition government, but Theotokis actually stepped down because he had expressed his intention of resigning as soon as election results were announced, not because of another candidate's victory.
nelda45notes: Unlike the 1946 elections, these were unsupervised by foreign observers.
nelda54notes: Greece was currently receiving Marshall aid and was under the Truman Doctrine.

notes: These general elections were proposed by Premier Venizelos because his minority government was not strong enough to carry the nation through its current trials.
nelda1notes: The last regular elections had taken place on March of that year.
nelda6notes: Under normal conditions, the parliament elected on March 5th should have lasted until the spring of 1954, but elections became inevitable due to the political muddle in the country. They were 3 years early.
nelda7notes: Venizelos resigned on July 28th but was asked by King Paul to form a new government that would supervise national elections in September, and he would run for reelection then.
nelda10notes: Venizelos resigned on July 28th and was asked by King Paul to form a new government that would supervise national elections in September.
nelda13notes: Even though the communist party remained outlawed, communist candidates were allowed to run. And other opposition parties were also running.
nelda17notes: Although the Greek economy was still dependent on foreign aid, it was already expanding.
nelda19notes: There were proposals of up to $250000000 during 1951 and 1952 by the Truman Administration.
nelda20notes: The parliamentary election results would affect the position of prime minister, considered the incumbent.
nelda27notes: Alexandros Papagos' Greek Rally party had just been founded in August and won the most seats, even though he didn't end up leading the government.
nelda32notes: Results favored Venizelos, as he became Deputy Premier and Minister of Foreign Affairs and formed a coalition government with Plastiras.
nelda40notes: Papagos' Party gained 110 seats, Plastiras' party gained 72 seats, and Venizelos' Party gained 56 seats. Even though he formed the coalition government with Plastiras, it was Plastiras who became Prime Minister.
nelda54notes: Greece's entry into NATO was starting to be debated.
nelda55notes: Although the West would had preferred Papagos' Right wing party to come to power, there was not  a significant change in the relations with Greece after the election.

notes: King Paul decided to dissolve Parliament in October and appoint a caretaker government to set up new elections. This was an effort to get a majority Government to aid the nation's grave economic situation.
nelda3notes: The Communist party of Greece was still outlawed, but other than that, opposition was allowed. The two main groups competing were the Greek rally of Papagos and the Progressive-Liberal coalition of Plastiras and Venizelos.
nelda5notes: Around 1000 candidates were competing for 300 seats.
nelda6notes: Only one year had passed since the last parliamentary elections. They were three years early then.
nelda10notes: King entrusted attorney general Kioussopoulos with the formation of a caretaker government to serve until a new cabinet is formed after voting.
nelda17notes: Greece economy was already prospering. Due to this, American aid dropped sharply: it was to get $82 million in 1953, compared to the $206 million it received in 1951.
nelda18notes: The country was still under a very serious economic situation. The elections were held primarily to try to get a party majority that could work on solving this.
nelda19notes: Greece was still receiving substantial economic aid from the US, $80,000,000 approx. in 1952.
nelda20notes: These parliamentary elections lead to a change in primer minister, who is considered the incumbent.
nelda21notes: Kiousopoulos, premier of the caretaker government, did not run in these elections.
nelda24notes: Kiousopoulos, premier of the caretaker government, was not associated with any party.
nelda39notes: Kiousopoulos, Premier of the caretaker government, was replaced by General Papagos. Party  had an overwhelming victory in the elections, winning 238 seats in the 300 seat parliament.

notes: The election was held under a new electoral law, passed on December 1955,  that combined proportional representation and reinforced-majority systems. First general election in Greece in which women had the right to vote.
nelda1notes: Last general election had been in 1952.
nelda3notes: The opposition camp was formed under the name of the Democratic Union, headed by Papandreu, Social Democrat and Liberal Party chief; and which comprises all leftists elements too.
nelda5notes: There were 980 candidates for 300 seats.
nelda6notes: They were 10 months early from when they were supposed to be held.
nelda8notes: Karmanlis had just been appointed Premier by King Paul after the death of Papagos and the formation of the caretaker government.
nelda10notes: A caretaker government was appointed after the death of Papagos in October 1955. The Papagos cabinet resigned and King Paul asked Constantin Karmanlis, Minister of Communications and Public Works, to form a new Cabinet with him serving as Premier.
nelda12notes: There were mixed expectations as to who would win the elections, the Democratic Union or the Radical National Union.
nelda19notes: Greece received around $60 million from the US in 1956.
nelda20notes: Legislative elections can lead to a change in prime minister, who is considered the incumbent.
nelda29notes: There were anti-British riots at the beginning of March over Cyprus, that developed a feeling of bitterness and disappointment toward the US. But they were not directly linked to the outcome of the election and relations were soon recovered.

nelda6notes: They were two years early.
nelda12notes: Karamanlis was expected to win easily, but he was not the incumbent at that point, as there was a caretaker government lead by Georgakopoulos.
nelda20notes: Legislative elections can lead to a change in prime minister, who is considered the incumbent.
nelda24notes: No party was associated with Georgakopoulos.
nelda34notes: The incumbent, Georgakopoulos, did not run and was not associated with any party or outcome.
nelda40notes: The vote count gave victory to Karamanlis.
nelda54notes: Greece was still pro-western and pro-American, and the election results enabled it to continue being like that. Greece was debating whether to allow US nuclear bases to be settled in Greece.

notes: Greece, legislative elections, 10/29/1961, round one of one
nelda4notes: three main political formations with mutiple parties under the umbrella (at least for the far left and the Centre Union): The National Radical Union, the Centre Union, and the far left
nelda6notes: Early elections, Karamanlis said he wanted to renew the mandate of his government before major decisions coming up. Others said he wanted to capitalize on successes such as the association with the European Common Market
nelda10notes: a caretaker governent was appointment by the King. The transitional government was led by General Dovas and was solely tasked with holding elections
nelda15notes: The Centre Union and far left both claimed fraud and violence during the election. It is likely that this was mostly post-election posturing, but cases were very well documented. It is uncertain that the electoral result was changed significant
nelda17notes: There was tangible economic improvement
nelda19notes: Both European aid and US aid are important.
nelda24notes: Karamanlis' incumbent National Radical Union party increased its led over the last legislature by 3 to 176 seats.
nelda27notes: Overall, the opposition (in the form of the Centre Union and the far left) lost a few seats to the incumbent National Radical Union.  However, the Centre Union increased its share of seats from 49 to 100, at the expense of the far left
nelda28notes: Both the Centre Union and the extreme (or far) left claimed violence and fraud.  Most people heard their claims, but no protests materalized.  Both political movements had their seated legislators pledge allegiance to the government.
nelda53notes: Pro-west party won the election

notes: Greece, legislative elections, 11/03/1963, round one of one, unable to form government, new elections in 1964.
nelda4notes: 4 parties contested the elections: the incumbent National Radical Union, the Centre Union, the United Democratic left (the pro-communists), and the Progressive Party
nelda6notes: Early. Prime Minister Karamanlis resigned following a dispute with the king about royal trips and over constitutional reform.
nelda10notes: Transitional caretaker government led by Mavromichalis
nelda12notes: However, Karaminalis and the NRU were expected to win by a narrow margin.
nelda14notes: No, however, the Centre union threatened to boycott the election if another candidate was chosen to lead the transitional government. This candidate, Pipinelis, had been a member of the National Radical Union, the incumbent party led by Karaman
nelda17notes: economic growth not as fast as before. Problems looming on the horizon. Western aid cut off.
nelda19notes: Aid was cut off before the elections because of disputes with the West.
nelda26notes: Most thought Karamanlis would win by a narrow margin.
nelda27notes: The Centre Union won 138 seats to the National Radical Union's 132 seats. However, by the late winter, it was obvious that the Centre Union could not form a viable ruling government and the parliament was dissolved and new elections were called
nelda28notes: This time around the elections were held to be generally honest by all political parties.
nelda50notes: However, US aid was cut off to Greece sometime before the election
nelda57notes: aid was cut off sometime before the elections because of political differences between the US and Greece

notes: Greece, legislative elections, 2/16/1964, round one of one, early elections b/c of the collapse of the previous government's inability to form a coalition.
nelda3notes: the Communist party is still banned.
nelda6notes: Early.  New elections were called after the winning Centre Union, with a slim plurality in parliament was not able to form a coalition government. On December 30 1963, the King called for new elections to be held in Feb. 1964
nelda10notes: the non-political interim government was led by Parakevopoulos, a deputy governor of the National Bank of Greece
nelda12notes: However, the head of the opposition National Radical Union, Karamanlis had resigned from Greek politics, going into self-imposed exile.
nelda17notes: economic growth was increasing, but many voters angry at the uneven pace of reforms and economic benefits
nelda19notes: US, EC aid
nelda21notes: Papandreou ran as the head of his party, the Centre Union
nelda24notes: Landslide victory for the Centre Union. With the largest vote % of the post war period with 52.7%. 171 seats of the 300.
nelda27notes: The United Democratic Left (EDA, pro-communist) did not contest nationwide and only attained 22 seats.  The National Radical Union and its ally the progressive Party won 107 seats, less than in the 1963 elections.

notes: Greeece, legislative elections, 11/17/1974, round one of one, first elections since 1964
nelda1notes: First elections in ten years, seven year dictatorship.
nelda2notes: Seven years of dictatorship
nelda3notes: The Communist party legalized for the first time since the Greek Civil War
nelda6notes: Early. Many expected that the elections would be held later in the year, if not in the next year.
nelda7notes: Using Karamanlis as the incumbent.
nelda10notes: However, Karamanlis, who took power after the fall of the Colonels, stayed on as head of the transitional government, even as he was running in the election--breaking with the tradition of appointing a non-political transitional government head
nelda11notes: However, concerns about the inability of the 400,000 Greek migrant workers in Europe to vote in Greece, the short campaign period, and the inability of students to vote b/c of old voter registers.
nelda17notes: military conflict in Cyprus, military expenditures, Euro Council aid withdrawn
nelda19notes: Until the Cyprus conflict, the US and Europe had generally supported the dictatorship
nelda24notes: Karamanlis won the command of pro-democracy forces and the support of many conservatives who had supported the Colonels regime (or at least who were afraid of a leftist takeover)
nelda27notes: Yes in the sense that this was the first elections after the rule of the Colonels. However, Karamanlis, the incumbent (of the civilian government created after the fall of the Colonels), and his party won 220 of the 300 seats.
nelda28notes: Many called this election the freest election ever held in greece
nelda43notes: See Q notes. for NELDA10
nelda52notes: Karamanlis took on an increasingly anti-American rhethoric before the elections. However, he maintained that he would remain pro-West. It is likely that the US also moderated its stance towards Karamanlis after his solid victory
nelda56notes: Relationship with NATO remains relatively ambivalent. But Greece was allowed into the European Council after the elections. Karamanlis very pro-Europe

notes: Greece, legislative elections, 11/20/1977, round one of one
nelda3notes: first time the Greek Communists (KKE) ran alone. Last election they ran under a political formation.
nelda4notes: 13 major parties ran, only 7 parties were seated. Rise of the far right as a powerful political force
nelda6notes: Early. Karamanlis asked the President to dissolve parliament and call for elections to renew the party's popular mandate before facing the three major issues of Cyprus, Turkey, and accession to the EC.
nelda7notes: Karamanlis ran as head of the New Democracy incumbent party.
nelda10notes: The older system of transitional leadership (in power for the few months before elections) was dumped in the 1974 elections and was never resumed. Instead, the Justice and Interior Ministers were replaced by non-political appointments.
nelda12notes: However, first time that the opposition is challenging the incumbent party on all fronts, as opposed to just domestic policy and selected issue areas in FP.
nelda14notes: However, opposition parties called the early election a constitutional coup. However, all parties participated. PASOK welcomed the early elections.
nelda19notes: US, EC aid.
nelda24notes: New Democracy won 171 seats in the 300 seat legislature, down from 220 in 1974.  PASOK came in second with 93, Centre Union-New Forces with 16, KKE with 11.
nelda27notes: the combined opposition gained seats relative to the ruling New Democracy.  PASOK gained the most seats of the opposition, strengthening the left-right polarization in a country that was formerly very conservative.
nelda54notes: Relations with NATO ambivalent-negative, with the EC, very positive.

notes: Greece, legislative election, 10/18/1981, round one of one, socialist victory
nelda6notes: Regular elections
nelda8notes: The incumbent, Rallis, took power after the former PM Karamanlis was elected to the Greek Presidency by an electoral college of the parliament in 1980
nelda10notes: As had been common practice since 1974, the incumbent government was reformulated as a caretaker government with non-political appointees for the Ministries of the Interior and Justice.
nelda14notes: The far-right withdrew from the election in order to give the ruling New Democracy Party (also conservative) a higher margin of votes.
nelda17notes: Many in Greece perceived a slowing the economic advances of the previous decade. Economic performance was a major election issue.
nelda19notes: European Community and US aid.
nelda24notes: PASOK won 172 seats, New Democracy 115, the Communist KKE won 13.
nelda27notes: the opposition PASOK won the election, the 1st victory for non-conservatives since 1964.
nelda54notes: Greece had become a full member of the European Community in Jan. 1981. Greece also rejoined the NATO military command structure in 1981. However, the election did not affect relations greatly--PASOK had been ambivalent to both,.

notes: Greece, legislatve election, 6/2/1985, round one of one
nelda6notes: Early election.  PASOK did not support Karamanlis' presidential reelection bid, despite telling New democracy it would. This triggered a major political crisis which in forced Papandreou to call for early elections.
nelda12notes: It was thought that the election would be close.
nelda19notes: US and EC aid, esp. US military aid.
nelda24notes: PASOK won 161 seats, New Democracy 126, KKE 12.
nelda26notes: polls indicated that it might be a close election. No polls predicted any clear winners. However, the election was a clear win for PASOK.
nelda27notes: New Democracy increased their seat margin by 10.
nelda50notes: However, while the relationship is close, Papandreou threatens to remove US military bases. US stance is to wait it out, believes that Papandreou would moderate policies after the campaign.

notes: Greece, legislative election, 6/18/1989, round one of one, inconclusive result, unstable interim government formed,
nelda6notes: New Democracy opposition politicians had been calling for early elections since late 1987. In response PASOK set the date of elections for June 18 1989 in June of 1988.
nelda12notes: In fact the electoral law was again changed, this time to the PR system to prevent New Democracy, which was expected to win, to get an overwhelming majority of seats in parliament. There were dozens of PASOK cabinet shuffles and votes of no confidence
nelda17notes: Serious disputes over economic policy.  Papandreou is unable to set stable economic policy over his term.
nelda19notes: EC and US aid.
nelda24notes: PASOK lost by a slim margin in parliament getting on 125 seats.  New Democracy led with 145, 6 shy of a majority.  The Left Coalition (including the KKE) attained 28. DIANA won 1 seat and an independent party won another.
nelda27notes: However, a coalition government was not formed b/c of various disputes between the two main parties ND and PASOK and the power broker Left Coalition. Eventually a government was formed between ND and the left Coalition with Tzannis Tzannetakis
nelda33notes: However, there were significant clashes between PASOK and New Demcoracy supporters with 32 people injured.
nelda37notes: An interim government was appointed for a three month term, elections planned for november.
nelda40notes: The interim government was tasked with prosecuting hearing on a corruption scandal affecting most of the previous PASOK government. New elections were to be held.
nelda50notes: However discussions continuing over the status of military abses in Greece

notes: Greece, legislative election, 11/05/1989, round one of one, all-party coalition formed, elections for the next year.
nelda4notes: New party formed and seated: the Ecologist Alternative. Three other major parties seated and two deputies from 2 independent parties.
nelda6notes: Early.  The previous government was given a three month mandate.  This round of elections was supposed to break the inconclusive balance of power in parliament.
nelda7notes: Tzannetakis was a compromise candidate for the Prime Ministership with the Left Coalition. In this election, the head of the New Democracy party ran as head of the party again, intending to take the Prime Ministership (Mitsotakis)
nelda10notes: unlike in previous arrangements where the ministers of Justice and the Interior would be replaced by non-political appointments, there was an interim government installed after the expiry of the three-month ruling government.
nelda12notes: It was likely that New Democracy would win the elections again. However, it was not certain at all that New Democracy would be able to get more than half of the seats in the parliament or be able to prevent a PASOK - Left Coalition government.
nelda17notes: debate over economic policy a major issue for the election
nelda19notes: EC and US aid.
nelda22notes: The head of the New Democracy party was the intended candidate for Prime Minister. See Qn. 7.

notes: Early parliamentary elections were held in Greece on May 6, 2012. The outcome of the election was largely seen as a protest vote against austerity measures, as parties that opposed harsh structural reforms imposed by the EU were returned to power. The Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok) and the conservative New Democracy (ND) were the two mainstream political parties that had joined the governing coalition in November 2011 to implement further austerity measures. Yet, these elections were a crushing defeat for Pasok and ND. Despite the fact that ND came in first with 108 seats (previously had 91), Pasok came in third with only 41 seats (previously had 160). The perception was that the biggest winner was actually the Coalition of the Radical Left (SYRIZA), who came in second with 52 seats (previously had 13). Because no party secured an overall majority, the government would have to rule in coalition. Unfortunately, after four separate attempts to build a coalition (first led by ND, then SYRIZA, Pasok, and a fourth effort led by President Karolos Papoulias) failed, the country was scheduled to face a second snap election in the coming months.
nelda33notes: Civilian deaths did occur after the election, but they were not inflicted by the government. They also were not directly related to the election, but rather the economic crisis. The suicide rate has increased in Greece since the onset of the debt crisis and subsequent austerity measures. As a result, at least two pensioners committed suicide in Athens during the election campaign.

notes: Early parliamentary elections were held in Greece on May 6, 2012; however, because the government failed to form a governing coalition, second snap elections were held again on June 17, 2012. The outcome of this election was largely interpreted as a referendum on Greece to continue with the Euro. The pro-EU bailout ND came in first with 129 seats (it had won 108 seats in the May election). And the radical leftist Coalition of the Radical Left (SYRIZA) came in second with 71 seats (52, previously). The Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok) came in third with 33 seats (44, previously). Despite no party securing a majority (again), the ND was able to form a governing coalition with other pro-bailout parties, Pasok and the moderate Democratic Left (DIMAR).
nelda6notes: The elections were not regular. They were snap elections that were held after early elections in May failed to form a governing coalition.

notes: This was the first parliamentary election held since the rejection of the UN-endorsed reunification plan. Also this was the first time that Turkish Cypriots who lived in the Greek-controlled part of the country were allowed to vote and stand for election. As a result, one Turkish Cypriot candidate ran for office with the right-wing EDI party. The (Communist) Progressive Party of the Working People (AKEL), and the right-wing opposition party the Democratic Rally (DISY) both gained 18 seats each. Nevertheless, the incumbent retained power because of the coalition formed between AKEL and the Democratic Party (DIKO) that gained 11 seats. Voting is compulsory.
nelda5notes: The House of Representatives' members are elected by open list proportional representation in multi-member constituencies.
nelda12notes: Both the President of the Republic, Papadopoulos, and the President of Parliament, Christofias, enjoyed high approval ratings prior to the election. Also, most opinion polls conducted up the time of the election showed Christofias's AKEL party receiving the most votes, and with the president's DIKO party coming in third in the vote count (thus retaining their coalition in government). However, because many polls also showed the number of those undecided (around 10%) at a very high percentage, it was very difficult to conclusively forecast the outcome. Furthermore, despite the fact that voting is mandatory by all citizens, the growing abstentions had become increasingly tolerated by the authorities.
nelda14notes: Since 1963, Turkish Cypriots did not recognize nor participate in the central government of Cyprus, as a result the allocated 24 seats in the House of Representatives (that were allocated to Turkish Cypriots by the Constitution) have remained empty. Although, in this election, one Turkish Cypriot did run with the EDI party.
nelda27notes: The main opposition party (DISY) gained 19 seats in Parliament during the last election, and they gained one less seat in Parliament this time around.
nelda54notes: With the exception of the UK. Greek Cypriots are currently questioning the justification for UK military bases on the island. Nevertheless, the UK is still one of the island's biggest trading partners.

notes: The 2008 Presidential election had two rounds (as per constitutional requirement in Cyprus when no candidate receives more than 50% of the vote in the first round of voting). There were nine candidates who contested the election in the first round. The government coalition parties included DIKO (the incumbent president's, Papadopoulos, party), EDEK, and AKEL. This coalition fell apart prior to the elections because they couldn't come to a consensus on a common presidential candidate. Thus, AKEL left the coalition and supported Christofias as their candidate. EDEK and AKEL remained supported the incumbent Papadopoulos. Kasoulidis was supported by DISY, Kinima Eleftheron Politon, and Evropaiki party. These were the three main contenders.
nelda12notes: and more recently Cypriots have shown evidence of being more committed to solving the issue in Cyprus, especially given their 2008 adoption of the Euro. It's evidence that European interests will force Cyprus politicians to be more compromising; thus, because Papadopoulos's views aren't necessarily moderate in regards to the division of the country, his reelection isn't a sure thing.
nelda14notes: The Turkish Cypriots have been boycotting elections since 1974 when they created their own constitution and governing bodies within the Turkish Federation State of Cyprus, TRNC (it's not internationally recognized). Thus, the office of the Vice President, which is supposed to be filled by a Turkish Cypriot, has remained unfilled.
nelda24notes: The incumbent president, Papadopoulos, came third in the first round of elections, and thus he didn't make it to the second and final round.
nelda26notes: All of the domestic polls indicated that the election was too close to call, placing the three main contenders within 3% popularity of each other. All the polls also showed that no candidate had a majority, but most of them put the incumbent in the lead, even if only by a couple of percentage points.
nelda27notes: The incumbent president was eliminated in the first round of voting.
nelda44notes: It should be noted that Papadopoulos did not make it to the second round of elections; nevertheless, as the incumbent he was still technically the leader of the country until a predecessor was chosen in the second round.
nelda50notes: The US has put pressure on the leadership of Cyprus to solve the issue of the Turkish Cypriots in the north, and the divide in the country, but there is no evidence that there is any kind of evident strain between Cyprus and the US.

notes: The 2008 Presidential election had two rounds (as per constitutional requirement in Cyprus when no candidate receives over 50% of the vote in the first round). There were nine candidates who contested the election in the first round. The government coalition parties included DIKO (the incumbent president's, Papadopoulos, party), EDEK, and AKEL. This coalition fell apart prior to the elections because they couldn't come to a consensus on a common presidential candidate. Thus, AKEL left the coalition and supported Christofias as their candidate. EDEK and AKEL remained supported the incumbent Papadopoulos. Kasoulidis was supported by DISY, Kinima Eleftheron Politon, and Evropaiki party. These were the three main contenders. The incumbent candidate, Papadopoulos, came in third in the first round, thus he was eliminated from the second round of voting. Only Christofias and Kasoulidis made it to the second round. The winner - Christofias - is a leader of the Communist (AKEL) in Cyprus, nevertheless he has promised to leave the issue of the free-market economy in Cyprus alone. His victory is seen as an opportunity to renew talks about the reunification of Cyprus, especially since he is seen as a more moderate candidate on the issue of the Cyprus division than the incumbent.

nelda14notes: The Turkish Cypriots have been boycotting elections since 1974 when they created their own constitution and governing bodies within the Turkish Federation State of Cyprus, TRNC (it's not internationally recognized). Thus, the office of the Vice President, which is supposed to be filled by a Turkish Cypriot, has remained unfilled.
nelda21notes: The incumbent candidate, Papadopoulos, had been eliminated in the first round of voting, thus he did not run in this second round of voting.

notes: The legislative elections that were held in Greek Cyprus on May 22, 2011 resulted in the main opposition right-wing Democratic Rally (DISY) winning 34% and 20 seats, two more than they won in 2006. The ruling party of President Khristofias, the left-wing Progressive Party of the Working People (AKEL), came in second with 33% and 19 seats, a gain of one seat. Both the ruling party and the main opposition party increased their share of the vote compared to their percentages in 2006. These elections are not expected to impact policy significantly; however, analysts predict that they will impact the nature of alliance formation in the time leading up to the presidential elections, scheduled for early 2013.
nelda27notes: It should be noted that the vote count was also a gain for the ruling party. This is possible in Cyprus because of the multiparty system (most ruling parties actually only have a plurality and usually rule in coalition).
nelda46notes: The OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights (OSCE/ODIHR) deployed an Election Assessment Mission (EAM) to Cyprus for the May 22, 2011 election. The final report deemed that the elections conducted in Cyprus were free and fair.
nelda54notes: Cyprus will hold the EU's rotating presidency in the second half of 2012.

notes: Generally fair election in Bulgaria, which is called early due to the resignation of the Prime Minister. Main issues included electricity prices, the uses of EU structural funds (in particular due to the fact that the party with the most votes ran on a distinctly pro-European platform, though they failed to form a government), and corruption. General distrust of politicians and the prominence of fraud led to a relatively low turnout rate.

notes: The ruling Socialist coalition government resigned in July 2014 due to economic crisis and widespread disapproval, sparking a snap election. This was Bulgaria�s third election in two years. Centre-Right GERB party won 33% of the votes, making Boyko Borissov the new Prime Minister, but a record of eight parties were elected to Parliament, exacerbating the ongoing political turmoil. Borissov is tasked with forming a new coalition government to compromise a majority and revive the country�s economy and faith in politics.

notes: An election which followed, and resulted in, severe political turmoil. notes: President Putin's United Russia party was heavily favored to win the Duma (Russian Parliament) elections, and it did. United Russia received over two-thirds of the 450 seats in the chamber, and the Communist Party of the Russian Federation (KPRF) came in second. Liberal opposition parties didn't win a single seat. In addition to the KPRF, two parties loyal to the Putin presidency won seats: the nationalist LDPR and Just Russia. Western observers and Russia NGOs criticized the elections, claiming that there was media manipulation during the campaign and widespread falsification of the results.
nelda12notes: Nevertheless it should be noted that almost all reports and opinion polls showed the United Russia party as the inevitable winner of the upcoming elections.

nelda17notes: Estonia had reached a record growth rate of 11.5% in 2006, and was enjoying a boom in its high-tech industry. It had joined the EU in 2004 and seemed to be profiting from this.
nelda20notes: Prime Minister is the incumbent leader, and Prime Minister is determined by dominance in Parliament. In fact Parliament elects a President, who then selects a PM with the approval of the Parliament.
nelda21notes: PM Ansip is associated with the Estonian Reform Party.
nelda24notes: Ansip's Reform Party won 31 seats (up from 19 in 2003), making it the largest party in Parliament. The composition of its ruling coaliton changes, however: previously it had been in coalition with the second largest party, the Centre Party, together with the Estonian People's Union (a small Agrarian Party). Following these elections it entered a coalition with the Estonian Peope's Union (as before), but instead of the Centre Party it entered government with the Pro Patria and Res Publica Union (the third largest party, and largest opposition party to the previous coalition).
nelda25notes: No prominent opinion polls were reported in international media.
nelda27notes: This is complicated. The incumbent coalition from before these elections, the Reform Party, Centre Party, and People's Union, changed from 19 to 31, 28 to 29, and 13 to 6 seats in Parliament respectively. This is an overall gain, implying a loss for the opposition parties. Indeed, the main opposition party, the newly amalgamated Pro Patria and Res Publica Union, decreased their aggregate share of seats from 35 to 19. However, due to differences in policy between the incumbent Reform and Center party, the new coalition after these elections contained the opposition Pro Patria and Res Publica instead of the Centre Party,and the opposition Social Democratic party instead of the Estonian People's Union. This shift came despite the fact the Pro Patria and Res Publica Union had actually LOST seats and the Centre Party had GAINED seats. So the vote count was not a gain for the opposition, but nevertheless they ended up in the new governing coalition.

notes: Elections for the Saeima (the unicameral parliament) resulted in a decisive victory for the ruling centre-right coalition led by incumbent Prime Minister Dombrovskis, who had become prime minister in March 2009 following the collapse of a previous government amidst the country's deep recession. The overriding issue of these elections was the austerity plan demanded by the $10 billion bailout led by the IMF and the EU. Prime Minister Dombrovskis called on voters' support for his Unity coalition arguing that the austerity measures implemented under his government were the only way to restore the country's economy. Latvia reportedly needed a further US$ 1.5-US$ 1.7 billion through budget cuts or tax increases over the next two years to respect the bailout terms. He promised to introduce the EU currency (the euro) in 2014. Dombrovskis government had become a sign of hope and was seen as the best way to gain accession to the euro by 2014. Dombrovskis harsh austerity plans were opposed by the main opposition social democrat party, the Harmony Centre, who were also notably pro-Russian. The emergent coalition consisted of the Unity alliance (his New Era party and the Civic Union), which took 33 seats; the Union of Greens and Farmers which took 22 seats; and the Fatherland and Freedom Union led a National Alliance that took 8 seats. In total, this amounted to 63 seats. The main opposition, the Centre for Harmony (a new party), won 29 seats.
nelda6notes: Elections were held as scheduled (at the end of the four year term that began in October 2006), despite considerable political turmoil and many reshuffles of government. In March 2009, the current incumbent Prime Minister Dombrovskis was approved by the Saeima (the unicameral legislature) to head a five-party centre-right government, after the previous Prime Minister resigned and his coaliton dissolved due to the deep economic recession in Latvia. Then, the People's Party withdrew from Dombrovski's 2009 coalition on March 22 2010, and Dombrovskis had to negotiate with another party to avoid the four-party coalition being reduced to minority status in parliament.
nelda18notes: Latvia experienced the worst recession in the EU following the 2008 Global Financial Crisis, and indeed, one of the worst national recessions ever seen in Europe. The country's economy shrank by 18% in 2009 and unemployment soared to 20%. Prime Minister Valdis Dombrovskis who took office in March 2009 implemented austerity measures including wage cuts of up to 50% in the public sector.
nelda19notes: In December 2008 Latvia was granted a 7.5-billion-euro bailout from the IMF and another 1.3 billion euros from the European Union. It was sorely needed - Latvia reportedly needed a further 800 to 900 million lats (US$ 1.5-US$ 1.7 billion) through budget cuts or tax increases over the two years to follow if the bailout terms were to be respected.
nelda20notes: The incumbent is in practice determined by Parliament, though in an indirect way: the President is indirectly elected by parliament to serve a 4-year term, and the Prime Minister is then nominated by the President and approved by the parliament.
nelda26notes: A Latvijas Fakti poll conducted between 25 and 27 September 2010 showed 21.2% support for Harmony Centre (the ethnic Russian party), 19.2% for Unity (Dombrovskis incumbent coalition), 9.9% for Greens and Farmers and For Fatherland and Freedom on 5.2%. There were, however, a large number of voters undecided, and these were thought to be Latvian rather than Russian - this explains why Unity rather than Harmony Centre eventually won.
nelda27notes: This was considered a decisive victory for the ruling centre-right coalition of Prime Minister Dombrovskis. The emergent coalition consisted of the Unity alliance (his New Era party and the Civic Union), which took 33 seats; the Union of Greens and Farmers which took 22 seats; and the Fatherland and Freedom Union led a National Alliance that took 8 seats. In total, this amounted to 63 seats. The main opposition, the Centre for Harmony (a new party), won 29 seats.

nelda54notes: In particular, Latvia's relations with the IMF and EU were under scrutiny in these elections, as the austerity conditions attached to the bailout were supported and criticized by different parties.
nelda58notes: The IMF and EU were clear in their preference for incumbent Prime Minister Dombrovskis: Dombrovskis was seen as the main guarantor of the austerity deal that included a 7.5 billion euros ($10bn) bailout. His policies since the IMF agreement had impressed investors, as his committment to austerity measured was steering Latvia out of its deep recession. Dombrovskis' main opposition, the Harmony Centre, opposed the IMF deal and conditions, and presented itself as a social-democratic alternative in the hopes of benefiting from widespread anger at the harsh austerity measures and 20% unemployment.

notes: Elections to the unicameral legislature (the Seimas) were held in Lithuania on October 14, 2012. This was the first of a two-round election. In Lithuania, 71 out of 141 seats are filled through a two-round race, and the remaining 70 are filled via proportional representation from the results of the first round.

The second round of legislative elections to the unicameral legislature (the Seimas) in Lithuania were held on October 2,2012. In Lithuania, 71 out of 141 seats are filled through a two-round race, and the remaining 70 are filled via proportional representation from the results of the first round. The Lithuanian Social Democratic Party won the election with a plurality, winning a total of 38 seats (a 13-seat increase). They defeated the center-right coalition headed by the Homeland Union Party, which came in second with 33 seats (a 12-seat decrease). The Labour Party came in third with 29 seats (a 19-seat increase). However, President Dalia Grybauskaite (an independent with conservative support), refused to allow the Labour Party to join the new governing coalition due to allegations of electoral fraud.
nelda24notes: Incumbent President Dalia Grybauskaite is an independent.

notes: This election re-elected the popular incumbent Dalia Grybauskait_ to the presidency. The election represented a continuation of Lithuania's strong democratic process relative to much of Eastern Europe and did not feature any notable examples of voter fraud or harassment of opposition.
nelda13notes: One leader, impeached former president Parksas, had been refused by the electoral commission to run again in this election due to his impeachment.
nelda15notes: The incumbent is known to have opposed the formation of a coalition government due to the Labor Party's alleged involvement with buying voters and with Russia connections

notes: This was the second round of the 2014 Lithuanian presidential election, in which incumbent President Dalia Grybauskait_ was re-elected to office. The election featured no notable errors or fraudulent results and continued the conservative president's tenure.
nelda13notes: As with the first round, the impeached former president was not allowed to run for legal reasons.

nelda1notes: Ukraine did not declare independence until August 24th.
nelda7notes: Kravchuk is coded by the Goeman's data as being the incumbent, however it should be noted that his position leading up to the election was Chairman of the Verkhovna Rada.
nelda10notes: Following the attempted coup d'etat in Moscow of 19th August, the Verkhovna Rada on 24th August adopeted a declaration of independence pending confirmations by referendum on 1st December, when presidential elections were also scheduled.
nelda11notes: Chornovil (Kravchuk's main rival) accused the news media of unfair basis. His campaign manager, Mr Les Paniuk, claims that 62 per cent of air time has been devoted to Mr Kravchuk and another former Communist candidate.
nelda13notes: The CPU (communist party) had been made illegal in August as a result of the attempted coup; however, this does not seem to have prevented former members of the party (including Kravchuk) from running.
nelda14notes: Ethnic Romanians expressed opposition to the referendum on independence scheduled for this day, but it does not seem they ever had candidates for the election for president (and thus these candidates could not boycott the election).
nelda16notes: The allegation of media bias was in favor of the incumbent in the sense that Kravchuk's former affiliation with the CPU made him in some ways an incumbent.
nelda18notes: The Soviet Union as a whole was in a severe state of economic crisis, and Ukraine was suffering as well. Ukraine was doing among the best of the Soviet Republics.
nelda21notes: Kravchuk
nelda25notes: The late November poll conducted by the Ukrainian Institute of Sociology, gives Mr Kravchuk 47.5 per cent of the vote, more than twice Mr Chornovil's rating of 21.6 per cent. (Financial Times (London,England))
nelda27notes: Opposition lost in the first round. Krazchuk took 62% of the vote with his closest rival (Chornovil) receiving 23%. (Europa)
nelda50notes: Relations began to change markedly following the break up of the USSR, but it is unclear how these elections affected the relationship.

notes: Third round of legislative elections, for 112 unfilled seats, of 450 total. Although this was the last official round that could have swayed the election, there were three more rounds in some constituencies from July until December. These further rounds were needed because of a rule requiring a 50% voter turnout in order for a candidate to be elected, a threshold that was not easily met in a number of constituencies. 45 seats were never filled because of these turnout rules.

nelda24notes: In the first round, Kravchuk received the greatest number of votes (37.7%), while Kuchma (his main rival running on a moderate reformist platform criticizing Kravchuk's slow reform policies) received only 31.3%. As neither received more than 50% of the vote, a second round was needed.

nelda57notes: An IMF mission left Ukraine on March 14 declaring that the country was not eligible to receive the US$49 million tranche of funds from the IMF's 1997 standby loan to Ukraine due in February.

notes: Snap general elections held in order to try to resolve the political crisis triggered by the April 2007 presidential decree that tried to dissolve Parliament because of sustained infighting between the President and Prime Minister

nelda47notes: The monitors discussed the issue of certain irregularities, but there was no significant vote fraud.
nelda51notes: The US government continued to criticize Lukashenko for increasing his executive powers. The fact that the former Communists took over the Parliament contributed to the US feeling that Belarus was moving away from democracy.
nelda57notes: Prior to the election, but not as a result of it, the IMF declined to give Belarus a loan because they determined that the state was not serious about making the necessary liberalizing reforms.

notes: that the EU and the US had set up for it with regard to free and fair elections, thus threats to withdraw aid and relations were not carried out. In the last elections held in 2003, which were marred by allegations of electoral fraud, the ruling Republican Party (HHK) of President Kocharian had established a coalition with the Rule of Law Party. Since 2003, the Rule of Law Party had withdrawn. In these elections, a coalition of three pro-government parties took a strong majority in the 131-seat National Assembly, giving a victory to Prime Minister Serge Sargsyan, who was considered the principal contender in the presidential race next year. Though opposition parties claimed fraud, international observers (of whom many were present) gave mostly positive reviews.
nelda11notes: The opposition parties accused the pro government parties of collecting voters passport data in exchange for bribes or welfare benefits.
nelda12notes: The governing Republican Party, led by Prime Minister Serzh Sarksyan and President Kocharian, was expected to win.
nelda16notes: Opposition parties held public rallies during the campaign without police harassment and were allowed free air time on public television - signs of an open campaign noted by the international community. Oppositon leaders felt differently, as television stations were controlled by government.
nelda19notes: Much American development aid for this post-Soviet nation.
nelda24notes: Final results gave a comfortable majority to the three pro-government parties. The HHK won a total of 65 seats, the PAP 25, and the Armenian Revolutionary Federation, 16.
nelda27notes: The results were considered a resounding victor for government forces.
nelda28notes: The opposition parties called for fresh elections, criticizing election irregularities.
nelda29notes: Opposition groups said the vote was falsified and  called for mass demonstrations in the capital, Yerevan, which did not really snowball. A small protest began in the capital as opposition parties claimed to have evidence of irregularities - there were no immediate reports of arrests or violence, and the protest ended when rain began to fall.
nelda33notes: The start of the election campaign was marred by a series of violent attacks, though it was noted that there were fewer than 2003.
nelda46notes: Six international organizations monitored the polls. These included the Inter-Parliamentary Assembly of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) and a joint Observation Mission of the Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights (ODIHR) - OSCE, the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, the OSCE Parliamentary Assembly and the European Parliament.

notes: These elections were for the unicameral parliament in Armenia's Presidential system.Though there were nine candidates, the election was mostly fought between Sargsyan, the candidate of the ruling Republican Party (HHK) of President Kocharian, and Levon Ter-Petrosian, the opposition leader who  led crowds amassing tens of thousands following his loss of the election.Prime Minister of Armenia, Serzh Sargsyan, won this presidential election in the first round according to official results, but this was disputed by former President Levon Ter-Petrossian, who placed second. Sargsyan won the election in the first round with 57%, with Ter-Petrossian coming in second with 17%. The opposition parties have stated that the election result was fraudulent, and mass violent protests caused President  Kocharian to declare a 20-day state of emergency. This was followed by mass arrests and purges of prominent members of the opposition, as well as a de facto ban on any further anti-government protests.
nelda5notes: 9 Presidential candidates officially registered.
nelda8notes: President Kocharian was not allowed to run for a third term.
nelda11notes: According to the opposition, votes were bought during the election campaign, television coverage was skewed, and intimidating men in large cars bossed vote counters.
nelda13notes: Though 9 Presidential candidates in all were allowed register, Raffi Hovannisian from Heritage Party and Aram Karapetyan from New Times Party were refused the certificates of residence in Armenia over the last ten years by the Armenian Police Department of Passports which would have allowed them register.
nelda16notes: Television coverage during the campaignw as skewed, and television stations - completely controlled by incumbents of the HHK (Republican Party), Prime Minister Serge Sargsyan and President Robert Kocharian -  mostly ignored the large rallies that gathered to protest the election results, despite the fact that the protests often numbered in the tens of thousands. Protesters said attending them was the only way to get news. CNN segments about Armenia were clipped from television programming.
nelda19notes: Much American development aid for this post-Soviet nation.
nelda21notes: Kocharian had reached his two term limit.
nelda22notes: As Kocharian had reached his Presidential term limit, the candidacy of Sargsyan (Prime Minister and also Republican Party, HHK, member) was backed by incumbent President Kocharian.
nelda29notes: Armenian authorities clashed with demonstrators in a violent confrontation that left at least 8 dead and more than 130 wounded. Crowds filled the streets each day for long after results were announced. It was estimated that ten people were killed overall.
nelda31notes: Tanks were used by the government. The police fired in the air and set off tear gas to break up a gathering of about 15,000 protesters. It was some of the worst political violence to hit post-Soviet Armenia.
nelda34notes: Results were favorable to the incumbent because his chosen successor (of the Republican Party HHK) won.
nelda46notes: The International Election Observation Mission (IEOM) was a joint undertaking of the OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights (OSCE/ODIHR), the OSCE Parliamentary Assembly (OSCE PA), the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe (PACE) and the European Parliament (EP).

Finland's incumbent was President Mannerheim, who had accepted the Presidency to see Finland through the end of the war and hold elections. The Social Democrats had been the most popular party pre-war, but with a leader who had been seen as pro-German, Mr. Tanner, the popularity of the social democrats waned.
nelda1notes: The last general elections were in 1939. The interim period was disrupted by WW2.
nelda3notes: The Communist Party, with their broad, new Democratice People's Union front, opposed Tanner's Social Democrats dominant in the government.
nelda10notes: Incumbent Baron Mannerheim had taken over the Presidency in August 1944 to end Finland's war with Russia, and publically stated that he would consider his mission fulfilled after these elections were held.

nelda57notes: Shortly before the election the USSR did held the reparations owed by Finland however, in an attempt to curry favor for the Popular Democratic League, who had suffered setbacks in the run-up to the election for proposing such a reduction.

notes: These elections were the first Presidential elections to involve a popular vote since before the Second World War, in 1937. Incumbent President Paasikivi, who was supported by the Social Democrats, Conservatives, Liberals and the Swedish party, was seeking re-election. The (opposition) Communists were supporting Mauno Pekkala, and the (opposition) Agrarians supported Kekkonen. Under the Finnish electoral system, the public votes for a 300-member electoral college on Jan 16-17. The electoral college then met on Feb 15th to vote for the president - members are bound to vote along party lines.  Russia exerted its influence by launching a press and radio campaign against Finland, with the Finnish Communists labeling incumbent Paasikivi an �agent of Western Imperialism.� Russia indicated that they considered Paasikivi an undesirable Finnish President. The Communist press  suggested that hundreds of alleged war criminals were leaving Finland and fleeing to Sweden, with the help of the Finnish authorities. The Soviet Union had accused Paasikivi of harboring 300 alleged Soviet war criminals, and thus violating the Soviet-Finnish peace pact. This exchange was considered the most serious warning issued to Finland from the USSR since the end of WW2. This criticism was thought to have boosted votes for the Communists. Paasikivi voiced his determination to remain friendly with Russia without become economically dependent on it, and without falling under explicit political influence.  In the first round (the public vote) of the election, electoral college candidates supporting Paasikivi won 167 of the 300 seats in the College of Electors, at 58.8 percent of the vote. Ultimately in the Electoral College round, Paasikivi won 171 of the 300 votes. Notably, the Communist party increased its vote from the 1948 parliamentary elections, and some of this gain was due to Russian pressure against Paasikivi.
nelda1notes: Public voting for the Presidential position had not occurred since before the Second World War, in 1937. Three Presidential elections had since occurred in - 1940, 1943, and 1946 - but had been exceptional due to war circumstances, in that they did not involve a public vote preceding an electoral college vote.
nelda27notes: With regard to the incumbent coalition supporting Paasikivi: the right wing Conservatives made gains - from 19 percent in the 1948 parliamentary elections to 27.3 percent in these elections. Support for the Social Democrats dropped, who won 27 percent of the vote in the 1948 parliamentary elections, won only 22.3 percent in the popular vote of the presidential elections. Overall however, the opposition made gains due to the relative losses of the Social Democrats, and the gains of the Communists. The main opposition came from the Agrarian party, who suffered a considerable loss in these elections as compared to their 1948 votes, while the Communist party increased its vote from the 1948 parliamentary elections. Some of this gain was due to Russian pressure against Paasikivi.
nelda50notes: Finland and the US had very slim relations due to Cold War politics.
nelda53notes: Despite not actually being behind the iron curtain, there was the wide-spread feeling that Finland had been written off by the West due to its proximity to the USSR, and its political reluctance to do anything that might antagonize its big neighbor.
nelda58notes: Russia exerted its influence by launching a press and radio campaign against Finland, with the Finnish Communists labeling incumbent Paasikivi an �agent of Western Imperialism.� Russia indicated that they considered Paasikivi an undesirable Finnish President. This exchange was considered the most serious warning issued to Finland from the USSR since the end of WW2. This criticism was thought to have boosted votes for the Communists.

notes: Prime Minister Urho Kekkonen of the Agrarian (Center) party led the popular vote in this Presidential election, with 27.7 percent (88 of the 300 electors). He also earned the support of the (Soviet-backed) Communist-led People�s Democratic Union in the electoral college, indeed Kekkonen was widely considered �Moscow�s Man� for his distinctly pro-Soviet leanings in the Cold War context. In the final round of the electoral college vote, Kekkonen won with the minimum 151 of the 300 seats. In the third ballot, he inched out Social Democrat candidate Fagerholm.  Under the Finnish system, the popular vote chooses members of the 300-member electoral college, who then are bound to party lines when they vote for the President in subsequent rounds. A majority of 151 in the electoral college wins the election.  The opposition to Kekkonen included the Conservative party (who supported outgoing President Paasikivi) and the Swedish People�s Party. Fagerholm, the anti-communist candidate of the Social Democrats, polled 23.9 percent of the popular vote and 74 electors. Incumbent President Paasiviki was dropped out of the race in the second ballot, as only the top two candidates are eligible to be considered for the third ballot. In Western diplomatic circles, the election of Kekkonen to the Presidential position (formerly he had been Prime Minister) was seen as maintaining the status quo of friendly Moscow-Helsinki relations.

Prime Minster Matti Vanhanen's senior ruling agrarian Centre Party narrowly won a plurality with 51/200 seats. It  only won one seat more than the main opposition party the National Coalition Party (NCP), which had gained a significant increase since the last parliamentary elections that were held in 2003. The NCP's success is partly due to the personal popularity of a party member - Sauli Niinisto - who had earlier defected from the Centre Party to the NCP. The incumbent president Halonen (a member of the SDP) saw its party lose 8 seats, and thus lost its membership in the new coalition government. The Social Democrats (SDP) are now the main opposition party.
nelda24notes: The party associated with the incumbent president Halonen, the SDP, lost 8 seats in parliament, and thus lost its membership as one of the coalition partners in the new parliament.
nelda26notes: Polls indicated that the SDP would probably remain a member of the new coalition party; yet, the election resulted in otherwise.

notes: The NCP, while losing seats, became the largest party for the first time in history. All 3 major parties lost seats, while the nationalist True Finn had a breakthrough, going from relatively unimportant to just below the largest 2 parties. The Centre Party-led coalition (including the NCP) lost its majority by 2 seats.

nelda27notes: Particularly for the True Finns, who represent a much stronger anti-EU voice than was previously heard in the major parties.

notes: and promised to reduce immigration by up to 90%, and this platform shocked Sweden: all the main parties criticized the SD's anti-immigration platform and urged voters not to support it. They also stated they would not cooperate with the SD. Demonstrations against the anti-immigration policies of the SD erupted after the results were announced, with demonstrators carrying placards stating �refugees welcome� and �no racists in our parliament.� Unlike fellow Scandinavians Denmark and Norway, where populist anti-immigration parties have been successful for years, the populace in Sweden had never before given the Sweden Democrats sufficient support to overcome the 4 percent threshold they needed to reach Parliament. Prime Minister Reinfeldt�s coalition formed a minority government in an enhanced coalition with the formerly opposition Green Party. This victory made Reinfeldt the first centre-right leader since 1921 to be returned to government in Sweden after serving a full term.
nelda8notes: There is no term limit for Prime Minister.
nelda11notes: Denmark (historically more sympathetic to anti-immigration parties than Sweden) complained mightily that the anti-immigration far right Sweden Democrats (SD) had not been given fair media coverage, and suggested that international observers should attend the election.
nelda17notes: Due to the global economic crisis, Sweden's economy shrank by 5.1% in 2009.
nelda18notes: In 2010 the economy was expected to recover, and an expansion of 4.5 was predicted -  the best performance among the 27 Member States of the EU.
nelda24notes: The four parties in Prime Minister Reinfeldt's government won a total of 173 seats, two seats short of a majority. His coalition then formed a minority government in an enhanced coalition with the Green Party. This victory made Reinfeldt the first centre-right leader since 1921 to be returned to government in Sweden after serving a full term.
nelda26notes: Three separate polls published a day before the election showed that the gap between incumbent Prime Minister Reinfeldt's coalition and the left-wing opposition was decreasing; nevertheless, the polls still gave the government a lead of between four and nine percentage points.
nelda27notes: Prime Minister Reinfeldt�s Alliance for Sweden dropped from 178 to 173 seats, meaning they had to form a government in alliance with the formerly opposition Green Party. Notably, the main opposition party (the SAP) actually recorded its worst result since 1914, taking only 112 seats. However, the very controversial, far-right anti-immigration SD won 20 seats - their first time winning seats in parliament. The success of the SD shocked many Swedish voters, and was the focus of global media reports.
nelda29notes: Shocked by the success of the far-right SD party (which had used neo-Nazi symbols in the 1990s), thousands of Swedes demonstrated after the results were announced, to ensure that Fredrik Reinfeldt knew how the public felt about keeping the SD out of his governing coalition, despite his minority government. About 10,000 people protested in Stockholm, in Gothenburg 5,000 took part in a �sorrow march against racism,� and 2,000 protesters gathered in the city of Malmoe. Protesters waved banners that declared �Refugees -- welcome!� and �No racists in our parliament.�
nelda45notes: Rght wing politicians in Denmark suggested that perhaps there should be international monitors to observe the election, as they claimed the far-right SD party had not been given fair media treatment. These claims were largely considered unfair by the majority of Swedes.

notes: ) took 99/100 seats. The remaining seat went to the main opposition force: Convergence for Social Democracy Party (CPDS), who tried to appeal to young voters by arguing that they needed to take back the country from the small and oil-rich elite.
nelda2notes: First multi-party elections were held in 1991. and since then the PDGE has remained the dominant party.
nelda3notes: It should be noted that although the government adopted a constitutional multiparty system in 1991, the president, Mbasogo, has kept a tight grip on power since becoming head of state in 1979.
nelda4notes: More than one party is technically allowed, but the president's PDGE Party held 98/100 seats previously, and won 99/100 seats in this election. Opposition leaders claim voter fraud, arbitrary procedures in many polling stations, disappearing ballot papers, early closing of polls, and the failure to replace ballot papers that had run out as just some ways the government limits the opposition's ability to be elected.
nelda5notes: There was a choice of candidates, but a lot of opposition candidates switched to the PDGE before the election because they knew the likelihood of their getting elected would be increased if they aligned themselves with the president's PDGE party.
nelda6notes: The President called for elections a year early in order to run them in tandem with municipal elections, notably to save money.
nelda13notes: The opposition Progress Party was banned from participating. Its leader, Severo Moto- who'd been in Spain in exile since the 1980s- had been sentenced in absentia to 62 years in prison for his alleged involvement in a 2004 coup attempt.
nelda17notes: The country is the third larges exporter of crude oil in sub-Saharan Africa. It has an extremely high poverty level; however, the perception is not any worse than it's been previously.
nelda19notes: Equatorial Guinea received a large amount of foreign assistance from the West in the 1980s and 1990s, but since then, many of these aid programs have ceased altogether or have been diminished. Nevertheless, it is important to note that Spain, France, and the EU continue to provide some project assistance, as do China, Brazil, and Cuba.
nelda24notes: President Mbsago's PDGE party had 98/100 seats in parliament before the election, and the outcome of this election gives the PDGE 99/100 in parliament.
nelda27notes: The PDGE incumbent party gained one more seat, to a total of 99/100 seats, as a result of the election.
nelda49notes: EU, France, and Spain boycotted monitoring elections because conditions for free elections did not exist.
nelda54notes: Equatorial Guinea exports a large amount of crude oil to the Western world. It's important to note that most opposition elements to the government are based in Spain, and relations between the two countries grew difficult after a 2004 attempted coup due to Spain's hosting opposition figure Severo Moto and the Equatoguinean government's belief that Spain had foreknowledge of the coup. Nevertheless, relations have since been cordial.

notes: Incumbent President Mbasogo won a landslide victory in the presidential elections. Mbasogo won over 95% of the vote, against some 3.6% for the main opposition candidate, Placido Mico Abogo, of the Convergence for Social Democracy Party (CPDS). Ever since a British mercenary, Simon Mann, attempted to topple Mbasogo with a failed coup in 2004- the country has been trying to rebrand itself as an emerging democracy to the West. Prior to the election, the president pardoned and freed Mann.
nelda3notes: It should be noted that although the government adopted a constitutional multiparty system in 1991, the president, Mbasogo, has kept a tight grip on power since becoming head of state in 1979.
nelda8notes: There are no term limits in Equatorial Guinea for the president.
nelda13notes: It should be noted that although opposition was allowed, it was pretty clear that the incumbent would win the election. Mbasogo is Sub-Saharan Africa's longest-serving head of state, having come to power in a violent military coup in 1979.
nelda16notes: The media is repressed by the government, which limits criticism of the regime. Equatorial Guinea tops the media freedom organization Reporters Without Borders' African League table for harassment and control of the press.
nelda17notes: The country is the third largest exporter of crude oil in sub-Saharan Africa. It has an extremely high poverty level; however, the perception is not any worse than it's been previously. The president even increased the minimum wage right a few months before the election, probably to boost his popularity.
nelda19notes: Equatorial Guinea received a large amount of foreign assistance from the West in the 1980s and 1990s, but since than many of these aid programs have ceased altogether or been diminished. Nevertheless, it is important to note that Spain, France, and the EU continue to provide some project assistance, as do China, Brazil, and Cuba.
nelda30notes: While there weren't riots after the election, there is wide evidence that suggests there was voter fraud.
nelda45notes: Observers invited to the election include the Central African Economic and Monetary Community, the Economic Community of Central African States, the EU, the Francophony International Organization, and the Institute for Democratic Studies in the US.
nelda48notes: Foreign journalists were refused visas to cover the event.
nelda53notes: Equatorial Guinea exports a large amount of crude oil to the Western world. It's important to note that most opposition elements to the government are based in Spain, and relations between the two countries grew difficult after a 2004 attempted coup due to Spain's hosting opposition figure Severo Moto and the Equatoguinean government's belief that Spain had foreknowledge of the coup. Nevertheless, relations have since been cordial, especially since the president released Moto in early November, prior to the presidential elections.
