notes: Presidential elections that were held in Gambia on November 24, 2011 resulted in the re-election of President Yahya Jammeh, of the ruling Alliance for Patriotic Reorientation and Construction (APRC), for the fourth consecutive five-year term in office. Jammeh initially took power in 1994 via a military coup, he was elected president in 1996, and re-elected in 2001, 2006, and now, 2011. According to official results, Jammeh received 71.5% of the vote. Ousainou Darboe of the United Democratic Party (UDP) received 17.4% of the vote, and Hamat Bah (an independent candidate who was supported by the opposition United Front) received 11.1% of the vote.
nelda5notes: Three candidates contested the presidential election in Gambia.
nelda15notes: President Jammmeh and the APRC party widely limited the ability of the opposition to effectively organize. Measures taken by the government included a decrease from 21 to an 11-day campaigning season. The government also repressed independent media and journalists, as well as threatened to forgo government resources to regions of the country that did not vote for the president in the upcoming election.
nelda28notes: There were widespread reports that were critical of the government; however, there's no evidence that suggests the populous was any more aware of these reports than they had been previously.
nelda45notes: manner. Observers from the Organization of Islamic Co-operation (OIC) were also present.
nelda50notes: Gambia's relations with the US, and with the West, in general, are not relatively good. This tumulus relationship has been marked by President Jammeh's repetitive human rights abuses and the lack of media freedom in the country.

notes: The legislative elections that were held on March 29, 2012 in Gambia resulted in the ruling Alliance for Patriotic Reorientation and Construction (APRC) maintaining its majority in the National Assembly. APRC won 43 out of 48 contested seats (there's a total of 53 seats in the unicameral legislature, but five of those seats are determined by presidential appointment). The National Reconciliation Party (NRP) won one seat and independent candidates won the four other seats. Six opposition parties boycotted the election, citing unfair manipulation of state resources and the media by the ruling party in order to secure their reelection. The Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) refused to send an observer mission to monitor elections because they deemed that the environment was unfair and that the elections wouldn't be fair. President Jammeh was recently reelected in November 2011. Jammeh is an interesting international figure, having claimed on record to be able to cure aids.
nelda11notes: ECOWAS refused to send an election monitoring mission because it deemed that the elections would not be free and fair.
nelda14notes: Six opposition parties (United Democratic Party, People's Progressive Party, People's Democratic Organization for Independence and Socialism, National Democratic Action Movement, Gambia Moral Congress, Gambia Party for Democracy and Progress, National Convention Party, and the National Alliance for Democracy and Development) boycotted the election stating that it was rigged in favor of the ruing party, APRD, and after a request to postpone the election was turned down.
nelda15notes: A fact-finding mission that was sent by ECOWAS in the months leading up to the election found that the ruling party was intimidating the opposition and controlling media outlets in an effort to skew the results of the election favorably in their direction.
nelda28notes: There's no evidence that suggests the electorate had access to widespread reports published by election observers from the AU that cited unfair election conditions.
nelda45notes: Monitors from the African Union (AU) and Commonwealth of Nations and Organization of Islamic Conference were present.
nelda49notes: Monitors from the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) refused to monitor the election because they deemed that the conditions didn't allow for it to be held freely and fairly. ECOWAS also criticized the African Union for sending monitors to the election.

notes: A relatively stable first round which heads to a runoff later in the year. This is the first election since a military coup d�etat earlier on in the decade, which saw a period of turbulence followed by a brief transitional government, headed by Traor� from the Alliance for Democracy in Mali. Overarching issues include the Malian economic crisis, price volatility, the role of the military in civilian affairs, and the state and health of other surrounding African nations. The latter is perhaps the most important, as the insurgents who destabilised the country in 2012 were largely armed by leftover weapons from the Libyan Civil War.

nelda12notes: Diouf was widely seen as the front-runner in the presidential election.

nelda12notes: The ruling PS was heavily favored to maintain its hold on its majority position within the National Assembly.
nelda17notes: In January 1994, Senegal undertook a bold and ambitious economic reform program with the support of the international donor community. This reform began with a 50% devaluation of Senegal's currency, the CFA franc.

nelda24notes: The ruling PS won 93 of the 140 seats in the National Assembly.

notes: This election resulted in a huge victory for the Sopi coalition, led by President Wade's PDS party. The election was boycotted by the major opposition parties.

notes: First round of two. The unofficial results for the 14 candidate race gave the incumbent, Wade, 35% and his number one challenger, Sall, 27%. Without an outright majority after the first round, Senegal requires a runoff.
nelda6notes: Shortly after Wade took power in 2000, a referendum was conducted in January 2001, after which Senegal adopted a new constitution. The Constitution, amongst other things, reduced the presidential term from seven to five years. This amendment was to take effect after Wade had completed his seven-year term in 2007. However, the 2001 Constitution was revised by Wade just a year after his 2007 re-election. Consequently, the former seven-year mandate was re-introduced while the shortened five-year term was discarded.
nelda9notes: The proper term limit for president is two terms, but the Constitutional Council approved Wade's running for a third term. At least six civilian deaths resulted from the pre-election protests.
nelda13notes: The Court invalidated three candidates
nelda14notes: A number of violent protest demonstrations broke out as a result of the court's granting Wade the chance to run for a third term
nelda33notes: According to Consultancy Africa Intelligence, the upshot of the nationwide protests (due to Wade's bid for a third term despite the constitutional term limit) thas been widespread pre-election related violence. The centre of Dakar, for instance, was plunged into violent incidents. Many buildings were set ablaze and a police officer died in the ensuing violence. At the Place de l�Ob�lisque, which is now associated with anti-Wade popular resistance, police reacted with tear gas to a peaceful protest organised by the M23 movement and joined by, amongst others, hundreds of ordinary citizens, opposition political parties as well as CSOs. A young woman was killed and many others were wounded as a result of the response from the police. A similar incident has been reported in the northern town of Podor, where the police opened fire on protesters resulting in the death of an old woman as well as a teenage boy.
nelda39notes: Not after the first round
nelda50notes: According to the US Department of State, Senegal enjoys an excellent relationship with the United States. The Government of Senegal is known and respected for its able diplomats and often has supported the United States in the United Nations, including with troop contributions for peacekeeping activities. The United States maintains friendly relations with Senegal and provides considerable economic and technical assistance. About 300 Senegalese students come to the United States each year for study.

notes: Second round of two. Sall replaces incumbent Wade amidst a peaceful election. This election victory is praised as a symblic feat for the successful democratization of Senegal.
nelda6notes: Shortly after Wade took power in 2000, a referendum was conducted in January 2001, after which Senegal adopted a new constitution. The Constitution, amongst other things, reduced the presidential term from seven to five years. This amendment was to take effect after Wade had completed his seven-year term in 2007. However, the 2001 Constitution was revised by Wade just a year after his 2007 re-election. Consequently, the former seven-year mandate was re-introduced while the shortened five-year term was discarded.
nelda9notes: The proper term limit for president is two terms, but the Constitutional Council approved Wade's running for a third term. At least six civilian deaths resulted from the pre-election protests.
nelda13notes: The Court invalidated three candidates
nelda14notes: A number of violent protest demonstrations broke out as a result of the court's granting Wade the chance to run for a third term
nelda33notes: According to Consultancy Africa Intelligence, the upshot of the nationwide protests (due to Wade's bid for a third term despite the constitutional term limit) thas been widespread pre-election related violence. The centre of Dakar, for instance, was plunged into violent incidents. Many buildings were set ablaze and a police officer died in the ensuing violence. At the Place de l�Ob�lisque, which is now associated with anti-Wade popular resistance, police reacted with tear gas to a peaceful protest organised by the M23 movement and joined by, amongst others, hundreds of ordinary citizens, opposition political parties as well as CSOs. A young woman was killed and many others were wounded as a result of the response from the police. A similar incident has been reported in the northern town of Podor, where the police opened fire on protesters resulting in the death of an old woman as well as a teenage boy.
nelda50notes: According to the US Department of State, Senegal enjoys an excellent relationship with the United States. The Government of Senegal is known and respected for its able diplomats and often has supported the United States in the United Nations, including with troop contributions for peacekeeping activities. The United States maintains friendly relations with Senegal and provides considerable economic and technical assistance. About 300 Senegalese students come to the United States each year for study.

notes: This was the first presidential election since Benin, then known as Dahomey, gained independence from France.
nelda1notes: Benin (then called Dahomey) became independent from France on August 1, 1960, and these were the first elections.
nelda19notes: Benin was very dependent on French foreign aid.
nelda33notes: There were riots the night before the election that led to two people being killed and even more injured.
nelda53notes: French aid was extremely important to this former colony.

notes: This election marked the transition from a military government to a civilian one. Only one party was allowed.
nelda1notes: A military coup occurred in October of the previous year.
nelda3notes: The electoral system awards the party with a plurality of votes all of the seats in the legislature.
nelda5notes: Only one party, the PDD, was allowed to submit a party list for the elections.
nelda6notes: The elections were early. The military coup in October forced early elections for a new government.
nelda7notes: The incumbency is the ruling transitional trifecta. They do not run in the elections. One cabinet member does and wins. However, the ruling Colonel Soglo is considered the incumbent, and thus he will be the person analyzed for all incumbency-related questions.
nelda9notes: The incumbency, the three heads of the three major parties overseen by the military, extended the future presidents' terms by eliminating limits
nelda10notes: The ruling trifecta, overseen by the military, planned to hold elections early in 1964.
nelda11notes: There was coercion and suppression. The electoral system also favors larger parties.
nelda13notes: Only one party was allowed to run.
nelda15notes: The three largest parties were all accused of continuing to suppress smaller opposition parties in various ways. In the end only one of the parties was allowed to field candidates.
nelda19notes: Benin was receiving Western aid.
nelda21notes: Colonel Soglo did not run. The deposed Maga also did not run, despite being in the transitional government
nelda27notes: The PDD, actually an opposition party, but because it was in the transitional government is an incumbent party, reentered government.
nelda50notes: Both the US and the USSR attempted to establish closer ties to the new country.
nelda54notes: Benin was a former colony of France, and it relies on aid from France. France also stations troops in the country.

notes: The incumbent, Apithy, was reelected.  The government of Maga had fallen due to his corruption and mismanagement of the economy, and a provisional military government had taken power.
nelda1notes: There had been a coup in October 1963, and then a provisional military government was put in place.
nelda11notes: Unlike the 1960 presidential elections, only Apithy, Maga's former Vice President  was a candidate (Maga had resigned in October 1963 over labor unrest and a military revolt).
nelda19notes: Benin's economy was doing poorly, and the country was still heavily dependent on France for aid.
nelda28notes: Although there was only one candidate, he was highly regarded and there is no evidence that there were reports critical of the government's handling of the election.
nelda51notes: Apithy was considered to be pro-Western.

nelda1notes: There were two military coups since 1965.
nelda4notes: The constitution of early 1968 calls for a one party state with competitve presidential elections.
nelda5notes: The military government chose five relatively unknown politicians for the presidency.
nelda6notes: The military governments never promised an election date.
nelda10notes: The military government had been in power for some years, and was not initially concerned with holding elections.
nelda11notes: Benin is a one party state, and candidates are selected by the military.
nelda12notes: The five candidates were unsure as to who would win.
nelda13notes: Any former President or Vice President of the Republic, President of the Assembly, or Prime Minister could not stand as a presidential candidate.
nelda14notes: On May 2, former  Presidents Maga and Apithy called for a boycott of the coming elections. 74% of the electorate did not show up to vote.
nelda17notes: The military government initiated neoliberal reforms. Benin was engulfed in an enormous debt.
nelda19notes: Benin was receiving Western aid.
nelda22notes: There were five chosen candidates.
nelda24notes: The military did not have a particular candidate.
nelda35notes: There was a wide spread boycott that led to only a few citizens voting--the elected candidate was illegitimate.
nelda37notes: A new election was held two months later.

nelda11notes: This was a referendum on continued rule. Benin is a one party state, and candidates are selected by the military.

notes: This election was set to run until March 31st, but was suspended  on March 28th by the military, and officially annulled on April 3rd.
nelda1notes: The military staged a coup in December 1969.  Moreover, these were the first elections were the populace voted individually - previously, the leader of their group or tribe had cast votes for the entire group
nelda4notes: While there was choice on the ballot between four candidates, there were no mentions of parties.
nelda5notes: There were four candidates, all of whom had been president previously for varying lengths of time.
nelda7notes: Although Souza, the leader of the military triumverate that ruled the country since the coup, did not run, few believed the election would really remove the military from power.
nelda11notes: There was speculation beforehand that the military would, as they indeed did, annul the election results.
nelda12notes: The army did not run in the election, and whether or not they planned from the beginning to annul the election is unclear.
nelda17notes: Under Zinsou, the president prior to the military coup, the economy had been doing slightly better, but Benin was still underdeveloped and poor.
nelda19notes: France gave Dahomey about 15 million in aid each year, including 3 million in direct budget subsidies - Dahomey's yearly budget was only around 32 million.
nelda21notes: Souza, the head of the military triumverate that had ruled since the 1969 coup, did not run.
nelda27notes: Maga, one of the four candidates, was expected to win.
nelda29notes: The military banned all assemblies and meetings the day after annulling the election results.
nelda30notes: The protests were against the annullment of the elections, not the election itself.
nelda32notes: The military cancelled the election part-way through, citing violence, thus there were no official results.  However, results would have only favored the opposition, since the incumbent did not run.
nelda33notes: There were numerous accounts of supporters killed or wounded, accounts which the army used to force the cancelling of the election.
nelda34notes: No results could have been favorable to Souza.
nelda39notes: Though the election was annulled, in May the military appointed a presidential council to rule, with the leading three candidates from the election to rotate through power, and Maga to be the first leader for two years.
nelda54notes: France, of which Dahomey was a former colony, had very close ties with Dahomey, for example, making up the yearly budget deficit that hovered around 10%.

notes: This was the first round of a two-round election.

nelda6notes: These were the first multiparty legislative elections.
nelda9notes: In 1984, the mandate of the presidency had been extended from three to five years. This had no effect on term limits (rules on term limits were not found).

nelda56notes: Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney pledged to increase aid to Benin following successful democratic elections.
nelda57notes: France and other external creditors forced radical political changes and the abandonment of Marxism-Leninism.

notes: Repolling was held in May due to irregularities.

nelda30notes: A number of candidates invaded polling stations in Cotonou, the capital city, accusing each other of fraud, and some voters, fed up with the lengthy procedures and delays, angrily tore up their voting cards and went home.

notes: Repolling was held in 13 constituencies.

notes: This was the first round of a two-round election.
nelda12notes: Kerekou was not expected to win.
nelda17notes: Benin is one of the fastest growing countries in Africa.
nelda25notes: The polls were not favorable in the sense that they showed a fairly contested election would occur.
nelda27notes: Following a first round in which Soglo beat Kerekou, Kerekou against expectations defeated Soglo in the run-off.
nelda29notes: The long delay in declaring a result triggered unrest on the streets and a political standoff. Somebody fired shots at the presidential palace, resulting in Soglo suddenly sacking his defense minister and taking personal command of the armed forces.
nelda47notes: Some allegations were made by observers of irregularities, some said that the election seemed to be legitimate.
nelda52notes: The U.S. Clinton Administration said it looked forward to a peaceful transfer of power and continued close bilateral cooperation with Benin. Whether this resulted in actual concrete change is doubtful.
nelda56notes: France stated that it will continue to help Benin in its democratic transition and economic restructuring aimed at improving the living standard of its people.

notes: This was the first round of a two-round election.

notes: Yayi defeats Houngbedji in election with over 53% of the votes, successfully avoiding a runoff election. The  opposition deemed the results as fraudelent, and protested heavily against the recognition of Yayi's reelection. The Constitutional Court of Benin confirmed Yayi's win.
nelda6notes: The election was postponed twice (originally scheduled to take place in February) because the constitutional court accepted the electoral commission's request for delays as a result of voting materials not being printed and election observers not being properly trained.
nelda18notes: Due to flooding in 2010, however, damage to the cotton fields caused increase food shortages and an expected lowering of GDP in 2011. Over 37% of the country is below the poverty line, making the economy a key election issue.
nelda28notes: Most claims concerning unfair election results stemmed from the opposition. Since the first reports of unofficial results indicated a win for Boni, the opposition leader has disputed Boni�s re-election. Houngb�dji claimed that the election was not fair due to the incomplete electoral roll and the shortages of ballots. He also alleged foul play by Boni as he reported instances in which ballot boxes were stuffed with pre-stamped ballots and cash payments were made to electoral officers for rigging the poll. Protests by Houngb�dji supporters occurred days after the Court�s announcement in the commercial capital of Cotonou. As a result some protesters, including a high-ranking opposition law-maker, were arrested and all public demonstrations were banned.
nelda47notes: The claims asserting voter fraud came from the opposition, whereas election monitors reported that the process was essentially peaceful and fair.

notes: The election was largely a victory for President Yayi. His coalition gained 14 more seats than it had in the previous legislative election, securing 41 seats of  87.
nelda6notes: Shortly before the beginning of the official parliamentary campaign, the Constitutional Court invalidated the candidature of some opposition candidates. The decision was challenged by the opposition parties. In order to resolve the disputes before the election campaign started and allow candidates to campaign for 15 days as required by the electoral law, the Election Commission postponed the parliamentary polls to 30 April. The term of the outgoing legislature ended on 22 April.�

notes: The electoral and political situation in Mauritania is rather complicated. It is spearheaded by a president, whose democratic legitimacy has been questioned by many opposition groups considering his dubious rise to power following political turbulence during the Arab Spring. This election itself was delayed multiple times, having been originally scheduled for 2011. Ultimately, most opposition groups boycott, leading to an overwhelming majority for President Aziz�s parliamentary group. Dominant issues include democratic legitimacy, the crisis, boosting productivity and promoting growth in rural areas, and addressing issues of transparency in the Mauritanian legal framework.
nelda6notes: Late

notes: An election which sees the incumbent, and questionably installed, President Aziz re-elected with over 80% of the vote. As in the 2013 parliamentary poll, most opposition parties boycott the vote entirely, leading to Aziz�s impressive re-election. His return is certainly helped by the existence of a rather biased media, as well as accounts of harassment and vote-tampering. The African Union observers and in their report praises the election for its peaceful nature, but only at times highlight the egregious malpractice which features more prominently in local reports.
nelda46notes: African Union observers did attend, and deemed the election peaceful albeit not fair.

nelda14notes: No opposition was allowed to run.

nelda19notes: The US, France, and other western countries supported Niger's budget.

nelda17notes: One of the poorest countries in the world, Niger's economy is based largely on subsistence crops, livestock, and some of the world's largest uranium deposits. Drought cycles, desertification, and a 3.3 percent population growth rate were stunting economic growth.
nelda24notes: The ruling party, MNSD, won the most seats in the National Assembly (29 of 83), however an opposition coalition came together following the election and formed a majority government.
nelda27notes: The ruling party, MNSD, won the most seats in the National Assembly (29 of 83), however an opposition coalition came together following the election and formed a majority government.
nelda28notes: Both the opposition and ruling party alleged fraud.
nelda33notes: The interim government guiding Niger to democracy after three decades of military or one-party rule feared armed attacks from the main rebel group, the Air and Azawak Liberation Front (FLAA). It accused the FLAA of destabilizing election conditions.
nelda45notes: 120 observers from the United States, France, Canada, the Organization of African Unity and other groups were monitoring the vote.
nelda51notes: U.S. relations with Niger have been close and friendly since Niger attained independence. A substantial U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) program in Niger focuses on agriculture and natural resource management as well as demography.
nelda54notes: Niger maintains a special relationship with France.

notes: These election were held over two days, from 07/07/1996 through 07/08/1996.

nelda29notes: The announcement of Mainassara's victory was met with violent protests in Niamey and other urban centres as Ousmane's supporters clashed with police. Tear gas was fired and hundreds of arrests were made.

nelda57notes: France cut off all aid as a result of the military coup and then stated that it awaited the restoration of democracy before it would restart aid to the Nigerien government, however on March 6 France announced the resumption of all civilian and military aid.
nelda58notes: The United States, France and Germany suspended aid to Niger after the January coup and demanded a return to democracy.

nelda6notes: Postponed from Sept 22 and then from Nov 10.
nelda12notes: With opposition parties boycotting the election and most of the independent parties running in support of the government, the ruling party had a robust expectation of victory.
nelda13notes: The Supreme Court invalidated 8 opposition political parties.
nelda14notes: In response to the invalidation of several opposition parties, the largest opposition parties announced a boycott of the election.
nelda15notes: Up until the beginning of October there was a ban on political gatherings and meetings, on the freedom of movement for opposition leaders, and on the freedom of opposition parties to organize.
nelda16notes: The ministry had also forbidden the press, including local correspondents for foreign media organisations, to quote opposition leaders, in the belief, observers say, that those who have chosen not to run in the election should not make too much fuss.
nelda24notes: The election resulted in a victory for the National Union of Independents for Democratic Renewal (UNIRD), close to President Ibrahim Barre Mainassara . UNIRD and its allies took 69 of the Assembly's 83 seats.
nelda46notes: Reportedly an observation mission from the EU monitored the election.
nelda50notes: A news report noted that the United States had not been convinced by what some Niamey observers were calling Mainassara's forced march towards democracy, and had limited their assistance to the humanitarian sector.
nelda53notes: A news report noted that France has boosted Niger's budget by 26 million dollars over the preceding five months. In June, the Bretton Woods institutions reported their approval. The International Monetary Fund signed a structural adjustment facility.

nelda52notes: The U.S. congratulated Niger on its successful holding of elections and noted that it looked forward to working with the people of Niger and the country's newly elected government. Relations with the USA appeared to improve, following.
nelda56notes: After the election, the French Government subsequently announced exceptional assistance to allow the payment of arrears. The EU suspended all assistance to Niger in the aftermath of the military take-over in April 1999 and made its resumption dependent on the reinstatement of democracy.
nelda57notes: Foreign donors reportedly were withholding almost all aid until Wanke restored democratic rule.
nelda58notes: Foreign donors reportedly were withholding almost all aid until Wanke restored democratic rule.

nelda12notes: Mamadou was widely seen as being in a good position to return to office.
nelda16notes: During the second half of 2003 increasing concern was expressed, both nationally and internationally, at apparent attempts to restrict the freedom of the press and broadcast media in Niger.
nelda17notes: Niger is a poor, landlocked Sub-Saharan nation, whose economy centers on subsistence agriculture, animal husbandry, and reexport trade, and increasingly less on uranium, because of declining world demand.
nelda24notes: Incumbent Mamadou Tandja won the second runoff round with 65.53% of the vote.
nelda46notes: There were observers from the UN and the International Organisation of the Francophonie.

notes: Note that sources conflict as to the correct date of these elections: while Keesing's and Europa list the election date as 12/04, the Election Results Archive, electionguide.org, and the Hyde elections list put the date as 11/16. News reports also referred to the December 4 parliamentary elections.
nelda11notes: The opposition accused the government prior to the election of preparing large-scale fraud.
nelda16notes: During the second half of 2003 increasing concern was expressed, both nationally and internationally, at apparent attempts to restrict the freedom of the press and broadcast media in Niger.
nelda17notes: Niger is a poor, landlocked Sub-Saharan nation, whose economy centers on subsistence agriculture, animal husbandry, and reexport trade, and increasingly less on uranium, because of declining world demand.
nelda24notes: At elections to the newly enlarged 113-seat Assembl�e nationale, held concurrently with the second round of voting in the presidential election, the MNSD won the largest number of seats, obtaining 47.
nelda27notes: The main opposition party PNDS increased its seat total from 16 to 25.
nelda28notes: The PNDS claimed that various electoral irregularities had occurred, including the use of state funds to finance the campaign of the MNSD.
nelda45notes: Observers came from the US, France, Germany, Niger, the European Union, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) and the Beninese Autonomous Electoral Commission (CENA).
nelda47notes: International observers said the elections were free and fair.

notes: These elections were held early, following a referendum that extended increased powers to the president. President Tandja had dissolved the previous National Assembly when they opposed the holding of this referendum. The MNSD coalition, supporting the president, won 76 (up from 47) of 113 seats. Real opposition boycotted this election.
nelda3notes: However, all the opposition boycotted.
nelda6notes: Held early after the referendum.
nelda14notes: All the major opposition parties boycotted.
nelda57notes: Niger's membership in the Economic Community of West African States was suspended due to the election, and the IMF, US and other nations suspended aid.
nelda58notes: ECOWAS, the US, the IMF and others threatened to (and did) suspend aid if elections were held, rather than delayed until they could be held democratically.

notes: The election followed a military coup in 2010 after the sitting president, Tandja, tried to extend his rule. PNDS won a plurality of seats, followed by MNS (Tandja's party). The former legislature had been disbanded after the military coup.
nelda1notes: President Tandja's term had ended in 2009 but he canceled elections and remained in power until he was deposed in a coup in 2010.
nelda6notes: The elections were scheduled for early January but were delayed because of logistical difficulties.
nelda11notes: Although there were worries, the election was generally predicted to be fair.
nelda19notes: Although much of the aid had stopped after the country faced sanctions after Tandja did not give up power.
nelda24notes: No party was associated with the ruling military.
nelda34notes: No party was associated with the military.
nelda43notes: The military leader in charge after the 2010 coup.
nelda47notes: Monitors were very pleased with the election, calling it a model for other countries returning to democracy.
nelda58notes: Sanctions were lifted by some groups following the elections, but there is no proof that the lifting of them was used to influence the election.

notes: The election was boycotted by most opposition groups
nelda13notes: Alassane Dramane Ouattara of the opposition RDR failed the electoral code's strict nationality and residence qualifications imposed on presidential candidates; it was widely believed that the code had been specifically drafted to exclude him.
nelda14notes: Candidates of the two main opposition parties, Laurent Gbagbo, leader of the leftist Ivorian Popular Front (FPI), and Dj�ny Kobina of the centrist Rally of Republicans (RDR), established in late 1994 by reformists, boycotted.
nelda15notes: An Ivorian court on June 7 upheld the conviction of two journalists, De Be Kwassi and Abou Cisse, at the opposition weekly La Patrie, for conspiring to give offence to the head of state. The two were sentenced to one year in prison.
nelda16notes: An Ivorian court on June 7 upheld the conviction of two journalists, De Be Kwassi and Abou Cisse, at the opposition weekly La Patrie, for conspiring to give offence to the head of state. The two were sentenced to one year in prison.

nelda33notes: Unrest after the October presidential election left some 35 people dead.

nelda47notes: They did not allege significant fraud, but noted that there were some areas of concern and called on the Ivory Coast to correct and improve the electoral process.

notes: The election was boycotted by some opposition candidates and marked by low voter turnout
nelda6notes: Delayed from Sept 17.
nelda13notes: In early October 2000 the Supreme Court announced that only five of the 19 candidates for the presidential election complied with the conditions of eligibility. Those whose candidacies were rejected included Ouattara and Emile Constant Bombet.
nelda14notes: Leaders of the PDCI�RDA and the RDR urged an electoral boycott in protest at the Supreme Court�s decision.
nelda17notes: Cote d'Ivoire is among the world's largest producers and exporters of coffee, cocoa beans, and palm oil. Consequently, the economy is highly sensitive to fluctuations in international prices for these products and to weather conditions.
nelda24notes: Preliminary results indicated that Gbagbo had received a greater percentage of votes cast than Gue�. However, on 24 October the Ministry of the Interior and Decentralization announced the dissolution of the national electoral commission.
nelda31notes: Protestors following the election were dispersed by soldiers and military police firing machine guns and tear gas.
nelda33notes: A student died after being thrown from an apartment window prior to the election due to political violence. Also prior to the election a bomb exploded in the capital, killing 4 people and wounding many others.
nelda41notes: The Government claimed that certain, unspecified, political parties had perpetrated electoral fraud, and announced that, following the readjustment of the results, Gue�, with 52.7% of the votes cast, had defeated Gbagbo.
nelda49notes: The United Nations, the Organization of African Unity, the European Union and countries such as the United States and Canada withdrew election observers or funding, saying the exclusion of major opponents had made a truly free and fair election impossible.
nelda50notes: Cote d'Ivoire's relations with the U.S. have traditionally been excellent, but have been somewhat strained since Section 508 restrictions curtailed nonhumanitarian aid following the December 1999 military coup.
nelda56notes: Relations with France, the country�s principal trading partner and provider of bilateral assistance, have been close since independence. French reaction to Gbagbo�s election as President in October 2000 was divided, largely along party lines.
nelda57notes: Section 508 restrictions curtailed U.S. nonhumanitarian aid following the December 1999 military coup. The restrictions were not lifted following the 2000 elections due to questionable governmental interference before and during the election.
nelda58notes: The United States condemned the exclusion of 14 presidential candidates from Ivory Coast's election, and said it was suspending assistance to vote preparations. The United States urged other donor nations to follow suit.

notes: Parliamentary elections were held in Cote D'Ivoire on December 11, 2011. An armed mutiny by the military in 2002 escalated into a full-scale rebellion that had to be brokered by a UN-peace agreement to stop the violence. Presidential elections that were held in 2010 led to a win for Alassane Outtara, but his opponent and incumbent Laurent Gbagbo refused to concede defeat. A four-month stand-off resulted in a civil war that left thousands dead. It was only after the forcible arrest and removal of Gbagbo to the International Criminal Court that Outtara could become president. Gbagbo's Ivoirian Popular Front (FPI) withdrew from contesting these parliamentary elections as a result of what they considered Gbagbo's illegall transfer to the ICC. The parliamentary elections resulted in a win for Outtara's Rally Republicans (RDR) with 127 out of 255 seats. The government allied Democratic Party of Cote d'Ivoire-African Democratic Rally (PDCI-RDA) won 77 seats.
nelda1notes: An armed rebellion in 2002 broke the relatively stable peace in the Ivory Coast. Since then, peace deals and renewed violence have marked the political transition.
nelda6notes: Elections were not regular. After an armed rebellion in 2002 that plunged the country into violence, it took prolonged peace agreements and UN support in order for presidential elections to be held in 2010. These parliamentary elections were only held after the presidential elections and the newly instated president could quell civil violence.
nelda10notes: The country was ruled by transitional leadership until the presidential elections were held.
nelda14notes: Former president Gbagbo's FPI party withdrew from the elections, as well as from the country's national reconciliation process, as a result of what they consider Gbagbo's illegal transfer to the ICC.
nelda33notes: Five civilians died in pre-election violence; however, post-election violence was virtually non-existent, partly because of the large amount of security that was allocated to polling stations during election day.
nelda50notes: The election of Alassane Ouattara was welcomed by the West, particularly France, who helped oust the former president after he refused to concede defeat.

notes: President Ouattara wins in a landslide against a fragmented opposition, parts of which boycott the poll due to their belief that it will be rigged and fraudulent. Ouattara, who took power in 2010, runs on his economic record, the rise of international investment in the Ivory Coast, and the relative peace which has taken hold of the country since the crises of 2011. While observers deem the election clean and fair, there are concerns on the local level about media narratives as well as corruption, which some say may have inflated Ouattara�s margin or altered the outcome.

nelda18notes: But, Burkina Faso remains one of the world�s poorest countries, ranking 161 out of 169 countries in the 2010 UNDP Human Development Index, with a per capita gross domestic product (GDP) of $580. About 80% of the population relies on subsistence agriculture, with only a small fraction directly involved in industry and services.
nelda19notes: From 2008 to 2009, annual assistance amounts more than tripled to $1.3 billion, and annual per capita assistance was estimated in 2009 at $81.
nelda50notes: U.S. relations with Burkina Faso are excellent. In addition to regional peace and stability, U.S. interests in Burkina are to promote continued democratization and greater respect for human rights and to encourage sustainable economic development. The signing of the MCC Compact Program made the United States Burkina Faso�s largest bilateral donor. Bilateral U.S. assistance in fiscal year 2011 was $22.25 million.

nelda1notes: Very little information is available about the regular holding of elections for seats in the Senate and the House of Representatives. However, sources seem to suggest that general elections had not been held for eight years, which contradicts the rotation of Senate seats every six years, and House of Representative seats every four years.
nelda3notes: Because the Reformation Party did not register their candidates with the Elections Commission sixty days before the election as was legally required, they were disqualified from the race. Petitions to hold the elections a few days later so that they could participate were rejected. Furthermore, it is subject to doubt whether, even if they had registered on time, the Reformation Party would have been allowed run.
nelda9notes: The Barclay amendment to the Constitution in 1935 was recently replaced by Tubman's own amendment, which imposed no limitation on four-year renewable terms after an initial term of eight years.
nelda12notes: They were the sole party running.
nelda13notes: Tubman resorted to an extreme legal technicality to disqualify Twe from running, first with the new United People's Party, and then with the legally recognized Reformation Party.
nelda15notes: Many of Twe's followers were jailed in the lead up to, and aftermath of, the elections. Twe himself was charged with sedition, and fled the country.
nelda16notes: Local newspapers and radio stations were used to denounce Twe and his followers, while being off-limits when it came to a response from Twe.
nelda17notes: National revenue had jumped from one million to ten million this year.
nelda19notes: The US gave a lot of aid to Liberia.
nelda27notes: Opposition was legally and officially absent, though the Reformation Party was actively rallying against Tubman.
nelda28notes: David Twe brought a case aginst the government's handling of the elections to court, as well as to the attention of the UN. Tubman's control of propaganda; however, and his relative popularity, prevented these allegations from being particularly disruptive.
nelda48notes: The failed opposition candidate David Twe did appeal to the UN to send election monitors, but his pleas fell on deaf ears; the UN never agreed to come.
nelda55notes: The UN and the US turned a blind eye to the undemocratic proceedings that suppressed opposition during these elections, and maintained the traditional friendly relationship.

notes: The True Whig Party (TWP) came to power in 1878 and ruled a de facto one-party government for over a century. The TWP's domination of the country's political system was characterized by considerable domestic stability, and Chief Executive William Tubman reigned as incumbent President rom 1944 - 1971. These elections were for his second term. He ran unopposed, though the newly formed aboriginal Reformation Party had intended to put forward Twe as a candidate, but was refused on the grounds that they had not registered in time. These were also the first elections that allowed women to vote, and if Twe had run a large aboriginal vote may have overwhelmed President Tubman.
nelda3notes: Because the Reformation Party did not register their candidacy for the Presidency to the Elections Commission sixty-days before the election as was legally required, they were disqualified from the race. Petitions to hold the elections a few days later so that they could participate were rejected. Furthermore, it is subject to doubt whether, even if they had registered on time, the Reformation Party would have been allowed run.
nelda9notes: The Barclay amendment to the Constitution in 1935 was recently replaced by Tubman's own amendment, which imposed no limitation on four-year renewable terms after an initial term of eight years.
nelda12notes: They were the sole party running.
nelda13notes: Tubman resorted to an extreme legal technicality to disqualify Twe from running, first with the new United People's Party, and then with the legally recognized Reformation Party.
nelda16notes: Local newspapers and radio stations were used to denounce Twe and his followers, while being off-limits when it came to a response from Twe.
nelda17notes: National revenue had jumped from one million to ten million this year.
nelda27notes: Tubman ran unopposed.
nelda28notes: Twe brought a case aginst the government's handling of the elections to court, as well as to the attention of the UN. Tubman's control of propaganda; however, and his relative popularity, prevented these allegations from being particularly disruptive.
nelda48notes: The failed opposition candidate Twe did appeal to the UN to send election monitors, but his pleas fell on deaf ears; the UN never agreed to come.
nelda55notes: The UN and the US turned a blind eye to the undemocratic proceedings that suppressed opposition during these elections, and maintained the traditional friendly relationship.

nelda16notes: President Tubman banned for example The Independent Weekly, a newspaper critical of his adminsitration. The Independent Weekly has been stongly supporting Independent Whig Party Presidential candidate Edwin Barclay.
nelda17notes: Rubber exports are the main source of public revenue for Liberia, but payments from this sector dropped by a third in the preceeding year. Timber income had also been lower than expected. Due to growing American and foreign investment, predictions that economic growth would soon be good were being made.
nelda19notes: Founded originally by former American slaves, Liberia has preserved a strong relationship with the US, and at this point was receiving millions of dollars in aid, as well as structural help in the form of education, health care, transport lines, and even army resources.
nelda20notes: The President was elected separately in concurrent elections.
nelda28notes: Barclay released a public statement to the nation, acuusing Tubman of election-rigging.
nelda33notes: A leading figure of Barclay's opposition party ITWP was killed by police, along with his son, while fleeing the capital after being accused of plotting to assassinate incumbent Tubmen after the election.
nelda50notes: Tubman's visit to the U.S. earlier in the year had increased aid totalling more than $20 million and 'technical assistance' to Liberia.
nelda53notes: After Tubman's visit to the US, WHO presence and malaria-programmes in Liberia stepped up.
nelda54notes: The head of the National Public Health Service in Liberia was made the WHO President.

notes: Liberia's  constitution was modeled after that of the USA with a strong President and a bicameral Congress. The True Whig Party (TWP) came to power in 1878 and ruled in de facto one-party government for over a century. The TWP's domination of the country's political system was characterized by considerable domestic stability, and Chief Executive William Tubman reigned as incumbent from 1944 - 1971. These elections were contested by incumbent President Tubman, former President Barclay from the newly formed Independent True Whig Party, and an independent candidate. Barclay won 0.5% of the vote, and independent candidate reportedly won a total of 16 votes. This was a heated election, as President Barclay had been responsible for Tubman's original rise to power.
nelda8notes: At this time in Liberia, the President was elected for an initial eight years, and then could be re-elected for an indefinite number of four year terms. President Tubman was running for his third term.
nelda9notes: The Barclay amendment to the Constitution in 1935 was replaced by Tubman's own amendment, which imposed no limitation on four-year renewable terms after an initial term of eight years.
nelda16notes: President Tubman banned for example The Independent Weekly, a newspaper critical of his adminsitration. The Independent Weekly has been stongly supporting Independent Whig Party Presidential candidate Edwin Barclay.
nelda17notes: Rubber exports are the main source of public revenue for Liberia, but payments from this sector dropped by a third in the preceeding year. Timber income had also been lower than expected. Due to growing American and foreign investment, predictions that economic growth would soon be good were being made.
nelda19notes: Founded originally by former American slaves, Liberia has preserved a strong relationship with the US, and at this point was receiving millions of dollars in aid, as well as structural help in the form of education, health care, transport lines, and even army resources.
nelda28notes: Barclay released a public statement to the nation, accusing Tubman of election-rigging.
nelda33notes: A leader of the opposition party ITWP was killed by police, along with his son, while fleeing the capital after being accused of plotting to assassinate incumbent Tubmen after the election.
nelda50notes: Tubman's visit to the U.S. earlier in the year had increased aid totalling more than $20 million and 'technical assistance' to Liberia.
nelda53notes: After Tubman's visit to the US, WHO presence and malaria-programmes in Liberia stepped up.
nelda54notes: The head of the National Public Health Service in Liberia was made the WHO President.

nelda6notes: House and Senate elections were held in 1951. House elections are constitutionally supposed to be held every four years, and Senate elections every six years. It is somewhat unclear why Senate elections were being held in 1959, as they had been held in 1951. Evidence for why Senate elections were not held in 1957 cannot be found. Mention of House elections in 1955 are also scant.

nelda19notes: Particularly in four years prior, Liberia received much economic and structural aid from the US, and as of this year, West Germany.
nelda27notes: There was no opposition to speak of.
nelda28notes: The election passed with little dissent or event.

nelda1notes: Liberia held elections since 1847, and the presidential term was changed in 1975 to a limit of a single term of 8 years. In 1980, Samuel K. Doe took over the government through a military coup and had run the country since.
nelda3notes: Doe established considerable obstacles to registration of the five main parties, including a required fee of $50,000 plus $100,000 security needed to contest the elections. Only the four major opposition parties were able to clear these hurdles.
nelda7notes: Samuel Doe, who ruled the country since his 1980 coup, ran again.
nelda11notes: Liberia's civilian politicians were anxious that elections to return the country to civilian rule this year may be sabotaged by Doe. Political leaders appealed to the United States to lead a Western initiative to observe the election run-up.
nelda13notes: Stringent regulations were enacted, allegedly after Doe realized that he did not possess the popular majority. Doe barred the two most popular opposition parties, the United People's Party and Liberian People's Party, from appearing on the ballot.
nelda14notes: Opponents of Doe threatened to boycott the election by telling their supporters not to vote if they are not allowed to monitor the counting. However, the opposition never carried out the threat.
nelda15notes: Doe imprisoned several opposition leaders for assassination attempts. However, some of these allegations were met with skepticism. Later, Doe released some of the political opposition leader's alleged to have been planning an assassination.
nelda16notes: Doe enjoyed the support of the government-controlled media. The only posters seen in the capital city of Monrovia supported Doe with slogans like ''Son of the Soil'' and ''The People's Choice.''
nelda17notes: Following the coup of 1980, the country's economic growth rate slowed down because of a decline in the demand for iron ore on the world market and political upheavals in Liberia.
nelda18notes: The economy was increasingly deteriorating.
nelda19notes: The country, with a population of only 1.9 million is, per capita, Washington's top aid recipient in Africa. Disbursements have increased from about $9 million a year at the time Gen Doe came to power to about $78 million in 1983.
nelda28notes: Opposition leaders criticized Doe's handling of the elections throughout the entire electoral process.
nelda30notes: All three opposition parties alleged significant vote fraud. Rebel troups engaged in battle with government forces in Monrovia in an attempted coup.
nelda31notes: The government used military force to kill and arrest the rebel troups.
nelda45notes: The US government monitored the elections, dispatching nine observer teams to Liberia.
nelda47notes: Initially, both government officials and opposition party leaders said that in many of the country's 1,800 polling locations voting was completed without violence or major violations of election rules.
nelda50notes: In the early 1980s, the United States provided Liberia more than $500 million for pushing the Soviet Union out of the country, and for providing the US exclusive rights to use Liberia's ports and land.
nelda51notes: Because the election was not deemed free and fair, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously passed a nonbinding resolution urging the Reagan Administration to suspend military assistance until new elections are held.
nelda57notes: The U.S. government, which is by far Liberia's largest foreign aid donor, monitored the voting. Congress demanded that U.S. assistance, $86 million this year, be withheld if the election was not found free and fair.
nelda58notes: In 1984, the US gave $83 million in foreign aid, covering fully a third of Liberia's budget, in return for free, multi-party elections.

notes: As in the 2005 elections, no party secured a majority in the parliamentary elections. President Sirleaf's UP came in first in the House elections, taking 24 seats. The CDC followed with 11. The LP, the NUDP and the National Democratic Coalition (NDC) took seven, six and five seats respectively. Six other parties took fewer than three seats each and the remainder went to nine independent candidates. In the Senate, the UP and NPP came in first, taking four seats each. The CDC took two and five other parties took one seat each.�
nelda13notes: Predictions indicated that the race would be extremely tight between Sirleaf and Tubman.
nelda14notes: Although the opposition did not boycott this round, Tubman would call supporters to boycott the second round.
nelda26notes: Predictions indicated that the race would be extremely tight between Sirleaf and Tubman, and that a runoff election would be likely.
nelda27notes: Sirleaf's Unity Party gained more seats than it had in 2005.
nelda29notes: CDC supporters rallied behind Tubman to protest the first round of elections. Tubman also announced an official boycott of the second round.
nelda30notes: Tubman denounced the first round of elections as fradulent.
nelda34notes: The National Elections Commission called for a peaceful continuation of the election, upholding the results from the first round as free and fair.
nelda47notes: The main international observation missions were headed by the Carter Center, Electoral Institute for Sustainable Democracy in Africa and the Economic Community of West African States. All international and domestic observation groups reported favorably on the conduct of the general elections, finding them to be orderly, transparent, and peaceful.
nelda54: Liberia is a founding member of the United Nations and its specialized agencies and is a member of the African Union (AU), the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the African Development Bank (ADB), the Mano River Union (MRU), and the Non-Aligned Movement

notes: Neither incumbent Sirleaf of the Unity Party nor opponent Tubman of the Congress for Democratic Change won a majority, so a runoff election would ensue. Sirleaf is Africa's only female president and was just awarded the Nobel Prize for helping to stabilize her war-torn nation; Tubman, a technocrat, is her chief opponent running with popular former FIFA World Player of the Year, Weah. After the first round of elections, Tubman told his supporters that he had evidence of widespread fraud and voting irregularities, calling for a boycott of the runoff election. Sirleaf called on Liberians to ignore the boycott and the National Elections Commission said the rnoff would go ahead as planned.

notes: This was the first election under the new consitution, following 13 years of military rule. It marked a relatively smooth transition from a military regime to a democracy. This round coding refers to the Senate elections.
nelda1notes: The country had been under military rule since 1966, but prior to that had been a democracy from 1960-1966. The new constitution, however, changed the government from a parliamentary system to a bicameral legislature and elected president base.
nelda6notes: The elections were not regular, but instead represented the transition from a military dictatorship back to a democracy.

nelda12notes: The military government had given up power.

nelda1notes: These were the first civilian elections in 9 years of military government.
nelda3notes: Only two government-created and sponsored parties were legal political parties.
nelda4notes: However, only two parties were legally permitted by the government; in the spring of 1989, political activity was again permitted. In October 1989 the government decreed the establishment of two grassroots parties.
nelda6notes: Elections were early; they had been scheduled for November 7, 1992, but were pushed forward to July 4.
nelda10notes: Nigeria at this time was ruled by a military government going through a transition phase to civilian administration. The date of the Third Republic, as the civilian government was to be called, was set for January 2, 1993.
nelda11notes: Only two government-created and sponsored parties were able to contest the election; several prominent human rights and democracy activists were detained in the run-up to the election.
nelda12notes: Both parties were created and funded by the government. Additionally, because this is the first election for the National Assembly, there was no ruling or incumbent party.
nelda13notes: Given that only two government-allowed parties were allowed to contest the election, other opposition parties were not legal and could not compete, preventing other potential opposition leaders from running.
nelda15notes: Several prominent human rights and pro-democracy advocates were arrested on charges of inciting riots that accompanied anti-government student demonstrations in mid-May 1992.
nelda24notes: In the 91-seat Senate, the SDP (Social Democrat Party) won 52 seats, its nominally conservative opponent the National Republican Convention (NRC) won 37 seats, and two by-elections were ordered. In the 593-member House of Representatives, the SDP dominated as well.
nelda33notes: Outbreaks of anti-government protests and of religious violence in several parts of the country in May left up to 300 people dead. The first series of riots began in Lagos on May 4 when commuters protested against a 500 per cent fare increase, and continued due to electoral malpractice.

nelda28notes: On June 24 Abiola proclaimed himself as president-elect and urged the international community to back him against the military. At the same time the Campaign for Democracy issued a call for a campaign of civil disobedience to force the NDSC to hand power to a civilian government.
nelda29notes: In late June there were reports of outbreaks of unrest in northern and western states. Political unrest, precipitated by the annulment of the June presidential elections, continued during July with pro-democracy campaigners.
nelda30notes: There were no allegations of vote fraud; protestors decried the annulment of the election.
nelda31notes: Riot police killed at least 11 protestors.
nelda32notes: Polling took place as scheduled for presidential elections in early June, but the elections were subsequently annulled by the ruling military junta, the National Defence and Security Council (NDSC), led by Gen. Ibrahim Babangida.
nelda33notes: In protests following the election annulment, riot police killed at least 11 demonstrators.

nelda51notes: On June 23, two days after the NEC had lodged an appeal against the Abuja High Court ruling with the Federal Court of Appeal in Kaduna, the NDSC junta announced that the presidential elections had been annulled.
nelda55notes: The annulment of the election attracted international criticism, particularly from the USA and the United Kingdom, which announced the imposition of military sanctions against Nigeria.

nelda3notes: In June 1996, legislation governing the formation of political parties was promulgated. Five of 15 political organizations that applied for registration were granted legal status in September. NADECO condemned the disqualification of the remaining 10.
nelda12notes: Following the rise to power of Abacha in 1993, he eliminated the previous two government-created parties. On 17 November 1993, following a meeting with senior military officials, Shonekan resigned as Head of State and immediately transferred power.
nelda13notes: Only 5 government-approved parties could run.
nelda14notes: Opposition leaders called for a boycott of the legislative elections even though they themselves could not contest the election.
nelda15notes: In March 1998 a number of associations that supported Abacha conducted rallies in favour of his re-election in August. UAD, a loose alliance of pro-democracy and human rights organizations, the United Action of Democracy, organized counter-demonstrations.
nelda24notes: No information regarding the vote tally could be found, but initial results showed that the United Nigeria Congress Party (UNCP) was likely to achieve a comfortable majority. All 5 parties, however, were seen as pro-government parties, with no real opposition.
nelda27notes: No actual opposition was allowed to legally run or even exist as a political party.
nelda29notes: At least seven people were killed on May 1 after police in the south-western city of Ibadan opened fire on demonstrators who were reportedly trying to set fire to a building. The protesters were estimated to number some 5,000.
nelda30notes: The protests did not appear to allege vote fraud, but rather seemed to express anger and criticism of the Abacha regime at large.
nelda31notes: At least 7 were killed when police opened fire on the demonstrators.
nelda33notes: Shortly before the election the Agence France-Presse news agency reported on April 24 that nine people had been killed in two bomb attacks on April 23-24. One bomb exploded in the south-western town of Ife-Ife.
nelda45notes: No information regarding international observers could be found.
nelda57notes: The limited sanctions regime imposed by the Commonwealth, the EU, and the US continued, albeit some had commented that the sanctions had begun to fray.
nelda58notes: The Commonwealth warned Nigeria that unless it continued its transition to democracy, further international sanctions and expulsion from the Commonwealth were possible. Nigeria's suspension from the Commonwealth continued, however.

nelda1notes: The previous election results were annulled following Abacha's death, and the National Assembly and the five legally permissible parties dissolved.
nelda6notes: Nigeria's election cycle could no longer be called regular.
nelda10notes: On Feb 1, a 10-person committee was set up to oversee the transition from military to civilan governance.
nelda12notes: Following Abacha's death and the ascension of Abubakar to head of state, Abubakar announced that the transition to civilian rule would be completed on 29 May 1999 (rather than 1 October 1998). The Government annulled the results of the election.
nelda17notes: The oil-rich Nigerian economy continued to be hobbled by political instability, corruption, and poor macroeconomic management. Nigeria's unpopular military rulers had failed to make significant progress in diversifying the economy away from oil.
nelda19notes: Just prior to the election, in late January, Nigeria announced an agreement on an economic programme had been reached with the IMF. The deal, which healed a 10-year rift between Nigeria and the IMF, was expected to be approved at an IMF meeting.
nelda24notes: There was no incumbent party to speak of; the PDP, however, as forecasted, won easily, emerging with majorities in both the National Assembly and in the Senate.
nelda26notes: Victories in the state and municipal elections, however, meant that the PDP (People's Democratic Party) was widely seen as the frontrunner in the legislative election.
nelda27notes: The opposition party PDP emerged with majorities in both houses of the legislature.
nelda45notes: The Commonwealth sent a 23-member observation team to monitor the legislative and presidential elections.
nelda47notes: Although the Commonwealth observation team noted that there were irregularities and serious shortcomings, they were not so substantial as to call the outcome into question. The U.S., too, commented that the elections were peaceful and generally satisfactory.
nelda50notes: After a period of increasingly strained relations, the death of General Abacha in June 1998 and his replacement by General Abubakar opened a new phase of improved bilateral relations. As the transition to democracy progressed, the removal of various sanctions progressed.

nelda1notes: Nigeria had had a series of coups, including one in 1993 after the previous elections. These 1999 elections were the first since that coup.

nelda56notes: The day that Obasanjo was inaugurated, May 29, the Commonwealth readmitted Nigeria as a full member. UK Foreign and Commonwealth Secretary Robin Cook arrived in Nigeria on March 8 at the start of a three-day visit, as a sign of improving relations.

notes: Legislative elections were held in Nigeria on April 9, 2011 after being delayed twice. The elections were originally supposed to be held on April 2. The elections to the 85-seat Senate and the 279-seat House of Representatives resulted in a win for the ruling People's Democractic Party (PDP). They won 53 seats in the Senate and 152 seats in the House of Represenatives. The Action Congress (AC) came in second in  with 18 seats in the Senate and 53 seats in the House of Representatives. And the CPC came in third, with six seats in the former, and 31 seats in the latter. Despite securing a plurality, the PDP actually lost its two-thirds majority in the Senate. The perception was that the AC (despite not winning the election) did significantly better than was expected, and was more successful than it had been in the previous election. The AC picked up seats lost by the PDP, and secured its place as the main opposition party. This election, relative to the ones held in 2007, 2003, and 1999, displayed the vulnerability of the PDP, proving that the ruling party isn't invincible.
nelda6notes: The elections  were late. They were originally scheduled for April 2, but were delayed twice by the Independent National Election Commission because of difficulties associated with getting materials to the polling stations.
nelda11notes: Even though there was significant violence prior to the elections, relative to previous elections there was a perception that these elections would be relatively better than those held in 2007, 2003, and 1999. One of the reasons that this perception existed was because the Chairman of the INEC (Independent National Electoral Commission), Prof Attahiru Jega, was considered very competent and fair in ensuring elections were held in a free and fair environment.
nelda26notes: Election polls that were held prior to the election were favorable toward the ruling party. Polls conducted by Nigerian newspapers predicted that the PDP and the president would win reelection in the upcoming parliamentary and presidential elections.
nelda33notes: ). Fannami Gubio was an ANPP candidate in the forthcoming gubernatorial elections that were schedued to be held shortly after legislative elections. The sect also conduced four bomb explosions and attacks against churches in late December. Also, at least 11 people died in a stampede during an election campaign rally for President Goodluck Jonathan (who was running for re-election: presidential elections were held a few days after the parliamentary election). On the eve of the parliamentary elections, 13 people were killed by a bomb in the INEC's office in Suleja, near the capital, Abuja. Human Rights Watch also reported that more than 85 people have been killed in political violence in Nigeria since the start of November. While not directly related to the legislative election, it should still be noted that widespread post- election violence erupted in northern Nigeria, and over 1000 people were killed. International observers cited that the violence was in response to the presidential election, which was held a few days after these legislative elections. It's also important to note that the violence and political violence in the run-up to the elections was not a reflection of organized conflict between the main political parties, but rather the result of localized struggles for power between rival politicians.
nelda47notes: While not held without irregularities, these elections were considered to be one of the most successful elections held in Nigeria.
nelda54notes: Nigeria is a key supplier of oil to the United States.

notes: A presidential election was held in Nigeria on April 16, 2011 (originally scheduled for April 9, 2011). Incumbent president Jonathan Goodluck of the People's Democratic Party (PDP) won re-election with 58.89% of the vote. Muhammadu Bugari of the Congress for Progressive Change (CPC) came in second with 31.98% of the vote, and Nuhu Ribadu of the Action Congress (AC) came in third with 5.41% of the vote.
nelda7notes: Jonathan Goodluck won the PDP's primary in January, to become the party's presidential candidate. Goodluck's decision to run for re-election was controversial because there's an informal agreement within the PDP that power should sit with a northerner for two terms before it's returned to the south. Incumbent President Jonathan Goodluck is a southern Christian who assumed the presidency in 2010, following the death of then President Umaru Yar'Adua (a northern Muslim).
nelda11notes: Even though there was significant violence prior to the elections, relative to previous elections there was nevertheless a perception that these elections would be relatively better than those held in 2007, 2003, and 1999. One of the reasons that this perception existed was because the Chairman of the INEC (Independent National Electoral Commission), Prof Attahiru Jega, was considered very competent and fair in ensuring elections were held in a free and fair environment.
nelda26notes: Election polls that were held prior to the election were favorable toward the ruling party. Polls conducted by Nigerian newspapers predicted that the PDP and the president would win reelection in the upcoming parliamentary and presidential elections.
nelda29notes: Protests occurred in the north after the re-election of Jonathan Goodluck. At least 1,000 people died in election-related violence.
nelda31notes: I could not find any evidence that the government had used violence against protesters. This is very likely to be because the violence was not marked by clashes between the government and opposition parties, but rather localized struggles among citizens who were dissatisfied with the re-election of Jonathan Goodluck and those that were not.
nelda33notes: ). Fannami Gubio was an ANPP candidate in the forthcoming gubernatorial elections that were scheduled to be held shortly after legislative elections. The sect also conduced four bomb explosions and attacks against churches in late December. Also, at least 11 people died in a stampede during an election campaign rally for President Goodluck Jonathan. On the eve of the parliamentary elections, 13 people were killed by a bomb in the INEC's office in Suleja, near the capital, Abuja. Human Rights Watch also reported that more than 85 people have been killed in political violence in Nigeria since the start of November. Also widespread post- election violence erupted in northern Nigeria, and over 1000 people were killed. International observers cited that the violence was in response to the presidential elections. It's also important to note that the violence and political violence in the run-up to the elections was not a reflection of organized conflict between the main political parties, but rather the result of localized struggles for power between rival politicians.
nelda47notes: While not held without irregularities, these elections were considered to be one of the most successful elections held in Nigeria.
nelda54notes: Nigeria is a key supplier of oil to the United States.

notes: The president of Gabon, Omar Bongo, died on June 8th, and as a result (as per the constitution) he was replaced on an interim basis by the president of the Senate, Rogombe. New elections are constitutionally required to be held within within 45 days, so the interim government requested that the Constitutional Court  extend (and it did) the deadline because the interim government, under the circumstances couldn't immediately hold elections. The elections resulted in the victory of Bongo's son, Ali-Ben Bongo. There was widespread violence as a result of the elections because of allegations of voter fraud.
nelda1notes: The incumbent president, Bongo, died on June 30th. According to the constitution, the head of the Senate, Rogombe became interim president and was tasked with holding new elections within 30-45 days. However, the elections were late because the interim government asked the constitutional court to allow for a delay, given the circumstances and time crunch and the need to revise voter polls in a country that hadn't held presidential elections in a record 41 years.
nelda6notes: because the elections were not regular, given that they were brought about because of the death of the former president.
nelda7notes: The country was ruled by an interim government, in which the interim president was not allowed to run the presidential elections they were responsible for conducting.
nelda8notes: The incumbent, Interim President Rogombe,  was running the presidential elections and was not allowed to contest the elections; and thus his term limit was until new elections could be held.
nelda10notes: The previous president, Bongo, died on June 8th, thus in accordance with the constitution, he was replaced on an interim basis by the president of the Senate, Rose Francine Rogombe, on June 10th, until new elections were held on August 30th.
nelda16notes: The incumbent didn't contest the elections
nelda17notes: The world economy was in the wake of the recession that started in 2008, and oil price fluctuations had affected Gabon's economy; yet, Gabon had still retained a GDP surplus. Nevertheless, fluctuations in world oil prices had caused a dip in the country's surplus, and they'd forced the government to reduced spending. Furthermore, political uncertainty as a result of Bongo's death was perceived as further affecting economic activity because companies would delay investments (including the large Chinese Belinga iron ore project) until they were sure the country would remain politically stable. There was also widespread uncertainty over the prospects of oil prices and the revenue that could be made from them.
nelda29notes: Allegations of voting fraud triggered rioting after the election. Protesters burned Gabon's embassy in Dakar, Sengal, and the French consulate in Port Gentil, Gabon. Opposition candidate Pierre Mamboundou was hurt by a tear-gas canister during the protests.
nelda33notes: There was significant violence prior to and after the announcing of the results of the election. Police fired tear gas at opposition demonstrators who camped outside the electoral commission in the capital overnight. The demonstrators had dragged a coffin into the main square to represent the death of the Bongo regime. After the results were announced, opposition supporters attacked the French consulate in the oil hub of Port Gentil, setting the building alight and ransacking nearby shops. The demonstrators' rage was directed at France because the former colonial ruler was widely believed to have propped up the Bongo regime. Demonstrators also broke down the doors to a prison, liberating the prisoners. Also, a television station was attacked by masked men who opened fire with artillery on the station, damaging its satellite uplink.
nelda47notes: No evidence of Western monitors found. Thus, NELDA 47 is coded N/A.

nelda50notes: The US is the main importer of Gabonese oil.
nelda54notes: Although it should be noted that Gabon's diplomatic relationship with France was largely centered around the deceased president (Bongo Sr. ). Yet, there was no evidence that this relationship was diminished after the elections (even though some media outlets speculated it might). Also, because Bongo's son became the new president, and the incumbent party maintained its grip on government, this suggests that Gabonese policy in regards to France will most likely remain unchanged (and the French are probably aware of this), or at least, this is the perception.
