notes: Legislative elections were held in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) on November 28, 2011, simultaneously with presidential elections. The elections to the 500-seat National Assembly (the lower chamber of the bicameral legislature in the DRC) resulted in a win for parties supporting President Joseph Kabila's People's Party for Reconstruction and Democracy (PPRD). They secured two-thirds of the seats. Nevertheless, the election results were widely disputed, and officials called for a rerun of the polls in seven of the 169 voting districts where violence had disrupted the election. Etienne Tshisekedi, leader of the opposition Union for Democracy and Social Progress (UDPS) called on UDPS MPs to boycott parliament, citing that the legislative elections were rigged.
nelda2notes: These were the second multiparty elections held in the DRC since independence in 1960.
nelda5notes: An astounding 19,000 candidates were registered to contest the election to the National Assembly. In Kinshasa (the capital), 5,351 candidates contested the 51 National Assembly seats that are available.
nelda45notes: International monitors from the EU, the Carter Center, and the Southern African Development Community (SADC) were all present as observers during the election.

notes: Presidential elections were held in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) on November 28, 2011. The election resulted in the re-election of President Joseph Kabila, who secured 48.95% of the vote in disputed elections. Etienne Tshisekedi of the Union for the Congolese Nation (URDC) came in second with 32.33% of the vote. The Carter Center, the EU, and US Secretary of State Hilary Clinton disputed the election results. The Carter Center cited that election rigging, ballot stuffing, and government harassment of the opposition was widespread.
nelda45notes: International monitors from the EU, the Carter Center, and the Southern African Development Community (SADC) were all present as observers during the election.

These were the first multi-party elections since independence. Results were highly undemocratic. No western elections observers came. notes: After years of political debate between the CCM (ruling party) and CUF (opposition), the two political parties finally reached a power-sharing agreement. In January 2010, the unicameral Zanzibar (an autonomous region within Tanzania) House of Representatives adopted as law a bill that outlined the parameters of a government of national unity and called for a popular referendum on the plan. In July 2010, Zanzibar voters gave their approval to amend the constitution to allow for a unity government in Zanzibar. Thus, these elections were forecasted to be relatively peaceful because it wouldn't be a winner take all system where the Zanzibars were left out of having sufficient political represenation in parliament. The election saw the continued dominance of the CCM, but with a significant seat increase in parliament by the opposition CUF and Chadema parties.

notes: These were the fourth multi-party elections to be held in Tanzania. The ruling CCM party candidate was incumbent President Kilwete, who was reelected with 61.7% of the vote, reduced significantly from 80% in 2005. The Chadema party was for the first time the recepient of the most opposition votes. Chadema's presidential candidate Slaa received 27% of the vote, and CUF's candidate Lipumba received 8%. Although the elections were conducted without major disturbances, Chadema officials raised concerns about voting and tabulation procedures. They also raised concerns about the constitutional prohibition on challenging presidential election results following their formal announcement.

notes: This election - the first since 1992 and the outbreak of MPLA vs UNITA civil war - was widely considered a positive step forward. President dos Santos' Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola - Workers' Party (MPLA) was the incumbent, against the main opposition party, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA). The final results gave 191 seats to the MPLA and 16 to the UNITA. The latter originally challenged the results, but conceded defeat after the election commission rejected its claim for lack of evidence. The remaining seats went to small parties. UNITA (opposition) leader Samakuva praised the elections as an important step for the consolidation of the country's fragile democracy. There were problems of voter intimidation, badly organized polling, and biased media, all commented on by Western observers present - but considering this election was in the wake of a violent and bloody civil war, these elections were largely considered a success.
nelda1notes: These elections were for all seats in the National Assembly. General elections had previously taken place in September 1992.
nelda2notes: In the 1992 elections, President dos Santos' Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola - Workers' Party (MPLA) won 129 of the 220 seats contested in the National Assembly, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA), led by Mr. Jonas Savimbi, took 70 seats, and the remaining seats went to small parties.
nelda3notes: A total of 5,198 candidates from 10 political parties and four coalitions contested these elections.
nelda6notes: Regular elections had been postponed repeatedly as a result of the civil war that had engulfed the country following its independence from Portugal in 1975, the last elections had occurred in 1992. Hence political actors had no shared expectations of when elections should occur.
nelda11notes: and it predicted that the election would not be free and fair. UNITA claimed their supporters were being intimidated, and that there was fraud on election day.
nelda12notes: It was widely expected that the ruling MPLA of President Jos� Eduardo dos Santos would win a majority. Early indications were that the MPLA would win a landslide victory at the polls.
nelda15notes: The MPLA's main rival, the UNITA, accused the MPLA of intimidating UNITA supporters.
nelda16notes: The MPLA's main rival, the UNITA, accused the MPLA of dominating the State media. The Liberal Democratic Party criticized the MPLA's use of military airplanes, helicopters and boats during the election campaign, as others did not have access to these modes of promotion.
nelda17notes: The country had experienced double-digit economic growth from 2002 - 2008. That figure reached 20 per cent in 2008, due to the oil and diamond industries. However, nearly 70 per cent of Angolans live on less than US$ 2 a day. So underneath the impressive growth, there was in some regards, considerable economic crisis.
nelda19notes: Angola receives a particularly large amount of aid from the US.
nelda24notes: The final results gave 191 seats to the MPLA of President dos Santos and 16 to the UNITA (main opposition party).
nelda27notes: In the 1992 elections, President dos Santos' Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola - Workers' Party (MPLA) won 129 of the 220 seats; whereas, in these elections they won 191. UNITA dropped from 70 seats in 1992, to 16 in these elections.
nelda33notes: and that 4 of UNITA's supporters had been killed in the lead up to the elections.
nelda46notes: The European Union sent about 100 observers. The Southern African Development Community (SADC) declared that the polls to have been credible, peaceful and transparent.
nelda47notes: Thus there were not allegations of vote fraud, as such.
nelda50notes: Since 1993, President Dos Santos has promoted close relations with the US. The US was the primary supporter of President Dos Santos' MPLA against the UNITA forces in the civil war.
nelda54: US, EU, Portugal, UN, Community of Portugese Speaking Countries.
nelda54notes: Since 1998, Angola has endeavored together with the UN Security Council to impose and carry out sanctions on UNITA (the main opposition party) as the civil war raged.

notes: The incumbent President Guebuza's party, Fremilo, retained its majority in parliament.
nelda12notes: It should be noted that the ruling party had retained control of government since the 70's, there doesn't seem to be evidence that the party was confident of victory prior to the elections. And even though there were some irregularities at polling stations, the outcome of the elections (according to EU observers) would not have changed even if the irregularities hadn't been present.
nelda13notes: Opposition parties, most notably MDM, were banned from running in the National Assembly election and provincial assembly elections by the National Elections Commission (CNE). They alleged that missing registration documentation was the reason behind MDM's inability to run; nevertheless, there was significant concern regarding the transparency of Mozambique's multi-party elections.
nelda17notes: Despite the global economic downturn, economic growth in Mozambique remained strong because of significant donor support from other countries, such as the start of work on the US Moatize coal project, a doubling of gas exports through the Sasol pipeline and the construction of a second fuel pipeline to South Africa.
nelda18notes: There is a perception; however, that the country has reaped the benefits of post-conflict catch-up growth and that economic expansion and poverty reduction are in danger of losing momentum.
nelda19notes: In October 2009, the country received a $500 million loan from the EU and Danish and Dutch governments to build a railway line to link the coal-rich northern Moatize mines to the port of Nacala by 2015. The IMF also increased the amount of aid offered to Mozambique in early 2009, in order to offset some of the affects of the global economic crisis on the Mozambique economy.
nelda46notes: The Organization of American States sent 53 observers from 13 countries in the Americas and Europe.

notes: Incumbent President Guebuza was reelected to a second term. However, the elections were considered flawed because of voter fraud, questionable disqualifications of candidates, and Frelimo use of government resources during the campaign. As a result, Freedom House removed Mozambique from its list of electoral democracies. Guebuza ran as the Frelimo candidate, Dklakama ran as the opposition party Renamo's candidate, and Daviz, who split from Renamo and formed his own party, the Democratic Movement of Mozambique (MDM), ran as its candidate. MDM was banned from contesting the National Assembly elections that were held on the same day.
nelda7notes: The incumbent ran for reelection.
nelda12notes: It should be noted that the ruling party had retained control of government since the 70's, there doesn't seem to be evidence that the party was confident of victory prior to the elections. And even though there were some irregularities at polling stations, the outcome of the elections (according to EU observers) would not have changed even if the irregularities hadn't been present.
nelda13notes: Although there was concern that the the MDM candidate (Simango) would be banned from contesting the presidential election. Simango accused Frelimo, the incumbent party, of using the elections commission to try to ban his candidacy in the election.
nelda17notes: Despite the global economic downturn, economic growth in Mozambique remained strong because of significant donor support from other countries, such as the start of work on the US Moatize coal project, a doubling of gas exports through the Sasol pipeline and the construction of a second fuel pipeline to South Africa.
nelda18notes: There is a perception; however, that the country has reaped the benefits of post-conflict catch-up growth and that economic expansion and poverty reduction are in danger of losing momentum.

notes: Elections were held on the same day for the Senate, House of Assembly, and the Presidency. This coding is for the bicameral Parliament. In the Senate, 60 members representing each province are elected by direct popular vote (60 of 93). In the lower House of Assembly, all 210 member are directly elected. In this elections, Mugabe's Patriotic Front (ZANU-PF) won 30 seats in the Senate (compared to 43 in the last elections though the number of seats was different), and 97 seats in the House of Assembly (compared to 78 in the last elections, note an amendment meant the number of seats had changed). Overall however, this election was a loss for Mugabe's ZANU-PF, as they lost control of the House. The Opposition was a popular front called the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC). Mugabe's ZANU-PF loss to the MDC was unprecedented, and it occured in the face of all odds. The opposition MDC became the largest party in the House of Assembly, winning 99 of the 207 confirmed seats. Mugape's ZANU-PF, which took 97 seats, lost control of the House for the first time since independence. The MDC-AM (a breakaway opposition party) took ten seats. However, the ZANU-PF remained the largest party in the Senate, with 30 seats. However, the Electoral Commission (widely considered to be Mugabe's hand-puppet) called for a re-count, and later arrested some MDC parliamentarians so that ZANU-PF regained prominance. These elections were marred by fraud and corruption.
nelda6notes: President Mugabe had pushed several Constiutional amendments through the legislature in September 2007, including one which allowed for elections for all seats in the House of Assembly and 60 in the Senate (both Houses of the bicameral legislature) in 2008. Elections to the House of Assembly had previously taken place on 31 March 2005, and according to the pre-amendment constitution, should have been held every 5 years.
nelda11notes: Violence, intimidation, and a history of rigged elections meant that it was abundantly clear that these elections were not going to be free and fair.
nelda12notes: The violence, intimidation, and rigging was of an intensity that predetermined Mugabe's ZANU-PF power, through whatever means possible. Indeed, when the MDC earned more seats, Mugabe's government simply called for a recount until they had only one less seat in the House of Assembly than the MDC. They then arrested two MDC MPs on their way to Parliament, to ensure that ZANU-PF was assured a majority!
nelda13notes: Some MDC members had been arrested on trumped up charges.
nelda15notes: Human Rights Watch on March 19th reported media bias, intimidation and threats used against oppositions, and an Electoral Commission obviously in support of Mugabe.
nelda16notes: During campaigning, opposition leaders complained of intimidation and vote-buying, unequal media coverage, a biased electoral commission, and serious anomalies in the demarcation of voting constituencies. Indeed, the main newspaper and radio station were state-owned. In a Human Rights Watch report, unequal media coverage was also brought up.
nelda18notes: The poll was held against the backdrop of hopeless economic collapse, with an annual inflation rate exceeding 100,000 per cent in February 2008. Only 20 per cent of adults reportedly have regular jobs. Basic food was unavailable in much of Zimbabwe. An estimated 4 million of the country's 12 million inhabitants had reportedly fled the county. The economy had deteriorated to the point that it was widely thought that even Mugabe, with his blatant use of violence and fraud, would find it challenging to suceed in these elections.
nelda19notes: Sanctions had been long imposed on Mugabe's person and the Zimbabwean state by the US, the EU, and other potential-aid benefactors.
nelda20notes: President is elected by direct vote.
nelda24notes: The loss of Mugabe's ZANU-PF was unprecedented, and it occured in the face of all odds. The opposition MDC became the largest party in the House of Assembly, winning 99 of the 207 confirmed seats. Mugape's ZANU-PF, which took 97 seats, lost control of the House for the first time since independence. The MDC-AM (a breakaway opposition party) took ten seats. One independent candidate was elected. However, the ZANU-PF remained the largest party in the Senate, with 30 seats.
nelda29notes: This is probably because there was such widespread violence from the state that protests were not possible. Riot police were disseminated thickly throughout the country.
nelda32notes: Mugabe's ZANU-PF had failed to obtain a majority in the House of Assembly, so on April 13 the state-run Sunday Mail newspaper announced that the Zimbabwe Electoral Commission would conduct a full recount of the presidential and parliamentary ballots cast in 23 constituencies in the elections, (22 of which had voted for the MDC opposition). Even after this recount, the Financial Times on April 28 reported that it looked like ZANU-PF still had failed to retain a majority of the House of Assembly. Elections to fill three vacant seats in the House were held in parallel with the presidential run-off. The final results gave 100 seats to the MDC, 99 to the ZANU-PF, ten to the MDC-AM, and one to an independent. On 25 August, parliament held its first session, nearly six months after the elections. Two MDC members elected to the House of Assembly were arrested on their way to parliament. In short, parliament was deadlocked, and eventually MDC and ZANU-PF signed a powersharing agreement whereby Mr. Tsvangirai (MDC leader) became Prime Minister, and Mugabe kept the Presidency.
nelda33notes: On May 10th, the Guardian reported that the Zimbabwe Association of Doctors for Human Rights had counted 22 people dead and 900 tortured in post-election violence.
nelda45notes: . Furthermore, observers from the Pan-African Parliament reported that more than 8,000 non-existent voters were registered in one Harare constituency.
nelda48notes: The European Union, which had concluded that the 2002 presidential elections had been rigged, the Commonwealth, as well as other Western observers, were not allowed to observe the elections.
nelda50notes: The US had been vocal in its condemnation of Mugabe, and harsh sanctions were in place.
nelda51notes: The outcry against the conduct of these elections reflected the fact that elections were held on the same day for Senate, House of Assembly, and President, hence there was more media coverage than there would have been for just House of Assembly elections.

notes: These were marred by violence, fraud, delayed announcement of results, and potentially fraudulent results that precipitated a second round run-off. In this presidential poll, the three main candidates were Mugabe, Morgan Tsvangirai (leader of the main opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change or MDC), and Simba Makoni, a former ZANU-PF (Mugabe's party) minister of finance and economic development. It was thought that the crisis state of Zimbabwe's economy would mean Mugabe's win was not guaranteed. During campaigning, opposition leaders complained of intimidation and vote-buying, biased media coverage, and a farce of an electoral commission clearly in Mugabe's pocket. Election results were not announced for one month after the elections, causing MDC supporters to expressing concern and fear that ZANU-PF was rigging the election. Finally the Commission announced that   Tsvangirai (MDC) had defeated incumbent Mugabe. However, because Tsvangirai had not won by a majority, a second round run-off was necessary. Tsvangirai claimed that the Electoral Commission had reduced his vote count so as to precipitate a run-off. The months between this election and the run off were full of much death and torture of opposition supporters.
nelda1notes: Presidential elections had been held in 2002, and before that in 1996.
nelda6notes: The Presidential term lasts for 6 years, and the last elections were in 2002, thus these were on time. Note that Mugabe had introduced constitutional amendments so that legislative elections would be held on the same day, even though they had happened in 2005 and according to the pre-amendment constitution, should have been held every 5 years.
nelda8notes: President does not have a term limit according to the Constitution of Zimbabwe.
nelda9notes: In 1987, upon ascending to power, Mugabe amended the Constitution to abolish the position of Prime Minister, vest full powers in the President, and eliminate a term limit.
nelda11notes: Violence, intimidation, and a history of rigged elections meant that it was abundantly clear that these elections were not going to be free and fair.

nelda16notes: During campaigning, opposition leaders complained of intimidation and vote-buying, unequal media coverage, a biased electoral commission, and serious anomalies in the demarcation of voting constituencies. Indeed, the main newspaper and radio station were state-owned.
nelda18notes: The poll was held against the backdrop of hopeless economic collapse, with an annual inflation rate exceeding 100,000 per cent in February 2008. Only 20 per cent of adults reportedly have regular jobs. Basic food was unavailable in much of Zimbabwe. An estimated 4 million of the country's 12 million inhabitants had reportedly fled the county. The economy had deteriorated to the point that it was widely thought that even Mugabe, with his blatant use of violence and fraud, would find it challenging to suceed in these elections. On Feb. 21st, the national central statistical office reported that inflation had risen to 100,580 per cent in January - by far the highest rate of inflation in the world.
nelda19notes: Sanctions had been long imposed on Mugabe's person and the Zimbabwean state by the US, the EU, and other potential-aid benefactors.

notes: This second round run-off (June 27th) between incumbent President Mugabe and opposition leader Tsvangirai of the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) was marked by the displacement of hundreds of thousands, the murder of dozens of MDC supporters, and widespread torture. Ultimately, Tsvangirai had to pull out, such was the violence and danger to his life (assassination plots had driven him from the country). On June 22 he pulled out and pleaded for international action to prevent �genocide� in Zimbabwe. His withdrawal came after 2,000 armed government supporters had broken up an election rally in the capital. There was widespread international outcry against Mugabe's use of violence: the G8 and United Nations released condemnations and considered further sanctions against Zimbabwe. Regional leaders, too, panned Mugabe's conduct. Finally, the Zimbabwe Electoral Commission announced the results: they gave Mugabe 85.5 per cent and Tsvangirai 9.3 per cent, with 5.2 per cent of ballots spoiled.
nelda6notes: Legally,MDC pointed out that the run-off election should be held no late than May 24, 21 days after results of the first round were announced. However, on May 14th the Zimbabwe Electoral Commission postponed the date of the run-off until as late as July. The government announced: �The period within which a second election for the office of the president is hereby extended from 21 days to 90 days from the date of announcement of results of the first poll.� Then, on May 16 the ZEC announced that the run-off would be on June 27.
nelda8notes: President does not have a term limit according to the Constitution of Zimbabwe.
nelda9notes: In 1987, upon ascending to power, Mugabe amended the Constitution to abolish the position of Prime Minister, vest full powers in the President, and eliminate a term limit.
nelda11notes: Even regional leaders - usually reluctant to condemn each other - spoke of the blatant violence and fraud surrounding the conduct of this run-off. For example, Jacob Zuma (leader of South Africa's ruling African National Congress) told business leaders in Johannesburg �I cannot sit here and say I'm comfortable there's going to be a run-off and it will be free and fair.� Tsvangirai actually had to leave the country during the lead up to the run-off, as assassination plots on his life were uncovered.
nelda12notes: No one else was running against Mugabe.
nelda13notes: Though Tsvangirai would probably argue that he was prevented from running by threats on his life, and the killing and torture of his supporters. Legally however, he was not kept from running. he pulled out on 22 June, pleading for international action to prevent �genocide� in Zimbabwe.
nelda14notes: Tsvangirai pulled out of the election on June 22, bowing to the pressure of vicious violence exacted by Mugabe's government on MDC supporters.  Previous weeks had seen the deaths of more than 80 MDC supporters and the displacement of 200,000 people.
nelda15notes: They killed, arrested, and tortured them. For example, the MDC's secretary general was arrested and charged on June 19 with treason, publishing false statements, and insulting the president.Tsvangirai said that over 50 people had been killed in political violence and 25,000 had fled their homes in the lead up to these elections. Human Rights groups supported observations of mass torture and murder.
nelda16notes: A complaint of the MDC and of Human Rights Watch was the biased and unequal media coverage afforded to Mugabe.
nelda18notes: The election was held against the backdrop of hopeless economic collapse, with an annual inflation rate exceeding 100,000 per cent in February 2008. Only 20 per cent of adults reportedly have regular jobs. Basic food was unavailable in much of Zimbabwe. An estimated 4 million of the country's 12 million inhabitants had reportedly fled the county. The economy had deteriorated to the point that it was widely thought that even Mugabe, with his blatant use of violence and fraud, would find it challenging to suceed in these elections. On Feb. 21st, the national central statistical office reported that inflation had risen to 100,580 per cent in January - by far the highest rate of inflation in the world.
nelda19notes: Sanctions had been long imposed on Mugabe's person and the Zimbabwean state by the US, the EU, and other potential-aid benefactors.
nelda27notes: The opposition MDC candidate pulled out of the election. The Zimbabwe Electoral Commission announced the results on June 29, giving Mugabe 85.5 per cent and Tsvangirai 9.3 per cent, with 5.2 per cent spoiled.

notes: These were the last elections before the Apartheid era. At this point, South Africa was a British Dominion. The Smuts Party, though considered by the UN as repressive, was in the eyes of the opposition Nationalists, fairly liberal. The Nationalists and their leader Malan were running on a campaign line of strict segregation and secession from the British Empire, and possibly the UN. The months preceding this election saw the break up of some of the smaller parties, so the election was essentially fought by the Nationalists and the United Party. Smuts lost by a slim margin of 224 votes, as the Nationalist (together with the smaller Afrikaners Party) won a majority in Parliament. Smuts lost mainly due to the color issue, with the Nationalist's hardline segregation winning votes amongst the white electorate. Key about this election is that though multi-party, it was hardly democratic - aside from a few thousand colored male voters who were required to fulfil economic and educational requirements that the whites did not have to, the effective elctorate was of European origin.  Black or colored South Africans did not have the right to run or form opposition. This election ushered in the party that introduced apartheid to South Africa.
nelda3notes: But only from those of European origin. The native population of South Africa, almost five times larger than those of European origin, was completely disenfranchised.
nelda6notes: They were several months early. It was suggested that this was because the incumbent United Party would have suffered from later elections, due to the rising cost of living and the imminent dollar deficit crisis, which had until then been hidden by an influx of British capital.
nelda11notes: Though before the elections the Nationalists conducted a 'whispering campaign,' accusing the United Party of holding 'sham elections.' This was not taken particularly seriously. Having said that the elections were considered to be free and fair, it must be recalled that this is purely because it was contested exclusively by the white minority.
nelda13notes: The nine million coloured or black citizens of South Africa were not allowed party representation in the elections, and so though there was opposition allowed, it was only allowed amongst the white-supremecist elite. The African National Congress, for example, was not considered a legal political party.
nelda18notes: However, there was a dollar deficit crisis (a deficit of 100 million pounds was estimated for the year) expected to break a month or two after the election, and with the election over, Smut would be able to bring back import controls to counter this.
nelda29notes: Though there was considerable shock at the unexpected results.
nelda50notes: South Africa was a good trading partner of the US, and furthermore, the white population feared the Communist threat passionately, as it promised to bring 'equality to the African.'
nelda52notes: Malan, in order to distance South Africa from Britain, encouraged more capital influx and trade with the US.
nelda55notes: when Smuts lost his Prime Minister's seat. Malan also spoke of withdrawing from the UN, as some of the Nationalists had proposed incorporating Southwest Africa into their territory - a UN mandate. The Nationalists had also clashed with the UN previous to the elections, over the status of Indians in South Africa (India had brought a complaint of abuse to the UN). The secession did not happen, but Malan's attitude to the UN and Britain was still far frostier than Smut's had been.

notes: The lead-up to the elections was marked by considerable unrest amongst the non-white population, as they protested  the exclusively white race of all legal parties. The Nationalist Party, running on its hardline white-supremecist party line of apartheid, increased its majority to 29 seats more than the United Party, up from the previous lead of 13 seats. This was seen as a vote of confidence for its apartheid policies, and fuelled more organized and united opposition and dissent amongst the disenfranchised non-white majority of South Africa's population. The legal opposition party, the United Party, was not as strictly pro-segregation as the Nationalists, but was nevertheless an advocate of white supremacy.
nelda3notes: Though only from the parties of European origin. The black and colored populations were completely disenfranchised.
nelda11notes: Though it must be noted that there was considerable concern amongst the majority non-white population that the elections would not be free and fair, as they were completely disenfranchised. Amongst the white political parties however, free competitive elections were expected.
nelda12notes: Competitive outcome was anticipated.
nelda13notes: All non-white leaders were disenfranchised.
nelda15notes: The Nationalist Party violently broke up various United Party meetings and rallies.
nelda27notes: The United Party lost votes, and the Nationalist Party made slight gains.
nelda28notes: Though, notably, not on the grounds of election fraud. Rather, there was increasing criticism of the government's racism and the white-supremecist nature of legal parties from the non-white South African majority.
nelda29notes: There was a general strike organized by the African National Congress before the elections, in protest of the exclusively white government. Notably, passive and non-violent resistance was occuring, as a central doctrine of for example the main non-white party, the African National Congress. Following the success of Malan's pro-apartheid government, ANC President Luthuli called to action South Africa's non-white population, heralding a mass effort involving industrial strikes and economic boycotts.
nelda30notes: Rather, the racist nature of South African law and government.
nelda33notes: Strikes, brawling, and stone throwing characterized the election race between the United Party and the Nationalists, and native protest also peaked as racial tension grew.
nelda50notes: Good trade, and anti-communism solidarity ties.
nelda54notes: Though, notably, the relationship with Britain and the UN was not as warm as it had been previous to Malan's 1948 election.  Malan had also said that South Africa would become a republic some time in the future, while probably remaining part of the Commonwealth. He also talked much of seccession from the UN, though never actually took action.

notes: The pro-Apartheid Nationalist party beat the United Party (white supremecist as well, but more moderate) by an even more striking majority than they had in 1953. These elections were characterized by fever-pitch racial tension. Protests, strikes and demonstrations, organized jointly by many non-white political organizations (the African National Congress being the most prominant), were met with violence from the Nationalist government, and a general strike was put down just days before the election.
nelda3notes: Though exclusively from the non-white strata of the South African population.
nelda11notes: Though protests and strikes demonstrated against these elections, and obviously the exclusively white elections were neither free nor fair to the non-white majority of South Africa, between the government and opposition party free and fair competitive elections were expected.
nelda12notes: Competitive elections were expected.
nelda13notes: All non-white parties were legally prevented from putting forth opposition candidates, most notably the ANC.

nelda15notes: They did not harrass the legal opposition - however, violence and disruptive tactics were used against the non-white opposition that was not allowed to run, such as the ANC, who had organized a general three day strike in Johannesburg. The strike was violently broken up by the police.
nelda28notes: About 60% of the few colored men allowed to vote boycotted the election, with pickets showed the words 'dummy elections,' and mass protest was organized by the non-white organizations of the nation, with a three day general strike during election week. The international press was also critical of South Africa's racist electoral system.

notes: These elections were for the National Assembly of Botswana. The National Assembly then elects the President, hence these elections indirectly determine the President. These October 2009 elections were the first to be held under President Seretse Khama Ian Khama, who had succeeded former President Festus Mogae in April 2008. Thus this was Ian Khama�s first democratic test. His party, the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), had been in power since independence in 1966, and despite the massive economic recession that had crippled Botswana recently, the BDP was still expected to win these elections due to Khama�s popularity and the divided opposition. The final results gave the BDP 45 seats, while the opposition BNF took six seats, followed by the BCP and the BAM, who took four seats and one seat respectively. Thus Khama, as the BDP candidate, was re-elected to the Presidency for his first full term. These elections were widely considered to have been conducted smoothly.
nelda8notes: Khama had only been in power for a short interim period since April 2008.
nelda12notes: President Ian Khama's Botswana Democratic Party was expected to remain in power because the opposition vas very divided, and he enjoyed wide popularity - he is the son of Botswana's first post-independence President.
nelda18notes: The 2009 elections were held in the midst of the worldwide economic crisis, which had devastated Botswana's diamond-based economy. Botswana's economy had shrunk by 11.5% in the fiscal year ending in June 2009. Some of Botswana's diamond mines were forced to close, and the country had been plunged into debt.
nelda19notes: The EU was in fact soon to step up aid, given Botswana's crisis. Botswana is often offered as the poster child for the positive potential of aid.
nelda20notes: The office of the leader was not contested because these elections were for the National Assembly, which then elects the President.
nelda25notes: A poll by the University of Botswana Faculty and Afrobarometer showed that 69% of respondents would vote for the BDP�s candidate for the Presidential election.
nelda27notes: The opposition forces lost two seats in these elections � one to the ruling BDP, and one to an independent. In the previous elections of 2004, the ruling Botswana Democratic Party, led by the then President Mogae, won 44 of the 57 directly elected seats. The main opposition force, the Botswana National Front (BNF), took 12 seats and the Botswana Congress Party (BCP) won a single seat. The final results of these October 2009 elections gave the BDP 45 seats, while the opposition BNF took six seats, followed by the BCP and the BAM, who took four seats and one seat respectively.
nelda45notes: Most election observers were from the African Union and South African Development Community (SADC).
nelda46notes: The EU sent monitors, and beforehand the International IDEA group audited Botswana's Independent Electoral Commission.
nelda50notes: The US works closely with Botswana on African issues, and considers Botswana a leading example of African success.

notes: Peaceful election in Botswana which sees Ian Khama win a third term as President (an office whose holder is elected by parliament). There is some criticism of Khama�s �authoritarianism�, but this is largely not reflected in the electoral process; despite some concerns over media freedom and very sparse accusations of fraud, the poll generally seems to transpire smoothly.

notes: Elections were called early by the monarch of Morocco as part of the Arab Spring. Committees from various parties wrote up a constitution in July 2011. After the new constitution, the prime minister replaced the monarch as the head of government for the first time. Thus, the incumbent, King Mohammed is a monarch and his successor is the prime minister. After the election, King Mohammed remained king of Morocco. Furthermore, although the king nominated his prime minister, the constitution essentially mandated him to nominate the winner of the election.

notes: These elections were the first elections held since independence on July 3, 1962, after a bloody war of independence with France that had begun in 1954. The country was still unstable at this point and clashes among factions led to civilian deaths.

nelda16notes: At this point Ben Bella had started consolidating his power over the media, especially newspapers, and used them to promote his party and the election.

nelda54notes: Despite having fought a bloody war for independence, Algeria still had very close ties with France, and relied on them for such things as economic aid, teachers and doctors.

notes: This was the first presidential election held in Algeria since independence. Ben Bella of the National Liberation Front (the only legal party) was the only candidate. He secured re-election (Bella had iniitally been head of the transitional government in Algeria).
nelda1notes: This was the first presidential election under the new constitution of 1963, and the first presidential election in Algerian history, and since independence from France in 1962.

nelda17notes: When many of the Europeans left after independence they took large amounts of money and business with them, and Ben Bella had not made a coherent economic plan for the country.
nelda18notes: Urban unemployment had improved since 1962, when it was at 70%, and more children were in school (thanks to tens of thousands of teachers from France) and more factories operating than since independence; however, the economy was stil very dependent on foreign aid.

nelda58notes: The USSR was also a supporter of Algeria, giving them 225 million in purchase credits. It was part of Ben Bella's policy to remain neutral, and he could not have afforded to be otherwise.

notes: These elections were for the lower house (National People's Assembly) of the bicameral parliament. Incumbent President Bouteflicka, whose party alongside two coalition members, won these elections. Main issues involved the onslaught of violence perpetrated by the FIS Islamic insurgency and North African Al Qaeda which had marred the three weeks previous to the election. The Presidential Alliance (Bouteflicka's National Liberation Front, the National Democratic Rally, and the Movement for a Peaceful Society) won a total of 263 seats (compared to 284 in 2002) of the 389 available.The National Election Monitoring Commission at first recognised widespread signs of electoral fraud which it then retracted hours later, agreeing on a version that was closer to that of the Home Secretary � that the elections were generally without incident. High security around polling stations (it was thought that bomb attacks were quite likely) ensured that voting passed off without much incident.

This year, the FLN remained the largest party with 136 seats but it lost 63. Its allies, the RND and the MSP, took 62 and 51 seats respectively, thus giving the ruling camp a total of 263 seats (compared to 284 in 2002).

The leader of the al-Qaeda Organisation in the Islamic Maghreb called for a boycott of the elections in a statement broadcast on al-Jazeera television, describing the elections as a comedy and declaring that anyone taking part in them would be committing a sin.

notes: A November 2008 constitutional amendment abolished presidential term limits in order to allow President Bouteflicka to participate in these elections for a third time. Bouteflika, candidate of the two main pro-regime parties (the National Liberation Front and the National Democratic Rally, RND), won over 90 per cent of the vote of a turnout of 74.5 per cent; his closest challenger, Louiza Hanoune of the Workers' Party, won just over 4 per cent of the vote. As Algeria was still in the midst of a struggle with radical Islamist militant groups, more than 150,000 policemen were deployed to ensure the security of the elections. Six car bombs attacks were reported during the elections, and clashes erupted following the results between pro- and anti- Bouteflicka forces. Opposition leaders denounced these elections as unfair, but the international community congratulated Bouteflicka on his re-election - perhaps because of Algeria's strategic importance as an oil producer and anti-terrorism ally.

notes: Elections to the National Assembly (the lower house of the bicameral legislature) were held in Algeria on May 10, 2012. Following the Arab Spring upheavals in 2011, the Algerian people called upon President Abdelaziz Bouteflika and his ruling National Liberation Front (FLN) to reform and democratize the government. The FLN had been in power since it successfully secured Algerian independence from France in 1962, and most controversially, the FLN proved the lengths it was willing to go to remain in power when it refused to give up power to the Islamist FIS that had won national elections in 1991. As a result, the FIS has been banned from contesting elections in Algeria since then. To pacify protestors President Bouteflika agreed to hold elections, pass an election law in December 2011 (that made it easier for new political parties to form), and expanded the number of seats in the National Assembly from 389 to 462). Despite the calls of reform, these elections resulted in a reinforcement of the status quo, with the ruling FLN securing it's plurality in the National Assembly and increasing its seat count to 221 (up from the 136 seats they had in the outgoing parliament). Prime Minister Ahmed Ouyahia's National Democratic Rally (RND) retained its second-place position with 70 seats (they had 62 seats in the outgoing parliament). The Green Algeria Alliance (a group of moderate Islamist parties with links to the ruling elite) came in third with 48 seats. And in fourth place was the secularist Front of Socialist Forces, Algeria's oldest opposition party, that ended its decades-long boycott to contest these elections, citing the presence of international observers as a motivating factor. Overall, the voter turnout was surprisingly low, and the international community was surprised that these elections reinforced the status quo, given the recent calls for reform that had shaken Algeria and the Arab world.
nelda6notes: These elections were not regular. They were held as a result of the pro-democracy movement that called upon reform in 2011.
nelda13notes: The banned Islamist FIS was not allowed to contest the election. This ban was reinforced in the new political parties law passed in December 2011. The FIS has been banned in Algeria since 1991, when it won the first round of the legislative elections and the ruling FLN refused to recognize their success and hand over power.
nelda14notes: that took place in the lead up to the elections. For example, Moussa Touati (leader of the Algerian National Front, FNA) criticized the decision to increase the size of the National Assembly, arguing that it was simply a political ploy by the ruling party to make it more difficult for a strong opposition bloc to form in the new Assembly, and thus ensure thei continued hold on power. And some, such as the secular opposition party, the Berber Rally for Culture and Democracy (RCD) actually boycotted the election. In the lead up to the election, many young Algerians also took to social media and called upon a boycott of the elections. The Independent Youth Movement for Change (MJIC), which had formed from the pro-democracy movement in 2011, also urged a boycott of the election via social networking sites. It's believed that the MJIC had a significant impact on the low voter turnout in these elections. The banned FIS also called upon a boycott of the elections
nelda24notes: President Abdelaziz Bouteflika's ruling National Liberation Front (FLN) retained its plurality in the National Assembly and increased its seat count from 136 in 2007 to 221 seats in the new National Assembly. Prime Minister Ahmed Ouyahia's National Democratic Rally (RND) also retained its second-place position and secured 70 seats (they'd won 62 seats in the 2007 elections).
nelda27notes: The vote count was technically a gain for the opposition. The new election law that was passed in December 2011 regulating the creation of new political parties (and the continued ban of the FIS to contest elections) resulted in 44 political parties that contested these National Assembly elections. The new law combined with the increase in the size of the Assembly (from 389 to 462 members) resulted in 30 out of the 44 parties gaining seats in the new Assembly. Thus, even though the two main parties retained their pluralities, the size of the opposition was greatly increased after these elections.
nelda28notes: Despite the fact that international election observers deemed the elections to have been free, many opposition parties and the public in general, were not very happy with the results of the election. The reinforcement of the status quo came as a shock to many Algerians, who argued that, while there might not have been any outright fraud that was conducted, the political process itself (for example, article 87 of the new election law and the member increase in the Assembly) was manipulated to benefit the ruling establishment and make it more difficult for opposition forces to gain any relevant representation.
nelda29notes: I could not find evidence that there were widespread protests following the election. This is rather strange, given the perception of indignation over the results; however, the opposition has been mired by fractions, so it may simply be that there was no successful organization of protests to the election.
nelda45notes: Over 500 international monitors observed the election. The Carter Center, the National Democratic Institute, and numerous NGOs from the European Union and Arab League all sent monitors to observe the election.
nelda47notes: Despite the fact that the government denied monitors' access to national party lists, Western observers weren't too critical of the elections, claiming that they were an important and positive first-step in the democratization of Algeria. US Secretary of State Hilary Clinton cited the increased number of women that were elected to national office as a positive sign.

notes: First elections following the Arab Spring. The two most prominent features are: first, the massive boycott organized by almost all opposition parties, leading to a straightforward victory for Bouteflika, and second, the massive amounts of fraud which are perpetrated. There is strict political control by the regime, which harasses opposition members and regularly arrests journalists. Everything is tightly controlled, in order to ensure Bouteflika�s continued rule.

notes: Following the upheavals of the Arab Spring, Tunisia was the first to hold elections. On October 23, 2011 elections to a Constituent Assembly were held in Tunisia. The Assembly would be charged with drafting a new constitution as well as organizing upcoming legislative and presidential elections. The October election resulted in a victory for the moderate Islamist party, Ennahda, which secured 89 out of 217 seats. The Congress for the Republic (CPR) came in second with 29 seats. The Popular Petition (AC) won 26 seats, the Democratic Forum for Labour and Liberties (Ettakatol/FDTL) won 20 seats, and the Progressive Democratic Party (PDP) secured 16 seats. The remaining seats went to 14 different parties who all received five or less seats. 8 seats went to Independents. Rachid Ghannouchi, party leader of Ennahda, has pledged not to set up an Islamist state, to respect multiparty democracy, and has claimed that his party is modeled after the governing AKP party in Turkey. Because Ennahda did not win an outright majority, it will inevitably form a coalition government. Its possible coalition partners are leftist, liberal parties. The biggest secular party, the CPR (which came in second), is amidst negotiations with the winning Ennahda about the formation of a governing coalition.

notes: Turbulent election in Tunisia, which is the first free election in the country�s history and the first after the Arab Spring events which unfolded in 2011. notes: Runoff election for the first round presidential poll.

Male adult suffrage only, 95% per cent of the electorate were illiterate so voters in the towns were required to drop their ballot-papers into boxes bearing the colour of the candidate they supported, while in rural districts they voted orally in the presence of a committee consisting of a returning officer, a judge, and a local notable. Elections led to a sweeping victory for pro-government forces winning 46/55 seats, National Congress Party only won 7. Despite this, it is important to note that NCP won substantial majorities in all the districts of Tripoli city and its outlying areas.
nelda3notes: Most of the candidates ran as Independents. The only organized party contesting the elections was the National Congress Party, the principal Opposition group, which advocated a strongly nationalist and anti-foreign policy, including the removal of Western military bases in Libya, and was believed to be receiving financial and moral support from Egypt; winning 7 seats.
nelda6notes: These were the first elections since independence, hence there were no prior expectations.
nelda11notes: Concerns are expressed by Sadawi, leader of NCP.
nelda13notes: Immediately after the elections political parties were abolished. The National Congress Party, which had campaigned against a federal form of government, was defeated throughout the country. The party was outlawed, and Sadawi was deported.
nelda18notes: The country is in no foreign debt, however it is extremely impoverished.

nelda33notes: Violence in Tripoli led to 8 deaths and 110 casualties.

nelda19notes: As part of a broad assistance package, the UN Technical Assistance Board agreed to sponsor a technical aid program for Libya that emphasized the development of agriculture and education. Foreign powers, notably Britain and the United States, provided development aid. Steady economic improvement occurred, but Libya remained heavily dependent on foreign aid. In exchange for their airbase the US provided an impoverished Libya with $2 million in foreign aid.

Britain was granted military bases in exchange for financial and military assistance, Libya also concluded a 20 year treaty of friendship and alliance with Britain. The next year, Libya and the United States signed an agreement under which the United States also obtained military base rights. Also noteworthy, Libya established full diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union in 1955, but declined a Soviet offer of economic aid.

notes: Elections to the General National Congress were held in Libya on July 7, 2012, after having been postponed from June 19, 2012.  This is the first general election to be held in Libya after the toppling of Colonel Muammar Gaddafi in 2011. The four-decade rule of Gaddafi was marked by a ban on political parties - a ban that was lifted prior to this election. The newly elected GNC will replace the National Transitional Council (NTC) in Libya, which served as an interim legislature following the popular uprising that ousted Gaddafi. The newly elected GNC will be tasked with holding upcoming parliamentary elections. Over 2,600 individual candidates contested the election, and while a majority are running as indepedents, about 400 are affiliated with a political party. The election resulted in the centrist National Forces Alliance (NFA) led by former interim Prime Minister Majmoud Jibril securing 39 of the 80 seats filled from party lists. The moderate Islamist Justice and Development Party (JDP) came in second with 17 seats. 120 seats went to independent candidates, and it's expected that the JDP will have further support within the GNC from independent candidates. There  was violence, including the death of an electoral commission official when his helicopter was fired at amidst tensions between militia groups in control of different parts of the country.
nelda6notes: These elections were not regular.
nelda12notes: The incumbent is coded as the Chairman of the National Transitional Council (the interim legislature tasked with holding elections to the GNC), who was Abdul Jalil.

notes: Nearly three years after the collapse of Moammar Gadhafi�s regime, national elections were held for the Constitutional Drafting Assembly amid a political and security crisis. Political infighting and international questioning delayed and ultimately hindered the process. The elections were said to be �soundly administered� but did not adequately represent the countries women and minorities. Some cultural groups boycotted the election and two refused to take their allotted seats, while multiple districts held re-run elections because of security threats that prevented voting on the set day. Despite there being two separate transitional governing bodies, there was no clear executive power in the time before the CDA election, so all variables concerning the incumbent have been coded as �N/A�.

notes: This election was the first election held since Abboud, a military leader who took power in 1958. A transitional government tasked with holding elections for a Constituent Assembly to compose a constitution was in power. However, there were massive boycotts from three large Southern provinces in the Sudan, so it was agreed that these remaining seats be filled after negotiations with South Sudan. In addition, these were the first elections in which women were allowed to vote; election days for men and women alternated over the election period, which lasted from April 21 to May 8th.
nelda1notes: The country was under military rule from 1959 until 1964.
nelda6notes: These were the first elections after the end of a military regime.
nelda7notes: Al-Khalifa headed a caretaker transitional government tasked with holding elections to form a constituent assembly to write a constitution; however, he was not associated with a party and the cabinet contained members from different parties.
nelda12notes: The incumbent government was composed of multiple parties and the leader, al-Khalifa, did not seek power in the elections.
nelda14notes: The People's Democratic Party boycotted the elections and tried to prevent voting, leading to more than 14 deaths related to the elections. In addition, most southern parties called for a boycott, which led to elections being delayed in the south.
nelda17notes: The Sudanese economy was heavily dependent on cotton and was very susceptible to price fluctuations.
nelda19notes: The Sudanese government relied heavily on foreign aid.
nelda33notes: 14 people were killed in election related violence when the People's Democratic Party boycotted the election and tried to prevent voting.
nelda44notes: Al Azhari was president, chosen by the Assembly, but he had little power.
nelda50notes: In the 7 years before this election, US aid to Sudan had been more than 80 million total. After this election the Prime Minister requested more US aid to improve rural conditions.
nelda54notes: The World Bank lent millions of dollars to Sudan, mostly for infrastructure development.

notes: These elections were held only in South Sudan. Although these elections were held two years after previous elections, they are coded as two rounds of the same election because they were held to fill the same Constituent Assembly.

nelda11notes: Due to unrest and boycotts in the south, these elections were not expected to be free and fair. The very informal process of registering voters and the difficulty of collecting votes from people living in the bush only heightened this sentiment.
nelda12notes: The right wing Umma Madhist party, the largest winners in the first round, and the Arab Nationalist Party, the second largest winners and part of the coaltion government, were confident of winning a majority of the Southern seats.

nelda1notes: The elections were late. They were originally scheduled to be held in 2009 as per the Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA) that was signed between northern and southern Sudan in 2005; nevertheless, because of a resurgence in conflict in the region, the elections didn't take place until April 2010.
nelda2notes: These were  the first multi-party elections in Sudan in 24 years.
nelda6notes: The elections were late, but they were not considered regular; therefore, the question is coded as N/A.
nelda15notes: The government particularly harassed the opposition in the south part of the country. The International Crisis Group reported that the ruling party (NCP) had gerrymandered electoral districts.
nelda16notes: All media is controlled by the central government, and independent media outlets are not allowed to publish material critical of the government.
nelda17notes: The rampant growth of the Sudanese economy in recent years is due to the extensive oil revenues they've received. Nevertheless, even though Sudan receives a significant amount of money from oil sales, rampant corruption and conflict have meant that the people of Sudan haven't quite benefitted as much as they should (this is most likely a large consequence of the extensive number of conflicts Sudan has been engaged in since the late 1990's).
nelda18notes: The country was still recovering from the effects of the war in Darfur that had ended in 2006 with the signing of the Darfur Peace Agreement and the Chad-Sudan conflict that lasted from 2005-2007. Furthermore, there were still isolated incidences of violence across the country and rampant corruption among government officials.
nelda19notes: The EU is the major source of aid to Sudan, particularly Darfur. The U.S. Government has contributed more than $8 billion in humanitarian, development, peacekeeping, and reconstruction assistance for the people in Sudan since 2005. The World Bank, IMF, UN, and European countries are also major sources of aid, as well.
nelda25notes: There are no opinion polls in Sudan.
nelda27notes: The last parliamentary election (2000) was boycotted by every single party other than the incumbent President Al-Bashir's party (NCP); so yes, this was definitely a vote count gain for the opposition.
nelda28notes: There was a Youtube video that recorded election fraud (ballot stuffing) that circulated widely both among the domestic population and worldwide. Because of the video, the results of the election in that specific district were canceled.
nelda34notes: There were canceled results in one district because it was proven voter fraud occurred; however, the cancelation wasn't significant and it didn't impact the outcome of the election.
nelda47notes: Former US President Jimmy Carter, of the Carter Institute, issued a statement acknowledging the legitimacy of the elections, despite the irregularities that were observed.
nelda48notes: The government denied most NGO groups who were trying to deliver aid to Darfur access to the region.
nelda49notes: There was substantial worry among international actors whether the elections would be fair, but there doesn't seem to be evidence that any monitors refused to go because of that.
nelda50notes: An arrest warrant was issued by the Hague against President Al-Bashir in 2009. The US also maintains continued sanctions against Sudan until there is an acceptable resolution to the conflict in Darfur and a free and peaceful southern referendum.
nelda57notes: One of the requirements before US sanctions can be lifted is a peaceful referendum in the south, which is largely contingent on the environment and nature in which the elections occur. Furthermore, because the ICC had issued an arrest warrant for Al-Bashir for crimes related to the Darfur conflict, and Sudan is reliant on largely EU aid, it is unclear whether or not either the EU or the US ever threatened to withdraw aid from Sudan.

notes: These elections in Iran were the first elections with real opposition, and were an experiment by the Shah with more political freedom. The incumbent party blatantly rigged the elections, leading to widespread protests and ultimately the Shah annulled the elections, which were held again the following year.
nelda2notes: This was the first election with organized parties, and there were two parties (the incumbent National Party and the opposition People's party) in this election as well as independents.
nelda6notes: Though these were the first elections with opposition, Iran had a long tradition of elections.
nelda11notes: Opposition accused the Shah's government of planning to manipulate the elections. During the elections some voters were not allowed to vote when they wanted to vote for a party other than the incumbent party.
nelda13notes: The Communist Party was outlawed.
nelda15notes: There were multiple allegations that the Shah's secret police discouraged the radical Nationalist (as opposed to the incumbent National Party) candidates from running as independents.
nelda16notes: A New York Times survey rated Iran as one of the countries with the most press freedom in the Middle East near this time.
nelda17notes: Iran suffered from high inflation, fiscal irresponsibility, unchecked government spending and lacked good fiscal policy. The IMF and the US were encouraging Iran at this time to improve policy
nelda19notes: Iran received foreign aid from the US and the IMF
nelda27notes: The Nationalist Party, the party which won the most seats in the previous elections, gained more seats in this election
nelda28notes: The opposition parties, the People's party and the Independent Party accused the incumbent Nationalist Party of voting irregularities
nelda29notes: More than 1,000 workers and students protested in Tehran concerning the voting irregularities, and Dr. Amini, a former Minister of Finance and Ambassador to the US also brought evidence before the Shah showing that people had voted illegally.
nelda31notes: Though there were small incidences of police dispersal while the elections took place there was no evidence of police violence
nelda33notes: Though shots were fired while dispersing election unrest they were fired over the heads of the crowd and there were no reported deaths.
nelda34notes: The Shah called for the resignation of deputies to allow for a new, freer election, and halted the counting of the ballots, effectively cancelling the results.
nelda37notes: New elections were held on January 10, 1961.
nelda38notes: The National Party again won the next election; however that parliament was subsequently dissolved.
nelda39notes: Though Eghbal's National Party, the incumbents, won the election and Eghbal became premier, he stepped down within a month due to protests and discontent over possible vote rigging, and the Shah appointed Imani, who was not aligned with a party.
nelda48notes: There is no evidence that international monitors were requested to attend.
nelda50notes: Iran under the Shah had a pro-Western foreign policy, and a defense agreement with the US, and had received more than 500 million in aid, investment and loans from the US since 1951
nelda54notes: The US was by far the most important source of money and support for the government. The IMF did loan some money but not nearly as much.
nelda58notes: Though the USSR had earlier warned Iran that they would be considered hostile if they signed the 1958 defense agreement with the US, there were no threats at this time or linked to the elections

notes: Members of the opposition also called for a boycott of the election. Thus, the election was widely perceived to be a contest between supporters of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei. Both groups of supporters make up the ruling Conservative alliance. The majority of seats were determined in the first round, which was considered to have been a landslide victory for supporters of the supreme leader, also referred to as the Principists. After the conclusion of the first round, Iranian media outlets announced that supporters of the Supreme leader had won about 75% of the seats to the 290-seat Majilis.

notes: Members of the opposition also called for a boycott of the election. Thus, the election was widely perceived to be a contest between supporters of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei. Both groups of supporters make up the ruling Conservative alliance. The majority of seats were determined in the first round, which was considered to have been a landslide victory for supporters of the supreme leader, also referred to as the Principists. The second round determined the remaining 65 seats of the 290-seat Majilis. The election resulted in the Conservative coalition winning a total of 182 seats, the reformist coalition secured 75 seats, 14 seats went to religious minorities, and the remaining 19 seats were won by independent candidates.

notes: Interesting election which takes place against the backdrop of heightened tensions with the US and a deep domestic economic crisis, worsened by the impact of international sanctions. The idiosyncratic Ahmadinejad is no longer eligible for the presidency, having already served two terms, and he is thus succeeded by Rouhani, who is regarded as more moderate. The nature of the Iranian political system and electoral process - extremely opaque and riddled by fraud - make it such that free and fair elections are impossible, and this election reinforces that assessment.

notes: This is the first Turkish election where parliamentarians do not choose the President. Instead, the public chooses (popular vote). The referendum that made this change took place to put this new rule in place 2007. Turkish Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan, who served as the country's head of government since 2003, was elected president.

Stakes high due to ongoing peace process with the Kurds, a stumbling democracy, an economic recession on the horizon, the prospect of constitutional reform, a stalled EU accession process, and tension in Turkey-U.S. relations. The election was widely regarded as a referendum of sorts on the president's call for greater executive powers.

Snap election: President Erdogan was hoping that his Islamist Justice and Development Party would secure a resounding majority of the seats in parliament. A super-majority would position him to make constitutional changes that would result in greater presidential powers. Leftist, pro-Kurdish HDP party passes 10% of vote share, enough to deny president a �supermajority� and consequent constitutional changes.

notes: The political framework of Iraq is  a federal parliamentary representative democratic republic. Under the amended Iraqi constitution, the members of parliament are elected in a popular election. Those who comprise the parliament later vote for the Prime Minister and for the president, but these general elections themselves do not determine who is elected Prime Minister or president of Iraq. This is an interesting election because prior to its commencement, the Supreme Court of Iraq found the electoral system to be unconstitutional and in need of amendment.
