notes: These mid-term elections were for the Majlis Ash-Shura, or Shoura Assembly, which is the upperhouse of the Egyptial bicameral parliament. At stake were half of the 176 directly elected seats (there are 264 seats over all). These 2007 elections were the first held under new constitutional amendments, passes in March 2007, which abolished judicial supervision of elections and banned political activities based on religion. This was understood to handicap the electoral chances of the Muslim Brotherhood (MB), an Islamic opposition group banned since 1954. Despite the government�s crackdown on the MB, the group fielded 19 candidates who ran as �independents.� In the lead up to these elections, approximately 800 MB members were detained and two of the other main opposition parties - the New Wafd Party and the Nasserist Arab Democratic Party � declared that they would boycott the elections, due to the unfair constitutional amendments. MB-backed candidates kept a low profile during the election campaign, in the face of a police crack-down. During polling, some opposition supporters were barred from entering polling stations, and some polling stations in MB strongholds were simply closed.   A total of 60 of the 77 candidates secured the majority vote required to be elected in the first round (11 June). The NDP took 59 of these seats while the opposition Tagammu Party took one. In the second round (18 June) the NDP won all 17 remaining seats. Thus the NDP won 87 seats of the 88 contested seats (up from 85 in 2004). The MB accused the government of gross fraud and irregularities in the voting procedure.
nelda3notes: Though the difficult conditions for oppositoin parties meant that of the 609 candidates contesting this election, 69 candidates came from opposition parties.
nelda11notes: There had been a harsh crack-down on the Muslim Brotherhood including many arrests, the new constitutional amendments were thought to make room for fraud, and two main opposition parties boycotted.
nelda13notes: The Muslim Brotherhood was banned, meaning their candidates had to run unofficially, as independents. Roughly 800 members of the Muslim Brotherhood were reportedly detained in the lead up to these elections.
nelda14notes: These elections were boycotted by two opposition parties - the New Wafd Party and the Nasserist Arab Democratic Party - which had formerly been part of the coalition with the Muslim Brotherhood (known as the National Front for Change) in the 2005 elections.
nelda15notes: There had been a harsh crack-down on the Muslim Brotherhood including up to 800 arrests, opposition members chose to keep a low profile, and many suspected oppositoin supporters were barred from the polling stations. The Economist of June 16 reported that, on voting day, riot police had surrounded polling stations in districts where Brotherhood candidates had a chance of winning.
nelda19notes: Particularly from the US
nelda27notes: In the previous elections for the upper house, held in 2004, the ruling National Democratic Party (NDP) of President Hosni Mubarak won 85 of the 88 directly elected seats. In these elections, a total of 60 candidates secured the majority vote required to be elected in the first round (11 June). The NDP took 59 of these seats while the opposition Tagammu Party took one. In the second round (18 June) the NDP won all 17 remaining seats. Thus the NDP won 87 seats of the 88 contested seats (up from 85 in 2004).
nelda28notes: The MB publically accused the government of gross violations and irregularities, noting that many of their supporters had been barred from voting. The government was forced to issue a denial.
nelda33notes: Clashes between supporters of independent (therefore rival) candidates and Mubarak's NDP supporters resulted in the death of one man, with several others injured. Police arrested 400 MB members.

notes: These were the first of three elections to be held in Egypt over the next 16 months. These 2010 elections were for 88 (half) of the 176 directly elected members in the Shoura Assembly, the upper house of the bicameral Parliament. Later in the year, the more hotly-contested People�s Assembly would have elections.  These Shoura elections saw more opposition parties field candidates than usual � in the previous elections, the repressive political atmosphere had discouraged many from taking part. However, a recent constitutional amendment meant that parties must hold seats in either house of the Parliament to field a Presidential candidate (elections would be held in 2011), thus encouraging the opposition parties to engage more fully with these elections. However, the main opposition parties - the Wafd, the Tagammu party and the Arab Democratic Nasserist Party - failed to form an electoral coalition. The illegal Muslim Brotherhood (MB) backed 14 independent candidates. The MB were officially banned, though the media focused on whether the MB would fare well in these Shoura Assembly elections as a forecast of the People�s Assembly elections due in late 2010. The MB reported that its candidates faced growing hostility as the elections approached. Forty of its members were arrested during the campaign, and Mubarak�s security forces used violence to break up opposition rallies. During voting, many opposition supporters were refused access to voting stations. The MB and the opposition Wafd Party accused the NDP of vote rigging. Ultimately, the NDP won 80 of the 88 contested seats, while four opposition parties won a seat each. The MB-backed candidates did not win any seats.
nelda14notes: Though most of the main opposition did not boycott (they had in 2007) on account of the fact that they wanted to win a seat, which was a requisite for fielding a Presidential candidate in the upcoming 2011 elections, other smaller parties opted to boycott, such as the liberal National Democratic Front.
nelda15notes: The MB and other opposition parties said that its candidates faced growing hostility as the elections approached. Forty of the MB's members were arrested during the campaign. Essam El-Erian, an MB spokesman, reported that a Brotherhood election monitor in Beheira, a governorate about 50 miles northwest of Cairo, was shot as he tried enter a polling station and was sent to hospital with a broken femur. The Brotherhood also accused the NDP of harassing their candidates in the run-up to the elections, putting them under 24-hour surveillance, removing the organization�s campaign posters from the streets. State security also fired live ammunition and tear gas into an opposition crowd to disperse a campaign rally in Beheira.
nelda17notes: Though growth was still acceptable, it had slowed recently and thus was a subject of discussion for these elections.
nelda19notes: Particularly from the US.
nelda27notes: In the previous Shoura Assembly elections (2007), the ruling National Democratic Party (NDP) of Hosni Mubarak swept 87 of the 88 seats at stake. In these elections, the NDP won 74 seats in the first round and 6 in the second round. Four opposition parties won a seat each, though the MB-backed candidates did not win any seats. Hence the NDP�s representation dropped from 87 in 2007 to 80 in these elections.
nelda28notes: . The Electoral Commission ultimately received 498 complaints about the electoral process.
nelda29notes: In fact, there were protests in Egypt around this time, though they were not directly related to these elections. The protests erupted after the brutal torture and murder of Khaled Said, a blogger who had put a video of corrupt police activities online. Human Rights Watch on June 30 clamed that on June 10, 13, and 20, security officials had beaten and arbitrarily arrested demonstrators peacefully protesting Said's death. On June 25th, 4,000 Egyptians had taken to the streets in Alexandria.
nelda33notes: There was considerable violence on the behalf of security forces, including the firing of live ammunition into campaign rallies in Beheira and the non-fatal shooting of an MB election monitor.
nelda48notes: Opposition parties and NGOs called for international supervision for these elections, but Mubarak's NDP refused. The Secretary of Education for the NDP announced that while the NDP welcomed national monitors, international observation was unacceptable.

notes: These were the second of three elections to be held in Egypt over 16 months. These 2010 elections were for the lower house of the bicameral Parliament, the People's Assembly. These elections were the first held under the new Constitutional amendment introduced in June 2009 that raised the number of members of the People's Assembly from 454 to 518. Previous to these elections, a pro-democratic movement had slowly been building momentum: in February 2010, Nobel Peace Prize laureate and former Director of the IAEA Mohamed ElBaradei launched a campaign calling for change. The Muslim Brotherhood was one of the strongest opposition forces, though it was officially banned (since 1954). Its members were allowed to run for election only as independent candidates. In these 2010 elections, the major opposition parties included the New Wafd Party (NWP), which fielded 168 candidates; the National Progressive Unionist Grouping (Tagammu, 66 candidates) and the Nasserist Party (31 candidates). In addition, 135 MB-backed independent candidates declared they would be running.  In the first round, 209 NDP candidates, 7 independents, and 5 opposition candidates earned the required majority to be elected (no MB-backed candidates). Ultimately in these 2010 elections, the NDP took 427 of the 512 contested seats, and opposition parties took only 16. The remaining 69 seats went to independent candidates, many of whom were considered close to the NDP. It is difficult to directly compare if the opposition gained as the number of seats available had been altered since 2005, but generally speaking in the 2005 elections the NDP won 72.4% of the contested seats, while in these elections they won 83.4%. Hence the opposition lost ground. Polling day was marred by protests and violent clashes, with opposition parties reporting vote rigging, multiple voting, and the use of intimidation against their supporters. This fraught state of affairs caused the MB and the NWP to call for the cancellation of the second round, a request that was refused. T
nelda11notes: The elections for the upper house, the Shoura Assembly, held just months before these in June, had been marred by widespread fraud and police violence. Even Amnesty International issued a rare press statement on the plight of the Muslim Brotherhood members in Egypt, demanding the Egyptian authorities release or charge the members who had been arrested in the lead up to this election with a recognizable crime.
nelda13notes: Many Muslim Brotherhood members were arrested in the lead up to these elections, and a dozen of the candidates backed by the MB were disqualified from the contest.
nelda14notes: In February 2010, Nobel Peace Prize laureate and former Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency Mohamed ElBaradei launched a campaign calling for government and electoral change. In September before these elections, ElBaradei urged all opposition forces to boycott the elections on the grounds that election fraud would predetermine results. Though most parties still participated, some did not: the Tomorrow Party (Al-Ghad) of former presidential candidate Ayman Nour announced that it would boycott the elections.
nelda15notes: Over 1,200 MB supporters were arrested while campaigning or in clashes with police in the run-up to these elections.
nelda16notes: In October before these elections, the country's telecommunications regulator set new rules for companies sending text messages to multiple mobile phones,such that they were forced to obtain licences, which were rarely forthcoming. Furthermore, the main satellite operator shut down 12 private television channels on grounds of violating the terms of their broadcasting licences. The opposition party NWP criticized the media clamp-down.
nelda19notes: Particularly from the US.
nelda27notes: These elections were the first held under the new Constitutional amendment introduced in June 2009 that raised the number of members of the People's Assembly from 454 to 518. In the previous People�s Assembly elections of 2005, President Mubarak's National Democratic Party (NDP) won 320 of the 442 directly elected seats. The National Front for Change (NFC) - an opposition coalition comprising 12 opposition parties and the Muslim Brotherhood (MB) - took 96 seats, of which 88 were attributed to the MB, six the New Wafd Party (NWP) and 2 the National Progressive Unionist Grouping (Tagammu). Ultimately in these 2010 elections, the NDP took 427 of the 512 contested seats, and opposition parties took only 16. The remaining 69 seats went to independent candidates, many of whom were considered close to the NDP. It is difficult to directly compare if the opposition gained as the number of seats available had been altered since 2005, but generally speaking in the 2005 elections the NDP won 72.4% of the contested seats, while in these elections they won 83.4%. Hence the opposition lost ground.
nelda28notes: The violence and rampant fraud of these elections caused the MB and the NWP to publically call for the cancellation of the second round run-off elections, a request that was refused. The MB and the NWP then withdrew their candidates from the run-off, and after several MB-backed candidates filed appeals with the Administrative Judicial Court, on December 5th the Supreme Administrative Court (SAC) issued seven rulings, including an order that the run-offs be halted in Cairo. The SAC rulings would have voided 184 of the 508 directly elected seats, thus leaving only 324 members, a number insufficient to hold the People�s Assembly under the constitution. Thus, as the elections had failed to elect the minimum number of members, the SAC invalidated both rounds of the elections and ordered that new elections be held. This debate was the subject of Egyptian public discourse throughout this highly fraught month.
nelda29notes: The massive fraud in the first round caused the MB and the NWP to call for the cancellation of the second round, a request that was refused. The MB and the NWP then withdrew their candidates from the run-off, a move which was declared �illegal� by the Higher Elections Commission such that the withdrawn candidates would be considered to have been defeated. This tense period was filled with public demonstrations.
nelda30notes: The Muslim Brotherhood staged demonstrations at vote-counting centres to protest the rampant rigging, for example in Mansoura around 1,000 people gathered to chant religious and political slogans. In another close-by town, Mahalla, police beat protesters with batons.
nelda33notes: Nine people were killed in election violence. Police officers violently used batons and tear gas to disperse a group of more than 1,000 people trying to observe the vote-counting process in the working-class Nile Delta town of Mahalla.
nelda34notes: However, it should be noted that this election was in fact cancelled by the Supreme Administrative court, though the Higher Election Commission ignored the ruling. The massive fraud in the first round caused the MB and the NWP to call for the cancellation of the second round, and furthermore, several MB-backed candidates filed appeals with the Administrative Judicial Court in order to declare the results of the elections null on grounds of vote rigging. Multiple circuits of the court ordered that the announcement of results should be halted. Then on December 5th, the Supreme Administrative Court (SAC) issued seven ruling, including an order that the run-offs be halted in Cairo. The SAC rulings would have voided 184 of the 508 directly elected seats, thus leaving only 324 members, a number insufficient to hold the People�s Assembly under the constitution. Thus, as the elections had failed to elect the minimum number of members, the SAC invalidated both rounds of the elections and ordered that new elections be held. Instead, the Higher Election Commission dismissed the SAC decision and defended the integrity of the results. Hence ultimately, the results were not cancelled.
nelda48notes: Mubarak's regime would not agree to have international observers at these elections.

notes: This was the first round of the three phases of legislative elections for the People's Assembly of Egypt in order to elect 498 seats. Each phase represents a different region of the country, and the first round elections in the phases were staggered. The first round of the first phase started on November 28th, 2011. The first round of the second phase started on December 14th, 2011. The first round of the third phase started on January 3rd, 2012. The Freedom and Justice Party obtained 49% of seats in the first phase, 48% of seats in the second phase, and 37.5% of seats  in the third phase.
nelda1notes: Elections were originally scheduled for September of 2011, but were suspended due to fears that established parties would gain an unfair advantage from the earlier date.

notes: This was the second round of the three phases of legislative elections for the People's Assembly of Egypt in order to elect 498 seats. Each phase represents a different region of the country, and the second round elections in the phases took place following the first round in each phase. The second round of the first phase took place on December 5th, 2011. The second round of the second phase took place on December 21st, 2011. The second round of the third phase took place on January 11th, 2012. The Freedom and Justice Party obtained 49% of seats in the first phase, 48% of seats in the second phase, and 37.5% of seats in the third phase.

notes: This was the first election in Syria since the end of the French mandate, complete withdrawal of French troops from the country, and the implementation of a new electoral law. Information on this election is fragmentary; little substantive information could be found about the conduct of it. However, the research indicated that the election was a seen as a decline for the National Bloc, which had been the leading party in the parliament since the last election in 1943 and to which the president, Shukri al-Kuwatli, also belonged. As the National Bloc (National Party) lead the coalition formed afterward, they won the election despite a decline.
nelda1notes: This was the first direct parliamentary election; all previous ones had been indirect.
nelda24notes: Even though the National Bloc (which was succeeded in this election by the National Party) lost seats, it took part  in the government coalition formed after the election.
nelda30notes: The riots were mostly between rival tribal groups.
nelda33notes: One person died in election-related violence before the election was held.

notes: This was the first election in Syria since the end of the French mandate, complete withdrawal of French troops from the country, and the implementation of a new electoral law. Information on this election is fragmentary; however, research indicates that the election was a decline for the National Bloc, which had been the leading party in the parliament since the last election in 1943 and to which the president, Shukri al-Kuwatli, also belonged. The ruling party continued its rule in a coalition, however. This second round changed nothing from the results of the first round, as it only involved some 35 seats of 142.

notes: After the June presidential elections, al-Zaim was deposed in a second military coup, this one led by Sami Hannawi and also promising democratic reform. While Hannawi, the army officer who led the coup, is listed as the de facto leader of Syria at the time, many saw these elections - used to elect a constituent assembly that would also focus as a parliament - to be the freest elections ever in the Middle East and a true harbinger of multiparty democracy. However, before the elected government could even convene, another coup toppled Hannawi's government.

notes: Adib al-Shishakli had deposed Hannawi in a December 1949 military coup, and had since then ruled effectively as a dictator (there had been several indirect elections in the intervening years) through his puppet, Fawzi Selo. Concurrent with this election was a referendum on a new constitution for Syria based on the United States' constitution. This election was mere show in an attempt to legitimize his regime.

notes: Adib al-Shishakli had deposed Hannawi in a December 1949 military coup, and had since then ruled effectively as a dictator. He was elected president in a July 10th election that also approved a new constitution. Per the new electoral rules, a parliamentary election had to be held. Political parties, banned at the presidential election of 1953, were reinstated shortly before the October parliamentary election, with Shishakli's Arab Liberation Movement leading.
nelda2notes: Political parties had been officially disbanded for the presidential election, but were allowed once more for this one.
nelda3notes: All leaders of opposition parties boycotted the election and refused to run. Only one member of the parliament was not of Shishakli's Arab Liberation Movement.
nelda7notes: The election did not involve the incumbent's position.
nelda14notes: Most opposition candidates boycotted the election by backing out the day before the election.
nelda52notes: Shishakli's policies  were regarded as more pro-American.

notes: Mere months after Shishakli's 1953 election as president, popular unrest sparked yet another military coup. This time, the military turned over power to an appointed caretaker government under former president Hashim al-Atassi in order to arrange new, fair parliamentary elections. Former president Kuwatli urged Syria's political parties to join together in a grand coalition under his leadership, and all acceded save the Socialists and Communists. Independent candidates managed to gain the plurality, with the People's Party being the largest organized party represented in the new Parliament.
nelda1notes: Between the previous year's elections and this one, there had been another military coup.
nelda7notes: The election did not involve the incumbent's position.
nelda11notes: The army was forbidden from interfering.
nelda33notes: Three people were killed and 60 wounded in politically-motivated violence after the election.
nelda51notes: Shishakli had been pro-US, or at least friendly, but the new parliament was less so.

notes: Mere months after Shishakli's 1953 election as president, popular unrest sparked yet another military coup. This time, the military turned over power to an appointed caretaker government under former president Hashim al-Atassi in order to arrange new, fair parliamentary elections. Former president Kuwatli urged Syria's political parties to join together in a grand coalition under his leadership, and all acceded save the Socialists and Communists. Independent candidates managed to gain the plurality, with the People's Party being the largest organized party represented in the new Parliament. This second round of elections merely confirmed what the first round had suggested, with only 35 seats up for a vote the second time around.

notes: Election takes place during the Syrian Civil War and is widely deemed a sham. Backdrop of economic disaster, bloodshed across the country, and very little political or electoral transparency. notes: These elections were fought between the 14 March Coalition and the 8 March coalition � both named after a series of demonstrations that followed the assassination of former Prime Minister Hariri by suspected Syrian/pro-Syrian forces in 2005.  The 14 March coalition (which comprised much of the incumbent outgoing parliamentary majority and was Western-backed) was a mainly Sunni movement led by Saad Hariri, son of the assassinated Prime Minister Rafik Hariri. It included the Progressive Socialist Party, the Christian Lebanese Forces, and the Christian Phalangist party, as well as numerous smaller groups. The opposition 8 March coalition includes the Iranian-backed Shia Hezbollah and the pro-Syrian Shia Amal movement headed by Nabih Berri. Other key players in the opposition bloc are the (mainly Christian) Free Patriotic Movement of former army General Michel Aoun. Ultimately the Western and Saudi-backed 14 March incumbent coalition, which won a slim parliamentary majority in the last election in 2005, claimed a narrow victory in the face of a strong challenge from the Hezbollah-led opposition backed by Syria and Iran (71 seats compared to the opposition�s 57). On the one hand, because these elections passed in relative calm, they were seen as a triumph of democracy. On the other hand, because they reproduced the same divisions that had rocked the country for years, it was seen as heralding little change.
nelda7notes: These elections would determine the Prime Minister (a key position), but President is the head of state in Lebanon, and s/he is determined by an indirect vote of Parliament.
nelda11notes: Because the elections were so heavily monitored by both sides and international forces, and because so much was hanging on them there was not fear of them being conducted badly. There was, however, fear of violence breaking out or the losing parties refusing to accept results.
nelda15notes: There had been much violence from both pro-Syrian and pro-Western forces in the years between the 2005 elections and these elections, but because times were so tense before these elections, harrassing each other was too risky.
nelda17notes: Given the global economic downturn, Lebanon was thought to be doing alright, but was suffering nevertheless. The Economist Intelligence Unit in 2009 revised downward its economic growth forecast for 2009 Lebanon to 2.4 percent from 2.7 percent, while in parallel, it increased its estimate for real GDP growth for 2008 to 6.3 percent from 4.2 percent.
nelda19notes: The US gives a lot of aid to Lebanon.
nelda24notes: President Suleiman was distinctly independent - this is the only way both poles of Lebanese politics would accept him as their president.
nelda27notes: The opposition had a vote count gain of only one seat: the final results gave victory to the 14 March Coalition with 71 seats, while in the 2005 elections, former Hariri�s coalition (now manifest in the 14 March coaltion) won 72 seats compared to the 56 of the oppositon, thus the 2009 elections showed a slight gain (of one seat) for the opposition.
nelda29notes: In fact, to considerable surprise, Hezbollah's TV station, al-Manar, carried 14 March leader Hariri's victory speech live in the middle of the night, and conceded immediately afterwards that the March 14 had won a majority. The results were smoothly accepted by Lebanese standards.
nelda33notes: The Lebanese media reported two cases of politically- motivated arson and three cases of political partisans shooting at their rivals. Burned and vandalized campaign posters and billboards were common sights in various parts of the county. On the whole though, it was remarked that widespread violence of the kind previously seen in Lebanon was not evident in this election.
nelda46notes: International observers attended from the EU, the Arab League, the Carter Foundation, the Turkish government and the US National Democratic Institute.
nelda47notes: The EU's Election Observation Mission praised the participatory spirit of the Lebanese elections, though it gave recommendations such as including the use of pre-printed ballot papers. The Carter Center's observation mission praised the democratic progress seen, but also noted various shortcomings and recommended that the electoral system be made more representative. In general, significant vote fraud was not observed.

nelda58notes: The US warned that it would review aid to Lebanon if the (pro-Syrian, pro-Iranian and anti-Israel) 8 March Coalition won the elections.

notes: A rubber-stamp election that allowed for the transition of power from the autocratici incumbent Saleh to his Vice President, Hadi.  Inspired by the Arab Spring, protests against Saleh exploded in 2011 as separatist groups form the North and South began to challenge his power through violent protests. Saleh was forced to agree to early elections that would lead to his replacement, part of a deal orchestrated by the Gulf Cooperation Council in response to the rampant anti-government protests. Only one candidate would be on the ballot, making the election more of a formality than anything else. Despite the lack of potential for voter fraud, the election was marred with its own share of problems--namely, chaotic election violence before, during, and after the fact. The newly elected President Hadi will oversee the two-year transitional period to new leadership.
nelda5notes: Although there was no rule against having another candidate, there was only one candidate on the ballot, Abd Rabuh Mansur HADI.
nelda6notes: The election took place in order to oust the incumbent, Saleh. Largely inspired by the Arab Spring, protests against Saleh began to take flight in 2011, Saleh finally agreed to a peaceful power transfer orchestrated by the Gulf Cooperation Council that would replace Saleh with his vice president, Hadi. The GCC called for early elections to allow for the transition as quickly as possible.
nelda11notes: election that would finalize the transition of power to vice president Hadi. There were no opponents.
nelda25notes: This question is really not applicable given that there was only one choice of candidate on the ballot.
nelda33notes: There was a tremendous amount of violence before, during, and after the election. This was largely due to the tumultuous state of the country in the first place, regardless of the rubber-stamp election. The anti-Saleh protests quickly escalated into violence before the election, separatist rebel groups (from the North and South) engaged in violence during the election to encourage boycotting, and anti-government protests failed to subside after Hadi's official approval. In fact, violence was so rampant throughout the election process that a number of polling stations were forced to shut down.
nelda47notes: Voter-fraud was not the focus of the observations; rather, election violence was the main concern.

notes: Legislative elections took took place in Bahrain in November 2014. The legislative branch of government is a bicameral National Assembly, consisting of the Consultative Council (40 members appointed by the King) and the Council of Representatives or Chamber of Deputies (40 seats; members are directly elected to serve four-year terms). The 2014 election would be in the lower house -- the Council of Representatives or Chamber of Deputies. The election itself was boycotted by the Shiite Islamist opposition; elections were boycotted by the Shi�ite Muslim opposition over accusations that constituency changes would still favor the Sunni Muslim majority represented by the ruling family. Overall, the government announced the voter turnout as 52.6%, (although the opposition undermined this and said claimed it was only 30%).
First popular elections for membership to the Consultative Assembly. These elected positions have no direct power, as all decision-making authority is vested in the ruling monarch.

Election held for the advisory Consultative Assembly. Political parties are banned and the monarch has the power to negate election results if desired. Voters do not directly elect the parliamentary leaders into their seats on the Consultative Assembly. The top three candidates per local district (as determined by the electorate) are nominated to a committee, which then filters the nominated names and offers a final list to the Sultan. Sultan Qaboos Bin Said then decides who shall serve on the legislature.

nelda19notes: Afghanistan received aid from the UK, US and USSR.
nelda24notes: It is unclear the exact affiliations of those who were elected, but the parliament that was elected was not controlled by pro-government factions.

notes: The election occurred sometime in February (date of February 1 is an estimate). Occurred after a suppression of rights in 1951 and 1952, and was considered a regression from the 1949 election.
nelda2notes: No parties were legally recognized.
nelda3notes: All candidates ran as independents. There was no legal opposition.
nelda5notes: There were 2 opposition candidates in Kabul, but in the rest of the country the people voted for the official candidate chosen by the local government.

nelda24notes: Though there was no clear party in power before the election, the council was controlled by a primarily anti-government faction, and the government faction took control in the election.

notes: Legislative elections were held in Afghanistan from August 26th to September 8th, 1965 (Round 1 of 1).

notes: This was the first democratic election for the lower chamber since the adoption of a new constitution the previous year (elections for the upper chamber took place the previous month).
nelda3notes: Parties were not legalized under the new constitution until the 2nd set of elections.
nelda6notes: The elections were held a year after a new constitution was passed, a year after they otherwise would have been held.
nelda12notes: There were no legal political parties
nelda19notes: Afghanistan received significant aid, including from the US.
nelda20notes: Although the prime minister changed after the election, he was not elected nor directly affiliated with a party (as there were no parties in this election). The PM changed as a new cabinet was formed but was not directly elected.
nelda24notes: The incumbent was not affiliated with a party.
nelda29notes: Students rioted after the election in anger at the cabinet being formed, which led to the resignation of the prime minister.

nelda2notes: Candidates had to stand as independents. Party laws were not assented to by the King.
nelda12notes: Although there were no parties, conservative candidates were confident of victory.
nelda19notes: Afghanistan received aid from the USSR and the US.
nelda27notes: Pro-Soviet candidates lost seats.
nelda29notes: There was civil unrest leading up to election.
nelda33notes: There was civil unrest, but there was no evidence of deaths.

notes: The election was held during the civil war in Afghanistan, in the wake of the recent Soviet withdrawal.
nelda1notes: The Soviet invasion disrupted political life.
nelda10notes: Soviet troops had just left, and the ruling puppet government oversaw a government of national reconciliation which allowed rebels to vote.
nelda13notes: Some opposition leaders were prevented from running. The rebel muhajedeen were still fighting a civil war despite government assurances that rebels could run for office.
nelda14notes: Many of the rebels chose to fight instead of being incorporated into the political system.
nelda24notes: Western news reports did not have exact figures; however, the Afghani election commission annouced that the government party (PDPA) lost seats and were in the minority.
nelda27notes: It is unknown which parties won how many seats.
nelda33notes: There was an ongoing civil war.
nelda45notes: The UN helped mediate between the government and the rebels. However, there were no news reports of foreign election observers in Afghanistan.
nelda50notes: The US government supported the rebels.

notes: These were the first elections that were held after the Taliban was ousted from the government.
nelda6notes: Elections were originally scheduled for January 2004, were put off until September 2004, and finally took place in October 2004.
nelda8notes: An Afghani Constitutional Assembly met and completed a new constitution in January 2004, paving the way for a presidential election to be held and ending the interim government of Hamid Karzai.
nelda11notes: There were significant concerns that Hamid Karzai's close relationship with the U.S. and the influence wielded by the U.S. would prevent the elections from being free and fair.
nelda14notes: Before elections, opposition candidates threatened to boycott the election unless Hamid Karzai stepped down from his post as interim leader to campaign. Following the elections, 15 of the presidential candidates alleged voter fraud.
nelda25notes: Hamid Karzai was greatly favored to win, but reliable polls could not be found.
nelda28notes: There were allegations of voter fraud and general criticism by members of the opposition; however, it is unclear how far this information was distributed.
nelda29notes: Most opposition candidates, including powerful regional leaders and some who have large private militias, condemned the election as fraudulent and illegitimate. However, there do not seem to have been mass protests/riots post-election.
nelda33notes: The election was more violence- free than expected, and this question has thus been coded No. However there were numbers of incidents involving violence both before during and after the election, with a few deaths following the elections.

notes: These were Afghanistan's first parliamentary elections since the transition from American occupation.
nelda1notes: This is the first parliamentary election since transition from American rule.
nelda2notes: This is the first parliamentary election since transition from American rule.
nelda4notes: Parties are legal, but the legislature is non-partisan.
nelda10notes: There was an interim government, but it was not tasked with holding elections.
nelda12notes: The legislature is non-partisan.
nelda15notes: About 300 woman candidates received death threats, but it is unlikely the government was responsible.
nelda19notes: The US had just turned over rule after its occupation.
nelda24notes: The incumbent was not associated with a party that ran in this election.
nelda33notes: 8 candidates were killed.
nelda52notes: The US was happy to see the first parliamentary elections in Afghanistan after it toppled the Taliban regime.

notes: Election day for these Presidential elections was recorded as one of the bloodiest since the war began in 2001 - bombs, shelling, and insurgent attacks prevented many from accessing polling stations. Prior to the elections, Karzai had engaged in a systematic effort to collect or buy voter registration cards from local people. Western diplomats predicted that precautions designed to prevent fraud would be ineffective in insecure districts of the south, where election monitors could not go. Campaigning during these elections was severely restricted by security problems, with the rebel Taliban committed to disrupting the electoral process. President Hamid Karzai and his chief rival, former foreign minister Abdullah Abdullah, were to be the only two candidates in a November 7th runoff election. However, Afghanistan's Independent Election Commission canceled the second round of voting after Abdullah withdrew from the race. Abdullah had demanded major changes to guard against a repetition of the widespread fraud found to have marred the first round of this Presidential vote (coded here).
nelda6notes: Under the 2004 constitution, elections should have been held no later than 60 days before the end of President Karzai's term in July 2009. However, the International Election Commission (IEC) announced on Jan. 29 that presidential elections had been postponed until Aug. 20, because of security concerns and logistical difficulties (accessing mountain areas and insufficient materials). This decision meant that the poll would not take place until three months after the expiry on May 22 of the term of presidential incumbent Hamid Karzai. This decision was highly controversial, as opposition groups accused Karzai of extending his time in power, and questioned the legality of Karzai's stated intention to remain in office during the interim period.
nelda8notes: Karzai was eligible to run again.
nelda9notes: Constitutionally, Karzai should have stepped down when his term expired in May. Because the elections were postponed for three months, he declared his intention to stay in power for these extra three months.
nelda11notes: Before the elections, numerous world press articles emerged detailing the systematic attempt by supporters of Karzai to collect or buy voter registration cards from local people. Furthermore, prior to the elections, Western diplomats predicted that precautions designed to prevent fraud would be ineffective in insecure districts of the south, where election monitors could not go. It was also reported that Karzai forged political alliances with leading Afghan warlords who controlled militias and tribal networks, in order to carry out a vote fraud schemes accounting for a very large proportion of the votes.
nelda12notes: Karzai's victory in a run off was uncertain. These elections were presented by the media as competitive, as it was not thought that Karzai would earn enough votes to win outright.
nelda14notes: The Taliban called for a boycott of the election.
nelda18notes: Still in the midst of a bloody war, Afghanistan was split between Karzai and Western control, Taliban control, and warlord control.
nelda24notes: Karzai was an Independent candidate unattached to a particular party.
nelda25notes: The U.S. financed two main polls, conducted by Glevum Associates and the International Republican Institute.
nelda26notes: The polls showed Karzai leading. However, his lead was not enough to avoid a second-round run off according to these polls: the poll by Glevum Associates showed Karzai at 36 percent, and the survey by the International Republican Institute had him at 44 percent of the vote.
nelda27notes: In the 2004 election Karzai had won 55.4%, exempting him from a run-off. In these elections, he had fallen short of this mark, with 49.67%. His closest opposition, Abdullah Abdullah, had earned a significant 30.59%.
nelda28notes: The world was awash with reports of the blood spatter and well-documented fraud that characterized this election. From Western Election Monitors to the Taliban, Karzai's government was panned for its conduct during these elections.
nelda33notes: Taliban attacks increased in intensity, proficile and number in the run-up to this election. These included a suicide car-bomb attack on NATO headquarters in Kabul five days before the election, in which at least 7 people died and 90 were injured. The two days before the election were marred by Taliban bomb, rocket, and mortar attacks, including a suicide attack on a NATO convoy on which killed at least 10 people - all in the capital. Despite a government blackout on news reporting of election day violence, it was clear that there were numerous attacks and fatalities to police, troops, and civilians. Indeed, the International Security Assistance Force estimated that more than 400 Taliban attacks had taken place on election day. Human Rights Watch remarked that this was one of the most violent days in Afghanistan since the beginning of the war in 2001. Polling stations were frequently closed due to violence.
nelda47notes: about fraud after detecting unusually high turnout in some Taliban-plagued regions.
nelda51notes: There were higher politics at work, and too much invested in the success of Afghanistan as a state to allow Karzai's behavior in these elections to negatively affect his alliance with the West against the Taliban.
nelda57notes: Too much was at stake in terms of international reputation, democratic sustainability, and anti-insurgency efforts to risk  cutting off aid to Afghanistan.
nelda58notes: The Western forces attempted very strongly to influence Karzai's conduct during these elections, in the hopes of making them as democratic as possible.

notes: These elections are for the lower house of the bicameral legislature, the House of Representatives. These elections were intensely violent and marred by widescale fraud. A major issue thought to have upped the stakes of these elections was that holding credible polls was seen as a key step for Afghan forces towards taking control of the country's security by 2014 in order to allow the withdrawal of US troops. Though the absence of political parties (they are legal, but most candidates stand as independents) makes it difficult to determine the changing lines of support and opposition for incumbent President Karzai, it was thought that his support waned in the outcome of these elections. His ethnic group - Pashtun - lost seast, 90 compared to 112 in the 2005 elections.
nelda2notes: Previous House of Representative elections had been held in 2005.
nelda6notes: These parliamentary elections were initially called for 22 May, but the Independent Election Commission announced in January 2010 that they would be postponed to autumn 2010. The IEC cited budget problems, security concerns and logistical hurdles. A similar postponement had occurred for the Presidential elections the year previous.
nelda11notes: The Presidential elections the year before had been panned with widespread allegations of fraud. Months before this election on 17 February 2010, President Karzai issued a presidential decree amending the Electoral Law of Afghanistan. Among key changes, the decree granted the President the right to appoint all five commissioners of the Electoral Complaints Commission - this was not thought to be a good omen for the free-and-fair nature of elections.
nelda12notes: Afghan members of parliament are largely independent candidates, unassociated with parties. Indeed, only 9 per cent of the candidates running in these elections were formally affiliated with a political party. Ethnicity rather than party affiliation is the main factor influencing political alliances.
nelda13notes: When the campaign for these elections officilaly began on June 23, there were 2,577 officially registered candidates. Later 36 candidates were prevented from running (legally disqualified) on the grounds that they had links with private militias.
nelda14notes: The Taliban ordered an election boycott and announced that it would attack the 2010 polls. It stated that anyone associated with the poll would be a legitimate target.
nelda16notes: The incumbent, Karzai, was unaffiliated with a party and only loosely affiliated with candidates for the House of Representatives.
nelda18notes: Still in the midst of a bloody war, Afghanistan was split between Karzai and Western control, Taliban control, and warlord control.
nelda24notes: No party is associated with Karzai.
nelda27notes: In the absence of formal political parties, observers were mostly agreed that opponents of President Hamid Karzai had gained some ground in these elections. Pashtuns, the country's traditional rulers, won around 90 seats, as opposed to the 112 obtained in the 2005 elections. Being the main allies of President Karzai (who is Pashtun), support for President was believed to have been reduced in the new legislature. The decrease was partially attributed to the fact that voting did not take place in some Pashtun areas. An analysis of the results by the New York Times concluded that Karzai would be able to count on the support of at least 100 members of the new House. His main opponent in the presidential election of 2009, Abdullah Abdullah, claimed to have the support of at least 90 members for his loose Hope and Change alliance.
nelda28notes: Before the publication of the final results, the Election Commission discarded over 1.3 million ballots - nearly a quarter of the total - for fraud and irregularities and invalidated the results of 19 winning candidates. Several incumbent parliamentarians challenged the results. By the end of September over 4,000 official complaints had been received by the Electoral Complaints Commission.
nelda32notes: Pashtuns, the country's traditional rulers, won around 90 seats, as opposed to the 112 obtained in the 2005 elections. Being the main allies of President Karzai (who is Pashtun), support for the President was believed to have been reduced in the new legislature. The Karzai-appointed Electoral commission  invalidated the results of 19 winning candidates before results were announced. On 10 February 2011, the Special Electoral Commission (SEC) appointed unilaterally by Karzai (and ruled illegal by the Constitutional Commission and House of Representatives) announced that it had decided to unseat 83 of the newly elected members. The House of Representatives called for the disbanding of the SEC. Again, on 23 June 2011, the SEC ruled that 62 sitting members would have to be replaced because of alleged poll fraud. At the time of this coding (Oct 2011) this had yet to be resolved.
nelda33notes: In the run-up to the poll at least 23 people, including four candidates, were killed in election-related violence. The Taliban launched regular attacks in their efforts to disrupt the campaign, and succeeded in killing at four candidates prior to polling and abducted several others. On the election day itself, voting was disrupted by many rocket and bomb attacks, which forced the closure of hundreds of polling stations. Polling day was thought to have seen about 100 more attacks than the 280 recorded on the presidential vote of 2009. Five campaign workers for Fauzia Gailani, a businesswoman, legislator, and prominent critic of violence against women, were abducted and murdered during the course of the campaign.The National Democratic Institute reported that it had witnessed several serious election-related incidents, including attacks on polling stations and voters.
nelda34notes: Though it is difficult to tell given the lack of formal political parties, support for Karzai was thought to have diminished in these elections.
nelda47notes: Independent observers reported witnessing numerous instances of electoral fraud. Nevertheless, the elections were widely praised by the Afghan government and were endorsed by the USA, the UK, and the UN. This was understood to imply waning patience amongst the Western backers of President Karzai to uncover and challenge the widespread electoral fraud that had been evident in the presidential contest of 2009.
nelda58notes: The Western forces attempted through provision of security and techical aid to improve the democratic performance of this election.

notes: Interesting election in Afghanistan which features the first smooth transition of power from opposing politicians. Due to term limits, Karzai is no longer eligible to run, and so is replaced by Ghani following a run-off. A new phenomenon in this election: polling, which had previously not featured in Afghan elections. Despite these innovations, there are still concerns over fraud and vote-tampering, which are widely aired in the aftermath of the election.
Runoff to the April 2014 presidential poll, with Ghan coming out as the victor despite Abdullah winning 45% of the vote in the first round.

notes: Power is concentrated in the executive presidency and corruption is pervasive. Although the constitution declares the country to be a secular democracy, it is actually an authoritarian state that was dominated by its first president, Saparmyrat Niyazov, who retained this monopoly until his death in December 2006. The People's Council decided to select his successor through public elections in February 2007. Six candidates were approved to run in the election, out of eleven contenders. All of the candidates were members of the Democratic Party. The candidate nominated by the opposition coalition (whose members are mostly in exile) was not approved. Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov, who served as Acting President until elections could be held (and is coded as the incumbent), also won and became president.
nelda1notes: In 1999, the People's Council unanimously approved a law that said Niyazov (president from 1992 until his death in 2006) would serve for life.
nelda2notes: Independent political activity and opposition is not allowed in Turkmenistan.
nelda5notes: It should be noted that each candidate was a member of the incumbent Democratic Party. This was the first time there was a choice of candidates on the ballot in Turkmenistan.
nelda6notes: These elections were not regular, they were held following the death of former President Niyazov.
nelda7notes: The incumbent, Acting President Berdymukhammedov, took office after former President Niyazov died. The incumbent ran in the election and won.
nelda9notes: As per constitutional requirement in Turkmenistan, the role of Acting President should go to the chairman of the Mejles (Parliament), and yet within hours of Niyazov's death, the prosecutor's office launched criminal proceedings against the incumbent Mejles speaker, Atayev. Berdymukhammedov's appointment as acting president necessitated changes to the constitution, not only to be acting head of state, but also to contest the presidential election. Before these amendments were passed, an acting president had been ineligible to stand for reelection, and the minimun age for a presidential candidate (50) was changed to 40 ( Mr. Berdymukhammedov was 49 at the time of the election).
nelda10notes: The previous president had died in December 2006, thus there was a caretaker government until elections were held in February 2007 to elect a new president.
nelda12notes: The incumbent party was sure of victory because it was the only party legally allowed in Turkmenistan.
nelda13notes: Opposition is not allowed in Turkmenistan.
nelda15notes: While opposition is technically not allowed in Turkmenistan, this doesn't mean that opposition parties don't exist, all of whom are exiled. The three main groups include the United Democratic Opposition of Turkmenistan (UDOT), Watan (Fatherland), and the Republican Party. They planned to put forward candidates for the election, but they were thwarted by the government, who refused to allow any of the opposition members to return to the country.

nelda28notes: While there is evidence of reports critical of the government's handling of the election, there isn't any evidence that these reports reached large numbers of people within Turkmenistan.
nelda45notes: This is the first time that foreign observers were invited to monitor elections, presumably as an effort to dispel Turkmenistan's authoritative image abroad.
nelda47notes: Several human rights groups and Western leaders claimed the elections were rigged.
nelda50notes: Turkmenistan has one of the world's largest reserves of natural gas and oil. The US (as well as Russia, China, and Iran) import significantly from Turkmenistan.

notes: The elections to the Mejlis (Assembly) were held in Turkmenistan, and it was the first election since independence in which other parties were allowed to contest the election. In reality, this wasn't really true because no legal opposition parties had been set up and the fact that the election took place in single-seat constituencies greatly diminished the opportunity for anybody other than members of the Democratic Party of Turkmenistan to gain a seat. In fact, all candidates were members of the party, or government pre-approved independents.

nelda3notes: The 7 opponents of the incumbent (some of whom are from his administration) all expressed support for him during the campaign.

nelda8notes: There are no term limits (they were abolished in 1999 by the incumbent's predecessor).

nelda50notes: The countries cooperate on some development issues but do not have a robust relationship as the US is critical of Turkmenistan's human rights record.

notes: Tajikistan gained independence from the USSR in 1991, and since then, it has been through a civil war (1992-1997) between the Rahmon government and the UTO (a coalition of Islamic leaders and secular politicians). The 2010 Parliamentary elections resulted in yet another reaffirmation of President Rahmon and his Party's (People's Democratic Party of Tajikistan: PDPT) rule in Tajikistan. PDPT secured 55 out of 63 seats. The PDPT and the President have a strong hold at both the national and local levels. The elections took place using a mixed electoral system, with 22 MPs elected via party lists and 41 via single-mandate constituencies. The threshold for party representation is to claim 5% of the vote. The Social Democratic Party (SDP) was founded by the former legal advisor Zoirov, who resigned in 2003 over the referendum that increased the possible presidential terms of Rahmon until 2020. The Islamic Revival Party (IRP) also made up the opposition. It is the only legally existing Islamic party in Central Asia. The Socialist Party (SP) is also an opposition party.
nelda9notes: The office of the incumbent is not contested in this election, thus this is coded as N/A. However, it is important to note that there was a referendum held in 2003 that increased the possible presidential terms of Rahmon until 2020.
nelda12notes: Various newspapers reported that the elections were a foregone conclusion prior to election day. The incumbent party was expected to win a majority of seats and thereby reinforce the authority of President Rahmon.
nelda13notes: There is evidence that Rahmon's government kept a close watch on all opposition leaders, making it difficult for them to gain any grassroots support, which in effect prevents them from presenting a serious challenge to the status quo. Nevertheless, there wasn't any outright denial by the government to allow opposition leaders to run in the election.
nelda15notes: There is no evidence the government committed violence against opposition members; however, there is evidence that opposition members were aggressively kept a close watch on. It is true that there were irregularities (potential ballot stuffing) during the elections, and that there were biases prior to the elections, (the media is largely controlled by the state authorities). However, there wasn't any evidence of direct harassment on individual opposition members.
nelda16notes: Rahmon's government and the PDPT control most of the media in the country.
nelda18notes: Despite being one of the poorest countries in the world, the current economic situation is no worse than it's been before. In fact, relative to the civil war period 1992-1997, and the economic situation in 2008 in Tajikistan, the country's growth is not so bad. The Rahmon government is currently constructing the Roghun dam, which has the potential to make Tajikistan the largest electric power producer per capita, causing a breakthrough in Tajikistan's development and exports. Nevertheless, construction is proving to be a challenge because of the country's limited financial resources, thus the burden is falling on Tajik citizens, who the government is attempting to coerce into buying shares that will finance construction.
nelda25notes: ones.
nelda28notes: Leaders of opposition parties came out with public statements after the election, stating that the elections were unfair. Rahmatillo Zoirov, the head of the opposition Social Democratic Party of Tajikistan, complained that in Dushanbe his party's observers were made to sit in corners of the polling stations and were unable to keep an eye on the process.
nelda43notes: Previous spellings of his name, including the one in Archigos, were Rahkmanov. Rahmon changed the spelling in 2007, presumably to make it less Russian sounding.
nelda47notes: They said there was evidence of ballot stuffing and proxy voting, and media coverage of campaigning was minimal.

notes: President Bakiyev's Ak-Jol party won 71/90 parliamentary seats. The opposition party Ata-Meten failed to win any seats in parliament, despite their second place national finish behind Ak-Jol. Officials said Ata-Meken had not gained enough votes in the second city of Osh. A newly passed election law made it mandatory for parties to secure .5% of the vote in each region. Western observers strongly criticized the elections and the new rules that were essentially aimed at eliminating opposition party representation within parliament.

notes: President Bakiyev easily secured re-election. Bakiyev received 76% of the vote, and his closest rival, Atambayev, a former prime minister, received 8%. notes: Mongolia became a communist country after its formal independence in 1921. For over six decades the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party (MPRP) monopolized political power, being confirmed in non-competitive elections since the 1950s. o The Constitutional Amendment of 1944 introduced universal and equal suffrage. Direct elections to the Ih Hural (General Assembly) by secret ballot were held regularly since 1951. When the Baga Hural was actually abolished early in 1950, the In Hural took over its functions (becoming a unicameral Parliament) and its chairman became the official Head of State. It should be kept in mind that despite this democratic appearance, all real power lay in the Mongolian Revolutionary People's Party (MRPR)'S Central Committee. Mongolia was a tightly controlled authoritarian state. All candidates for election were designated by the MPRP. Notably,  Parliamentary elections were non-competitive, and yet the MPRP was regularly confirmed by formally landslide electoral victories.

nelda17notes: Mongolia's economy had been hit badly by the global recession due to its heavy dependence on minerals and FDI inflows and because it was overheating at the time of the downturn in the world economy.
nelda19notes: IMF, donor countries
nelda26notes: Opinion polls showed a very close race between the two candidates, which was most likely viewed negatively by the incumbent. Prior to this election no incumbent had lost an election, and no presidential election (of the five that were held democratically in the past two decades since Mongolia became a democracy) was this close.
nelda52notes: The opposition party (MDC) was considered to be pro-Western. Western mining executives reported that the MDC's victory in the recent presidential election could help to smooth negotiations with foreign mining companies which are hoping to access Mongolia's rich mineral reserves. The incumbent president Enkhbayar, who lost the election, had a significant relationship with Russia. His loss in the election is largely seen as a gain for Western mining companies, particularily the US, and a loss for Russian mining interests. The newly elected president, Elbegdorj, also made public statements that he would be willing to work with Western companies to achieve the best interests of Mongolian citizens.
nelda56notes: Refer to notes on NELDA 52.

notes: On June 28, 2012 elections to the Great Hural (unicameral legislature) in Mongolia were held. The election resulted in the main opposition Democratic Party of Mongolia (DPM) winning a plurality of 31 seats. The ruling Mongolian People's Party (MPP) came in second with 25 seats. And the Justice Coalition, made up of the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party (MPRP) and the Mongolian National Democratic Party (MNDP) won 11 seats. The president of Mongolia since 2009 is Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj of the Democratic Party; yet, the ruling MPP had maintained a majority in parliament prior to these elections. Initially, the MPP had rejected the results of the election, boycotting the new parliament and demanding a recount of the vote. Eventually, the MPP ceded power to a newly formed government coalition made up of the DP and MPRP.
nelda18notes: High inflation continues to be a cause of economic concern in Mongolia; nevertheless, economic growth is relatively high and there doesn't seem to be a perception of crisis.
nelda45notes: There was no evidence that international monitors were present during the election.

notes: India achieved Dominion status in August 1947, when it was also divided into the Indian Union and Pakistan. With the Constitution of India, proclaimed in 1950, the country became a Republic. The Indian Parliament consists of the President and two houses. The Lok Sabha (House of the People) functions as the Lower House or House of Commons, after the Westminster model, and members are election by national general election of universal suffrage. Before 1977, the party system was a �one-dominant party system� with the Indian National Congress (INC) at the center. This political system was commonly referred to as the Congress System (the INC was  in power from 1952�1977). The INC did not gain a majority of the popular vote, but was still the biggest single party by a considerable margin. The opposition parties - particularly the communists - faired better than was expected. The position of the incumbent was the Prime Minister (Nehru), which was contested as it was determined by this Parliamentary election.
nelda1notes: These were the first Indian national elections.
nelda4notes: Nine political parties - including the Communist Party - were qualified to contest the national election.
nelda7notes: These elections are Parliamentary elections, and the Parliament determines the Prime Minister (incumbent).
nelda10notes: The British left India in the hands of Nehru's INC in 1947, leaving the INC to establish a Constitution and hold elections.
nelda12notes: Indeed, the INC was the only party that spanned the entire nation. Nevertheless, the elections were taken seriously by the INC and intense campaigns were launched. They became very nervous in the middle of the voting months about the considerable communist gains.
nelda15notes: Some communist candidates were jailed for menial reasons and prevented from campaigning, though they were still allowed run.
nelda16notes: Newspapers like the Times of India regularly questioned and critiqued Nehru's actions
nelda18notes: In 1951, India was on the brink of famine - it had not been able to produce enough food to feed its population, and was making desperate pleas to the international community for grain. The economy was in recession. A spat of natural disasters, crop failure, and the booming population were putting incredible strains on the Indian economy.
nelda19notes: Particularly in light of the food crisis, India received aid from a diverse number of sources, from both poles of the Cold War. Great Britain, the U.S.A., Canada, Australia, China, and Russia all sent aid and claimed stakes in India's international allegiance.
nelda20notes: Elections are Parliamentary, and the Parliament determines the Prime Minister (incumbent). Nehru, at this time, was chief of the INC, the main party in Parliament.
nelda27notes: This was the first election so any votes won were considered a 'gain.' However, the opposition parties did gain a considerable fraction of the votes - in particular, the strength of the Communists and leftist-allied parties was remarked upon, particularly in the South.

notes: These elections were carried out relatively smoothly, though the intensity of clashes between supporters of the leading Indian National Congress Party, and the opposition Communist Party, had intensified since the last elections. The INC won 865 seats, about the same number as in the 1951-52 elections, and increased its proportion of the total vote from 45 to 47 per cent. Opposition gains (particularly in the South) were still substantial.  The incumbent was Prime Minister Nehru, and as the Prime Minister is determined by Parliament, the office of the incumbent IS contested in this election.

nelda6notes: The previous elections concluded in 1952, and elections were held every five years.
nelda12notes: The incumbent was particularly not confident in the Southern States. The election campaign period was notably vigorous.

notes: coalition surfaced in these elections, comprised of leftist parties and small regional parties.  The subject of these elections was the economic downturn -both the UPA and the NDA underscored the need for economic stimulus plans. The final results gave 261 seats to the UPA and 159 to the NDA. The parties in the Third Front won a total of 78 seats. Though these elections were generally thought to have run quite smoothly given the herculean task they presented, Maoist rebels and some inter-party clashes meant that the death toll ran quite high.

Also, Maoist commander Kameshwar Baitha won a Lok Sabha seat reserved for minorities for the Jharkhand Mukti Morcha party (despite being imprisoned), and as a result was reportedly expelled from the Maoist movement for contesting the elections.
nelda17notes: The 2009 elections were held against the backdrop of a national economic downturn, triggered by the global financial crisis. GDP growth dropped to 5.3 per cent in the final quarter of 2008, compared to 9 per cent a year earlier.

nelda26notes: The Star News-AC Nielson poll predicted 257 seats for the UPA and 184 for the NDA, with the Third Front earning nearly 96 seats. Other reports, however, showed neck-and-neck competition.
nelda27notes: In the previous 2004 elections, the United Progressive Alliance (led by the Indian National Congress) won 214 seats while the then ruling coalition, the National Democratic Alliance (led by the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party), took 187 seats. The final results of these elections saw the UPA increase their seats to 261, while the NDA took 159. The parties in the Third Front won a total of 78 seats.
nelda28notes: No pronouncedly critical reports of the government's handling of the elections. World Press reports tended to praise India for a relatively smooth conduct of such a massive democratic enterprise.
nelda29notes: In West Bengal, clashes between opposing party supporters (as well as the police) saw 24 people injured on May 17, a day after the results of the elections were announced.
nelda33notes: In the first phase of voting, Maoist rebels disrupted the elections by attacking polling stations. This clash between the rebels and the police claimed at least 17 lives. Then during phases four and five of the voting, attempts by the Maoist Naxalite rebels to disrupt the elections killed at least 36 people in attacks that included a landmine attack. Aside from the Maoist rebels, at least five people were killed and scores injured in election-related violence in the north-eastern state of West Bengal between supporters of the Communist Party and those of the AITC and their Congress allies, and there were also clashes between supporters and the police.
nelda45notes: Though there do not seem to have been international observers present, due to the complex internal Election Observing apparatus India has set up, after the results of these elections were announced the BBC reported that according to the civil society governance watchdogs, the Association for Democratic Reforms and the National Election Watch, out of the 543 newly elected legislators, at least 153 had criminal cases pending against them. Of these, 74 faced serious criminal charges, including murder and gang warfare.

notes: The opposition PDP scored an upset win, with 32 of the 47 open seats. Bhutanese relations with neighbor India become the primary campaign issue as they cut major subsidies, doubling the cost of kerosene and gas in the country just before elections. Incumbent Jigme Thinley was criticized for straining the important relationship by meeting with the Chinese president. Both parties agreed to not make Indian relations an electoral issue in future years. Voter expressed distrust in politicians and general fatigue, this being the third election in 2013.

nelda50notes: The U.S. and Pakistan have had an increasingly worse relationship (partially resulting from debate over Kashmir), culminating in the U.S.'s cut-off of aid because of Pakistan's nuclear program. Pakistan openly expresses resentment of the U.S.'s involvement.
nelda53notes: Following Soviet occupation of Afghanistan, the U.S. formed a significant relationship with Pakistan, which had since become strained.
nelda55notes: The U.S., which had already cut off its aid, began negotiations with Pakistan about the aid. However, the U.S. was expected to take a hard line that would make compromise difficult, while continuing to suspend aid.
nelda57notes: U.S. foreign aid was cut off prior to the election, but only as a result of suspicions of Pakistan's plans concerning nuclear weapons; the U.S. Congress then threatened to cut off aid indefinitely if Bhutto was not allowed to run in the election.
nelda58notes: A U.S. Congressional committee threatened to dissolve the U.S.-Pakistan relationship and supply no more military or financial aid if Islamabad's nuclear program was not reversed or if this election was not free and fair.
