nelda1notes: In 1999, a military coup placed Pervez Musharraf as the Pakistani leader, and democratic elections were suspended. Musharraf postponed general elections, and in May held a referendum extending his presidential rule for five years.
nelda7notes: According to the Irish Examiner, when he cast his ballot in nearby Rawalpindi, Musharraf said: 'Power will be handed over to the elected government, whichever party wins.' However, he retains the power to remove any prime minister and dissolve the national Assembly.
nelda10notes: Military rule was established by Musharraf's 1999 military coup.
nelda11notes: Both domestic and international observers believe the government was engaging in pre-poll rigging in order to keep Musharraf in power. For example, opposition leaders were allegedly being forced to join the pro-government party.
nelda13notes: President Musharraf decreed that all candidates must have a college degree, which eliminated 90% of candidates in Pakistan's mostly illiterate population. He also decreed that no candidate could have unpaid loans, which included a single unpaid electricity bill.
nelda16notes: The EU alleged that the government misused media to favor the pro-Musharraf party.
nelda17notes: However, inflation is lowering and the economy is stabilizing.
nelda19notes: President Bush promised Musharraf more aid for his help in the war against terrorism.
nelda20notes: Musharraf still intended to remain president.
nelda25notes: Some obvservers alleged that pre-election polls were rigged as well as the vote.
nelda33notes: However, these were significantly less violent, compared to previous elections.
nelda47notes: The EU condemned the election as seriously flawed.
nelda48notes: However, some monitors left because they were told by the government that they would not be protected by the military at polling stations.
nelda50notes: Pakistan allied with the U.S. to support the war on terrorism.

notes: These elections resulted in a heavy defeat for the Pakistan Muslim League- Qaid-i-Azam (PML-QA), the party created as a political vehicle for President Musharraf after his military coup in 1999. This election was widely seen as a referendum on Musharraf's rule. Former PM Bhutto's party, the Pakistani People's Party (PPP) took the lead with at least 87 directly elected seats. The other major opposition party, the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) won at least 66 seats. The ministers in the previous cabinet lost their seats - among them were close personal allies of Musharraf. The PPP and PML-N formed a coalition government, despite the fact that the parties are ideologically divergent.
nelda1notes: These elections were, however, postponed from the scheduled date of Jan. 8 because of the damaged caused by riots in the wake of the assassination on Dec. 27, 2007, of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto.
nelda6notes: The elections were late because of riots caused by the assassination of former PM Bhutto.
nelda10notes: Although Musharraf did declare a state of emergency in November 2007.
nelda13notes: Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif was barred from running in these elections because of a 1999 court conviction. Sharif was convicted of hijacking a plane that then-General Musharraf was on. The alleged hijacking was part of the events that led to General Musharraf ousting Sharif in a coup.
nelda14notes: Initially, former PM Sharif had called for a complete boycott by all opposition parties, but after Bhutto's party announced they would run, the other main opposition parties decided that they would contest the elections as well. Nevertheless, the religious Islamic Party and the Movement for Justice party of the former cricket star Imran Khan, decided to boycott elections. Both parties were vocal critics of Musharraf.
nelda15notes: A state of emergency was declared in November of 2007, and quite a large amount of opposition members were jailed. This compromised their ability to run in the upcoming parliamentary elections held in February 2008.
nelda33notes: There was at least one incident that involved a suicide bomber who killed 37 people at a political rally, two days before the election. It was perceived as an attempt to intimidate voters.
nelda47notes: The EU election observers said the completeness and accuracy of the voters' register were in doubt prior to the elections. Also, the secrecy of the vote was compromised at many stations. The staff only sporadically checked whether voters already had ink on their fingers before giving them a ballot paper, meaning that some people probably voted more than once.
nelda54notes: President Musharraf was seen as a great ally of the Bush administration in the war against terror.
nelda57notes: Joseph Biden, who was a US senator at this time and also the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, was an election observer for this election. He said that the US should cut military aid to Pakistan if the elections were substantially rigged.

notes: Stable election in Pakistan which sees the incumbent PPP lose its significant majority in parliament. The election is said to be particularly violent, with numerous attacks perpetrated by the Taliban and other groups scarring the Pakistani political landscape. Nonetheless, the elections are praised by observers for their relative stability and fairness.
nelda33notes: Three candidates and hundreds of civilians died in the buildup to the election.

notes: These were the first elections that were held since Bangladesh declared independence. The Awami League won a landslide victory gaining 293 out of 300 seats.
nelda1notes: The Constituent Assembly was dissolved in December of 1972; these were the first elections of the newly independent country.
nelda2notes: Bangladesh had declared independence in 1971; in this election there were more than a dozen parties.
nelda11notes: The campaign period was marred by violence and voter intimidation.
nelda18notes: There  were massive food shortages, rapid population growth, and the country hadn't recovered from the severe cyclone that hit the country in 1970.
nelda25notes: There was an expectation that the Awami League would win the elections, but there were no specific reliable polls.
nelda27notes: These were the first contested elections.
nelda29notes: There was violence before the election, but voting day was peaceful.
nelda33notes: Prior to the election there was violence, but there were no significant civilian deaths.

notes: Rahman called for the first presidential elections after he had won a massive victory in a presidential referendum in 1977. Rahman won 77% of the vote. He had recently legalized political parties and revoked media censorship.
nelda6notes: This was not a regular election; called for after the President won a resounding victory in a referendum in 1977 regarding staying in power.
nelda11notes: Political parties had only recently been legalized and media censorship had just been revoked; thus, there were still concerns regarding how democratic the elections would be.
nelda17notes: Foreign aid combined with a reform program had significantly improved the state of the economy.
nelda25notes: Rahman had won a landslide victory in a referendum several months earlier, but there was no reliable polling data.
nelda27notes: This was the first presidential election.
nelda28notes: Some claimed that there were some fraudulent tactics employed by the Rahman government, but it is unclear whether these reports were widely known.

notes: This was the first election since Parliament was dissolved in 1975. The Bangladesh National Party won 237 out 330 seats.
nelda1notes: Parliament was dissolved in 1975.

notes: Mr. Abdus Sattar, the Vice-President of Bangladesh, who had acted as President since the assassination of President Ziaur Rahman on May 30, 1981, was elected President by an overwhelming majority on November 15, 1981.

nelda1notes: This was the first election after four years of military rule. Three previous attempts to hold elections were abandoned after opposition parties refused to take part.
nelda2notes: Previous multiparty elections were held in 1979.
nelda6notes: The election was scheduled for late April, but pushed back to May after opposition parties boycotted the election and Ershad's government created a compromise with the opposition parties.

nelda1notes: Hossain Mohammad Ershad seized power in a military coup in 1982. This election is the country's first in eleven years.
nelda2notes: These were the first multiparty elections after nine year military rule.
nelda7notes: A politically neutral interim leadership ran the government and held elections. The interim Prime Minister banned all members of the interim leadership from running in the elections.
nelda9notes: The incumbent is the interim leadership, who held relatively clean elections.
nelda10notes: Following the ousting of Ershad due to domestic protesting, an interim government was established, led by former Supreme Court Chief Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed and other politically neutral advisors.
nelda11notes: Party leaders had concerns that the ousted President Ershad is attempting to sabotage polls. Local newspapers are threatened and attacked after reporting about certain political figures.
nelda17notes: There was an economic slowdown resulting from the Gulf War crisis and natural disasters.
nelda19notes: Only after the May cyclone did aid levels rise to high levels.
nelda24notes: The incumbent (meaning the interim Prime Minister) did not have a party; he was politically neutral. Ershad's Jatiya party still won seats, but two opposition parties won a far greater number of seats.
nelda26notes: Polls indicated that the Awami League will win but will fall short of majority.
nelda28notes: No critical reports existed; in fact, the interim administration led by Ahmed had high public support.
nelda29notes: After state-run television announced Khaleda Zia's Bangladesh Nationalist Party won, rival political groups began fighting with knives and guns.
nelda33notes: There were prison revolts, politically motivated murders, political assassinations, attacks on newspapers and journalists. However, journalists reported that the election was remarkably peaceful, compared to past elections.
nelda45notes: Teams of observers from America, Japan, Britain, the Commonwealth, the European Community, and the subcontinent were present.
nelda47notes: The foreign observers said the voting appeared to be fair.

nelda6notes: General elections in Bangladesh scheduled for January 18 were postponed three times, finally settling on February 15, following talks between poll officials and leaders of about 60 political parties.
nelda8notes: There is no term limit for parties.
nelda11notes: All major opposition parties claimed that there can be no free and fair contest unless the Prime Minister and her caretaker Government step down and a neutral administration is installed to supervise the voting.
nelda14notes: The Awami League, the Jatiya party, and the Jamaat-e-Islami - the three main opposition parties - boycotted the polls.
nelda18notes: The economic crisis resulted from a number of factors, including: economic devastation by natural disasters (such as floods and cyclones), the lack of foreign investment, and, most importantly, the opposition parties organizing labor strikes.
nelda28notes: All major opposition leaders made widespread allegations that the government was holding an unfair election.
nelda29notes: Opposition militants clashed with police and fought gun battles with government supporters in a campaign to force the re-elected prime minister, Begum Khaleda Zia, from power, claiming that the polls were not free.
nelda33notes: Significantly more violence was present compared to the previous election, this time widely instigated by the opposition.
nelda37notes: The new election was held on June 12, 1996.
nelda38notes: The Awami League was declared the winner in the June 12 election.
nelda47notes: The monitors that actually recognized the election alleged that widespread ballot stuffing took place. The official Bangladesh election commission never released any numbers concerning voter turnout.
nelda49notes: Most monitoring groups never considered this election an actual election because no opposition ran.

notes: These were the second set of legislative elections held in Bangladesh in 1996. The first legislature was dissolved very early, and new impartial elections were held by a caretaker government.
nelda6notes: Elections were held only a few months after the previous legislative elections due to continued protesting from the opposition, which resulted in the Prime Minister's resignation.
nelda7notes: The incumbent is the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Bangladesh, who stood in as the head of the caretaker government.
nelda12notes: We consider the ruling party the Bangladesh National Party (BNP), which won the previous election (boycotted by major opposition parties). The ruling party was forced by opposition strikes and protests to hold new elections.
nelda16notes: The media is primarily state-controlled, with a number of criminal penalties for libel or slander.
nelda19notes: Bangladesh worked closely with the IMF to modernize its economy.
nelda20notes: The incumbent is coded as the Prime Minister in this Parliamentary system, although a President does exist.
nelda27notes: The opposition Awami League won the largest share of seats.

notes: This election was delayed (originally meant to be held in 2007) by the military caretaker government in charge of the country. The election resulted in a landslide victory for the Awami League-led coalition.

notes: This election was controversial and widely seen as not credible by international observers due to a mass boycott by 18 opposition parties. notes: Following the assasination of Aung San (of the Anti-Facist People's Freedom League) and his cabinet - the charismatic and unifying Burmese leader who had emerged from the struggle for national independence, U Nu (also of the AFPFL Party) became the first Prime Minister after independence on 4 January 1948. This new AFPFL-government was faced with the daunting task of a uniting a state which was on the verge of disintegration - various ethnic groups as well as communist insurgents stood in radical opposition to the government. Constant internal disorder and armed rebellions led to a continuous postponement of these first parliamentary elections, which were finally conducted in three stages: June, August and October 1951. The AFPFL and its allies secured an overwhelming parliamentary majority. These elections were held in serial form throughout the different regions of the country, from June to October 1951. They were massively successful for the government party, AFPFL, which won an overwhelming 95% of the vote. Because these are parliamentary elections and the parliament determines the Prime Minister, who is incumbent chief of the state, these elections DO determine the incumbent chief of state.
nelda6notes: Constant internal disorder and armed rebellions led to a continuous postponement of the first parliamentary elections, which were finally conducted in three stages: June, August and October 1951.
nelda10notes: In 1948 the British handed over their colonial control of the Burmese state to Aung San's AFPFL's transition government, which was tasked with establishing the new state's democracy. Due to assasinations and rampant civil strife, the first Parliamentary elections took three years to materialize.
nelda11notes: A vigilent electoral commission ensured relatively free and fair conditions. Radio time was allocated equitably to all parties contesting, for example.
nelda16notes: Equitable radio time attributed to all parties, for example.
nelda17notes: Still recovering from Japanese occupation, and in the throes of civil turmoil, Burma was still very poor and largely agricultural. Though Presidential rhetoric can be found praising the improving levels of rice production, the state was nevertheless far from economically robust.
nelda18notes: Masses of refugee peasants had fled to urban centres due to the rampant ethnic strife, grinding the already floundering agricultural economy to an almost halt. Though production had improved from the near collapse of 1948-1949, it was still no where near post-war levels.
nelda19notes: In 1950, Burma signed the Technical Aid agreement with the US, calling for the expenditure of the current year of $8 million.
nelda24notes: U Nu's AFPFL won a landslide victory.
nelda27notes: Though the AFPFL won a vast majority, as these were the first Parliamentary elections and opposition parties did secure some seats in Parliament, they therefore did make gains.
nelda28notes: Election was widely considered free and fair.
nelda32notes: Results were favorable to the incumbent.

notes: Following the 1951 elections, the AFPFL had been overwhelmingly powerful. Before the 1956 elections, several opposition parties combined their forces in the National Unity Front (NUF) in order to challenge the AFPFL domination. Although the support for AFPFL slipped to 48% of the vote, the party secured a majority of 174 seats while the opposition won only 48 seats. In view of the declining electoral support, U Nu tried to reorganize the AFPFL. As a result, the party split into a �clean� faction led by U Nu and a �stable� faction. This marked the beginning of a political deterioration in which many ethnic minorities fought for separate states, and the military junta of today was put in place.
nelda7notes: Position of Prime Minister is determined by the Parliament, hence these elections determine the incumbent.
nelda12notes: Competitive elections
nelda13notes: Arakan Nationalists swept the polls in their ethnic region, defeating AFPFL dramatically. In one district however, the Arakan candidate was jailed and was thus unable to contest.
nelda15notes: Though not to a debilitating or even particulalry note-worthy extent
nelda17notes: The government's economic plans had hit numerous administrative difficulties, there was a lack of essential coal and iron resources, and a lack of education meant that transition from agricultural to industrial society was proving very difficult. Admittedly, Burma's reparations settlement with Japan was particularly helpful in providing construction and engineering expertise, and preparations for railways and electrical power lines were well advanced by 1956. US aid early in the 1950's had also helped encourage the economic recovery. Nevertheless, a rice-industry crisis beginning in 1955 had presented another setback.
nelda18notes: In 1955-1956, the most lucrative sources of government income (rice exports) contracted drastically, the price of rice tumbled, and numerous markets were lost.
nelda19notes: American aid had been discontinued in 1953, as Rangoon declined the offer of continuing it in order to preserve their international neutrality - they were suspicious of American motives and the consequences of accepting so much American aid in a world of cold-war politics.
nelda24notes: U Nu's AFPFL won .
nelda27notes: A National Unity Front coalition included various workers' and peasants' parties, and was formed in opposition to the AFPFL to try and balance its dominance of votes. This coalition did considerably well. Overall, opposition candidates polled 46% of the popular vote.
nelda28notes: No critical reports.
nelda39notes: U Nu voluntarily resigned, and his partner in the AFPFL leadership U Ba Swe stepped up. U Nu ostensible resigned to find time to reorganize the party and to generate an improvement of public morale and faith in the AFPFL.
nelda50notes: Supported the US effort in Korea - Burma was wary of the fact that they may some day need similar aid against an encroaching communist insurgency.
nelda52notes: No change in relations
nelda54notes: In 1950, seeing the outbreak of the Korean war, Burma opted to align itself with the anti-communist Western powers. This support had been considerably retracted by the mid-1950s, and Burma was making a concerted effort to appear neutral (supported PRC's entry into the UN), but the ties to the West were nevertheless still present. It had grown particularly wary of the US, but still retained friendly relations with London, and attributed high value to its UN membership.
nelda56notes: No change in relations

notes: UNP won a majority in the first election since Sri Lanka's independence.

notes: This election resulted in a defeat for the ruling UNP; an absolute majority was won by the People's United Front.

notes: The Sri Lanka Freedom Party won a majority of seats in the Parliament despite not winning the popular vote; Sirimavo Bandaranaike, the wife of the former Prime Minister who was assasinated in 1959, became the first Prime Minister in the country.
The United National Party gained 39% of the vote and unseated the Sri Lanka Freedom Party.

A new election was held on November 9th.

notes: Controversial election held early in 2014 was cancelled for a number of violations (people voting on different days, which is against the Thai constitution) as well as widespread protests. There were also abundant accusations of media bias and harassment, as well as some violence. Eventually, a new election was supposed to take place in June but this was cancelled due to a military coup which took place in May. As the original result was voided by the Thais Supreme Court, no actual results were ever released - meaning it is not possible to know whether the cancelled result favoured the incumbent or not, for instance.

notes: Elections followed the violent ousting in July 1997 of leader Ranariddh of FUNCIPEC party by Hun Sen, the second PM who had ruled Cambodia since 1981 in the CPP. Under international pressure, Hun Sen did not abolish the National Assembly elected in previous elections, but violence and political intimidation kept him and the
nelda3notes: Hun Sen, under international pressure and threats of aid cut-off, allowed parties other than the CPP to participate in elections, though some maintained that elections were rigged and unfair.
nelda14notes: Some opposition candidates threatened to boycott the election unless polling was delayed, allowing for more time to prepare for the elections.
nelda24notes: Previous elections put FUNCIPEC in power, but 1997 election violence brought CPP to power, and they remained there through these elections
nelda26notes: Independent polls suggested the CPP was in third place among the top three political parties in popularity. An earlier poll suggesting the FUNCIPEC would win 1998 elections by a large margin was said to be one of the reasons behind Hun Sen's termination of the CPP-FUNCIPEC coalition.
nelda27notes: Because the National Assembly was left in tact after Hun Sen ousted his co-Prime Minister, the FUNCIPEC party remained officially in the majority (despite violence and intimidation keeping many FUNCIPEC politicians out of the National Assembly). Following 1998 elections, Hun Sen's CPP party achieved a majority.
nelda30notes: Accusations of fraudulence and the CPP's failure to build a coalition in the period following the elections eventually led to opposition taking to the streets.
nelda47notes: Though many internationally were critical of the elections (especially the domestic opposition groups), Western monitors eventually deemed the elections sufficiently free and fair.
nelda50notes: Following Hun Sen's ousting of the co-Prime Minister, the US cut off aid and  refused to provide money to fund the election processes (though they did send participants for the UN's Joint International Observer Group).
nelda52notes: The US returned to providing some aid to Cambodia (mainly channeled through regional NGOs), though many restrictions on aid to the government remained.
nelda58notes: Cambodia lost its seat in the UN and its membership in ASEAN following the violence and ousting of 1997. The UN demanded a free and fair election, involving the opposition, before the country could regain recognition.

notes: Parliamentary elections were held in Vietnam on May 22, 2011. The ruling Communist Party of Vietnam (CPV), the only legal party in Vietnam, secured 458 seats, with an additional 38 seats going to members who are CPV supporters. 4 seats were won by independent candidates.
nelda4notes: Vietnam is a one-party state. The Communist Party of Vietnam (CPV) is the only legally permitted party.

notes: Presidential referendum following separation from North Vietnam; contested by Prime Minister Diem and former Emperor Bao Dai. Diem won the rigged election with 98% of the vote.
nelda1notes: First elections in South Vietnam.

notes: Overwhelming victory for Diem's government; Diem had succeeded in suppressing or incorporating into his own party most oppostion.
nelda1notes: South Vietnam had held one set of elections prior to this, but as they were a new country, elections were not regular.

notes: Overhwhelming victory for Diem's government party (121/123 seats)
nelda3notes: Only independents were allowed run, aside from the government party.

notes: Despite communist threats and violence, this first regular presidential election (Diem had been appointed by plebiscite in 1955) went relatively smoothly, with Diem winning by a landslide.  South Vietnam was increasingly dependent on US military aid.
nelda1notes: This was the first regular election (Ngo Dinh Diem had been appointed by a plebiscite in 1955, but that had not been a regular election).
nelda11notes: The 1955 plebiscite was widely considered rigged, and the other candidates accused Diem of corruption.  In addition, communist guerillas threatened those who voted for Diem with death.
nelda13notes: There is no evidence that the communists attempted to field a candidate and were prevented from running, or boycotted, though the communists did try and organize a country-wide boycott of the election to deligitimize the country.
nelda17notes: The South Vietnam economy was very dependent on US foreign aid.
nelda19notes: South Vietnam received substantial aid from the US- in 1961, 65$ million in military equipment, and 136$ million in economic aid.
nelda27notes: The incumbent won 78% of the vote, and this election was widely seen as a defeat for the communist party.
nelda33notes: There was significant violence concerning the election, most notably from communist guerillas.
nelda53notes: Diem prefered US sponsorship to that of France, (former colonizer) and tailored his policies and actions accordingly.

notes: This election went smoothly, with only supporters of the incumbent ruling part of Diem and his family allowed to run.  US-South Vietnam ties were strained at this point, with the US threatening to reduce economic aid if Diem did not liberalize.
nelda1notes: The legislative term had been extended (previous elections had been held in 1959, and the term was 3 years) during the state of emergency and martial law decreed by the government.
nelda3notes: Though there were multiple parties, no opposition was allowed.
nelda5notes: However, no opponents of the Diem government were allowed to run.
nelda6notes: The elections were one year late, as the previous elections for the 3 year term legislature had been held in 1959.
nelda13notes: Though the seats were contested, no opponents of the government were allowed to run.
nelda15notes: Opposition was not allowed and many were jailed.
nelda16notes: The president used martial law and the declaration of a state of emergency to justify press censorship.

nelda33notes: Though there were Vietcong threats against those who voted, there were no reports of significant violence involving civilians.
nelda50notes: The US was very important to Vietnam, given the war on North Vietnam, however relations between the two governments were strained.
nelda53notes: The US was South Vietnam's most important ally.
nelda57notes: The US threatened to cut off aid if Diem did not change certain policies and reduce corruption.

notes: This election for the most part went smoothly, with some civilian deaths due to the Vietcong.  A constituent assembly was elected, and there were multiple candidates and parties on the ballot, though communists and neutralists were prevented from running.

nelda3notes: However, communists and 'neutralists' were not allowed to run, but not all candidates were supporters of the military government.

nelda53notes: The US was South Vietnam's most important ally.

notes: This legislative election for the upper house of the bicameral legislature proceeded without major upset, with the ultimate outcome being a mildly pro-government Senate.  There was significant violence due to the Vietcong's attempts to delegitimize the election.

nelda4notes: Though there were lists of candidates, all candidates had to run as independents.

nelda19notes: South Vietnam's economy was badly damaged by the war, and the country was heavily dependant on the US for military and economic aid.

nelda34notes: Though some candidates were not exaclty supporters of the incumbent government, all were pro-government.

nelda52notes: The elections were viewed as very important by the US government, almost as a tipping point for the US's continued involvement in Vietnam.  Thus, when the elections went relatively smoothly, relations improved,as before the eleciton they had been strained.

notes: These elections were the first since Malaysia (at the time, Malaya) had achieve independence in 1957, and were for the lower House of Representatives. Both the King (who was Head of State), and the Senate were elected indirectly. The result was a victory for the ruling Alliance Party�the multi-racial organization led by Tengku Abdul Rahman and comprising the United Malays' National Organization, the Malayan Chinese Association, and the Malayan Indian Congress. The Alliance Party has ruled Malaya since 1955, when it won 51 of the 52 seats in the former Legislative Assembly; moderate in outlook, it supports the Commonwealth link with Britain and is actively anti-Communist.The Alliance's main opponent was the Pan-Malayan Islamic Party, which stood for the establishment of a Melayu nation with special rights and privileges for the Malays in all levels of society; it was dedicated to the creation of a theocratic State based on the tenets of the Koran, and was considered more radical. The Alliance was seen as more stable and middle-of-the-road, which was attracted to the electorate in this decade of transition. Indeed, Malaya had been under a state of emergency since 1948, with government forces at war with communist guerrillas in the jungles.
nelda1notes: Malaya had held its first democratic elections in 1955 before its independence in 1957.
nelda2notes: Malaya had held its first democratic elections in 1955 before its independence in 1957.
nelda7notes: It was understood that Razak, who had only been standing in for Rahman as he recuperated his health and directed the Alliance's electoral campaign, would return the premiership to Rahman if their Alliance was successful in the elections.
nelda8notes: as such.
nelda12notes: The Alliance was widely expected to win, it was just a question of whether they would maintain the extent of their strong support.
nelda17notes: Malaya was profiting heavily from its relationship with the British Commonwealth, to whom it was the main supplier of rubber and tin. International rubber prices were high, and production  was rising.
nelda19notes: Total British aid given or promised to the Federation since independence amounts to �33,000,000, comprising �9,000,000 towards the cost of the emergency in 1957�59; �8,000,000 as a grant towards the development of Malaya's armed forces; �8,000,000 worth of equipment and property transferred to the Malayan forces; and a �4,000,000 development grant. Furthermore, a US aid package of $20 million was financing the development of new roads and communications infrastructure.
nelda21notes: It was understood that incumbent Razak, who had only been standing in for Rahman (both were from the United Malays' National Organization) as he recuperated his health and directed the Alliance's electoral campaign, would return the premiership to Rahman if the Alliance front was successful in the elections.

nelda44notes: Tengku Abdul Rahman, the first Prime Minister of the Malayan Federation and leader of the UNMO Party within the governing Alliance, announced his resignation from the premiership in February 1959 in order to focus his efforts on the election campaign of the Alliance. Dato Abdul Razak (the Deputy Premier and Minister of Defence) stepped in as Prime Minister, and Rahman then resumed the Premiership when the Alliance won the elections.

nelda54notes: The Alliance government is friendly to Western and African countires, and has military agreements with Britain, Australia and New Zealand which involves having these troops stationed in Malaya (an issue of major contention for opposition parties). The Alliance government has also pledged support to the UN. The Alliance has also made it clear that it has no interest in relations with the Communist bloc.

notes: These elections featured a concerted and coordinated campign by opposition parties calling for reform. The ruling coalition Barisan Nasional (BN) suffered a massive reduction in votes. The BN remained the largest party in parliament with 140 seats but did not win a two-thirds majority, its worst result since the country's independence in 1957. The number of seats controlled by the opposition jumped from 19 to 82. BN, for the first time, lost its two-thirds majority in parliament. The huge swing against the Barisan National coalition (which had effectively ruled since 1957) shook the incumbent party and put in doubt the system of racially-based politics on which their power depends.
nelda6notes: : these early elections would take place one month before the ban on his participation in elections was due to expire. Ibrahim was convicted of corrupt practices and sodomy in a highly contested and supposedly politically-motivated 1999 court decision, and was barred from running for election until 15 April 2008. His wife and PKR president, Mrs. Wan Azizah, said that if she was elected in the 2008 elections, she would step down so that Mr. Ibrahim would be able to contest the ensuing by-election.
nelda11notes: Human rights monitors and opposition leaders had warned that the ruling coalition (Barisan Nasional, BN) might manipulate the vote in tightly fought seats. Phantom voters and gerrymandering were at issue.
nelda13notes: Though it was technically legal, the fact that opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim was not allowed participate because he was incarcerated and the elections were early was a move widely viewed as strategic. Ibrahim was convicted of corrupt practices and sodomy in a highly contested and supposedly politically-motivated 1999 court decision, and was barred from running for election until 15 April 2008. His wife and PKR president, Mrs. Wan Azizah, said that if she was elected in the 2008 elections, she would step down so that Mr. Ibrahim would be able to contest the ensuing by-election.
nelda16notes: Opposition parties joined human rights advocates in a group called Bersih (Clean) to demand fairer electoral boundaries, cleaner electoral rolls and fairer media coverage. Television and newspapers are licensed and heavily influenced by the government, so opposition parties rely on internal newsletters and the Internet.
nelda20notes: Prime Minister is incumbent head of state, and is determined by these legislative elections.
nelda24notes: It was still the largest party in parliament, though notably it did not win a controlling two thirds.
nelda27notes: The BN remained the largest party in parliament with 140 seats but did not win a two-thirds majority, its worst result since the country's independence in 1957. The number of seats controlled by the opposition jumped from 19 to 82.
nelda29notes: Concerns over electoral fraud triggered a clash between supporters of the opposition Islamic party PAS and state police in the northern state of Terengganu. 22 people were arrested.
nelda31notes: Police used tear gas to disperse 300 people clashing over fears of electoral fraud in Terengganu.
nelda45notes: Aside from the electoral commission, these elections had an independent monitoring body known as Mafrel, or Malaysians for Free and Fair Elections.

notes: An election which sees the incumbent rewarded for years of strong economic policies and continued growth as he is re-elected, albeit with a minority in the popular vote. The election is followed by protests and claims of fraud and gerrymandering.

notes: Presidential elections were held in Singapore on August 27, 2011. These were the first contested presidential elections held in Singapore since 1993. Four candidates contested the election, and because the post of president in Singapore is largely ceremonial, presidents are technically not associated with any party. Nevertheless, the winner of the election, Tony Tan (who won 35.2% of the vote) was the former Deputy Prime Minister and the preferred candidate of the ruling People's Action Party (PAP). Tan Chen Bock (a former PAP legislator) came in second with 34.85% of the vote. Tan Jee Say (a former parliamentary candidate for the opposition Singapore Democratic Party) came in third with 25.04% of the vote, and Tan Kin Lian came in last with 4.91% of the vote.

notes: There was considerable violence during the elections. There was also widespread allegations of electoral fraud, leading to recounts and re-polling in some places.The final results were made available at the end of the month, with the Executive Secretary Eduardo Ermita claiming that 163/219 seats in the House of Representatices went to the government's TEAM (Together Everyone Achieves More) Unity coalition.

The Liberal Party candidate, Benigno Aquino III, was elected president. Outgoing president Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo won a seat in the House of Representatives in the legislative elections that were held on the same day. Votes were counted (for the first time) by computer machines in order to eliminate voter fraud. International observers criticized the poor performance of the voting machines, interference in the polling by political party workers, vote buying, and violence and intimidation in Mindanao. Nevertheless, the armed forces (AFP) said that there was a reduction of violence during elections compared to the 2007 legislative election violence.
The election was significant for being a midterm election because it was a test for President Aquino's policies and to see how much influence he could have over congress.
nelda52notes: Under the Obama Administration, the US increased their bilateral ties with the Philippines.

notes: Following its independence in 1945, and the eventual Dutch withdrawal in 1949, Indonesia was deeply divided. Several constitutions were undermined by numerous rebellions and separatist challenges, and these chaotic circumstances precluded the holding of parliamentary elections for nearly five years. Pending the enactment of an electoral law, a temporary parliament was installed; parties negotiated the distribution of its seats on the basis of their respective presumed strength in it. The 1953 Election Law finally paved the way for the country's first parliamentary elections in September 1955. These were the only free and fair elections held before 1999. One hundred and seventy-two parties and groups contested the 1955 polls, 28 of which won seats. Apart from an Islam-secularism cleavage, both camps were internally split. President Sukarno (head of state, not determined by these elections), was associated with the Nationalist Party, whose tended to be more friendly than others towards the Communist Party. The opposition to this friendship was Masjumi, the largest Islamic party, who typically aligned themselves with the Socialist Party. The Nationalists tended to be neutralist, and colder towards the West, while Masjumi was more pro-Western. In the final results (voting occurred over 6 months), both the Nationalists and Masjumi won 57 seats. Premier Harahap of Masjumi was replaced as Premier by the Nationalists' Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo, who had previously been Premier from 1953-55. The Communists were excluded from government. Previous to these elections the Nationalists had been in opposition to the Masjumi-led government coalition, but following the election they held the Premiership in a new Masjumi-Nationalist coalition.
nelda1notes: These were Indonesia's first elections, and attempts to hold elections previous to this had been constantly thwarted by political instability. The 1949 Federal Constitution established a union between the Dutch-controlled regions in the outer islands and the territory held by the Republic in Java and Sumatra, but this text was however short-lived, and was replaced by the more centralist (temporary) Constitution of 1950, which laid the groundwork for a parliamentary system. The legitimacy of this new political system was undermined by numerous rebellions and separatist challenges. These chaotic circumstances precluded the holding of parliamentary elections for nearly five years.
nelda7notes: The position of the incumbent not contested - the Prime Minister was determined by these elections, but  the President was considered the incumbent ruler (Sukarno), and he was chosen by indirect vote.
nelda10notes: Following the introduction of a temporary Constitution in 1950 (which replaced the 1949 Constitution), and pending the enactment of an electoral law, a temporary parliament was installed; parties negotiated the distribution of its seats on the basis of their respective presumed strength in it. The 1953 Election Law finally paved the way for the country's first parliamentary elections in September 1955.
nelda12notes: The current government was a coalition lead by Masjumi. Its main support was drawn from the Masjumi, the Socialists, the Christian (i.e. Protestant) Party, the Catholic Party, the Democrats, and  the Greater Indonesian Federation. The Nationalist Party had left this coalition recently -  the Indonesian Cabinet headed by Dr. Sastromidjojo (Nationalist) resigned on July 24 as the result of a dispute between the Government and the Army leaders, who had refused to accept the new Chief of Staff nominated by the Defence Minister. The (opposition) Nationalists, in potential alliance with the Communists, were fierce contenders for government.
nelda17notes: Runaway inflation, corruption, and unstable politics meant Indonesia had stagnated when the Dutch pulled out.
nelda19notes: Indonesia was receiving various economic aid, includng from the US, who had provided over $30 million in aid, and the total funds so far made available by Australia to Indonesia under the Colombo Plan amount to �A.1,500,000.
nelda24notes: Sukarno (incumbent President) was known to favor the Nationalist party, who regained a position in the government coalition following this election. Note that the incumbent party coalition did NOT involve the Nationalists before this election, but rather was led by Masjumi.
nelda27notes: The Nationalists gained the Premiership, having previously been in opposition.

notes: Following its independence in 1945, and the eventual Dutch withdrawal in 1949, Indonesia was deeply divided. Several constitutions were undermined by numerous rebellions and separatist challenges, and these chaotic circumstances precluded agreement on a final Constitution until elections for this Constituent Assembly were held in 1955. The results of the elections for the Indonesian Constituent Assembly, which started on Dec. 15, 1955 and ran for several months, were officially announced in Jakarta on July 16. The results were much as the results for the Parliamentary elections, held only months before. The Nationalist party won 119 seats, Masjumi (moderate Islamic) their main contenders won 112 seats, Nabdlatul Ulama (a more radical Islamic Party) won 91 seats, and the Communist Party 80. Many other parties won a small fractiion of the seats.  Apart from an Islam-secularism cleavage, both camps were internally split. President Sukarno (head of state, not determined by these elections), was associated with the Nationalist Party, which tended to be more friendly than others towards the Communist Party. The opposition to this friendship was Masjumi, the largest Islamic party, who typically aligned themselves with the Socialist Party. The Nationalists tended to be neutralist, and colder towards the West, while Masjumi was more pro-Western. As Masjumi was leading in the government coalition before the September Parliamentary elections (which were still in progress in December), they are treated as the incumbent party while the Nationalists are treated as the opposition in these elections. The Nationalists were however the party the incumbent President, Sukarno, was associated with.
nelda1notes: These were Indonesia's first elections, and attempts to hold elections previous to this had been constantly thwarted by political instability. The 1949 Federal Constitution established a union between the Dutch-controlled regions in the outer islands and the territory held by the Republic in Java and Sumatra, but this text was however short-lived, and was replaced by the more centralist (temporary) Constitution of 1950, which laid the groundwork for a parliamentary system. The legitimacy of this new political system was undermined by numerous rebellions and separatist challenges. These chaotic circumstances precluded the holding of national elections for nearly 5 years.
nelda2notes: First multiparty Constituent Assembly elections.
nelda7notes: The position of the incumbent was not contested in Constituent Assembly elections.
nelda10notes: Following the introduction of a temporary Constitution in 1950 (which replaced the 1949 Constitution), and pending the enactment of an electoral law, a temporary parliament was installed; parties negotiated the distribution of its seats on the basis of their respective presumed strength in it. The 1953 Election Law finally paved the way for the country's first parliamentary elections in September 1955.
nelda12notes: The government before the September Parliamentary Elections (still in progress in December) was a coalition lead by Masjumi. Its main support was drawn from the Masjumi, the Socialists, the Christian (i.e. Protestant) Party, the Catholic Party, the Democrats, and  the Greater Indonesian Federation. The Nationalist Party had left this coalition recently -  the Indonesian Cabinet headed by Dr. Sastromidjojo (Nationalist) resigned on July 24 as the result of a dispute between the Government and the Army leaders, who had refused to accept the new Chief of Staff nominated by the Defence Minister. The (opposition) Nationalists, in potential alliance with the Communists, were fierce contenders in these elections.
nelda17notes: Runaway inflation, corruption, and unstable politics meant Indonesia had stagnated when the Dutch pulled out.

notes: A presidential election was held in East Timor on March 17, 2012. Because no candidate managed to receive a majority of the vote, a run-off election is scheduled to be held on April 16, 2012 between the top two contenders. Francisco Guterres of the Fretilin Party came in first with 28.76% of the vote, and Taur Matan Ruak (who ran as an Independent with the support of the CNRT) received 25.71% of the vote . Incumbent president Jose Ramos Horta (who ran as an independent)  came in third with 17.48% of the vote and was thus eliminated from the election.
nelda24notes: The incumbent ran as an independent candidate, thus there was technically no party that was associated with the incumbent.

notes: A run-off presidential election was held in East Timor on April 16, 2012 between Francisco Guterres of the Fretilin Party and Taur Matan Ruak (who ran as an Independent with the support of the CNRT). Incumbent president Jose Ramos Horta (who ran as an independent)  came in third with 17.48% of the vote and was thus eliminated from the election in the first round. The run-off election resulted in a win for Ruak, who received 61.23% of the vote.
nelda24notes: The incumbent ran as an independent candidate, thus there was technically no party that was associated with the incumbent.

notes: Parliamentary elections were held in East Timor on July 7, 2012 to the 65-member National Parliament (unicameral legislature). The elections resulted in the National Congress for the Reconstruction of Timor (CNRT) of Prime Minister Kay Rala Xanana Gusmao winning 30 seats, overtaking its partner in the ruling coalition, Fretilin (Revolutionary Front for an Independent East Timor), which won 25 seats. Fretilin had actually increased its seat count (it had 21 seats in 2007); however, it was because smaller parties that didn't manage to retain seats won in 2007 in this election that resulted in CNRT increasing its seat count by 12 from 2007. The Democratic Party (PD) won 8 seats, and the National Reconstruction Front of Timor-Leste (FRENTL) won 2 seats.

notes: These elections were for the lower House of Representatives, which determined the Prime Minister. Senate elections were held simultaneously. This general election resulted in the defeat of the Labour Government, which had been in office for ever eight years, and in a victory for the Liberal and Country parties, which, under the joint leadership of Mr. Menzies and Mr. Fadden, fought the elections as a coalition in opposition to the Australian Labour Party. This year was the first under the new electoral rules established in 1948, which enlarged the House of Representatives from 73 seats to 121. A strong anti-Communist agenda fueled the Liberal success over the leftist Labour Party, with the coalition winning a 24 seat majority.

notes: These elections were notably earlier than usual - The action of the Labour majority in the Senate in blocking the Commonwealth Bank Bill after it had twice been passed by the House of Representatives led Prime Minister Menzies to request the Governor-General on March 18 to grant a double dissolution (i.e., to dissolve both the Senate and the House of Representatives) in order that general elections could be held. The general elections of Parliament resulted in a victory for the Liberal and Country Party coalition under the leadership of Mr. Robert Menzies, which obtained majorities both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate. These elections were for the lower House of Representatives, which determined the Prime Minister. Senate elections were held simultaneously. In the elections for the House of Representatives (123 members) the Government coalition gained 69 seats (Liberals 52, Country Party 17) and the Labour Party 54, giving the Government a majority of 15 as compared with a majority of 27 in the former House. The Labour Party, though unsuccessful in gaining a majority, thus increased its representation in the Lower House. However, it lost its majority in the Senate, thus allowing Menzies pass the Commonwealth Bank Bill with the new results.
nelda6notes: The elections were early.  The action of the Labour majority in the Senate in blocking the Commonwealth Bank Bill after it had twice been passed by the House of Representatives led Prime Minister Menzies to request the Governor-General on March 18 to grant a double dissolution (i.e., to dissolve both the Senate and the House of Representatives) in order that general elections could be held, despite the fact that the Parliament elected in 1949 was barely half-way through its normal term.The Commonwealth Bank Bill, as originally drafted by the Menzies Government, was designed to repeal the Labour Government's Banking Act of 1947 and, specifically, laid down that the control and management of the Central Bank should be vested in a board of directors instead of in a single Governor assisted by an advisory council.
nelda8notes: The incumbent is the Prime Minister, who does not have a limit on terms served in the Parliamentary system.

nelda19notes: The International Bank in Washington had loaned $100,000,000 to Australia in 1950. The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development was one of the two institutions (the other being the International Monetary Fund) set up at the Bretton Woods Conference in July 1944 to facilitate international trade and borrowing by making the currencies of countries more freely available to those other countries needing them.

nelda19notes: The International Bank in Washington announced in July 1952 that a loan of $50,000,000 had been granted to the Commonwealth of Australia. About one-third of the loan would be used for agricultural development to help raise farm production by 1958 by 10 per cent over the present level; nearly one-half would be used for coal mining, the iron and steel industry, railways, road transport, and electric power; and about one-fifth would be spent on increasing the production of nonferrous metals and minerals (including lead, zinc, copper, tin, aluminium, tungsten, and pyrites) and for other industrial development directly related to basic economic activities. The loan (the second to be made by the International Bank to Australia, the other being in 1950) would be for 20 years.

nelda6notes: The elections were early. Mr. Menzies explained that there were two principal reasons for having another election only 18 months after the last. Firstly, under the Constitution there had to be an election for the retiring half of the Senate during the present financial year, and to have an election for the House of Representatives on the same day was economical and made for stable government. Secondly, as Dr. Evatt's deputy leader, Mr. Calwell, had said, �the tensions and strain now existing in Canberra had made parliament practically unworkable.� However, it was generally understood that Menzies had called the elections early in order to improve the Liberal majority in the House, by taking advantage of the damaged reputation of the head of the Labour opposition, Dr Evatt, who had been implicated in the Soviet spy scandal Petrov Affair.

nelda18notes: Australia's overseas balance had been dropping steadily in spite of the import cuts imposed in October 1955. A vast demand for imported goods had put an immense strain on the country's balance of payments, and the wage level was threatening export capacity. Nevertheless, the new measures proposed by the Government gave every reason to suppose that the Government's objective of balancing its external accounts by the middle of 1956 would be achieved.
nelda19notes: The International Bank in Washington announced on July 9 1952 that a loan of $50,000,000 had been granted to the Commonwealth of Australia. The loan (the second to be made by the International Bank to Australia, the other being in 1950) would be for 20 years.

nelda54notes: During the election campaign, when asked questions on defense and foreign policy ,Mr. Menzies emphasized Australia's adherence to the principles of the U.N. Charter, and said that his Government would continue its efforts to promote goodwill and trade and to give assistance to Australia's Asian neighbours. They would co-operate with Britain in defense, would honor the ANZUS treaty, and would remain an active member of the Manila Treaty Organization. Australia was also cooperating with Holland on developing New Guinea for ultimate self-government.

notes: These elections were for the lower house of Parliament, the House of Representatives, which determined the Prime Minister. Senate elections were held simultaneously.  Prime Minister Menzies' Liberal and Country Party coalition government was returned to power with an incresed majority in the House of Representatives and, for the first time in three years, with a majority in the Senate. Mr. Menzies not only won his fifth consecutive general election but also obtained his biggest majority in the House of Representatives since he first took office in 1940. These were the first elections after the opposition Labour party split - The Democratic Labour Party broke away from the main Labour Party  in 1956 under the name of the Anti-Communist Labour Party. Foreign policy debate was of considerable importance in these elections - Menzie refused to follow Britain in recognizing Red China, in keeping with his close relationship with the US in Pacific foreign policy. The opposition Labour; however, had announced that they would recognize Red China if put into power.
nelda8notes: The incumbent is the Prime Minister, who does not have a term limit.
nelda12notes: The governing Liberal-Country coalition announced it expected to increase its majority from 26 to 38.
nelda17notes: The coal, steel, and oil industries were all developing promisingly, the government was monitoring the economy closely, and productivity was increasing.
nelda19notes: A loan of $15,000,000 was issued to the Australian government in London before this election on Oct. 15 for works and housing programmes, to be developed by the Australian Commonwealth and State Governments in 1958-59. It was the first Australian borrowing in London for development purposes since 1929. In a further loan operation, the Australian Government was issued a cash loan of $25,000,000 in New York. The International Bank in Washington had also loaned $50, 000, 000 to Australia, in increments beginning in 1952.

Australia would not recognize Communist China under Menzie - the Labour party had said they would, if they had beaten out Menzie's Liberals. The New Guinea question should be settled by the International Court of Justice if Indonesia's claim to Dutch New Guinea was based on alleged legal right; if Indenesia contemplated armed aggression in furtherance of her claim, it should be resisted by the United Nations. Australia would continue to co-operate with the Dutch authorities in developing the native population in New Guinea for ultimate self-government. The Menzies government had also supported the British-French involvement in the Suez crisis.

notes: This election, fought over issues of taxation and a mild recession, was very nearly a complete defeat for the Liberal/Country Party Coalition of Robert Menzies that had lasted 12 years. He survived with only a one-seat margin in the House of Representatives.
nelda17notes: Australia was in a minor recession at the time.
nelda26notes: The polls showed a great drop in support for the Liberal/Country coalition, though still predicted them winning.

notes: Having governed for two years with a one-seat majority in the House, Menzies called this election to go forward on several important issues with a solid majority.
nelda6notes: The elections were about a year earlier than they would have been otherwise.

notes: This election was only for one half of the Australian Senate.
nelda25notes: I was unable to find evidence of polls.

notes: Punctuated by a visit by LBJ, this election was fought over Australia's involvement in the Vietnam War and conscription of soldiers and only involved the House of Representatives. Intraparty contention led to splits in both major parties, but the Liberal/Country coalition succeeded in returning to power with an increased majority.
nelda12notes: With significant disunity in the Labor party and polls showing Liberal/Country popularity by comfortable margins, and despite violent anti-Vietnam protests, the government was relatively sure in would win.
nelda26notes: Polls were favorable to the incumbent by a margin of about 10%.
nelda29notes: There had been violent protests before the election on the subject of Vietnam.
nelda52notes: The positive change in relations with the US reaffirmed Australia's dedication to the Vietnam effort.

notes: This election was only for half of the Senate and thus could not affect the government; however, the Liberals' loss of two seats and Labor's gain of one in this election showed a changing electoral tide.
nelda24notes: The Liberals lost two seats, but maintained the balance of power through the help of the Democratic Labor Party.

notes: This election was only for the House of Representatives and was thus capable of changing the government; however, the Liberals maintained control by a handful of seats.
nelda24notes: The Liberals were reduced to a bare majority of a 3-5 seat margin.
nelda26notes: The Labor Party was shown to be ahead considerably and was ahead in the popular vote in the end.

notes: This election was only for the Senate, so it could not influence the PM. Vietnam and American defense installations in Australia were large issues.
nelda24notes: Due to the support of the Democratic Labor Party, the Liberal Party was still able to maintain its control. The Labor Party gained no seats.
nelda26notes: Support for Liberals in polls had recently declined.
nelda27notes: The Democratic Labor Party, while generally supporting the Liberal Party's right-wing policies, was not in a coalition with them and gained seats in this election.

notes: This election was only for the House of Representatives. Fought almost exclusively on domestic issues, it was the first time a Labor government had gotten into office in 23 years.
nelda17notes: Australia had been going through a minor recession.

notes: election (in which both the House and Senate are disbanded and put up to a vote at once) at the request of Prime Minister Whitlam after the Liberal-dominated Senate rejected a budget bill.
nelda6notes: While this was the date of a regularly-scheduled election, the fact that the whole Senate and House were up for a vote means that it was early.
nelda12notes: Polls showed the Labor party to be leading comfortably.
nelda24notes: The incumbent's party did not gain the Senate, but maintained control of the House and the position of Prime Minister.
nelda26notes: Polls showed the Labor Party to be ahead, though by smaller margins than in the previous election.
nelda27notes: The Liberals kept the Senate and gained four seats in the House.
nelda32notes: Though the Labor party remained in power, they had not regained the Senate and had lost some of the margin in the House.

notes: until a double dissolution election could be held. The election was a landslide victory for the Liberals, who gained a 10-vote margin in the Senate and an 40-vote margin in the House.
nelda6notes: The elections were a full year and a half  ahead of schedule.
nelda10notes: The Liberal government installed by the Governor-General was intended to last until it would call elections.
nelda12notes: All polls were disfavorable toward the opposition Labor party.
nelda17notes: Australia was in it deepest recession since the 1930s.

notes: Liberal Prime Minister Fraser decided to call this election a year early to head off any worsening favor because of a continuing economic slump. While at the beginning of the campaign it looked like the Labor Party had a chance of winning, the Liberals eventually won the election with only a slightly reduced majority.
nelda6notes: The elections were a full year ahead of schedule.
nelda12notes: For several weeks, it looked as if the Labor party would win, but the polls turned around at the last moment.
nelda15notes: The Liberal government of Queensland disbanded a state-funded medical operation for the Aborigines based on the allegation that the doctors were pressuring them to vote Labor - with no evidence to back up the claims.
nelda17notes: Australia was still in it deepest recession since the 1930s.
nelda26notes: For several weeks, it looked as if the Labor party would win, but the polls turned around at the last moment.
nelda27notes: The Labor party gained several seats.

notes: The first regularly-scheduled election since 1970, this election was very hard to call, with different polls supporting different candidates throughout the campaign. The Australian economy was still somewhat sour with high unemployment, and the country's relation with the US was also an issue. The incumbent government was returned with a diminished majority.
nelda12notes: For several weeks after polls showed a clear Liberal majority, it looked as if the Labor party would win, but the polls turned around at the last moment.
nelda17notes: Australia, though experiencing inflation below the world average, was still suffering from high unemployment and discontent.
nelda26notes: For several weeks, it looked as if the Labor party would win, but the polls turned around at the last moment.
nelda27notes: The Liberal party's majority was cut from 50 to about 20.

notes: This early double dissolution election was called by Liberal Prime Minister Fraser in order to resolve an issue of freezing government wages and to take advantage of the recent resignation of the Labor party leader. Unfortunately for him, the plan backfired, and Labor ended up winning the election quite handily.
nelda12notes: All polls had the Labor Party leading against the Liberals by some margin.
nelda17notes: Australia, though experiencing inflation below the world average, was suffering from its highest unemployment rates ever.
nelda26notes: Polls consistently favored the Labor party.
nelda27notes: The Labor party gained a 30-seat majority.

notes: This election was called early by Labor Prime Minister Hawke to capitalize on the huge lead he and his party had in opinion polls at the time. However, he unexpectedly ended up with a smaller margin, perhaps because of votes cast for the new Nuclear Disarmament Party.
nelda6notes: See note.
nelda12notes: All polls had the Labor Party leading against the Liberals by a huge margin.
nelda17notes: Australia had begun to recover from its recession.
nelda26notes: Polls consistently favored the Labor Party.
nelda27notes: The Labor Party's margin was cut.

notes: This election was called early by Labor Prime Minister Hawke to capitalize on a division on the Liberal Party and to gain a mandate for his economic programs. Labor won the election with little change in its margin.
nelda6notes: See note.
nelda12notes: All polls showed the Labor Party leading, but by small percentages.
nelda17notes: Australia had begun to recover from its recession, but was still running into hard times.
nelda26notes: Polls consistently favored the Labor Party.
nelda27notes: The Labor Party's margin grew slightly.

notes: This election was called two months early by Labor Prime Minister Hawke because he felt that campaigning had already begun and did not want to go through three months of it. The Labor Party barely won the election, ending with only a 2-seat majority.
nelda6notes: See note.
nelda12notes: All polls showed the Labor Party leading, but by very small percentages.
nelda17notes: Australia had begun to recover from its recession, but was still running into hard times; unemployment, inflation, and interest rates were all worsening.
nelda26notes: Polls consistently favored the Labor Party, but by tiny margins.
nelda27notes: The Labor Party lost enough seats to diminish it to a 2-seat margin.
nelda32notes: Though the Labor Party won, it was perceived as a loss, given the closeness of the result.

notes: The election, which could have taken place as late as May, was called early by Labor Prime Minister Keating, despite signs that a worsening economy could lead to a Liberal victory. Against all polls and predictions, the Labor Party won with a slightly increased majority.
nelda6notes: See note.
nelda12notes: Polls showed the two parties to be neck-and-neck.
nelda17notes: Australia's economy had dipped even farther, with unemployment at the lowest point since the Great Depression.
nelda27notes: The Labor party actually increased its margin, in spite of all predictions.

notes: The Liberals were favored going into the election and won with a huge majority. It was widely seen as a vote against Labor Prime Minister Keating.
nelda12notes: Polls showed the ruling Labor Party to be behind to various degrees.
nelda17notes: Australia was seen as stagnating on the way out of a recession. The economy was not as bad as before, but still wasn't great.
nelda27notes: The Liberals came out of the election with a pproximately a 40-seat majority.

notes: Liberal Prime Minister John Howard called this election early to preempt economic conditions in Australia getting worse, as all predictions were showing they would. Though the new anti-immigration and racist One Nation Party threatened to become the powerbroker in the Parliament early in the campaign, it failed to receive even one seat. Howard's party won the election with a greatly reduced majority despite a quite unpopular Goods and Services Tax proposal.
nelda12notes: Polls were neck-and-neck between the Labor and Liberal parties, and no one knew exactly how well the new One Nation party would do.
nelda17notes: Although the Liberal government had produced budget surpluses, a weak Australian dollar and faltering Asian markets threatened to bring a limping economy once more into recession.
nelda26notes: The polls showed the election as being too close to call.
nelda27notes: The Liberals' majority was reduced to eight seats, and the Labor Party saw it as a victory.

notes: While the Labor Party had generally been leading in opinion polls, Prime Minister John Howard's ruling Liberal Party was able to gain significant support from its decision to reject several boatloads of Middle Eastern and Afghan refugees seeking to enter Australia and its support of the US' new War on Terror. He ended up increasing his margin in Parliament by several seats.
nelda12notes: Polls generally showed the Liberal Party to be leading, but they were by relatively small margins.
nelda17notes: The Liberal government had helped the economy to recover somewhat, even though unemployment was still relatively high.
nelda26notes: The polls generally favored the Liberals, if only by small margins.
nelda27notes: The Liberal government won several more seats.

notes: While all indicators had predicted a close election, Prime Minister John Howard's Liberal Party was actually able to increase its majority. Australia's participation in the Iraq War weighed large on voters' minds, but the economy's success was generally attributed to the Liberals.
nelda12notes: Polls generally showed the race to be too close to call.
nelda26notes: Polls generally showed the race to be too close to call.
nelda27notes: The Liberal government won several more seats.

notes: Howard of the Liberal Party had been Prime Minister since 1996, and was seeking his 5th term in these elections. However, he had recently found himself on the wrong side of public opinion due to his refusal to ratify the Kyoto protocol and due to his commitment to the war in Iraq. In these 2007 elections, the opposition Labor party led by Mr. Rudd, took 83 seats (an increase of 23), while Howard�s Liberal Party took 55 (a drop of 19). The Labor Party also took the lead in the Senate.
nelda7notes: Prime Minister Howard was seeking his 5th consecutive term in office.
nelda11notes: The campaign - though very competitive and heated - was remarkably civil, with both Howard and Rudd passing respectful remarks about each other.
nelda12notes: for incumbent Prime Minister Howard.
nelda15notes: Two days before voting day, leaflets circulated in Sydney by volunteers and members of the incumbent Liberal Party linked the ALP to Muslim extremists. However, Prime Minister Howard condemned the act and emphasized he had not authorized the leaflets.
nelda17notes: Howard was running his campaign on his economic record, which has delivered more than a decade of solid growth and budget surpluses.
nelda26notes: Labor had maintained a considerable lead through much of the campaign.
nelda27notes: The Labor Party took 83 seats (an increase of 23), while Howard�s Liberal Party took 55 (a drop of 19). The Labor Party also took the lead in the Senate.
nelda50notes: Outgoing Prime Minister Howard had been a staunch supporter of President Bush's decision to go to war in Iraq, and had stood with Bush as the only two leaders of industrialized nations not to ratify the Kyoto protocol on greenhouse gas.
nelda51notes: Where Howard had been a staunch ally of U.S. President George W. Bush, new Prime Minister Rudd had campaigned on a promise to immediately begin talks with the Bush administration and the Iraqi government about withdrawing Australia's 550 combat troops from Iraq by mid-2008. Furthermore, his first act as Prime Minister was to seek ratification for the Kyoto protocol. Though the Australian relationship with the US was by no means rocky under Rudd, it was not as close as it had been under Howard.

notes: These elections were the first to be held under new Labor Party (ALP) leader Prime Minister Julia Gillard, who had succeeded Mr. Kevin Rudd two months earlier. Mr. Tony Abbott was the leader of the main opposition Liberal Party. Taxes and immigration policies were the main issues, though the Labor and the Liberal party did not differ massively in their platforms.  These elections resulted in the first hung parliament since 1940, as no party secured a majority in the House of Representatives. The opposition Liberal-National Coalition took 73 seats, while the incumbent Labor Party took one less � 72. Four independents and one member of the Green Party also took seats. In the Senate, the Liberal-National opposition took 18 seats compared to the ALP�s 15. Neither the ALP or the opposition conceded defeat, and an anxious period of negotiation with the independents ensued. On 7 September, Prime Minister Gillard announced that her incumbent ALP would form a minority government, with the support of 3 independents and the Green Party.
nelda6notes: Elections were constitutionally due in November 2010, but due to a change in the leadership of the incumbent Labor Party, these elections were several months early. In the previous elections of 2007, the Labour Party had been voted in to power and Mr. Rudd sworn in as Prime Minister alongside the Deputy Prime Minister, Ms. Gillard (the first woman to hold a Prime Ministerial position). Though Mr. Rudd initially enjoyed high popularity, following his decision to shelve a carbon emissions trading scheme and his proposal of a 40% tax on mining profits, his leadership of the Labor Party was challenged and Ms. Gillard became party leader, acceding to the post of Prime Minister in June 2010. One month later, she announced elections would be held on August 21st.
nelda17notes: The country's economy stayed relatively strong despite the global economic crisis.
nelda18notes: Australia was able to avoid recession during the worldwide economic downturn, and had a historically low unemployment rate.
nelda24notes: The incumbent's party won one less seat than the opposition did in the House of Representatives, and three less in the Senate. However, with the support of independents and the Green Party, Gillard's ALP formed a minority government.
nelda26notes: New Prime Minister Gillard was extrememly popular, thus the ALP initially had initially enjoyed a comfortable lead over the Liberal-National coalition. However, during the election campaign, several ALP members revealed that Ms. Gillard had opposed a pension rise and a paid parental leave scheme while she was Deputy Prime Minister. This news triggered a sharp decline in her popularity and in the Labor Party's ratings in opinion polls. For example, according to the survey by Newspoll for The Australian newspaper on Friday, voters were split 50-50 between the two main parties. Before that, another Newspoll survey had put Labor at 52% and the Liberals at 48%.
nelda32notes: The vote counts favored the opposition Liberal-National coalition, but the ultimate minority government arrangement favored the incumbent.
nelda34notes: The vote count favored the opposition Liberal-National coalition, but the ultimate minority government arrangement favored the incumbent.

notes: The election occurred following an unrest for a few years in which there was a dispute between PM Somare and O'Neill over who was the legitimate prime minister. PM Somare reshuffled the cabinet and then stepped down to face charges of financial mismanagement, being replaced by interim PM Abal. The election was surrounded by considerable controversy and delays.
nelda6notes: The assembly voted to delay the elections by 6 months but they were not delayed following an outcry over the move.
nelda27notes: The People's National Congress Party gained 20 seats while the ruling National Alliance Party lost 20 seats. Other opposition parties also gained seats.
nelda29notes: There were significant pre-election protests over talk of delaying the elections. Post-election protests were less organized but violence erupted between tribes and political groups over the election. Unions also organized protests to delegitimize PM O'Neill.
nelda33notes: Significant violence was reported throughout the campaign. Significant gun violence was rampant and there were reports of people being hacked to death at polling stations. There was also a high profile case of 7 people being murdered and cannibalized in election-related violence.

nelda47notes: Monitors found significant voting irregularities, particularly with falsified voting lists and a one week extension of voting, during the election.

notes: These elections were for the House of Representatives, which determine the Prime Minister. General elections held on Nov. 27, 1946, for the 80 seats in the N.Z. House of Representatives resulted in the return of the Labour Government, which had held office for 11 years. PM Fraser therefore remained in power. The Labour Party, however, lost further seats to the National Party and will have a majority of only 4 in the new House. The incumbent Labour Party emerged with 42 seats, and the National Party with 38 after gaining 4. The main issue of this election was economics - the Labour Party campaigning  on its record of the last 11 years, notably in the field of social security and allied benefits, while the National Party offered a more liberalized model.
nelda1notes: Though elections were not held from 1938 -1943 because of the war, in 1943 there had been a House of Representatives Election.

The Labour government ensured there was full employment, but there was also a considerable lack of consumer goods, coal and lumber, particularly following the war. Combatting Inflation was a consideration. There had been much spending on the war. Total Cost of War: Mr. Nash gave the total cost of the war to New Zealand as �640,000,000, of which, he said, 35 per cent, or �221,775,000, represented War Loans outstanding, all domiciled in New Zealand.

The Labor Party won 56-37-2.
