notes: After six years of somewhat disastrous radical economic reform by the Labor Party, the voters turned their 56-37 majority into a 68-28 win for the conservation National Party in this election. The outgoing Labor PM had taken his place only eight weeks before the election.
nelda17notes: NZ was in a significant recession.
nelda26notes: The polls overwhelmingly favored the opposition National Party.
nelda27notes: From 14 seats behind the ruling party to a winning margin of 40 seats.
nelda52notes: The National Party was much more pro-US.

notes: At stake in this election were the three-year-old National Party government and whether NZ would switch to a mixed member proportional system of elections. The MMP system was instituted, and two third parties got two seats each; there was a hung parliament until absentee ballots gave the National Party a 50-45-2-2 victory.
nelda17notes: However, there was still significant unemployment.
nelda26notes: The polls favored the ruling National Party, though by a small margin

notes: This was NZ's first national election run under the mixed member proportional system, and the representation of third parties shot from 4 seats to 39. No party go an outright majority and both the Labor and National parties jockeyed for influence over the NZ First Party, which eventually sided with the National to give them the election victory.
nelda17notes: After a slight recovery, there was still significant unemployment.
nelda26notes: The polls favored the ruling National Party as the largest party, though by a small margin.
nelda27notes: See notes.

notes: This was NZ's second national election run under the mixed member proportional system. The left wing coalition got 63 of 120 seats, making Helen Clark the first elected woman PM for NZ, replacing the first woman PM, Jenny Shipley.
nelda17notes: It was still in a minor recession.
nelda26notes: The polls favored the opposition Labour Party.
nelda27notes: See notes.

notes: This was NZ's third national election run under the mixed member proportional system. It was called several month early, purportedly because of the collapse of one of the coalition parties and to take advantage of Labor's current high standing. Genetically engineered crops were the largest issue in the campaign. Labor remained in power through an unofficial voting alliance with the Greens.
nelda6notes: See notes.
nelda26notes: The polls showed a loss in strength for the Labor party and its allies.
nelda27notes: See notes.

notes: A very heated election in which racial issues arose. Polls flip-flopped on who would win, and Labor eventually won with one seat less than in the previous election, entering a coalition with the NZ First Party.
nelda26notes: The polls showed a toss-up.
nelda27notes: See notes.

notes: The 2008 general election on November 8 was comfortably won by the John Key-led National Party, ending the nine-year reign of the Labour Party. National won 45% of the popular vote (58 seats) to Labour's 34% (43 seats). The Green Party won nine seats; ACT won five; the Maori Party picked up an additional Maori seat to bring its total number of seats to five; the Progressives and United Future won one seat each.� Key announced the formation of a new National-led center-right government in coalition with the right-leaning ACT and the centrist United Future party. National also entered into a limited support agreement with the Maori Party. Collectively, this gave the government 69 votes to pass legislation in the new 122-member parliament.
nelda18notes: This was in the wake of the 2008 recession.

notes: The incumbent National Party won a plurality of seats in an election that had the lowest voter turnout since 1887. The opposing Labour Party lost ground, while the smaller Green Party gained seats.
nelda17notes: The economic growth was at about 2%, so although it was not very strong it was improving from an economic contraction in 2009.
nelda27notes: The main opposition party lost seats in the election.

notes: A straightforward election in New Zealand. The incumbent National party is victorious, as had been predicted by opinion polls. Overshadowing this election is the issue of the G-20 Summit taking place in Australia, and the government�s strong record on job creation and economic stability. Some minor controversies throughout the process, but nothing of significance.
nelda6notes: Early

notes: First elections held since independence in 1980, held on schedule. Unlike in many other small Pacific states, there are political parties and a coherent political apparatus in Vanuatu; Walter Lini�s party, the Vanaaku Pati, is victorious, meaning that Lini stays on as PM.
Second post-independence election are held in relative stability with Walter Lini staying on as Prime Minister.

Lini loses a vote of confidence in September and is replaced as head of the VP by Kalpokas. The election is more narrow than previous ones, and Kalpokas� mandate is not renewed, as Maxime Carlot wins an indirect ballot for PM after failing to secure a majority.
Stable elections which see Carlot supplanted as PM.
Early elections are held; controversy surrounds the election, including violence, accusations of corruption, economic downturn, and electoral fraud.
nelda6notes: Both early and late. Early elections were triggered by a confidence vote defeat for PM Vohor, but they were scheduled to be held in January, and were postponed after rioting in response to high-level corruption.

notes: Relatively stable election compared to the chaos and violence erupting in other Pacific Island states. Natapei, who succeeded Kalpokas after the latter failed a vote of confidence, is re-elected as PM amid some controversy, including the corruption and fraud highlighted by Transparency International.

In the small archipelago nation plagued by unstable coalition governments, voting has again brought uncertainty as to what the new government will look like. The ruling Vanuaaku Party saw their share of seats largely diminish, despite the Prime Minister believing that these snap elections would bolster support. The voting was calm, but counting was setback when a mob burned ballot boxes that were on their way to be counted. There was no call for a by-election since the burned ballots had already been tentatively recorded. The elections were a major advance for opposition candidates and women, who won seats for the first time since the 80s.
nelda29notes: A �mob� of opposition supporters burned four ballot boxes as they were on their way to be counted

notes: Stable election which takes place in strong economic conditions. Nonetheless, the incumbent is not re-elected, but rather, former PM Natapei is returned to power. Corruption is said to have dwindled over the past few years.
nelda19notes: Economy still heavily reliant on foreign aid and investment.
nelda56notes: Relations with Tawan are said to expect improvement, as Natapei previously led a pro-Taiwan government.

notes: The Premiership passes between a few people between the elections of 2008 and 2012 as numerous votes of no confidence are held. Kilman is the incumbent at the time of the election, which he wins. International observers deem it fair.
These were the first elections after independence.

Following a vote of no confidence in 1981, PM Peter Kenilorea of the United Party was replaced by Solomon Mamaloni of the People�s Alliance Party. Mamaloni and the PAP are thus coded as the incumbent in this election.
nelda50notes: The Solomon Islands were engaged in a conflict with the United States over the presence of US Tuna Fishing boats in Solomon Islands waters. A Solomon Islands patrol boats seized a California-registered boat  in June 1984, and a �Tuna War�, newspapers reported, ensued.
nelda52notes: Although the Kenilorea government backed the previous administration�s actions, they worked quickly to resolve the �tuna war�, which had resulted in a trade blockade from the United States, by early 1985.

notes: PM Peter Kenilorea survived two no-confidence motions before resigning in 1986. He was replaced by the Deputy Prime Minister Ezekiel Alebua, also a member of the United Party. The election saw a major blow to the United Party, and the incoming PM Solomon Mamaloni of the People�s Progressive Party became the first Prime Minister since independence to win an absolute majority.
nelda27notes: The incumbent United Party suffered a major blow from the People�s Progressive Party.
nelda50notes: In 1988, the US had established an embassy in the Solomon Islands.

notes: PM Mamaloni resisted calls from Parliament to step down, and separated from the PAP, forming his own Group for National Unity and Reconciliation. Although the outgoing PM�s group received a plurality of votes, it was defeated by an opposition coalition.
nelda24notes: While the outgoing Prime Minister�s newly formed Group received a plurality of votes, it was defeated by an opposition coalition.

notes: By the end of 1994, PM Francis Billy Hilly was ousted in favor of Solomon Mamaloni, who was elected by a parliamentary vote in November 1994. This election saw the victory of the first female MP, Hilda Kari.
nelda18notes: A report from Australia indicated that the economy was on the brink of collapse.
nelda33notes: 1997 saw the beginning of a conflict between Malaitian migrants and residents of Guadalcanal, but this conflict was not directly related to elections.

notes: These elections were held after the dissolution of parliament by a Coup d�etat by the Malaita Eagle Force (MEF) in 2000. Manasseh Sogavare was elected to replace PM Ulufa�alu by a parliament temporarily-in-exile aboard an Australian naval vessel. The Australian government helped mediate a set of accords between the Sogavare government and the MEF rebels who had taken over the capital.
nelda1notes: The previous government was deposed in a coup d�etat, and after a series of accords handed government off to Manasseh Sogavare, who at first attempted to postpone elections.
nelda6notes: Although the Sogavare government tried to postpone the elections, they failed to amend the constitution, which mandated an election every four years. The election was funded primarily by Australia, New Zealand, Taiwan, and the United States.
nelda11notes: Concerns were raised by the 2000 coup, the ongoing conflict, and the Sogavare government�s attempt to postpone the election.
nelda18notes: According to IPU, the elections were held amidst a financial crisis.
nelda28notes: Although IRI observers indicated a largely free and fair election despite some problematic aspects of the electoral administration, IPU reports that the elections were �marred by allegations of fraud�.
nelda33notes: Although a set of accords had been reached, the civil conflict still experienced intermittent flare-ups. IPU reports that a woman was shot the weekend before elections. However, there does not appear to be a significant amount of violence aimed at influencing the results of the election.
nelda46notes: The election was attended by IRI observers.
nelda47notes: While the IRI indicated that there were a few cases of fraud, violence, and intimidations, they considered the elections to be free and fair on the whole.
nelda50notes: The United States had financially assisted the Solomon Islands government in the administration of these elections.
nelda54notes: Australia and New Zealand had been part of the effort to restore order after the coup.

notes: This election mostly revolved around the political and economic recovery from the Islands� civil conflict, for which Australia and New Zealand had sent assistance in 2003. A record number of women (24) contested the elections. Protests and allegations of corruption followed the announcement of Snyder Rini�s candidature for PM, and intensified following his election. However, Mr. Rini resigned on 26 April, just two days into his incumbency, prior to a no-confidence vote in parliament. Manasseh Sogavare was then elected as PM on May 4, 2006.
nelda6notes: Elections were held after the early dissolution of parliament.
nelda11notes: There were concerns raised before the elections due to the last elections� alleged fraud and the civil conflict between the two elections.
nelda17notes: The economy was expected to continue to recover in 2006.
nelda19notes: The islands received a significant aid from Australia and New Zealand, particularly in relation to the rebuilding process.
nelda29notes: Protests in Honiara targeted the Chinatown area and alleged that Mr. Snyder Rini had unfavorably favored Chinese businessmen. Protests occurred after Mr. Rini�s candidature was announced and after his election.
nelda30notes: Protests alleged that the newly elected Prime Minister was corrupt and heavily tied to the government of Taiwan.
nelda31notes: The Australian-led forces that came to address the demonstrators were criticized for their tactics, including the use of riot gear and tear gas.
nelda33notes: Although the Honiara riots destroyed a significant amount of property, especially in Chinatown, and injured a number of police officers, there does not appear to have been a significant number of civilian deaths.
nelda44notes: Initially, Snyder Rini of the Independent Group was elected; however, he stepped down within a few days due to widespread protests. Manasseh Sogavare was elected on 4 May 2006.
nelda46notes: Commonwealth and other observers were present.
nelda47notes: Although observers noted some irregularities, they overall considered the election to be free and fair.

notes: The Solomon Islands have been characterized by weak political parties and highly unstable parliamentary coalitions, with frequent votes of no confidence and changes in Prime Minister. These elections were general parliamentary elections that resulted in no party gaining a majority, leading to three weeks of negotiations before veteran politician Danny Philip was elected Prime Minister by a majority of one vote. Political parties in the Solomon Islands are loose groupings. The largest grouping included the Solomon Islands Democratic Party (SIDP), which returned 14 legislators, and the Solomon Islands Liberal Party (SILP) of outgoing Prime Minister Derek Sikua, with two legislators. Danny Philip is leader of the Reform Democratic Party (RDP), which has two seats. His opponent was Steve Abana of the SIDP and was also backed by the outgoing Prime Minister Sikua.
nelda7notes: The outgoing Prime Minister Sikua had initially planned on presenting himself as a candidate for Prime Minister, but he decided not to when he realized that he didn't have the support in Parliament.
nelda27notes: While the newly elected Prime Minister's party did gain two  seats in Parliament (compared to zero in the previous election because they didn't exist), parties in general are loosely associated with candidates in the Solomon Islands. Their significance only matters after the election when the Prime Minister needs to be elected by Parliament. There doesn't seem to be a clearly defined opposition party, given that 50% of every parliamentary election results in independent victories, as did this one. Also, no party received a majority, and the party of the newly elected Prime Minister was only recently created (prior to the election), and thus, was not associated with any opposition force in the previous parliamentary elections.
nelda31notes: RAMSI troops fired on the riot and killed one person.
nelda33notes: There was one death in the capital after RAMSI troops opened fire when trying to suppress a riot, thought to involve the supporters of different candidates.

notes: This election resulted in a hung parliament - despite there being no formal opposition groups or parties. Basically, it becomes impossible to elect a prime minister as the two broad factions which emerged were split evenly. As a result, new election has to be held in November in order to resolve this issue, probably Tuvalu�s first bout of political instability since independence. It was also somewhat marred by allegations of corruption in government.

notes: Stable election in Tuvalu, where there are no political parties and thus a somewhat eccentric voting process. In addition, the island had in past years been plagued by political instability, and a relatively smooth electoral process was thus warmly heralded.

Election which sees a significant number of incumbents from the ruling party lose their seats as growing numbers of young voters turn out to enact political change. This leads to some turmoil, as irregularities are reported; similarly, the indirectly elected new president is forced to resign after losing a vote of confidence just two weeks after his ascension.
Most incumbents were reelected, advantaged by the accomplishment of independence and new income from the newly instated and approved Compact of Free Association.

notes: Palauan Nationalist Party (PNP) was established by friends of Johnson Toribiong and Kyoni Isechal to win support for that year's election. Toribiong dropped out of the race in late October. Kuniwo Nakamura and VP Remengesau come to power.

notes: For the first time in Palau's history, presidential and vice presidential candidates were required to run as teams. Four teams of candidates participated in the election's first round. Economic issues stemming from the 2008-9 crisis were important campaign issues, as was increasing emigration.

notes: A newly introduced three-term limit resulted in significant turnover in the legislature

Prospects for the incumbent were not good from the start of the campaign, in part due to corruption allegations. First round competitors were Peren Totsi, Johnson Toribiong, and Tommy Remengesau, Jr. After the first round Totsi dropped out of the race and pledged support for Toribiong.

Prospects for the incumbent were not good from the start, in part due to corruption allegations. Tommy Remengesau, Jr. becomes president, replacing Johnson Toribiong, while Antonio Bells is elected VP.

notes: This first post-independence election was held alongside a referendum which was to determine whether representatives would have four-year terms in parliament. While the referendum failed, the parliamentary election in itself was a success, transpiring smoothly and relatively fairly. While there are some concerns over corruption, these are minor and insubstantial. As a side note, and as in the case of many other Pacific island states, there are no formal political parties, and as such many questions are coded somewhat particularly.
nelda19notes: Particularly from France.
nelda20notes: The leader is determined through an indirect election held following the Parliamentary election by the members of Parliament.
nelda50notes: Receives a substantial amount of aid and military support.
nelda55notes: There is growing and in fact substantial resentment towards the French presence in the Pacific, which intensifies following this first-independence election.

notes: Election held alongside a referendum on whether or not to hold a constitutional convention in 1990, which passes. The election transpires smoothly and fairly, with main issues being global recognition of the FSM (which is a momentous struggle, as even former colonizers often refuse to recognize them as independent), economic aid and growth, and fishing revenues.

nelda50notes: Micronesia was engaged in a Compact of Free Association with the United States.

notes: Election follows a constitutional convention earlier in the previous year which saw some minor to changes to the political process. However, there are still no political parties, and the president is still elected by an indirect election in parliament AFTER the parliament is elected.
nelda19notes: From Japan and the US

notes: Stable election held which sees the selection of a new Parliament. Main issues concern foreign policy, and relations with the US (particularly on the issue of foreign investment). Closer relations with other Pacific states are an issue as well. There are some concerns over an election result in Faichuk, on the island of Chuuk, though calls for a special election are dismissed by the Supreme Court.
nelda28notes: Particularly concerning a re-election in Faichuk.

notes: Economic issues are at the forefront this time around, rather than foreign policy as in the past. First, several ill-advised investments have come back to bite the Micronesian government, as fishing ventures have gone sour. Also, numerous state governments - such as the Chuuk Island State government - are on the verge of bankruptcy due to numerous years of fiscal mismanagement. Election results reflect this.
nelda18notes: Investment crisis plagues Micronesia. Failed fishing investments in particular have caused economic downturn.

notes: Stable election which still takes place without political parties featuring. After the previous president Olter dies in 1996, Nena replaces him as acting president and wins a full term in this election. The backdrop to this election is the devastating impact of Typhoon Fern, as well as the economic woes facing the island states, which include massive public sector indebtedness.
nelda10notes: There was a temporary, acting president installed, but he was not explicitly tasked with holding elections.
nelda18notes: Particularly as a result of the impact of Typhoon Fern.
nelda54notes: In April the Asian Development Bank announced a loan of $18 million for public-service reform and development of the private sector.

notes: Smooth election in which central issues are Micronesia's relationship to the U.S., and whether an aid agreement set to expire in 2001 was to be renewed, as well as disbursement of government funding for infrastructure projects.
nelda54: Pacific Islands Forum, Australia, U.S., Asian Development Bank

notes: Stable election which takes place under the continued leadership of President Leo A. Falcam. There are no glaring issues with the election, which is largely free of controversy. Main issues concern relations with the U.S. and Israel, with the former renegotiating terms of an economic assistance and defense compact. Another issue is a cholera outbreak which had claimed several dozen lives over the years preceding the election.
nelda19notes: New aid packages with the US have been negotiated, amounting to $61 million a year for fifteen years.
nelda56notes: Following the election, relations with Israel are strengthened, as the foreign minister is replaced with a more pro-Israel one in the new cabinet.

notes: Stable election which sees incumbent President Leo Falcam lose his seat in Parliament, meaning that he is eventually replaced in his office following an indirect election for the presidency in May of 2003.

Stable elections in which there is minor controversy over ballot access. Other than that, things continue as usual, with Micronesia having no permanent political party structure and the President (head of government) being elected via indirect vote of the Parliament several months after the actual, direct, election.
nelda27notes: Again, there is no formally recognized opposition in play here.
nelda28notes: Some concern over distribution of ballot boxes on faraway islands, but nothing major beyond that.

notes: A heated election uncharacteristically marred by controversy. For instance, there was some strong debate over incidents of vote-buying, as well as squabbles over freedom of the press over the course of the election. Furthermore, there are numerous accusations of corruption against the president, which tar what is usually a clean and fair political process. A sluggish economy serves as the backdrop of the election, as Micronesia is unable to avoid the impact of a burgeoning financial crisis, in part due to its still-strong relationship with the US.

This election continues a worrying trend in somewhat dirty elections in Micronesia. As in the previous poll, there is some concern over ballot box access and media relations. But there is also growing worry over the President's use of power and state funds, which he is said to use questionably throughout his term in office. There are also some post-election legal challenges, but these are mostly waved off by courts.
nelda16notes: Concern over state use of treasury funds. This not only in regard to media, but also infrastructure investment and other issues.
nelda46notes: Including some native organizations in the Pacific
nelda47notes: Minor issues and controversies, but fraud nonetheless.

notes: While State department human rights reports paint a grim picture of the political scene in Micronesia, the island nation's electoral process seems to run quite smoothly, as this particular election transpires without significant delay, aberration, or incident. In fact the State department praises Micronesia for holding regular free and fair polls. Though there are some concerns, as usual, over corruption and state use of funds, there are no major electoral mishaps.

Elections widely regarded as free, fair, and energetic by international observers. Main issues include economic woes - largely caused by a crippling drought sweeping the Pacific Islands - and a growing AIDS epidemic. Some concerns about voting process reported by local press.
The previous government had been ousted, and a whole new cabinet reelected.
nelda55notes: Some observers think relations with New Zealand will weaken following the election of the new Lealofi government.

notes: Efi was reelected following a successful first term and beneficial socioeconomic conditions.
